assignment_name: Prepare for the Life after College

description:
Submit

Comprehensive Project

The purpose of this project is to get you familiar with a 10k. (Remember that every public company is required to file a 10k on an annual basis with the SEC.) Before you get started, let's outline the requirements:

  • Your paper should be greater than 3 pages
  • Organize your paper according to the numbers shown below, meaning "1. provide your answer" go to the next line, "2. provide your answer" and so on. I want to be able to quickly find where you answered each of the 10 questions. 
  • Please do NOT copy the questions into your report. I already know what they are. :)
  • Please do NOT copy and paste information in from the annual report. 
  • Please keep your margins to 1" and your spacing to 1.5 (please no double spacing)
  • Use Calibri 12 point font

Step 1: The following video will walk you through how to choose a company, use the Edgar database, and provide some hints on completing the assignment.

Step 2: Choose the company you will be analyzing. If you already have one in mind, jump to step 3. If you don't have a company in mind, select a company from the following list of companies: Fortune 500. (If this link does not work, do a search for the top 100 companies in the United States.)

  • Tip: Avoid choosing a company in one of the following industries: (1) Financial services (like a bank), (2) Insurance, and (3) Oil and Gas.

Step 3: Next locate the company 10-K annual report using the EDGAR database.  If you aren't sure how to do this, please watch the video above. :)

Step 4: Using the annual report, and thinking like a potential investor, please respond to the following questions (remember the writing rules above): 

  1. Locate the consolidated statement of operations/earnings/income. Which accounts are you least familiar with? Scroll down to the footnotes (shown just below the financial statements) and see if you can find a footnote that talks about these accounts you identified. (It would be in the first 3-4 pages of the footnotes.) What did you learn? Now look at all the numbers on the income statement, has anything changed significantly over the last few years? What would be a reason for the change? 
  2. Locate the consolidated balance sheet/statement of position. Which accounts are you least familiar with? Scroll down to the footnotes (shown just below the financial statements) and see if you can find a footnote that talks about these accounts you identified. (It would be in the first 3-4 pages of the footnotes.) What did you learn? Now look at all the numbers on the balance sheet, has anything changed significantly over the last few years? What would be a reason for the change? 
  3. Compute 3 different ratios for two years, this way you can see the change in the ratio from year-to-year. What does each ratio tell you about the company? Was there a significant change between the years? Why do you think that change occurred?
  4. Locate the 10-K of a competitor and run the same 3 ratios on this competitor. (The ratios on the competitor can be for just one year.) How is your chosen company doing when compared to their competitor? Were you surprised by any of the results? Why? 
  5. Scroll through the footnotes and find two of them that are interesting. Describe what is in this footnote. What did you learn? Would this information help you make a better decision about the company? If you could talk to the someone from the company, what additional questions would you ask them about the footnotes you read? 
  6. Considering the managerial accounting topics that we learned in this class, what kinds of product or service decisions do you think that your company would have to face? (Think about make vs. buy, add vs. drop, buying equipment/building using NPV or IRR, etc) Who should be making these types of decisions? How quickly should these decisions be made? Why? 
  7. Think about the module on budgeting. What would be the benefits of seeing the company's budgets for production, materials, cash, etc.? Right now this information is not provided in the annual report. Is it important enough to require companies to provide the budget information? Why
  8. Do a search for recent news about this company and its management team. What did you learn? Would any of this news change your willingness to invest in this company?
  9. If you could sit down with the CEO, CFO, CIO, COO, CMO, etc. what 3 business questions would you ask? Also, what one question would you ask purely out of interest/for fun? 
  10. If you were given $100,000 to invest in a publicly traded company, would you choose the company that you analyzed, why or why not?
  11. What would be the value of choosing a different company and going through steps 1-5 again? How could an activity like this comprehensive project prepare you for your chosen profession?

assignment_name: Module 14: Submit Student Rating of Instruction (SRI)
description:
Submit

I ask you to please complete the Student Ratings of Instruction (SRI) carefully and thoughtfully. The SRIs provide me with your direct feedback about what is working well and what could be improved in the course and with regard to my teaching, specifically. I use this feedback to set annual teaching goals and to make improvements to the course. Here are a few things to keep in mind as you complete this instrument:

  1. I want to hear from everyone to better understand your many different perspectives
  2. The feedback on the SRI is anonymous, so you can feel free to be honest but also please be constructive.
  3. This feedback comes straight to me and is also available to my department chair and dean.
  4. It is most helpful if you provide specific feedback—e.g., “The instructions regarding how to complete X assignment need some clarification, as I struggled to understand some of the formatting requirements” instead of “Unclear expectations.”
  5. Please ensure that the feedback you are providing is for the right course :)

I thank you in advance for taking the time to complete the SRI!

- To get credit, complete the SRI and upload a screenshot of your receipt into this assignment

** NOTE: You should get an email with a link to the survey. If you don't, you can also get access by going to myUVU. Click on the Students tab and select My Academics. You will see a link to Rate Your Instructor and when you click on that, it will take you to a list of your active registrations. Only the classes with open SRIs will have a link at the bottom of the course information for SRIs.

The comprehensive project will require you to analyze the 10-K of a company as a group of students and present the findings to the class. Each group will be assigned a 10-K for a different company. Links to the questions, group assignments, and links to the 10-K for each group are included below. Most of this project will take place during class time.

Project Questions (everyone should download this to help you prepare for class on November 30th)

Group Assignments (Included at the bottom of this assignment)

Group 1:  (Hasbro 10-K)

Group 2:  (Mattel 10-K)

Group 3:  (Parker Hannifin 10-K)

Group 4:  (Pentair 10-K)

What you need to do:

-Read and analyze the assigned 10-K for 2 hours before class (focus on reading content related to the questions. If you have trouble finding where to look in the 10-K, use CTRL-F to search for the words you're looking for).

-Come to class on Wednesday, November 30th and work with your assigned group on the analysis of the 10-K.

-Come to class on Monday, December 5th and be ready to discuss your company's 10-K with the class (discussion will be focused on the questions in the assignment document, so focus on that to be prepared). You do not need to prepare a formal presentation. Just be ready to tell us about your company and answer my questions.

How your grade will be determined:

-Your preparation before coming to class on Wednesday, November 30th

-Your participation (and effort) in your group during class on Wednesday, November 30th

-Your participation (and effort) during the discussion during class on Monday, December 5th

assignment_name: Course Overview Assignment - Proctorio Set-Up (Remotely Proctored)
description:
Proctorio Practice

For this quick assignment, you will be

- setting up Proctorio 

- becoming familiar with the program

- taking a practice quiz 

YOU WILL NEED A BLANK SHEET OF PAPER WITH YOUR NAME WRITTEN ON IT FOR THIS PRACTICE QUIZ. Please have this next to you before you begin. 

You will also need some form of ID to enter the exam. (This will be a rare occurrence that this is required.)

What is Proctorio?

Proctorio, is the online proctoring system that UVU is integrating into their online classes. It is used by schools like Harvard and Standford and is meant to assist student integrity and to help keep the playing field fair for all students enrolled in an online course.

This class is part of a pilot program to have it heavily integrated into the class. Most of our quizzes and assignments will have some level of integration with Proctorio this semester. It is super easy to use, and is easy to install but requires about 15-30 minutes of time to get it set up. I also recognize that it is an extra step and would so appreciate your feedback on it throughout the course as we test it out. 

How to get Proctorio set-up

I have attached UVU's student setup guide below and I have also included links to help give you more insight and information about the program, how to use it, and who to contact when it doesn't work (this happens sometimes). Keep in mind that while we will be using Proctorio a lot, we will not be using all of the features. For example, you rarely will have to have your web camera or audio on! Because, weird. 

If you are really struggling with the set-up, you can click on the FAQ link below and you will be given an option to set up a live chat to have someone help you. 

Once you have gotten it set up, you will be taking this practice quiz (it is SUPER easy, I promise :)) to make sure everything is working properly and you have an idea of how the program functions. 

Please do not attempt this practice quiz UNTIL you have set up Proctorio, otherwise, you will lose the points. 

Items to make note of

  • -Proctorio MUST be used with a Google Chrome browser.  
  • -The level of rigidity (what you can and can't do while the program is running) will be different for each of the different assignments and quizzes. For example, some assignments will allow you to open up other browsers to do research or watch a video, while others will lock down that feature. You will want to make sure to really pay attention to the quiz information that Proctorio gives before you begin your specific assignments and quizzes. I have had students get locked out because they accidentally clicked on an outside tab or browser before without realizing that they were not allowed for that particular assignment. Be aware of what the requirements are so that doesn't happen to you. 
  • -It is your responsibility to install the program on your computer, get it set up, and troubleshoot. Just like it is your responsibility to have access to a working and capable computer for an online class. 
  • -Once you begin an assignment/quiz/exam in Proctorio, the timer will start running, even if you click out of the exam and stop Proctorio from running. Most assignments will have 480 minutes to submit (8 hours) and you can reenter to work on them. However, that means that your assignment needs to be submitted before that 8 hours is up. After that, it will lock you out. Most quizzes and exams need to be completed in one sitting. This is something that you will be notified of before you begin the assignment/quiz/exam. Make sure to pay attention to the instructions that I and Proctorio give so you are fully aware of what is expected. 
  • -When a student signs into a test, Proctorio will require that they look into the web camera with sufficient clarity that their eye movements can be tracked. Glasses inhibit the recognition process and should be removed during the verification process. Once they are cleared by Proctorio they can put their glasses back on to take the test. We will rarely use the eye movement or web camera functions with the exceptions of the exams and a few other quizzes. This practice quiz is one of those exceptions. 
  • - Again, to reiterate most of our quizzes and assignments DO NOT require that the web camera or audio is on. I would hate that as a student, and so I have tried to limit the web camera/audio requirements as much as possible. Usually, we are just using the program as an anti-plagiarism tool. 
  • - Sometimes, and this makes no sense to me, but Proctorio will require a code to access the program. Very rarely, the program will glitch and will not show the code to the student - SO ANNOYING! If this happens

1). Let me know so I can track it (remember we are testing this level of use of Proctorio for this class).

2) Then you need to reach out via live chat and they can give it to you and let you in.

I apologize in advance if this happens to you. Just know that it isn't totally out of the realm of reality and it isn't anything that you are doing wrong. Technology can be great sometimes, but it can also be a massive headache as well. 

For further help or information click the links below. 

Student Proctorio Set-Up

https://proctorio.com/students

https://proctorio.com/faqs

 Other Proctorio Information for UVU Students

Proctorio Troubleshooting

eeae103aaeaa23b1113a6a083f30ac40519157

Watch, Read, and Submit

Can art change the world? Or at the very least, impact it? 

In this module, we were introduced to the power and significance of art. From prehistoric handprints on cave walls to artworks heralded as priceless masterpieces, art and visual culture can be a powerful method of communication. However, does it have the power to change the world, or to redirect a society or movement? For this assignment, you are asked to explore the work of street artists JR and Banksy. 

NOTE: The links for the assignment are embedded in the questions. You will need to start the assignment or click "take the quiz" in order to access them.  

First, start off by reading the following Smithsonian Magazine Article on the elusive, yet ridiculously famous and wealthy graffiti artist Banksy. Then answer the corresponding questions. 

Second, you will watch a Ted Talk by JR titled: One Year of Turning the World Inside Out. Then answer the corresponding questions. 

Third, you will participate in a classwide discussion (On the next page Module 1 Assignment - Part 2) and need to... 

1). Critically and analytically assess if art can have a lasting or massive impact and how.

2). Creatively consider and elaborate, if you had the mode and means, what cause or problem would you bring awareness to in regards to street art and how? 

 

Other information about this assignment: 

  • You will have one attempt to complete Part 1 of this assignment. Once you hit submit, you will be closed out, and Canvas will automatically take your highest score. So, check your answers, and make sure everything is completed before you submit. 

  • Part 1 of this assignment will be monitored by Proctorio. Only click on in-assignment links and don't attempt to open a new tab while you are taking the quiz as it will lock you out. 

  • This attempt maxes out at 480 minutes. This means that with each attempt you start, you will have 8 hours to finish it. Keep this time in mind if you leave the assignment, as it will run down the clock. 

4a209107801bbc1ee87b28abb1db66bb522614

Discuss

 

For this assignment, you will contribute your thoughts to a group discussion both on art as a whole as well as on the street art of JR and Banksy. 

Directions: Discuss your personal response and feelings to the following questions below. Then read and comment on the two students in front of your response. If you are the first student to comment, you will comment on my response as well as on any other random student you choose at a later time in the week. If you are the second student to respond, comment on the student above you as well as on mine. 

Each of your own answers should be at least 3-4 sentences long, make sure you explain your answers. Be as descriptive as possible; avoid generalizations. The whole purpose of this assignment is to help us get to know you a little better as well as to contribute to the Module 1 Assignment - Part 1. Your answers should be a reflection of who you are, what you think about art, and how you would participate in street art movements if you had the mode and means. Answer the questions as honestly and thoroughly as you can, and you will receive full points. The grading for this assignment is based on a complete vs. incomplete basis. To help you get to know me just a little bit better, my answers are below.

  1. What has been your exposure to art?

  2. What do you think about art as a whole? Is it beneficial to society?

  3. Have you ever created a piece of art? Why or why not?

  4. What are you most interested in learning from this class?

  5. Critically and analytically assess if art can have a lasting or massive impact and how. Use at least two specific examples from JR and Banksy (Make sure your first example is a Banksy example and the second is JR.)

  6. Creatively consider and elaborate, if you had the mode and means, what cause or problem would you bring awareness to in regards to street art and how? Would you participate with graffiti-like Banksy or would you participate in JR's Inside Out Project? What would be your purpose? Would cause would you bring awareness to or what statement would you make? How and where would you paste or put your work of art? Be mindful and seriously consider what you would do. 

 

My Answers. (NOTE: I have chosen examples from both JR and Bansky that were not discussed in the article or video.) 

  1. What has been your exposure to art?

So, I am the world's WORST artist. My students always make fun of me because I can't even draw a solid circle. I wasn't really exposed as a child, I don't even think I took an art class in junior high. It wasn't until high school that I really gained an interest. Since then, studying art is kind of what we do as a family. My mom and I even took art history courses together just for fun when I was in college (hello, nerd alert!). Now, it is my living and passion. I am currently engaged in my graduate degree, I can not get enough. (That being said, I totally understand that this is a 1010 course and I so do not expect everyone to feel the same way that I do. What is so fun about life is that everyone has different passions. I just want you to be successful and have an enjoyable experience).    

2. What do you think about art as a whole? Is it beneficial to society? 

          To quote Kelly Kapoor from the office " UHHMAZZING". 

I always loved history and when I took AP Art History I was seriously hooked. I was fascinated by the ability that humans have to create something that can serve so many different purposes - psychological, historical, sentimental, sensual etc. Since then, I have had the opportunity to see and study art all over the world. I love being able to learn more about a culture, people, and place through art. It gives a glimpse into the past and current human condition. To me, art is a universal characteristic - it spans time and place. 

Do I think art is beneficial to society? Yes and no. Art is incredibly persuasive, it can persuade a culture, a people, religion, and even personal mood and feeling. Humans have the power through art to incite thoughts, revolutions, beliefs, emotions, and ideas. To me, it is more dependent on who is using the power of art and what they are doing with it. Art used by totalitarian governments is/was extremely powerful but I don't think it beneficial. However, art is often used as a way to promote discussion and dialogue, and that, I believe, is beyond beneficial.  

3. Have you ever created a piece of art? Why or why not?

Believe it or not, YES! However, my first real work of art was a totally abstract painting piece that was an experiment I did with my then-toddler. It has NO artistic principles or elements involved whatsoever. Since then I have painted occasionally and have several abstract pieces in my home. I am getting better, but it is not really my talent. I just enjoy throwing paint at a canvas sometimes haha.

4. What are you most interested in learning from this class?

I am most interested in you guys! It is so interesting having an online class because I create this quasi-relationships with my students. But, I love getting to know you through your comments, assignments, and thoughts. I know many of you are just knocking off a credit that you need to take and so I try to keep the coursework relatively doable and again, it is my hope that this is an enjoyable experience and you are successful in this course. Cheers! 

5. Critically and analytically assess if art can have a lasting or massive impact and how. Use at least two specific examples from JR and Banksy (Make sure your first example is a Banksy example and the second is JR.)

Without a doubt, art can have a lasting impact. Consider propaganda and political or religious visual culture.

What I love about Banksy is that he is such a loose cannon. Since he is so elusive, his artistic statements are uninhibited. Recently, I was so dumbfounded that when a small piece of his was up for auction. Within this particular piece, he had secretly built it in a self-destructing frame years earlier unbeknownst to the auction house.  When the piece sold for 1.4 million dollars, right then and there it starts shredding into pieces as an alarm rang out. WHAT A FREAKING BOSS. I love his statement that art should be for everyone and not just for the elite. However, his estimated worth is over 50 million dollars, so he is such an enigma. Two years later it is one of the most controversial art moments in recent history, and I think that it will be talked about and analyzed for decades. It brought awareness to class systems and social and economic issues in regards to access to art. If you want to know more, you can see the New York Times article here. 

The thing that I love most about JR is that his Inside Out Project is for everyone. I find it so inspiring that 20% of participants are from students in schools. When I was teaching at Alpine School District, I had my AP students actually participate in the program itself. It was so fun to see what they came up with. One of my favorite projects was a group of football players who decided to showcase and bring awareness to the special needs students at the school who were often overlooked. The scheduled interviews with each individual student in the special needs program, got parent permission, and then took the portraits themselves. It was something unique and I appreciated that the art project helped a group of teenagers look outside themselves. Looking outside ourselves is something that I think the world needs more of. 

6. Creatively consider and elaborate, if you had the mode and means, what cause or problem would you bring awareness to in regards to street art and how? Would you participate with graffiti-like Banksy or would you participate in JR's Inside Out Project? What would be your purpose? Would cause would you bring awareness to or what statement would you make? How and where would you paste or put your work of art? Be mindful and seriously consider what you would do. 

For the last several years, I have been doing research on fair trade, global child labor laws, and companies with a clean downline. It became really important to me that I was wearing and supporting businesses that care about and take notice to have clean supply chains, even if it means things are more inexpensive or their items are less popular to the masses.

In my research, I found that so many popular companies (Victoria's Secret and Forever 21 being big ones) have acknowledged using or having sweatshops, slave labor, or child labor in their supply chains (the above links have reports on both chains from NPR as well as the New Yorker) and the average consumer has no idea. 

Forced labor and child labor is a massive problem globally. UNICEF estimates that 1 in 10 children or 152 million children globally has to take part in forced child labor.  This is sickening for obvious reasons. As a mother, who also believes that education is one of the most important things for children and should be a right for all, I really struggle with these brands who deny these rights and mistreat impoverished people and children, especially for the means of profit. 

If I were to participate in JR's Inside Out Program, assuming I had the mode and means, I would take portraits of some of the children who are forced to work in these factories and I would paste them outside the flagship shops of some of the bigger retailers with these supply chain issues. I really believe that most people just don't know or consider that when they are buying a 5 dollar t-shirt from Forever 21 or even a 50 dollar set of lingerie that they are inadvertently supporting these brands with sketchy pasts and supply chains and thus child labor issues. This would be done in an attempt to educate and inform people that their purchases matter.

Watch, Analyze, and Submit

Johannes Vermeer, The Art of Painting, 1666 - 1668.

 

In this module, you were introduced to the seven different fundamentals of art and specifically asked to think about the use of light in one of Vermeer’s paintings. For this assignment, we are going to delve deeper into some of Vermeer’s works to examine his intentional compositions to find all seven of the different fundamentals. 

This assignment is a THREE part assignment. In this assignment, you will... 

1. Watch an 18-minute video on Vermeer from the National Gallery of Art in London that will help break down the different fundamentals

2. Match the different fundamentals with the three different works discussed in the video

3. Analyze a final Vermeer piece on your own. 

Johannes Vermeer, Woman Holding a Balance, 1665. Johannes Vermeer, The Music Lesson, 1662 - 1665 Johannes Vermeer, Girl with a Red Hat, 1665 - 1666.

Be sure to:

  • Choose the BEST answer and really consider what fundamentals are being used and where. You could easily B.S. almost any work or part of a work and say "there is space and color here". BUT we need to dig deeper and look at the why and the intention of the fundamentals. Vermeer was very specific in his composition, be specific in your choices and answers, and select what best fits. 

  •  Carefully watch the video as well as apply what you learned from the module. Make sure to have read each of the individual pages in the module. This will help you a lot as they each over the different fundamentals. It would also be helpful to have some quick notes nearby on each of the fundamentals, as you are going through this assignment. This will help keep the different aspects of each of the fundamentals clear.

  • You can stop and start the video at any time, and you can reenter the assignment if you need to go back and review the different fundamentals as you go along. 

Vermeer: Master of Light Compilation, National Gallery of Art. (Video will stop at 18:00)

 

Other information about this assignment: 

  • This assignment should take roughly 45 minutes to 1 hr and 30 minutes total if you complete it in one sitting.  

  • You will have three different attempts. Once you finish your third attempt and hit submit, you will be closed out and Canvas will automatically take your highest score. So, check your answers, and make sure everything is completed before you submit. 

  • This assignment will be monitored by Proctorio. Only click on in-assignment links and don't attempt to open a new tab while you are taking the quiz as it will lock you out. 

  • Each attempt maxes out at 480 minutes. This means that with each attempt you start, you will have 8 hours to finish it. Keep this time in mind if you leave the assignment, as it will run down the clock. 

3e011647c83abae4bc63b328c69704ed522614

Write, Assess, & Submit

 

Art Critique Assignment 

Description:

For this assignment, you will critique a work of art using the four-part Feldman Method and critiquing Eugene Delacroix's, Liberty Leading the People. If you need to brush up on your Feldman Method skills, review the material explanatory films and sample papers provided in the previous section. Description:

During this module, we were introduced to Roman art and architecture from the Republican and Imperial eras, and we studied portrait busts, imperial images, and architectural feats. Now, you will have the opportunity of expanding your knowledge of Roman art and design, by researching an additional example. This assignment is intended to help you research and help you prepare for the partial critique in the midterm exam that is structured similarly.  

Assignment:

You have been assigned a work of art or architecture from ancient Rome (see image below). You will be researching and completing a small response of 200-300 words on the political significance of this work. You will also need to find out who commissioned and designed this work. Your assignment will be graded on accuracy, detail, and relevancy. To receive points, you must address each of the questions below in full and include your citations. 

You will be addressing: 

  • What is the date of this work?
  • What is the style of this work?
  • What is the medium of this work?
  • Who commissioned this work?
  • Who actually designed (or created) it?
  • What was the use of this work?
  • What is this work's political and historical significance?

Assess, Guess, & Submit

Whew! This module was beefy! So cheers to you for getting through it and learning about the major styles, movements, and artists within the Renaissance. The Renaissance is arguably one of the most important stylistic movements in an art historical context. The Renaissance changed everything and started a boom in artistic thought. It was to art, what the tech boom in the '90s was to technology today. 

To help simplify and to help you better understand and classify the different and distinct movements/artists of the Renaissance, your assignment for this module is a guessing game. One in which you will be given works of art from the Renaissance that were not discussed in the module (I might have snuck a few well-known ones in there to give you a little break) and you will guess where the place (Italian versus Northern), the movement (Proto, Early, High Renaissance), and/or the artist (da Vinci, van Eyck, etc..). 

You can have as many written notes as you would like for this assignment but your computer and internet will be totally locked down to keep the guessing game fair. I highly suggest filling out the style chart for this module. Not only will it help you slay this assignment but you will also be able to receive E.C. for it at the end of the semester. The winners of the game (whoever is able to score a perfect score or the three students with the highest score in the class) get an additional 10 points extra credit added to their final grade. This will be announced the Monday after the assignment is due.

A quick note:

Sometimes I have classes where several students receive a perfect score. In this case, all get the extra 10 points. Sometimes no-one receives a perfect score but gets close. If this is the case, the students who get the three highest scores will get 10 extra credit points. In the event of ties, I will take the three highest scores and whoever has received a score within those three will receive the additional points. For example, if the three highest scores were 99.5, 99, and 98.5 any student that received those scores, even if they are tied, will receive the extra 10 points. 

Other information about this game:

- This will be monitored by Proctorio and your computer and other tabs will be totally locked. 

- You will only have TWO attempts. So check, and double-check your answers to make sure you answered each one. 

-Your attempt will need to be finished within 40 minutes of starting it. (The game itself shouldn't take that long, this assignment is more about the prep work ahead of time. But I wanted to give enough time just in case the image loading is slow etc..) 

-If you submit the game late, but you receive perfect points, you will receive your perfect score for this assignment but will not get the extra points added on. 

 

GOOD LUCK!

Assignment: Napoleonic Imagery 
(NOTE: PART 1 AND 2 are due at 11:00 pm 
to leave time for the self-assessment.)

Jacques-Louis David, Napoléon Crossing the Alps, 1801 (oil on canvas).

Introduction: 

"I shall slide into posterity in the shadow of my hero."

-David on Emperor Napoléon

 We have spent this entire module focusing on the “power of imagery.” Following the French Revolution, Napoléon Bonaparte was a man with an undeniable penchant for propaganda, persuasion, and power. In this assignment, you will have the opportunity of evaluating how the self-proclaimed Emperor of France used imagery. This assignment is a continuation of our Module 5 Assignment when we looked at propaganda from the Roman Empire. However, this time we will be studying how Napoleon used similar imagery and ideology as part of his conquests and self-promotion.

Directions:

Watch, or read the linked resources to follow, and answer the associated questions.

This is a three-part assignment. Please make sure to do ALL three parts. 

  • Part 1 (12 points) - Analyze and critique a commissioned work by Napoleon. (You will be able to choose from three specific works below.) Specifically, address the intent and how the work was used as a work of propaganda. 
  • Part 2 (15 points) - Cross compare a work from this module and an example of visual culture in your life and submit a small essay. 
    • Parts 1 and 2 will be written in essay form and submitted on this page here. Both can be on the same document. Please make sure to include any and all sources that you used. 
  • Part 3 (3 points) - Submit a self-assessment. This assignment and self-assessment will specifically help prepare you for the final comparative critique that we have coming at the end of the course. This will be taken on the following page.  In order to receive points for this assignment, you must take the self-assessment. Really consider areas that you can/need to improve for the final critique. Use the rubric to help you make sure that you have met all the requirements before you submit. 

Module 8 Assignment Part 1

Choose one of the following Napoleonic pieces below. Evaluate and analyze the piece you choose using the resources given. Write and submit a three-paragraph analysis on the image you choose regarding the propaganda of the image and how the visuals assisted Napoléon in his conquests and self-promotion. Discuss how the artist used at least 4 different elements/principles in a way to promote Napoleon's power and discuss relevant historical context.

Argue and Submit

 

Is Instagram an Art Form? Are Instagram, TikTok, Facebook, and other social media channels reinventing or destroying "art"?

Now that we have gone through the major art movements and events in Western Society, we are going to dissect and address a current question in the art world - How Does Social Media fit Into "Art"? Are social media feeds and images on social media artworks in and of themselves? Is social media beneficial to cultural progression or does it hinder it?

For our VERY last module assignment, (YAY!) you will use the same paradigm that we have been using when discussing artistic styles from ancient to modern times and you will be addressing how social media fits into art. 

The Assignment

- Read at least THREE of the articles below (or you may find your own if you want - you just need to make sure you cite ALL of your information.) Make sure you cite what you use at the end of your argument. 

- Decide where you stand on the argument and answer these questions. 1) How do you feel social media fits into our modern cultural landscape? 2) Does social media require the use of artistic elements/principles? 3) Is social media a new form of "art history" for the millennial age? 4)What are the possible drawbacks or benefits from this? 

- Create a succinct 2-3 sentence thesis statement introducing your stance on the argument at the beginning of your essay. 

- Back up your thesis statement with 3-4 paragraphs arguing why you feel the way you do. Make sure your argument is rooted in research (the articles you choose) as well as personal experience and opinion. 

NOTE: This assignment is not to be longer than a page. It is also not meant to take a major chunk of time, but rather help you to use some of the skills and information that we have been working on in this class and apply it something you encounter in your everyday lives, which is social media. I am not looking for a perfectly written and organized argument essay but want to know how you are able to apply art historical theory and context to a current social question. 

Save your response in Microsoft Word (doc or docx) or PDF file format. Attach your file and submit the assignment.

WELCOME TO MODULE 1! 

To receive points for this video assignment, watch the video (this one is a bit longer this week as we introduce visual culture as a whole) and then answer the corresponding questions in the survey below. You will want a spare sheet of paper and a pen out to record a few things as you watch.   

Note: There is a slight "trigger" warning as this video will start the discussion of visual culture. I use some imagery that is currently floating around in our modern political and cultural landscape to begin this discussion. I also get a little personal in my discussion and share some of my own personal reactions. This is in no way meant to mean that if you do or don't feel the same way as I do that you are right or wrong. This exercise is simply one where we will examine what visual culture is and how images can affect us, and those around us. 

However, one of these images has to do with the Confederate Flag. While the symbolism of the flag is not addressed in this video, (the main point in the video is for each of you to examine your own response to a few images that I show) I wanted to make sure to include an article from Professor Matthew Guterl of Brown University who is a Race and Nation Historian for anyone who wanted more information about the Confederate Flag. Today, especially in our political climate, the Confederate Flag is incredibly divisive. It is considered a symbol of hate, racism, oppression, and white supremacy today for many, and Prof. Guterl argues why it should no longer be used in any sort of political or cultural discourse, no matter what your political leanings may be. Click here if you would like to read: What the Confederate Flag Really Means to America Today, According to a Race Historian - The Washington Post. 

Note 2: I discuss an iconographic transfer on a fairly well known Christian and LDS work of art replacing a child with a prominent pop-culture icon. I would like to correct that the iconographic transfer is between a lamb and the pop-culture icon, not a young child. I totally misspoke! These videos make me nervous sometimes, and I can totally get ahead of myself :).

I know things are new and many of you are taking all of your classes online which presents a new challenge, and I am here to help you!

assignment_name: Module 6 Assignment Partial Critique Essay (Remotely Proctored)
description:
Complete

Using the text box entries, please IDENTIFY, ANALYZE, AND INTERPRET your assigned work of art employing the Feldman Method. You will be assigned your work of art once you begin the assignment.

Please follow the exact instructions below and use complete sentences. Grammar will not be strictly graded as this is a text box entry, but please still try to do your best.  This will be a proctored and locked down assignment and you will have 60 minutes to complete this section (55 minutes for assignment + 5 minutes for room scan/showing notes). You will be allowed to use 1 sheet of paper, double-sided, at 10-point font minimum, with 1-inch margins that can have ONLY your style charts on it. You will be required to show both sides of the document to the online proctoring service at the start of your assignment if you choose to use it. If you have gone through the modules, prepared, and created your style chart notes you will excel. This assignment must be completed in one sitting, once you start you will be required to complete the assignment.

Your goal is to give me as much knowledge as you can about the work. 

1) Using 2 sentences or less, please identify the name, style, location, and approximate date of this work.

 Identify:

 

2) Using at least 6 bullet points please analyze and discuss the elements/principles/mediums/techniques used by the artist. Must italicize the elements/principles/techniques/medium.

 Analyze:

1)

2)

3)

4)

5)

6)

 

3) Using at least two-three paragraphs please accurately interpret the piece. Discuss the importance of the work, what it was trying to communicate, any advancements, and any historical context that is related.

 Interpret:

2b1f5cedf9ea84016ba871466ee06110522614

Critique, Compare, and Submit

For our last assignment, we are going to revisit the Feldman Method for critiquing art that we studied in Module 3. However, this time, instead of critiquing just one piece of art, you will be comparing and critiquing two. The purpose of this final comparative critique is to demonstrate how much you have learned over the course of the semester regarding the visual components of appreciating art. If you need to review the Feldman Method, please see: 3.7 The Feldman Method.

You should have already started working on the first part of your critique in Module 9

For the rest of this assignment, you have two options.

For the first option, you can go to an Art Museum of your choice here in the state of Utah and choose one different work found at that particular museum and complete the comparative critique on the works of your choice. See the list below to get an idea of the different art museums here in the state. If you choose this option, you will need to submit some sort of picture of you in the museum, a ticket, handout or stamp as proof of entrance to the museum with your assignment.

For the second option, you can use the options given below from the Google Arts and Culture curated works and choose your second work from the remaining styles from any of the following selected styles below. (To clarify, you will be writing and comparing TWO pieces. One of these pieces should have already been selected back in Module 9.)

The Assignment:

For this comparative critique, you will be choosing two works as the subjects of a 1200 - 1600 word critique, using the Feldman Method. Format your paper with double spacing, 12 point Times New Roman font and 1” margins. Use the terminology learned throughout the course, including the elements of art and the principles of design, as well as terminology and analysis learned throughout the historical sections of the course. Make sure to include images of the pieces you are discussing, (either images you took or images found online) the names of each of your works, the artists, the styles, dates, and mediums.

YOU MUST ALSO CITE YOUR SOURCES

In your critique address each of the works separately using the Feldman Method first and then compare them following the same questioning process.

For example, when comparing make sure to address how the pieces compare and contrast as you describe them, analyze the different elements and principals employed, discuss the different interpretations and meanings found in each, and as you apply judgment to the pieces. Proofread before you submit your paper; make sure that it represents your best work and addresses the four-step Feldman Process.

Save your Critique in one of the following formats: doc, docx, pdf.  Attach your file and click submit. 

 OPTION 1:

Visit one of the following museums in person and select your second work of art to critique and compare. Make sure to include proof of entrance as well as images of the pieces you are discussing. (IF YOU HAVE NOT YET COMPLETED THE ASSIGNMENT FROM MODULE 9, PLEASE GO BACK AND PICK YOUR FIRST PIECE FROM ONE OF THE STYLES LISTED ON THE ASSIGNMENT PAGE)

Woodbury Art Museum
BYU Museum of Art
Utah Museum of Fine Arts
Springville Museum of Art
Utah Museum of Contemporary Art
Saint George Art Museum

OPTION 2:

Visit the following Google Arts online collections below. Select your second work of art from the remaining styles below. Make sure to include the images of the pieces chosen in your submission. (IF YOU HAVE NOT YET COMPLETED THE ASSIGNMENT FROM MODULE 9, PLEASE GO BACK AND PICK YOUR FIRST PIECE FROM ONE OF THE STYLES LISTED ON THE ASSIGNMENT PAGE AND THEN PICK YOU SECOND ONE HERE)

Style selections: (you only need to select one)

Abstract Expressionism - https://artsandculture.google.com/entity/m012yb9?categoryId=art-movement (Links to an external site.)

Abstract Art - https://artsandculture.google.com/entity/m0197s6?categoryId=art-movement (Links to an external site.)

Surrealism - https://artsandculture.google.com/entity/m073_6?categoryId=art-movement (Links to an external site.) 

Harlem Renaissance - https://artsandculture.google.com/entity/m019y_2?categoryId=art-movement (Links to an external site.)

Social Realism - https://artsandculture.google.com/entity/m01p0s6?categoryId=art-movement (Links to an external site.)

(Some of the Social Realist works are a tad rough so be prepared. Also, some are just standard editorial photographs. If you choose a work from this style, please make sure it is something that you can discuss and analyze.)

Pick one of the following topics or come up with your own. Research the topic using videos, books, review articles, and one piece of primary literature from PubMed (available through the UVU library). Learn as much as you can on the topic, take notes, do more research, and then sit down and tell the story.  Write a 2-3 page newspaper or magazine article that teaching others about the topic.  This is an information piece, not a research article.  Make it fun to read, interesting, and fact-filled.  Include references at the end of your article and cite these references in the article.  You will be graded on the accuracy of the information you present and the creativity with which you present it.  Use proper grammar, punctuation, and spelling.  

What’s the story?  

  1. What caused mass extinctions throughout the history of earth?  Is mankind contributing to the next mass extinction on our planet?  If so, how?  How can we get involved to reverse the effects if they are there?
  2. What invasive species are affecting life in Utah or another place in the USA? How and why do these invasive species alter an ecosystem and threaten it?  (Use a specific invasive species to detail its effects such as the fungus that wiped out the American Chestnut Tree or the fungus that is currently affecting North American Bats.)  What measures are being taken to counter the effect of invasive species?
  3. What is a trophic cascade? How has your chosen ecosystem been affected by the destruction of the top predator?  What measures have been taken to reverse the effect and have they been successful? (Two examples are the wolves in Yellowstone National Park and the whales and dolphins in the ocean.  There are likely others you will come across as well. Both of these have YouTube videos to get you started. Netflix also has Seaspiracy.)  
  4. What are prion diseases? How are prions transmitted?  What are the symptoms?  What effect have prion diseases had on ecosystems and humans themselves? What can we do to eliminate prion diseases from our food supply?
  5. What is sustainable farming? How is sustainable farming better for the environment than traditional farming?  How can we as consumers help to promote sustainable farming?
  6. What do we know about the effect of high fructose corn syrup on human health? Why and how is it produced?  Should it be banned from consumer products? 
  7. Are sugar substitutes such as saccharin, sucralose, and aspartame healthy for humans? What effect do they have on weight loss or weight gain if any?  Look into microbiome research to write your article on this one.
  8. Sarah Rigby a journalist for BBC Science Focus Magazine, claims that researchers at the University of Florida have discovered bacterial species responsible for neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Additionally, she claims that they have also discovered bacteria that counteract the effects of the “bad” microbes.   What causes dysbiosis of the gut microbiota?  How does this dysbiosis contribute to Alzheimer’s or Parkinson’s disease?  Does the data truly support this claim?  How can you make sure your gut microbiota stays healthy to prevent these types of neurodegenerative diseases?

Provide the topic you will be writing about along with three references on the topic.  Reference materials submitted here may change but I would like to see that you have begun working on the background.  Additionally, topic choice suggestions may be found under "What's the story paper!" itself.

This is a rough draft of your paper that will be reviewed by your peers.  It is your opportunity to get and give feedback that can help you polish the paper before it is turned in on December 1.  Reviews are anonymous so be truthful, helpful, and offer suggestions for improvement as though you are the editor of the paper or magazine in which it will be published.

assignment_name: Evaluating a Claim using the Scientific Process
description:
Ethics in science are extremely important for the public to have confidence in the research they help fund.  Individually, we also have a responsibility to evaluate scientific claims originating from scientific studies that impact our health and well-being. We need to determine if bias is associated with the findings, for example, or was the research funding provided by an individual or a company seeking financial gain from a particular result.  We must also determine if the study used controls, was repeated at least three times with the same results, used enough subjects to have significance, and was published in a peer-reviewed journal. 

For this discussion board, choose one of the two scientific claims supported by flawed research and write one to two paragraphs explaining two flaws in the research (4pt) and how each flaw could have been addressed appropriately in the original study.  For example, if the control group is missing explain an appropriate control that could have been used. (2pt) Secondly, explain why people still believe the claims even today though new research (using the scientific process appropriately) has revealed the flaws of the original study and refuted the results. (3 pt) Thirdly, share how your opinion about this claim changed before and after learning about the claim. (2pt) Use appropriate grammar, spelling, and punctuation. (1pt) 

You may, but are not required to respond to the posts of other students.

 

First Claim:  Vaccines cause autism. 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3136032/

https://www.chop.edu/centers-programs/vaccine-education-center/vaccines-and-other-conditions/vaccines-autism

 

Second Claim:  Underarm deodorant chemicals cause breast cancer.

Abstracts from the original papers:

http://is.gd/pPlxwZ  Darbre 2005

http://is.gd/ycqDD8 Harvey and Everett 2004

https://www.cancer.org/cancer/cancer-causes/antiperspirants-and-breast-cancer-risk.html

assignment_name: Diffusion, Osmosis and Active Transport SG
description: The study guide is accessible under Modules - Materials for exam 2.  It may be completed in a small group if you choose.  Please place all members of the group into a Project Group located under "People" on Canvas before submitting.  Grading as a group is only possible if all members are placed in the group on Canvas.
This study guide is located under modules - materials for exam 2.

You can find the study guide under Modules_Materials for Exam 2.  I have it as a group project because it is so long, but you may complete it by yourself as well.  If you are not using a group on Canvas, please remove yourself from the group or everyone will get credit for your submission.  If you are a group that is not on Canvas, be sure to form the group under "People".

assignment_name: Cancer a disease of the cell cycle.
description:
We have learned about the cell cycle and the signals or controls that are necessary to regulate the cell cycle appropriately.  We also learned that cancer is a disease of the cell cycle caused by an accumulation of mutations in genes encoding proto-oncogenes, tumor-suppressor genes, and DNA repair enzymes.  For this reason, our risk of developing cancer increases with age.  That said, some of us inherit mutations in these genes from our parents and have a higher risk of developing cancer at an earlier age. Inheriting a damaged gene is not in our control, but many behaviors that can lead to cancer are. This discussion board is a place to share your understanding, stories, and feelings about cancer

First - Read either the article from the Deseret News on lung cancer caused by radon exposure or the article from the National Cancer Institute on Human Papilloma Virus.  

https://www.deseret.com/indepth/2020/1/29/20862792/radon-radioactive-killer-utah-lung-cancer-picocuries-huntsman-cancer-institute

https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/causes-prevention/risk/infectious-agents/hpv-and-cancer

Second - Watch the video at the link below or read the transcript on Cancer in my life was a blessing.

https://baptisthealth.net/baptist-health-news/cancer-in-my-life-was-a-blessing-she-says/

Third - Write an essay that includes the following:

1.   Share how learning about cancer in general, or cancer caused by radon or HPV has changed your perspective on this topic. (10 points) 

2.  What behaviors of your own might you change as a result of this knowledge? (4 points)

3. Compare the experience of the breast cancer survivor to people in your life who have overcome or had cancer.  Did the women in the article and the person in your life who had or overcame cancer feel the same way about cancer? (4pt)

4.  Did this article or the person you knew who overcame cancer change your view of cancer?   If so how? (2 points)

 

 

.

This assignment may be accessed in full under Module 2. 

  1. The sequence on the next page shows the complementary base sequences in two strands of DNA. Polarity is also designated for each strand.  If the upper strand is a “coding strand”, what does the lower strand represent? _____________________________________________________________________
  2. If the sequence that is shown in capital letters represents the start of transcription, what role does the lower case sequence upstream of the capital letters provide to the gene?_____________________________________________________ (This is the sequence to which the enzyme that will make an RNA copy will bind to open the helix and begin transcription.) 
  3. The enzyme that will carry out transcription is called an _________________________.
  4. Transcribe the rest of the mRNA using the lower strand as your mold for complementary base pairing to build the mRNA .  Then use the codon chart on the back to translate the mRNA into a polypeptide.  Translation begins at the AUG that encodes the first amino acid (M) in the mRNA. Translation ends at the __________ codon in the mRNA.

 

  1. Inside a cell, what structures and molecules are necessary to translate the message?

 

 

  1. How does the tRNA molecule recognize a codon?

 

DNA (information)

5’ tgaccaccccccccccccctataatttcgaCTGGAGGATGCCAATGCATGCCGTTGAAGC AAATATATGCGAGGACGCAT ATTAACCTGAGTCCGCGGAG 3’ coding strand

               

 

3’actggtggggggggggggatattaaagctGACCTCCTACGGTTACGTACGGCAACTTCG TTTATATACGCTCCTGCGTA TAATTGGACT CACGCGCCTC 5’ _________

 

 

mRNA (copy of information)        5’CUGGAGGAUGCCAAUG                                                                                                      

You will need to find a codon chart on the web to translate.
You may take this quiz three times.  Make sure you study between attempts if you do not do well. Try to recall but do not use notes until after an attempt.
Feel free to use your notes and our book.  Do not use the internet.  Try to think through these questions yourself.  They are good practice for this section of the exam.
You may take the quiz twice.  Incorrect answers will be marked.  You may use notes.

This exam is on your honor.  It is not open book or open notes. You may take the exam twice and it is acceptable to re-study between attempts. The highest of the two exam scores will be kept. Incorrect answers are not marked nor will correct answers be visible until everyone has completed the exam.  As mentioned in class, you may use a 3X5 index card with notes during the exam and this will not be considered cheating.  You may also take note of topics that you need to re-study to retake the exam on a separate piece of paper.  Good luck.  I am certain you got this!

Today is the last day and last attempt at this exam.  It is a time to work with one other member of the class to pull your collective understanding and re-try the exam. You may not sit in a group and attempt to use the knowledge of one individual.  This will be considered cheating.  Those who have a high score should not simply give answers to those who didn't do as well.  Consider each other's choices and explain to each other why you think one answer is correct versus another.  It is a time to help each other and to improve your test-taking ability.  I have added a final question for you to add with whom you completed this attempt. The grade for this attempt will not be used if this question is not answered and answered honestly.  In other words, if a student lets me know that there were more than two people in his group, all member's grades will be disqualified.

The exam will be open for 75 minutes from the time you begin. You may use a 3X5 index card and you may access the codon chart if it doesn't show up for you in the exam.  The remainder of the exam is closed source so please do not use the internet, books, class notes, or friends and family to answer the questions. Trust in your own abilities; you know the information.  You have two attempts at the exam.  You may study in between attempts and Canvas will keep the highest of the two attempts.  I did not opt to show answers as I am afraid of cheating when I do this.

This exam is closed notes.  You will have two attempts and will be able to see incorrect answers between attempts but only right after the exam.  If you log out between attempts you will no longer be able to see incorrect answers.  You may study between attempts.  The two test attempts will be averaged.  Pay attention to bolded words as they offer direction for choosing correct answers.  Good luck!

assignment_name: Comments on Impromptu Speeches for EXTRA CREDIT
description: We could all use some extra credit at the end of the semester. Right?  So, if you would like to review your classmate's impromptu speeches, I will give you 10 points.  But you only get 10 points no matter how many you review.  OK?

assignment_name: Speech to Persuade - Peer Review Forms
description: We are changing things up a little here.  You will be sent the Peer Review Form via e-mail along with who you will be reviewing. It is NOT the form that has been printed in the "Guidebook."  Note that it is due on a Friday after the speeches are delivered.  That is because this form is a little more complicated and will include a review of the Speaker's Outline and Visual Aids.

By the day you deliver the recording of your "Speech to Inform," you must submit the completed information on the "Outline Worksheet" found in the Student Guidebook. It is worth 10 points. You may use a pen to complete the form and submit a PDF version or recreate the form in a word processing format (my preference as it is neater and gives you more room).

This speech requires you to have citations (3 to 5 primary sources). The citations must follow APA format.  If you don't know what that is, look in your Student Guidebook for COMM 1020 for guidance.

Complete the Topic Selection Worksheet for the Informative Speech Assignment.  This is found in Chapter 7 of the Student Guidebook with the title: Assignment: Informative Speech - Worksheet. Save the form as a PDF file, take a picture of the form or take a screenshot of the form and attach it to this assignment. You can also just write out the six questions or topics and submit them as a Word, PDF, or Text document (or whatever) Then submit the assignment.

assignment_name: Speech to Inform - Speech lab Form -
description:
Schedule a time to meet with a TA in the Communication Public Speaking Lab.  (http://www.uvu.edu/comm/ (Links to an external site.)
current_students/publicspeaking_lab.html)   (Links to an external site.)

The Form that the lab produces on your behalf is the "Practice Form" that you will be submitting.  Receive the lab form as proof of your attendance.  Take a picture of the lab form and attach it to this assignment or just submit it here.  The due date is set as the same day your speeches are due (March 31).

assignment_name: Submit peer review forms on Canvas (Speech to Inform)
description:
Submit your Peer Review Evaluations

For the final step of the peer review process, submit the Peer Review Evaluations. Attach the forms by saving them as Word-type files.   This step is worth 10 points.

Peer Review

Just as before, we will publish the list of speakers and who their Peer Reviewers are in an Announcement and via Email.

Then submit your peer review.  Peer reviews will be due on Friday, April 2 before 11:59pm.  Just to remind you, the speeches are due by March 31 and should be submitted via the McGraw-Hill link (with the little red cameras). You will attach your review here.

The form asks for your recommendation on Points (1 through 10).

This is the same information I published in the Announcements. But, while this assignment says that it is due on Feb. 7, earlier is better. 

Below you will see a list with two columns.  The first will be the Name of the Speaker ("Speaker") and the second is the Name of the Reviewer ("Reviewer").  Just like the Joke speeches, I want you to go to the McGraw-Hill site for the speeches you recorded and find the person whom you are reviewing. The Reviewer will complete the attached form (see how easy that is?).

Once you have completed the form, you will submit it as "Assignments: Same Old Bag Peer Reviews."  That form asks you how many points should be awarded to the Speaker.  No, I don't feel obligated to give the number of points you recommended.  Frankly, some of you have been pretty tough on each other! But I want your opinion.

This is an introductory speech so preparation was minimal. BUT, in the future, I am going to assign multiple reviewers to each speech.  This is to help you get more input. I am giving you a few days to write the review and to submit it.  And, yes, you get points for your reviews. 

Another change in future speeches is this: you will contact the Speech Lab to review your speeches.  As this was so short and does not require you to submit an outline, I didn't think it was worth the effort.

assignment_name: Rhetorical Analysis Assignment: Evaluation of an Outside Speaker
description:
This is an assignment based on Chapter 4 and, yes, it is essentially the same thing as your previous Outside Speaker Evaluation based on Chapter 2. .  We just want to base it on what you have learned in Chapter 4.  Therefore, Read Chapter 4 about the Rhetorical Analysis Assignment in the Student Guidebook.  Make sure to read all the information about the assignment, and follow the checklist included with the instructions.  Read the example paper and follow the APA style guide to cite your sources.  Follow the rubric included with the assignment. 

 

Complete the Outside Speaker Evaluation Form in the Student Guidebook.  Make sure to complete the assignment as instructed.  Attach your paper and submit your assignment. 

Save the form as a PDF file, take a picture of the form or take a screenshot of the evaluation forms and attach to this assignment.  To attach the image(s), click "Submit Assignment" in the upper right corner.  Then click on "Choose File" and attach your first file.  Click "Add Another File" if you have more than one file.  Continue to attach all your files.  Add any comments you may have and then submit the assignment.

assignment_name: Outside Speaker Evaluation Form (Rhetorical Analysis Assignment)
description:
Because of the error, this assignment has been extended. 

In a normal year, you would not be allowed to submit a Rhetorical Analysis of a speaker from the Internet.  The lockdowns and limitations on public events suggest we have to.  So this year, you get to choose a speaker of your choice.  Their speech must be at least 15 minutes long.  This is all found in the Student Guide, Chapter 4.  Complete the Outside Speaker Evaluation Form in the Student Guidebook.  Make sure to complete the assignment as instructed.   

Save the form as a PDF file, take a picture of the form or take a screenshot of the evaluation forms and attach to this assignment.  To attach the image(s), click "Submit Assignment" in the upper right corner.  Then click on "Choose File" and attach your first file.  Click "Add Another File" if you have more than one file.  Continue to attach all your files.  Add any comments you may have and then submit the assignment.

assignment_name: Chapter 9. Organizing the Body of the Speech
Read Chapter One in Lucas textbook

description: UVU is interested in making sure that our students appreciate the context of speaking to "A Global Audience." This Chapter is in the Student Guidebook.  Please read it and give me a short comment (about 1 page, double spaced, 12 point type) on what you think about the article.  You will be asked to do a paper on "Culture" a little bit later. Think of it as an easy way to earn some extra-credit points.  Chapter 2 is on the APA Style Guide.  While there is no assignment, you would be wise to keep it handy as you are going to need it through your college career as well as in this class.

On-Page 69 of your workbook, there is a page entitled, "Assignment: The Great Speech Performance. Worksheet.  If you have an on-line version of the workbook, it may have different pagination. You should turn that form or information in here.  You can actually write on the page you tear out or you can submit the information from your computer. Remember to copy it front-and-back.
Just to be clear, you have been assigned at least two people to review. You are submitting your review forms here (I posted these in the Announcement for March 13 and in an Email). Do not be late!

assignment_name: Playing Around With the Recording Tool
Tell Me a Joke - 3 minutes or less.  And it WILL be peer reviewed.

description:
As with your other speeches, you MUST present an outline.  The Student Guidebook for Comm 1020 has a sample of what this should look like.  It should be written in Complete Sentences!  Refer to Chapter 8 if you need help.

This outline must also contain at least Six Primary Sources in APA format.

In previous speeches, you were asked to use a Visual Aid.  This time, you must submit it BEFORE you give your speech.  Refer to the Student Guidebook, Chapter 8. You are being graded on its usefulness and how you implemented it in your speech.  You may want to refer to the "Lucas" textbook, Chapter 14.

I am not trying to kill you with a huge amount of work so late in the semester.  But I also want you to finish out this semester with a final exam that will means something to you and tell me what can do to improve it.  

This Final consists of three essays (50 points for each).  They should be at least 1 page each (for a total of three), double-spaced, in 12-point type. Please answer the following:

1. In our class we did several speeches.  Each had a different purpose, organization, structure, etc. Which was your favorite and which was your least favorite?

2. What did you learn or gain from this class?  I am looking for what you considered to be the most valuable thing you picked up?  And I am looking for what you thought was lame?

3. This may sound dumb, but I want to know what you considered your greatest failure and weakness?  No, I am not looking for a confessional.  I want to know how we can make this class better.

If you answer this fourth question, I will add 25 extra credit points to your score:

4. Has this class helped you in your educational journey? In short, is there anything that is going to be different in your life because you took it? If the answer is "Heck NO!" I will understand.  (I have been hurt before!)

For full disclosure, I don't like online speech classes.  You didn't get a chance to see each other, help each other, and get to know each other. This was not my decision (as I hope you know). The good news is that no one got sick and you got the points for this class to help you move through your education.  I am a wonderful, charming, and modest person (can you tell?).  I sincerely hope our paths cross again. 

I need these essays by Wednesday night.  Sorry, no late submissions.

Schedule a time to meet with a TA in the Communication Public Speaking Lab.  (http://www.uvu.edu/comm/
currentstudents/publicspeaking_lab.html) 

Receive the lab form as proof of your attendance.  Take a picture of the lab form and attach it to this assignment.  Then submit this assignment.

You are going to review one of the jokes that your classmates gave in the McGraw-Hill e-book assignment.  You are going to give them up to 5 points.  One point is if it was a bad joke.  Five points if it is a knee-slapper. I am going to make some adjustments to each student's final score so just lighten up!

The hard part is this: I want you to tell me WHY you gave that score. What was good about it? What was bad about it? I would prefer you turned this in as a "text entry" which is simple and easy. Tell me who you are reviewing. Then give me the score THEN give me your review or explanation.  

By turning this in, you are going to get 10 points. BUT YOU DON'T HAVE MUCH TIME!
