assignment_name: Persuasive Speech Topics or Select Your Own
description:
Submit

Some students do not know what topic they should use for a Persuasive Speech. This is meant to help you.  Complete the following assignment:
 
For this assignment, you can (1)  pick a topic from the list provided below or (2) submit your own unique persuasive speech topic. Write a one-sentence thesis statement for your informative speech.  Write a one sentence proposition statement for your persuasive speech.  

I encourage you to think carefully and critically about your speech topic. Pick a topic that YOU are invested, interested in, and committed to! 

The list of possible topics are in the link.

Updated Persuasive and Informative Topics.docx
This quiz is worth up to 15 extra credit points.

As this is the first quiz, you will be allowed two attempts. It would be a good idea to save your essay question answers in a word processor or notepad program so you don't have to re-do them on the second attempt.
This quiz covers Lockdown America, pp. 38-89.

This is an open-book quiz. You are allowed to consult this week's required readings, as well as your personal notes on those readings. You are not allowed to consult classmates while taking the quiz, and you are not allowed to search the web or look at any documents outside of the assigned readings and your personal notes.

For this first proposal worksheet, your task is to select two or three potential research topics, making sure that they fit the requirements outlined in the assignment description:

  • The topic needs to come from one of the content-based readings on policing and prisons we have done so far this semester (i.e., Alexander and Parenti).
  • The topic must be connected to social justice, as defined in “Social Justice and English 2010,” which we covered the first week of the semester.
  • The topic cannot be entirely historical—it has to have some contemporary relevance.

Once you have selected your topics, for each topic selected, type the following in the text box below:

1. Describe your topic briefly, and explain where you found it in the text, being as precise as you can (e.g., "On page 412, first full paragraph . . .").

2. Explain why you believe this topic fits the second two requirements from the assignment description: How is it connected to social justice? Does it have contemporary relevance? For some topics, you'll need to do more work to make your case that the topic meets these requirements.

When I'm evaluating your worksheets, I will give you feedback about the feasibility of each of your proposed topics, in order to help you decide which topic to focus on. I will also let you know if one or more of your topics will not work. Note: If you decided to go with a topic other than one of those listed here, you must resubmit this worksheet in order to receive feedback on the new topic.

A reminder about how these worksheets function:

  • Worksheets are mandatory---you must complete them before submitting the corresponding essay. As such, worksheets can be accepted late, with the accompanying penalty as described in the syllabus (a 7% deduction for each day the worksheet is late).
  • You may be asked to resubmit a worksheet that is incomplete or requires additional work. In such cases, you will receive a 0 grade on the first submission, but can still receive full points. You won't receive a late penalty as long as the original submission was made on time and you resubmit the worksheet in a timely  way.

Please do not submit this worksheet until you have submitted Worksheet #1 and received feedback from me on it. If you were asked to resubmit Worksheet #1, you must first do that, and wait for my feedback, before you move onto this worksheet. You will not be penalized for turning this worksheet in late if you are waiting for my feedback on the previous worksheet and you submit this worksheet in a timely manner after receiving that feedback.

1. In the first worksheet, you received feedback on 2-3 potential research topics. What topic have you selected? (Note: This needs to be a topic you’ve run by me, either through Worksheet #1 or over e-mail.) Make sure you have a topic you will be happy with before you submit this worksheet. Describe this topic in a detailed way, using at least 4-5 sentences, and described how you have refined and/or modified your topic since you submitted the first worksheet. As with the first worksheet, make sure you include the specific passage from the text where you found your topic, and include a short quotation from the text.

2. Most students need to work on narrowing their topic to some extent. How have you worked to narrow this topic? Are you having any trouble narrowing the topic?

Reminder: Do not submit this worksheet until you have submitted Proposal Worksheet #2 and received feedback. If you have been asked to resubmit Worksheet #2, do not submit this worksheet until you have resubmitted Worksheet #2 and received feedback.

You should carefully study the MLA materials and the Example Student Paragraphs from the February 16-19 weekly module before you complete this worksheet.

For this third and final Proposal Worksheet, you are asked to complete the following:

1. Briefly restate your chosen topic. You can copy and paste this from your previous worksheet.

2. List two sources you plan to use for the Project Proposal. These should both be sources found through the library databases. For each of these sources, provide the following details:

a. A complete and correct MLA citation. You should obtain these citations using the database's citation feature. (You'll need to double-check the citations to make sure they are correct.)

b. A short (2-3 sentence) summary of the source.

c. A brief description of how the source will be useful in helping you develop background knowledge on your topic.

3. A complete, detailed paragraph from your proposal. This paragraph should be 8-10 sentences long and should include plenty of details from one of the sources listed above, including plenty of short quotations and paraphrase, along with parenthetical (in-text) MLA citations. Use the examples found in the Example Student Paragraphs as models for the level of engagement with sources you should be aiming for.

This worksheet must be completed at least 24 hours before your scheduled conference. If not, your conference appointment will be canceled, and you will need to reschedule. This worksheet is due on Friday, March 5, although I won't be counting it late if it is received by Sunday, March 7.

Part 1:

Please submit the following in the comments box below:

1. Provide a complete and correct MLA reference citation for two potential sources for your Exploratory Research Essay. Both of these should be library sources that fit the requirements found in the assignment description. One of them should be a scholarly article. (You don't need to worry about the hanging indent or other formatting for these citations.)

2. A brief (3-4 sentence) description of how each source will be useful for your essay.

(Unfortunately, Canvas will not allow a text entry as well as file uploads, so the comments box must be used to submit these details.)

Part 2:

In addition, you should upload a PDF file for both of these sources, if one is available. PDF files are available for almost all scholarly articles and e-books. For e-books, please submit a PDF that includes the first 10 pages of the source, beginning with the title page. PDF files are sometimes available for general-interest periodicals, although usually not for newspapers.

For this worksheet, please submit the following elements of your Researched Argument Essay:

1.Your tentative or working thesis statement, as it stands at the moment. You can include the thesis statement itself or the thesis statement as part of a draft of your introductory paragraph, if you've got it ready.

2. One or two paragraphs from the body of your paper that show ways you have engaged with a scholarly article or book in order to help support your thesis statement or respond to a potential counterargument. In each paragraph, work to include plenty of detail from your source in the form of paraphrase and one or two short quotations, with in-text citations in MLA format. Also, work to make sure that each paragraph is centered around one idea, and demonstrates continuity with surrounding paragraphs.

Please copy and paste these items directly into the text-box below.
Please upload a PDF file here for the source used in your Researched Argument Worksheet.

By Monday, April 19, please submit/upload your Companion Piece to this forum. If your piece is a video, podcast, slideshow, etc., you don’t need to include anything else. However, if your piece is an image or poster of some sort, you should include a brief paragraph that describes why you picked your chosen format that puts the Companion Piece in context for your audience (which is your classmates).

Then, by the end of the day on Friday, April 23 respond briefly to everyone in the group, focusing on the following questions: What was the most appealing or interesting aspect of the presentation? Did it make you want to read the entire paper? Why or why not? Did the student do a good job of presenting the main idea of the paper in a concise and direct format?

Finally, create a list for yourself of your favorite 7-10 presentations. You’ll be selecting the essays of classmates to read next week based upon these selections. You don’t need to submit this list.

Grading: You will receive 20 participation points for responding to the submissions of your group members. If you respond to some of your group members, but not all, you will receive partial points. If you upload your project but don’t respond to group members, you will receive 3 points.

assignment_name: Critical Reading and Discussion Forum, Feb. 1-5
description:
Part 1: Your original post, which should respond to each of the following questions in answers of at least 100 words each. This post is due by the end of the day on Thursday, February 4. Part 1 is worth 30 points---10 points for each question. To receive full points, your questions should meet the length requirement and also include plenty of details from the text, with in-text citations including page numbers.

1. As in previous chapters, Parenti makes some very bold claims in chapter ten. For example, he argues that rape is "central to . . . the politics of incarceration" (184), that "rape almost seems like a central part of prison management" (185) and that "gangs, like rape, are an indispensable part of ruling America's captive populations" (195). What evidence does Parenti use to support these claims? Does his use of this evidence convince you? Why or why not? Be as specific as you can, and refer to specific passages, using in-text citations.

2. What was your reaction to reading chapter 10? How did you respond to it on a logical and emotional way? How did Parenti utilize appeals to logic (logos) and pathos (emotion) to support his arguments? Spend some time thinking about the experiences of a prisoner who is impacted by the realities of rape and gang violence discussed by Parenti. How would you react if you, or one of your family members, was placed in such a situation?

3. You were assigned two additional readings this week that update and speak back to Lockdown America---articles by Daniel Bergner and Franklin Zimring. Spend some time comparing and contrasting these readings. How do these texts support the claims made by Parenti? How to they contradict Parenti's arguments? How do the new readings reveal the complexities and contradictions surrounding policing and prisons?

Part 2: For the second part of this assignment, you are required to make a thoughtful, detailed response to at least five of your fellow group members in this forum by Monday, February 8 at 10:00 a.m. These responses should be at least 75 words each. If five group members did not make their original posts on time, you are required to respond to all of the group members who posted by 11:59 p.m. on Thursday night. In such an instance, you will be required to let me know in the Discussion Responses assignment, found in this module. You can also receive extra credit for making additional back-and-forth comments with your group members. Please see that assignment description for more details. This part of the assignment is worth 25 points---five points for each response.

assignment_name: Critical Reading and Discussion Forum, January 11-15
description:
The Critical Reading and Discussion Forum this week is centered around the excerpt from Michelle Alexander's The New Jim Crow that is required reading for the week, as well as the first reading selection from Christian Parenti's Lockdown America (pp. 3-18). You have been assigned groups you will be interacting with for this forum and for several weeks going forward, although you may be assigned to different groups for discussions later on in the semester.

Once you have read both selections carefully, please complete the following requirements in a post to the discussion forum by 11:59 p.m. on Thursday:

1. Summarize each reading in 100 words or more, demonstrating that you've read the entire text carefully and have a solid command of each author's arguments. I will be looking at these summaries carefully as I am grading these discussions.

2. Respond to the following questions concerning Alexander in several sentences each:

a. Alexander tells us that  she "reached the conclusions presented in this book reluctantly" (2), that she originally found the "idea of a new racial caste system" to be "absurd" (3), and she seems to be working to win over a reluctant reader as well. Does her argument seem controversial to you? Why or why not? Does she do a good job of defending her position?

b. What was your viewpoint on race and policing prior to reading this article? Did your point of view change? Did anything in particular about the article surprise you or make you re-examine formerly held perspectives?

3. Respond to the following questions concerning the selection from Parenti:

a. As you will recall, you were asked to look up and document several historical and cultural references from this selection as part of the reading process and as preparation for this week's quiz. For this assignment, I'm asking you to extend that effort by spending more time doing background research on one of these historical or cultural topics. To avoid overlap, take the number for the month of your birth, and add three. For example, if you were born in March, you would add 3 + 3 for 6; if you were born in December, you would add 12 + 3 for 15. Then, go to the resulting page number (i.e., page 6 for those born in March) and select an unfamiliar historical term from that page. Your next job is to look up that topic in a reference work (perhaps Funk and Wagnalls New World Encyclopedia or Wikipedia), and describe the topic for your group members in a paragraph of at least 4-5 sentences. The aim of this task is to enrich the reading of all group members by providing some background research.

b. Did this reading challenge your view of American history in any way? Did any of it surprise you? What was your perception of America in the 1960s and 70s before you read this chapter? What was your perception after you read it?

As you are discussing each text, please paraphrase or quote from specific passages, including parenthetical citations with page numbers. Format these citations the same way I did when I quoted from Alexander in question 2a.

4. Finally, briefly introduce yourself to your group members: What is your major? Do you have any interesting hobbies or interests? Do you have any pets? Can you think of an embarrassing incident you'd like to share? (You are also asked to send an e-mail to introduce yourself to the professor---you can copy and paste your response to this question to that e-mail.)

After you've made these original posts, a discussion should ensue among your group members. In this discussion, you should discuss the text with each other as if you were in a room together. You should make a minimum of ten posts, and you should respond at least once to each group member. At least half of these posts should be 50 or more words long. In order to allow flexibility for those who need it, these posts can be completed anytime before Tuesday, January 19 at 8:00 a.m. Of course, these forums will work best if you check back in a few times to read and respond to your group members.

Grading:

10 points for each 100-word summary (20 points)

5 points for each question on Alexander and Parenti (20 points)

5 points for introducing yourself

15 points for detailed responses to your group members

60 points total

Important Note: Critical thinking and exploring controversial topics from various perspectives are key elements of this course. As such, please maintain courtesy in discussion forums at all times. To do so, make sure that you present your experiences and viewpoints in a frank and honest way, but also keep in mind that some of your classmates may have very different experiences and viewpoints. You should always communicate with the assumption that some of the individuals reading your posts will differ from you in the following ways:

  • Sexual orientation
  • Gender identity and expression
  • Ethnicity, race, and/or national origin
  • Immigration status
  • Religious belief (or lack thereof)
  • Political affiliation and ideology
  • Social class

This does not mean you can't express your personal views. It does mean that you need to explain your views within the context of your beliefs and experiences and do so in a way that won't make someone who has had (possibly very) different experiences and viewpoints feel unwelcome or out of place.

For this assignment, you will be graded on the responses you made to group members for this week's Critical Reading and Discussion Forum. Your responses, of course, should be posted in the forum, not here.

Grading:

  • 25 points for making thoughtful, detailed responses to at least five group members. These responses should be at least 75 words each. If five group members did not make their original posts on time, you are required to post to all of the group members who posted by 11:59 p.m. on Thursday night. If this is the case, you must indicate it in the text box below, letting me know how many group members posted by the deadline and how many you responded to. Otherwise, it isn't necessary to put anything in the text box.
  • You will also receive up to 5 extra credit points for engaging in thoughtful and on-topic back-and-forth responses beyond the required five.

For this assignment, you will be graded on the responses you made to group members for this week's Critical Reading and Discussion Forum. Your responses, of course, should be posted in the forum, not here.

Grading:

  • 25 points for making thoughtful, detailed responses to at least five group members. These responses should be at least 75 words each. If five group members did not make their original posts on time, you are required to post to all of the group members who posted by 11:59 p.m. on Thursday night. If this is the case, you must indicate it in the text box below, letting me know how many group members posted by the deadline and how many you responded to. Otherwise, it isn't necessary to put anything in the text box.
  • You will also receive up to 5 extra credit points for engaging in thoughtful and on-topic back-and-forth responses beyond the required five.

The purpose of this discussion forum is to give you the opportunity to discuss and respond to the Project Proposals of your group members.

As I've indicated previously, you should think of your classmates as part of your audience for all of your papers in this class, and you will have the opportunity to read and respond to the writing of your classmates throughout the semester.

This forum plays a very different purpose than a peer review, and you shouldn't approach your responses in the way you would a peer review. The purpose here is to serve as an audience member, and to engage with your group members as a interlocutor, someone who is a part of the conversation on the topic chosen and who speaks back to the author.

You are required to respond to the posts of at least four group members. Please prioritize group members who have not received many responses yet.

One of the primary purposes of the Project Proposal is to make an argument as to why the chosen topic is worthy of consideration. Has the author of this proposal convinced you that their topic is worth your attention as a potential reader? How do they go about making this argument? Look at the specific evidence that they use. Why is that evidence convincing to you or not convincing to you? If you believe that this topic is not worthy of intensive consideration, explain why, backing it up with evidence from the text. Here you should be a critical reader of the text, approaching this proposal the same way you would a scholarly article or another text you encounter in a college class. Look at the claims being made as well as the specific, detailed evidence used to support those claims.

Your response to each group member should be at least 150 words. In response, make sure you briefly quote from and otherwise refer to specific parts of the text, within in-text citations, at least five times.

If you are turning your proposal in on time, you should submit your complete proposal to the forum by 1:00 a.m. on Thursday morning (Wednesday night). If your Project Proposal is not ready by the Wednesday deadline, you should submit a partial draft---as much as you have---by the end of the day on Thursday. 

Your responses to group members should be completed by the end of the day on Saturday, February 27.

Grading:

5 points for submitting your Project Proposal (or draft) by the deadline listed above.

Up to 5 points each for thoughtful, detailed responses to your group members.

25 points total

assignment_name: Critical Reading and Discussion Forum, Jan. 25-29
description:
This discussion forum will have two parts.

Part 1: Your original post, which should respond to each of the following questions in answers of at least 100 words each. This post is due by the end of the day on Thursday, January 28. Part 1 is worth 40 points---10 points for each question. To receive full points, your questions should meet the length requirement and also include plenty of details from the text, with in-text citations including page numbers.

1. As you read, SWAT stands for Special Weapons and Tactics (112). Think about the specific weapons and tactics that SWAT teams use, as described in chapter six. If you are unfamiliar with the weapons mentioned, look up one or two of them to gain a better understanding. Describe the specific weapon you researched, and also summarize or discuss one of the SWAT “tactics” Parenti describes. How would you feel if officers with these sorts of weapons, and using these sorts of tactics, were deployed in your neighborhood? How would you and your family members react?

2. In the later part of chapter six, Parenti makes some strong arguments. For example, he contends that “the whole discourse of law enforcement takes place within a larger context of increasingly racist, anti-poor demagogy” (132), that “military technology and training do not make people safer” (133), and that “ritualized displays of terror are built into American policing” (135, emphasis in original). As I always emphasize with my students, strong arguments should be supported with strong evidence. Are these claims justified and supported by Parenti’s evidence? Why or why not? Pick one of these examples to focus on and use details from the text (with in-text citations) to support your response.

3. What does Parenti believe are the causes for the buildup of incarceration in recent decades? (If necessary, review pp. 167-169). Do you agree with his assessment? Why or why not? If not, what causes do you believe led to this dramatic increase in the prison population? Use evidence from the text, with in-text citations including page numbers, to support your response.

4. Parenti describes some features of contemporary prisons in chapter nine, and some things that have been taken away from prisoners in the years before he wrote this book. What do you think of these changes? Should prison be like this? Do prisoners need things like weight-lifting equipment and law libraries? If you were in a position to establish public policy regrading prisons, what conveniences and “amenities” would you allow prisoners to have and what things would you prohibit? 

Part 2: For the second part of this assignment, you are required to make a thoughtful, detailed response to at least five of your fellow group members in this forum by Monday, February 1 at 10:00 a.m. These responses should be at least 75 words each. If five group members did not make their original posts on time, you are required to post to all of the group members who posted by 11:59 p.m. on Thursday night. In such an instance, you will be required to let me know in the Discussion Responses assignment, found in this module. You can also receive extra credit for making additional back-and-forth comments with your group members. Please see that assignment description for more details. This part of the assignment is worth 25 points---five points for each response.

The purpose of this week’s discussion forum is to give you the opportunity to share the results of your research so far with some of your group members, so that you can learn from the research and thinking that they have done, and have the chance to provide some feedback and suggestions to them as you are in the midst of the research process.

Please complete the following by Tuesday at 11:59 p.m.:

1.  In the text box below, write a 2-3 sentence summary of your paper, focused on your research question and the controversies discovered in the sources you used. Work to make this description as interesting and detailed as possible, so your group members will get a good idea of your research focus. 

2. Post a complete copy of your essay to the forum below, either by inserting a PDF or Word file, or by pasting the paper in the text box.

Following this, you should read and respond to the essays of at least five group members, using the short descriptions of the essays to decide which ones you’d like to read, and also focusing on those who haven’t yet received many responses. Please read each essay carefully, with the aim to learn from the research and writing technique of the author, and to provide feedback about possible paths forward for the final research essay. Please don’t read papers that you read for the peer review. Post your responses to group members by Friday at 11:59 p.m.

In your response, address each of the following questions:

1. What was the most interesting or surprising thing you learned from reading the essay? What was your understanding of the topic before you read the essay? How did your understanding change as you read?

2. Did the author respond to their research question in an interesting and provocative way? Did you make you think about the topic from new perspectives?

3. What questions did you have after you read the essay? What questions, problems, or perspectives would you encourage the author to pursue as they move forward with the research project?

4. How did this paper contribute to your understanding of social justice? 

5. Did the author use a diversity of sources that helped you see the topic from a variety of perspectives? Which of the sources used was most interesting or provocative? Why?

Grading (30 points possible):

5 points for uploading a complete essay

Up to 5 points each for thorough responses to five group members

Up to 5 extra-credit points for students who respond to more than five group members or engage in extra back-and-forth discussion with your group members. You can receive credit for extra responses so long as they are made prior to Sunday, April 4 at 11:59 p.m.

Please post your Researched Argument Essay here for by the end of the day on Friday, April 30. If your essay is not complete, post whatever you have by the deadline. You won't be penalized for posting a partial essay.

Then, by the end of the day on  Wednesday, May 5 you should respond to the essays of at least four of your group members. Use the list you generated from reviewing the Research Companion Pieces to decide which classmates to respond to, and focus on those who have not received many responses yet. Make sure to respond to each essay in a detailed and thoughtful way, focusing on the following questions:

1. Did you find the argument presented in the essay to be engaging and controversial? Why or why not? Did the essay make you think about its topic in a new and challenging way?

2. How did the essay reflect on the course theme, social justice? How did your understanding of social justice grow or change based upon reading this essay?

3. What were the most interesting, challenging, or provocative things you learned from reading this essay?

4. What was one thing you learned from reading this essay that will help you become a better writer?

5. What is one piece of advice you can give to the author to help them develop their writing skills going forward?

Grading:

5 points for posting your paper

5 points for each complete response to four classmates

Up to 7 extra credit points for responding to classmates and engaging in a back-and-forth discussion.

Note: You won't be able to make posts on Canvas after the end of the semester on Thursday, May 6 at 11:59 p.m., so all responses will need to be made before that time. There are no exceptions to this requirement.

For this peer review, you should carefully read and review the essays of three of your group members.

These are the requirements for this assignment:

1. Please post a draft of your Researched Argument Essay to this forum by Wednesday, April 21 at 11:59 p.m. To receive full points, your draft should be at least five double-spaced pages, but you will receive partial credit for a partial draft. Even if you don't post a draft, you will receive points for responding to the work of group members. You can post your draft by pasting it directly into the discussion forum.

2. Once you have posted your essay, you will be responsible for responding to the drafts of three class members in a thoughtful, detailed way, answering each of the questions listed below. Please post your responses by the end of the day on Saturday, April 24 in order to receive full credit.

3. You should give preference to class members whose topics are most closely related to yours, as well as group members who have received a low number of responses.

Reminder: A peer review is, by nature, a time sensitive assignment. Peer responses submitted after Monday, April 26, will not receive credit.

Grading:

15 points for posting a complete essay (partial points for partial essays)

5 points each for three complete, detailed responses, responding to the questions listed below

30 points total

You will receive up to 4 extra-credit points each for responding to up to two additional essays.

Peer Review Questions:

1. Is the introduction of the paper is engaging and specific? Does it include a hook that gets the reader's attention? Does it provide necessary background detail on the author's specific topic? Does it present a direct, bold, an controversial/risky thesis statement? Does it let you know what the author's purpose is? Does it provide a brief overview of the main points to be made in the paper?

2. Does the paper include a distinct introduction, body, and conclusion? Does the author create continuity by using transitions to connection one paragraph to another? Are body paragraphs introduced with topic sentences? Does each body paragraph focus on just one point or idea?

3. Do you feel that the author is sharing rich details about their research sources with you? Do you feel like you are learning new things about this topic? Where could the author provide additional details from their sources?  Do you feel that the author has strong command over all of the research sources used?

4. Does the author support the thesis statement in a strong way throughout the body of the paper? Did you notice any logical fallacies?

5. Does the author respond to one or more counterarguments in a thorough and convincing way?

6. Were the sentences clear and easy to read? Did they flow easily from one to the next?

7. If the author appears to be missing any in-text citations, please let them know!

If you miss several of the even-numbered questions, you should study the concept further and work on correcting all of your answers.

1. Please post a draft of your Exploratory Research Essay to this forum by the due date listed below. To receive full points, your draft should be at least four double-spaced pages, but you will receive partial credit for a partial draft. Even if you don't post a draft, you will receive points for responding to the work of group members. You can post your draft by pasting it directly into the discussion forum.

Next week, April 12-16, I'll be holding two live sessions at various days and times. In order to give as many students as possible an opportunity to participate in person and receive extra credit, I'm conducting a short survey to ask you about your preferred days and times.

Please submit your complete project proposal here, in PDF (preferred) or Microsoft Word format. Please make sure your proposal follows the guidelines listed in the Project Proposal assignment description.

Also, please submit a PDF file for any of your library sources that has a full-text PDF file available.

This assignment is due on Wednesday, February 24. The late due date is Monday, March 1.

I treat the proposals as an opportunity for you to discuss the preliminary reading and thinking you have done around your topic, and to receive feedback. As such, one of the key elements I’ll be focusing on as I grade is the degree to which you show detailed and sustained engagement with your sources—something I’ve mentioned before, of course. The key to receiving an A grade for your proposal is convincing me that you’ve done your work, that you really understand the topic based upon preliminary reading from the 2-3 required sources.

In addition to this, you’ll be evaluated based upon making sure you cover all the bases for the proposal requirements, and doing so in a thoughtful way. In particular, you should:

  • Make sure your topic fits the requirements in the assignment description and has been approved through the worksheet process.
  • Demonstrate adequate background knowledge on your topic.
  • Make an argument as to why the topic is important, why it is worthy of consideration, and why the reader should care.
  • Make sure you are citing your sources correctly, according to MLA requirements, both in the works cited page and with in-text citations.
  • Talk about ways that you are working to narrow your focus, or ways that you foresee narrowing your focus based upon your preliminary work to this point.
  • List and discuss your preliminary research questions.

Finally, you should make sure you are using the required library sources, as discussed in the assignment description. You should also avoid web sources, except for one optional Wikipedia article. Make sure your sources are helping you gain strong background knowledge on your topic.

Please submit your Researched Argument Essay here as a Microsoft Word or PDF file by Thursday, May 6 at 11:59 p.m. Papers cannot be accepted after this point except in the case of extenuating situations as discussed with the professor in advance.

If you don't submit PDF files for your sources, you may be asked to resubmit this assignment, and your grade may be delayed. Also, please make sure your works cited page includes a URL for all sources found through the web.

This quiz covers Lockdown America, pages 3-18.

In this last discussion post (yeah!), I want you to think about everything we covered this semester.  We explored many places and topics, and one of my main goals for this class is that you remember some earth processes in the future.  

Write one paragraph about what lesson, topic, assignment, or discussion that you will remember most after taking this class.  Why was this lesson so memorable?  Make sure to write a detailed paragraph of your experience. 

In addition to writing one paragraph, comment on two group members.  In your comment to group members, reflect on the lesson that they described as the most memorable.  What was your experience with this lesson?  Make sure to write a detailed paragraph of your experience.

In this discussion, you will take on the role as a policy maker, either at the national or global level.  Your task is to describe in three paragraphs how would you balance the increasing demand for food around the world with the need to ensure the health, quality, and sustainability of soil? 

Make sure your answer is grounded in the science of soils from Chapter 12.  Feel free to consult internet sources as needed, just make sure to provide the links in your posting.  

Respond to two group members.  In your response, tell them what you agree/disagree with and why, and what else they could consider in the policy ideas.

Description

In this activity, you will collect information about the potential earthquake hazards and vulnerability of where you live.  If you do not live along the Wasatch Front, you can use UVU's location, or some other place.  

Factors that affect seismic risk include:

  • Hazard: The chance that the building will experience strong shaking, soil liquefaction, or a landslide.
  • Vulnerability: The likelihood that the building will collapse due to those geological hazards.

Procedure

Follow these directions to collect your numbers for each index, and then input your information into the Google Sheet provided in the Module.  

First we will examine the physical geographic contexts of your location, then you will examine the dwelling itself. 

  • Examine the Strong Shaking Potential map on Page 16 of the Scenario for a Magnitude 7.0 Earthquake on the Wasatch Fault–Salt Lake City Segment report (found on Canvas). 
    • This is a map of the shaking intensity that is 10% likely to occur. Use the following categories to score the seismic hazard due to strong shaking. Score your location location using the numbers in parentheses, based on the ground acceleration. Put the score in the column labeled A on the seismic risk spreadsheet.
      • Purple to blue to green areas of the map: Low hazard (1)
      • Yellow to Orange areas of the map: Moderate hazard (2)
      • Red areas of the map: Significant hazard (3)
  • Examine the Liquefaction Potential map from the Utah Geologic Survey (https://geology.utah.gov/hazards/earthquakes-faults/liquefaction/#tab-id-2). This is a map of the likelihood of liquefaction due to earthquake shaking . Score your location using the numbers in parentheses, based on the liquefaction potential map. Put the score in the column labeled B on the seismic risk spreadsheet.
    • Low / Very Low hazard (1)
    • Moderate hazard (2)
    • High (3)
  • Examine the Landslide potential map of Page 21 of the Scenario for a Magnitude 7.0 Earthquake on the Wasatch Fault–Salt Lake City Segment (available here:  https://dem.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/18/2015/03/RS1058_EERI_SLC_EQ_Scenario.pdf).  In this report you will find 2 maps—one of landslide potential in wet conditions and one in dry conditions. You will try to take the average between these two maps.  Estimate the landslide hazard using the categories below. Score your location using the numbers in parentheses, based on the landslide hazard. Put the score in the column labeled C on the seismic risk spreadsheet.
    • Low hazard: grey areas on map, on flat land (1)
    • Moderate hazard: green to yellow areas on the map, at foot of slope or on gradual slope (2)
    • High hazard: orange to red areas on the map, building is on a steep slope (3)

Building construction plays a large role in determining risk.  

  • Examine your house or dwelling and see if there are any “soft stories,” floors of the building with few supporting walls, such as parking garages or large auditoriums, that are underneath other floors of the building.
    • If there are Soft Stories, enter 1; if no soft stories, enter 0
  • Buildings made of unreinforced masonry (brick or concrete without reinforcement) are particularly susceptible to earthquake damage. If there is clear evidence that a building is made of unreinforced masonry, that building gets a 2 in column C. If the building is made of masonry and it was built before 1970, give it a score of 1.5.
  • Buildings with a vertical irregularity (different parts at different heights) or plan irregularity (deviations from a box-shape) tend to fare poorly in earthquakes. Give each building with either type of irregularity a score of 0.5.
  • Number of people in the house/dwelling: The “value” we are using when calculating risk in this exercise is the number of lives at risk. If you live in a house, count the number of people that are regularly present.  If you live in an apartment building or multi-dwelling unit, estimate the number of people in your particular building.  

 

After you have completed the tasks above, open the Google Sheet and add a new row with your information.  The Google Sheet can be found here (Earthquake risk assessment sheet) and also on the Modules tab for this unit.  Your risk will be automatically calculated once you enter in the information in the columns.  The lower the number is the risk column, the better.  

In your discussion, share your results.  What was your risk score?  What were some of the biggest contributing factors to your risk score?  What surprised you about earthquake risk in Utah?  How could you reduce your earthquake risk? 

You will also comment on two group members.  Give a general reaction to their score and ask one question about their risk score that they did not discuss.  For example, you might ask why their risk of landslides was high, or liquefaction low.  Finally, help them think about ways to be prepared for an earthquake.  

Your original post is due Friday by midnight, and comments to your group members are due Sunday by midnight.

For this discussion, you will find an image of a karst landscape somewhere in the world. Three major karst landscapes are sinkholes, caves, and tower karst.  

  • Post the image of your landscape here, and make sure to include where this landscape is found.  
  • After you post your picture, explain how this landscape formed (one paragraph).  

 

After you have posted your landscape, comment on two other group members. 

  • In your comments, examine some challenges that these landscapes face.  Do some research into how many people visit the landscapes each year.  Brainstorm what some potential challenges are in managing this landscape given how it formed and the pressure form visitors.

In this last chapter of your book, many different coastal processes are discussed.  In this discussion, we will focus on the challenges facing coral reefs in the coming years.  

Choose one of the major coral reef regions in the world.  If you need help, Wikipedia has a pretty good list:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_reefs.  Pick one of these reefs to research.  

Write on paragraph for the following questions:

  • Where is the reef and what is the approximate size?  Why did you choose this reef to investigate? 
  • What are some major challenges facing the reef?  
    • For example, is the reef over-visited?  Or perhaps the reef is vulnerable to trash or sewage dumping?  
    • How is climate change impacting the reef?
    • **You might consider using Google News for this question.  Do you just use Wikipedia.  
  • What are some ways that the reef can be better managed, or what are some solutions to the problems the reef faces? 

 

After you have made your initial post, comment on two group members.  In your comment, you should state what you think about their solutions and what are some aspects they may have overlooked.

assignment_name: Why should we care about biodiversity?
description:
In this discussion, you will read the article entitled “Conservation of Biodiversity” (available as PDF or here (Chrome works best as a browser).  In the article, the author outlines some arguments for why we should care about biodiversity and extinction rates.  Also, read the summary of the new report our from the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services here. 

In your discussion posting, you will respond to this same question: 

  • Why should we care about biodiversity and extinction? 
  • What arguments do you think are most compelling? 
  • What did the authors not address that you think is critical for ensuring biodiversity?  
  • How can we communicate these scientific ideas in a compelling way to the general public?  

Your response should be at least 500 words. 

Respond to two of your group members’ discussion posting.  In your response, identify what you agree / disagree with and why.  Responses should be 200 words, and be thoughtful responses to the ideas presented.

Tuvalu:  Keeping Heads Above Water

https://ezproxy.uvu.edu/login?url=http://fod.infobase.com/PortalPlaylists.aspx?wID=114324&xtid=40372

Watch this short film Tuvalu: Keeping Heads Above Water. It shows how one country in the South Pacific Ocean is dealing with sea level rise.  Answer these questions: 

  1. How do various aspects of the physical geography of Tuvalu make sea level rise an issue?
  2. What environmental practices should the people of Tuvalu continue? What practices should they stop? 
  3. Do you think the global community should help Tuvalu? Why or why not? 
  4. What scientific studies can help Tuvalu in the future?
  5. If you were the president of Tuvalu, what would you do to ensure the future or your island nation?

In your response to two of your group members’ posts.  Do you agree with their plans for future?  Why or why not?  What else could they add to their plan to make it better?  Do you agree with their ideas about the role of the global community?  Why or why not?

Your book has a great discussion of the challenges of representing the earth through maps.  Since the earth is round and maps are generally flat, representing the earth is always a challenge.  Cartographers use different map projections when making maps, depending on what they want to show.  Map projections are ways to transfer data from a spherical surface to a flat surface.   

To gain an understanding of how really difficult making maps are, you will do an experiment in map making. 

For this experiment, complete the following steps: 

1.  Get a round fruit with a peel, such an orange, grapefruit, cutie, tangerine, etc.  

2.  Sketch out the earth on the fruit.  Use a globe, or look at online images of a globe, to help you sketch your continents and oceans as good as possible.  Your globe might look something like this: 

3.  Once your fruit globe is complete, remove the peel as carefully as possible.  

  • You can choose to make cuts or slices in the peel while you remove it.  Read on to Step 4 for more help.  

4.  Once you have the peel, figure out how to make the peels fit onto a flat surface.  Turn your globe into a map!  

  • You might try cutting shapes or lines in particular places to try to get your peel to lay flat.  

 

When you have made the best map you can, take a picture of the orange peel map and post it to your discussion group.  Along with the picture, write one paragraph on your experience of the experiment (what was easy?  what was hard?  how did it help you understand map projections?  any other thoughts?).  

Upload the picture of your map and the paragraph to Canvas by Friday at midnight.  

Comment to two group members postings by Sunday at midnight.  In your comments, discuss any differences you have between your maps and general reflections on their ideas.

Investigating inversions in Utah’s Wasatch Front

If you have lived in Utah during the winter, you have probably experienced or heard about the inversion.  An inversion is not something that creates pollution, but something that traps pollution in a localized area.  The “inversion” refers to a temperature inversion, where warm air above traps cold air at the surface (normally, warm air at the surface rises and cools, so cooler air is found above warm air).  When the cold air at the surface is trapped, so is all of the particulate matter and pollution the air contains. 

If you need a reminder of the inversion and its impact on pollution, here is a short video from 2013, one of the worst years on record:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kdCm4PYyWxo (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.

For this assignment, you will examine different aspects of Utah’s air pollution and inversion.   You will investigate and explain pollution along the Wasatch Front. 

The Utah Department of Air Quality can help you identify pollution issues:  https://deq.utah.gov/division-air-quality.   (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.Open the DEQ site, and select the Interactive Map option at the top.  Once you are in the map, click on the Air Quality section and select the item you want to examine, then click on the blue Search button on the bottom.  

  1. Source:  what are some of the primary sources of pollution in the Wasatch Front?  Pollution is grouped into two different categories:  point and non-point.  Review these definitions (here is a good website: https://www.epa.gov/nps/basic-information-about-nonpoint-source-nps-pollution (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.), and then provide detailed examples in our local context.  *For example, do not just list factories/power plants as point source pollution, but list exactly what factories or power plants and where they are located.  
  2. Atmospheric Conditions and Topography:  why are we in Utah prone to inversions?  Explain our topography and atmospheric conditions that leave us vulnerable to these conditions. 
  3. How to improve: Now that you have read about sources of pollution, think of 3 ideas that the State of Utah can implement to improve air quality issues.   Describe your 3 ideas for our local area in your response here.  

After you have posted, read the ideas presented by your classmates.  Comment on at least two group members.  In your comments, reflect on the sources of pollution they identified and evaluate their potential solutions.  What are some of the challenges for implementation of their solutions? 

Original post in due by Friday at midnight, with comments to group members due by Sunday at midnight.

In this discussion, you will watch a short documentary about Utah’s water future, think about science and Utah’s water, and discuss what are the most important issues to consider when thinking about Utah’s water future. 

https://video.pbsutah.org/video/utah-now-utahs-uncertain-water-future/

Answer the following questions in your discussion posting:

  1. Based on the film, what do you think is the biggest concern for Utah’s water in the future? Why do you think this is an issue for Utah? (1 paragraph)
  2. How could these issues be solved? (1 paragraph)
  3. Think of 3 scientific studies or approaches to studying Utah’s water that are needed to plan for the future. What could these studies tell us about Utah’s water? (1 paragraph)
    • The readings in Chapter 8 can help you think of scientific studies.
      • For example, we could develop of a study of different rates of evapotranspiration across the state to see how our water budget varies spatially and annually. This could help us plan pipelines or areas of priority water conservation. 
    • Ask three friends/family/co-workers if they know the source of their drinking water. (1 paragraph)
      • Write their responses.
      • Find out where their water actually comes from (you can easily search online).
        • Were their ideas about drinking water close to how the system works? (You should also tell them what you found!). 
      • How do you think knowing where your water comes from might change the way you use or think about the resource? Is it useful for people to know more about the water they use on a daily basis?

Respond to two of your group members’ postings.  In your response, indicate whether you agree or disagree about Utah’s water concerns and why.  Also comment on their ideas for further study and knowledge about water.

Your original posting is due on Friday by midnight, and your comments to group members are due on Sunday by midnight.

For this discussion, you will investigate a river in Utah.  You will include some images in your answers also.  Each person in your group should choose a different river in the state, and answer the following questions:  

  1. Where are the headwaters for this river?  
  2. What types of drainage patterns do you see in the drainage basin?  Include 1 image.  
  3. What type of stream channel (one of the two) is the river?  Braided or meandering?  Include 1 image that show the type of stream channels.  
  4. Evidence of erosion--include 2 images from the river's path that demonstrate erosion, and for each image explain how you see erosion in the image.  
  5. Evidence of deposition--include 2 images from the river's path that demonstrate deposition, and for each image explain how you see deposition in the image. 
  6. What is the base level of the river?  In other words, where does the river end? 
  7. Historical or recent flooding events (find one example).
  8. How does the river impact humans (find two examples)?

 

Examine two of your group members' river tours.  In your response to their tour, identify 2 differences and 2 similarities of your rivers.  Have you ever been to this river?  Ever heard of this river?  What could be some future challenges to this river? 

Your original posting is due on Friday by midnight, and your comments are due Sunday by midnight.

Utah has some of the most recognizable arid landscapes in the world.  For this assignment, you will pick one of our National Parks in Utah and analyze the landscapes according to themes in Chapter 18. 

 

Pick your national park.  Link to an iconic landform from the park that you will analyze. 

  • What special conditions and factors influence landform development in deserts? 
  • What is the role of running water, erosion, and deposition in the park and in your landform?
  • What is the role of wind in shaping the park and your landform?
  • Is there any evidence of playas and alluvial fans?  How do you know?
  • Is there any evidence of buttes and mesas?  How do you know?

Chapters 15 and 16 discuss how rocks are weathered, eroded, and deposited.  These are central processes in landscape formation, and can be really easy to spot once we understand the processes.  This assignment has two parts.  The first part of the assignment asks you to interpret some landscapes from Capitol Reef National Park.  The second part of the assignment asks you to compare flash floods and debris flows. 

 

Capitol Reef National Park

Did you know UVU has a Field Station in Capitol Reef National Park?  It’s pretty amazing.  For this first part of the assignment, you will discuss jointing, chemical weathering, and physical weathering that is visible in park. 

  • First, analyze the landscape formation processes in this image of the field station.  What evidence of jointing, chemical weathering, and physical weathering are visible here?  Write one paragraph. 

 

  • Next, examine this image of Cassidy Arch.  What evidence of jointing, chemical weathering, and physical weathering are visible here?  Write one paragraph. 

 

  • Finally, examine this image of Hickman Bridge.  How did this arch form?  You can do some research on how the arch forms (see Chapter 18), but make sure to summarize here in your own words. 

 

Mass wasting and flash floods in Utah

Mass wasting and flash floods are very intense processes of landscape formation.  Here, you will compare videos of flash floods and debris flowers in Utah. 

  • First, find a video of a flash flood in a canyon in Utah.  Paste the link to the video here. 
  • Next, find a video of a debris flow in Utah.  Paste the link to the video here. 
  • Compare and contrast these two events. 
    • How are they similar and how are they different? 
    • If you had to choose between the two, which of these would you rather experience and why? 
    • List and describe three strategies you would use if you were trapped in either a flash flood or debris flow.

assignment_name: Monitoring land cover changes over time
description:
Places are always changing, and as geographers we try to track and understand these changes.  An important innovation in tracking how land changes is the use of satellite imagery.  Geographers use satellite images and GIS (Geographic Information Systems) to track, measure, and visualize how the earth has changed.  For example, satellite imagery has been critical in monitoring deforestation and glacial melting in areas that are often remote and difficult to access.  

For this assignment, you will examine this collection of videos of earth changes compiled by Google Earth.  Google Earth uses satellite imagery, and through their time lapse and historical imagery features we can access images of places up to 30 years ago.  This compilation video shows some of the more dramatic changes on earth over the past few decades:  

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWw80tqUZ5J_T8EKLKEWYd_NcFPiq9zTN 

Choose 4 time lapse videos from this compilation to examine.  For each, watch the video a number of times and observe how the earth has changed.  You might want to slow down the video so you can see the images more clear (click on Settings (the wheel/spoke looking thing) in the lower right side of the video and change the speed to .25).  

For each time lapse, write one paragraph detailing the major changes you observed, and the potential consequences of these changes.  You should have 4 paragraphs explaining land use change.  Each paragraph is worth 4 points.   

For your final paragraph, compare these locations.  What location changed the most dramatically?  Why did some places change more than others?  What are some of the biggest implications of these changes?  This paragraph is also worth 4 points.

Chapter 1 of our book discusses earth-sun relationships.  These are key concepts in understanding climate and the changing of the seasons, so it is essential that you understand how the sun and the earth interact.   

For this assignment, you will read your book and also watch this short video about earth-sun relationships:  

Reasons for the seasons - Rebecca Kaplan 

Imagine you are with your family or friends, and someone asks about why we have dramatic seasonal differences in climate in Utah, but that Pacific Islands don't change too much.  Your task is to explain these differences based on earth-sun relationships.  

1.  What is the latitude of Utah (pick a city) and how does it compare to the latitude of the Pacific Islands (pick an island)? 

2.  How does the tilt of the earth on its axis impact how much energy from the sun a place receives during the year? 

3.  How does the tilt of the earth on its axis impact the angle of sun that a place receives? 

4.  How does the earth's revolution around the sun impact how much energy from the sun a place receives? 

5.  How does day length in Utah and the Pacific Islands compare during June and December? 

 

Make sure answers are complete and robust to show me that you understand the concepts!  

 

Also, this video does a good job explaining earth-sun relationships to kids.  I found it useful, and so might you! 

Earth's Rotation & Revolution: Crash Course Kids 8.1

assignment_name: Measuring the angle of the sun
description:
Measuring the angle of the sun on the horizon using shadows

To calculate the angle of the sun above the horizon, you can use shadows!  In this exercise, you will measure the length of shadows at three times during the day, and use the length of the shadow to calculate the angle of the sun above the horizon.  

For this exercise you will need a camera, something to cast a shadow (a friend, child, or other large object), a ruler or tape measure, and chalk (or someway to mark where you are measuring the shadows). 

 

To measure shadows, follow these directions:

  1. Find a place outside away from large trees to measure the shadow. This could be an unobstructed driveway or street, parking lot, or sidewalk. 
  2. Draw one circle to mark where you will stand to take the picture, and one mark for where the person or object will stand.
  3. Measure the height of your object, friend, or child.
  4. At three different times in the day (between 8-9 am, between 12-1 pm, and between 3-4 pm), go outside and measure the shadow.
    • Have the person or object stand in their mark and measure how long their shadow is, record what direction the sun is coming from, and what direction their shadow is projected.
    • After you have measured the shadow, go to your mark and take a picture.
    • Ask the person (or feel the object) what the sun and heat feels like.
    • Repeat three times during the day.
  5. Calculate the angle of the sun above the horizon at your measurement points.
    • To calculate the angle of the sun, use this equation:  in a scientific calculator or use an online calculator. 
      • To calculate the sun angle, first divide the height of the object by the length of the shadow:  then find the arctan (the inverse tangent) of the angle using an scientific calculator or online calculator such as this:  http://www.rapidtables.com/calc/math/Arctan_Calculator.htm
  6. What did you observe about the shadows and how they changed during the day?   Include information about how the participant experienced the sun, or what the objects felt like.
  7. Include your pictures and results and upload them here.  

 

Here is my example: 

  • April 29th, 9:30 am. 
  • Height of object (my son):  49 inches 
  • Length of shadow:  68 inches 
  • Sun angle on the horizon:  38°

For my example, my son measured is 49 inches tell, and his shadow was 68 inches long.  First, I calculated height of object divided by length of shadow:   = .72058824.  The online arctan calculator gave me a result of 37.77°.  This means that on April 29th at 9:30 am, the sun was approximately 38° above the horizon.

Clouds! 

For this assignment, you will observe clouds during the week and collect images of different cloud types (look at your textbook for cloud type classification).  Make sure to plan ahead since you may need several days to observe different cloud types. 

For each of the cloud types:

  • Record the following:
    • atmospheric conditions 
    • temperature
    • relative humidity
    • air pressure (using an online weather site such as weather.com)
    • time of day
    • general height of cloud (low, high, very high)
    • the cloud type (based on the descriptions in your textbook) 
  • You should aim for 5-7 different cloud type observations.  
  • If for some reason you can't go outside for even a minute to observe a few clouds, try looking through old pictures on your phone to see if you have any pics that include clouds, and then analyze those clouds. 
  • Include your pictures and your observations and turn it in! 

Turn in your observations by Sunday at midnight.

assignment_name: The Story of Your Favorite Coastline
description:
Tell the (physical geography) story of your favorite coastline

Chapter 20 of your textbook outlines multiple processes behind the formation of coastlines and physical processes that impact their current and future appearance. 

For this assignment, you will choose one coastline anywhere in the world and investigate how it formed and what processes are shaping that coastline now.

Your story should include a description of following aspects of coastal processes: 

  1. Waves
  2. Tides
  3. Storms
  4. Slope of seafloor
  5. Orientation of coastline
  6. Bedrock
  7. Streams and sediment
  8. Uplift
  9. Climate

This paper should be at least 500 words.

For this assignment, you will analyze one of the following documentary films based on the concepts from Chapters 13 and 14 in your book. 

  • Making North America:  https://ezproxy.uvu.edu/login?url=http://fod.infobase.com/PortalPlaylists.aspx?wID=114324&xtid=114679 (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.
  • America:  Rise of the Continents:  https://ezproxy.uvu.edu/login?url=http://fod.infobase.com/PortalPlaylists.aspx?wID=114324&xtid=57648 (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.
  • Eurasia:  Rise of the Continents:  https://ezproxy.uvu.edu/login?url=http://fod.infobase.com/PortalPlaylists.aspx?wID=114324&xtid=57649 (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.
  • Africa:  Rise of the Continents:  https://ezproxy.uvu.edu/login?url=http://fod.infobase.com/PortalPlaylists.aspx?wID=114324&xtid=57646 (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.
  • Australia:  Rise of the Continents:  https://ezproxy.uvu.edu/login?url=http://fod.infobase.com/PortalPlaylists.aspx?wID=114324&xtid=57647 (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.
  • Asia:  The Tectonics of Life and Death:  https://ezproxy.uvu.edu/login?url=http://fod.infobase.com/PortalPlaylists.aspx?wID=114324&xtid=58162 (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.
  • Oceania:  The Tectonic Ring of Fire:  https://ezproxy.uvu.edu/login?url=http://fod.infobase.com/PortalPlaylists.aspx?wID=114324&xtid=58164 (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.
  • Europe:  Tropical Beginnings:  https://ezproxy.uvu.edu/login?url=http://fod.infobase.com/PortalPlaylists.aspx?wID=114324&xtid=58165 (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.

Film analyses are NOT summaries!  These films have been chosen because they highlight and bring to life concepts from the readings.  Reading about plate tectonics or earthquakes can be pretty abstract, but documentaries show these earth features in vivid detail. 

You should examine key concepts, themes, or problems from the textbook and apply these concepts to the scenarios presented in the film.

Directions:

  • Examine the assigned chapters from the book, concentrating especially on key concepts.
  • Do not summarize the film, but rather apply course concepts to the scenarios.
  • Look for concepts and vocabulary in the book that appear in bold text—these might be a good place to start in looking for concepts. 
  • Watch one of the assigned films.
  • While watching the film, think about course concepts that apply and would be useful to make sense of the film.
  • Post at least a 500 word response to the film which includes your analysis of the film based on course concepts.
  • Please include the concepts from the book in bold text.
  • Please feel free to tell us if you liked the film, and generally what you thought of the film.

In this final essay assignment, we will think about how to survive off of natural systems.  Throughout this course, we have explored multiple aspects of our physical environment that influence our daily lives.  From plate tectonics and soils to temperature and evapotranspiration, you are now familiar with earth systems sciences that impact humans every day, in every way!  For this last assignment, you will answer the following question using principles of earth system science. 

  • Where should you go after you survive the zombie apocalypse? 

Assume you have survived the zombie apocalypse, but now have to figure out where and how to live off of only natural systems. Consider aspects from each Lesson on Canvas in your answer.   Explain how the concepts from each chapter, or one main concept from each chapter, influenced your decision of where to live.  Describe the concept and why you think it is important.  Each concept should be one paragraph (5 points per paragraph). 

  • Where would you go to live off natural systems? (Give as much locational detail as possible!)
  • Explain your reasoning with concepts from each chapter.

** For this final, you can make a video, PowerPoint, or other creative works rather than writing out an essay!  If you prefer to make a video rather than writing out your response to this assignment that is fine.  You can upload it to YouTube and send me the link, or upload it to the Google Drive and send me the link, or even just upload the file here.

Investigating the Soil Beneath You

In this assignment, you will explore the soil in your yard, a park, or somewhere you can dig a small hole.  You will first classify the soil based on texture feel, and then consult a soil map to see how your results compare. 

For this activity, you will need a small bottle of water, a measuring cup, a ruler or tape measure, and some paper towels to clean off your hands between samples. 

 Classifying soil texture

1) Collect three soil samples at different depths in your yard, a park, or somewhere you can dig a small hole.  You will want to make sure the first soil sample is below the organic layer (the upper most part of the soil where grass roots and other plant matter decay are present).  Collect about ½ cup of soil at each sample depth.  Make sure to record the depth at which the sample was taken. Include images of the samples and the soil pit/hole you dug. 

2) After you have collected the samples and recorded their depth, perform a texture feel analysis.  The flow chart below (scroll all the way to the end, or find it here:  https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_MEDIA/nrcs142p2_050352.jpg) provides you step-by-step directions to analyzing your soil texture.  Here is a good YouTube video that demonstrates various aspects of the test:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GWZwbVJCNec. 

3) Record your results in the table below.  

Soil Sample

Depth sample was taken

Texture classification
