 4)  After you classified your soil, investigate what these textures mean.  Here is a good blog post that describes different types of soil textures along with their uses:  http://agverra.com/blog/soil-types/.   In one paragraph, describe the uses, positive, and negative aspects of your soil samples.

As many of you know, last year Utah Lake experienced severe problems with algal blooms, which closed the lake and impacted water supply in the region.  For this assignment, you will investigate what causes algal blooms on the lake, and think about ways to solve these problems. 

Read these recent articles on Utah Lake for some background information on Utah Lake: 

  • State officials seek to avoid repeat of summertime algal blooms: https://www.ksl.com/?sid=44721370&nid=148,
  • First Utah Lake Summit seeks to answer questions, provide solutions for future: http://www.heraldextra.com/news/local/first-utah-lake-summit-seeks-to-answer-questions-provide-solutions/article_84d86b47-b967-56cc-9247-3af82848cef4.html
  • Will algal blooms return to Utah waters? If so, state officials say they’re better prepared: http://www.sltrib.com/home/5423688-155/will-algal-blooms-return-to-utah
  • Utah Lake’s poop-driven algal bloom is a crappy situation: https://www.wired.com/2016/07/pretty-algae-bloom-lake-utah-blame-pooping/ 

This chapter in your textbook discusses nutrient cycles that shape ecosystems, like Utah Lake.  These nutrient cycles are key to understanding the problems facing Utah Lake. 

Answer the following questions: 

  1. What biogeochemical cycle is most important to understanding algal blooms on Utah Lake? 
  2. Describe in detail (in your own words) how the cycle you identified above works and how it can be disturbed?
  3. How are humans implicated in the algal bloom problems on Utah Lake?
  4. How is Utah Lake connected to other waterways in the state?
  5. How could algal blooms on Utah Lake effect other waterways in the state?
  6. What species are impacted by algal blooms?
  7. Describe in detail three possible solutions for solving the algal bloom problem. (One paragraph for each solution).

How much water do you and your family use?  

This is a question that you might not think about too much, so now if your chance!  

For this assignment, you will first take the Water Footprint Calculator quiz here:  https://www.watercalculator.org/ After you answer a series of questions, you will get a result with your water use compared to the national average.   

After you have your results, read about water use in Utah here:  https://geology.utah.gov/map-pub/survey-notes/glad-you-asked/does-utah-use-more-water/  

Answer the following questions about water use.  

1.  What was your average water use and how did it compare to the national average? 

2.  List and describe 3 aspects of your water use that are high.  

3.  Do you think water use should be a concern to citizens and policy makers in Utah?  Why or why not?  

4.  How likely are you to make changes to your water consumption habits?  Why or why not?  What would compel you to change?  

 

Feel free to make a video for this assignment rather than an essay if you'd like!

For this assignment, you will interview 3 people about their views on climate change.  Climate change is often misunderstood by the general public, so this assignment will give you a chance to examine some of these misunderstandings and think about how you can help your communities understand the science behind climate change better.  

First, choose 3 people that you will talk to regarding climate change.  These people can be family members, friends, co-workers, neighbors, or anyone else!  In your interviews, ask the people about their concern over climate change, some potential solutions, and their perceptions on how others think.  

  • Here are some example questions (you can use these if you want): 
    • How often do you read, hear about, or discuss climate change?
    • What do you think most people in the United States believe about climate change? 
    • What are the major contributing factors in contemporary climate change? 
    • What do you think are the most pressing issues related to climate change? 

Write one paragraph for each interview that summarizes their responses.  (3 paragraphs total).  

After you have interviewed and examined their responses, compare their responses to information presented in these two sites:  Climate Change Opinion Maps and Climate Change Myths.  For each of these sites, examine the information presented on the sites, and then answer these questions: 

  • How did your participants ideas about what people believe about climate change compare the climate change opinion maps project?  
    • Look at the Utah data.  How did your participants answer to what the opinion map says about how people think about climate change in Utah?  
  • The science of climate change is clear, but many myths persist amongst the general public.  Were there any common myths about what is causing climate change that your participants discussed?  For example, many people think that earth's natural cycles of heating and cooling are what we see now, or that there is no scientific consensus.  
    • How do these myths compare to the scientific explanations presented on the Skeptical Science website?  
      • On the website, you will see a list of myths and then you can click on "What the Science says" to learn more about the evidence and data behind climate science.  
    • How you could you use this Skeptical Science to help others understand the science behind anthropogenic climate change?

Hello!

It was nice to have you in my class this semester and thanks for completing the SRI for this class. I look forward to seeing your feedback. Please upload a picture of your SRI receipt here for extra credits. Let me know if you have any questions.

Although the English were credited with the first permanent settlement at Jamestown, they weren't the first to explore the New World.  Portugal, Spain, Holland and France all made a presence at one time or another in the New World.  However one of the main criticisms of these expeditions was that they failed because these countries were unable or unwilling to colonize.  Where England succeeded because they were willing to establish colonies.

Why do you think the establishment of permanent settlements would be so important to the success of a country?

Please share your opinion and respond to the post of at least one other student.  This is meant to be an open forum for discussion so please keep responses civil.

In your opinion, do you feel the Constitution of the United States was meant to be a rigid or a fluid document? Rigid in that what was written should never be modified, and is absolute. Fluid in that the spirit of the document can be maintained but the language itself could be changed to meet current needs and circumstances. 

Just a reminder this is meant to be a forum for sharing opinions and open discussion.  Please keep responses civil and no bullying.

assignment_name: Role of Fed. Govt in early road projects
description:
When America developed the automobile, the need for roads became ever more necessary.  The building of the Cumberland Road marked the beginning of the Federal Road program but at the time, opposition to federal attempts at road building was strong because many felt that participation of the Federal Govt in such projects was unconstitutional.

Take yourself back to that time period. In your opinion, why would people feel that way about Federal participation?  Please share your opinion and respond to the post of at least one other student.

Protectionism is the theory or practice of shielding a country's domestic industries from foreign competition by taxing imports and maximizing exports.  From early colonial economy through today, this sentiment has been in place on various levels, with the U.S. wanting to maintain fair balances of trade and limitation of imports that could jeopardize domestic manufacturers. 

In your opinion, does Protectionist theory have a place in a global economy?  And if so to what extent?  Please share your opinion and respond to the post of at least one other student.

During the Civil War it was determined that the fact the North was able to industrialize at a faster rate than the agricultural South gave the North a strong comparative advantage during the conflict.

In your opinion why would the ability and/or desire to industrialize help the North during this time period? What advantages would that give the North that it wouldn't give the South?

Please share your opinion and respond to the post of at least one other student

Invention is defined as the creation of something new.  Innovation is defined as finding ways to adapt new ideas & efficiencies to existing products, services etc.

In your opinion, is one more important than the other? Can we have one without the other?

Please share your opinion and reply to the post of at least one other student.

assignment_name: Impact of price controls on the economy
description:
Price controls are government mandated minimum or maximum prices set for specific goods and are specifically put in place to manage the affordability of the goods.  Price controls were often put in place during WWI and WWII to prevent wartime gouging and help conserve goods for both domestic use as well as wartime needs.  Since then price controls have been discussed as options during times of crisis (natural disasters, acts of terrorism etc.) to maintain affordability and discourage advantage taking in the market.

In your opinion, are price controls effective?  What problems could there be (if any) with periods of extended controls on the market?  Please share your opinion and respond to the post of at least one other student.

In economics The law of unintended consequences refers to how economic decisions may have effects that are unexpected.  In the 1920's the automobile became the economic symbol of the decade.  In response to the gaining popularity of the automobile and the need for roads, some unintended consequences followed as well - hotels, restaurants, roadside attractions as well as construction and the advent of the suburb.

Can you think of other items and their unintended consequences?  Please share your opinion and respond to the post of at least one other student.

Brand recognition is the extent to which a consumer can correctly identify a particular product or service just by viewing the product or service's logo, tag line, packaging or advertising campaign, or even a jingle or theme song.  Brands are often used to distinguish the quality of one product over another.

In your opinion, how important is brand recognition today?  And does the recognition of a brand always signal superior quality of the product?

Please share your opinion and respond to the post of at least one other student.

Joseph Schumpeter describes creative destruction as the "process of industrial mutation that incessantly revolutionizes the economic structure from within, incessantly destroying the old one, incessantly creating a new one." Or put another way, when introduction of new products destroys the markets for older ones.  One example would be the invention of the TV. At the time that replaced things such as radio and eating out.

Can you think of other examples of how newer products/technologies replaced older more obsolete ones?  And just for fun, let your mind wander a bit. Can you think of an existing product/technology that will be replaced in the future and if so by what? Be the inventor here, and come up with something if you'd like.  Please share your opinion and respond to the post of at least one other student.

Since the founding of America there has been debate on what role the Federal Government should play in the economy, lives of the citizens etc.  This module discussed liberal and conservative platforms. Regulation vs. Deregulation, etc.

In your opinion what should the role of the Federal Government be in the U.S. today? Big government, little government? More involved, less involved?

Please share your opinion and respond to the post of at least one other student.  I realize that this can be a charged topic but remember this is a forum for sharing opinions and discussion.  You don't have to agree with every opinion shared but be civil in your responses and do not bully anyone because of their opinions.

In the text when they talk about challenges for the future, these include discussions about improvements in medical technology, improving distribution of income, demand for a highly trained workforce and the impact of aging populations (to name a few).

In your opinion what do you see as one of the greatest challenges facing the U.S. as we head into the future? If you were a policy maker and in charge, how would you address that challenge going forward?

Please share your opinion and respond to the post of at least one other student.  

Thank you for your participation in these discussion exercises. I hope it allowed you to do some critical thinking surrounding the various issues discussed!

Term Paper:  This paper will be worth 100 points.  I really don’t want this paper to be an exercise in drudgery so I am offering you several options for topics.  The paper may be on any topic we’ve covered in class.  You may also choose from a historical economist (Adam Smith, John Keyes etc.), or you may pick a subject relating to economic principles. The purpose of this paper is to see if you can take things from the past and find some application to present day.  So let your creative mind wander.  If you happen to pick an economist, tell a little about them and their economic philosophies and then relate their philosophies to today’s economic situation.

If you happen to pick a topic covered in class or another of your choosing, the same process would apply.  Take the first part of the paper to introduce the concepts you chose, and then spend the remainder applying those principles to present day economic situations. 

The length of the paper should be about 5-6 pages of text and should include at least 3 references.  The format of the paper should follow one style of writing and citing works (ie MLA, APA, Turabian).  The paper is due July 31, 2021.  Any papers turned in after this date will receive a 10% penalty.

Information about this dataset:

On April 15, 1912, the largest passenger liner ever made collided with an iceberg during her maiden voyage. When the Titanic sank it killed 1502 out of 2224 passengers and crew. This sensational tragedy shocked the international community and led to better safety regulations for ships. One of the reasons that the shipwreck resulted in such loss of life was that there were not enough lifeboats for the passengers and crew. Although there was some element of luck involved in surviving the sinking, some groups of people were more likely to survive than others.

The data presented in this workbook are taken from the actual Titanic passengers manifest. It consists of one target (survived) and three features (ship status, age, and gender). There are 2201 instances in the dataset and no missing values within the instances.

assignment_name: Ethical Approaches to Decision Making Discussion
description:
No unread replies.3030 replies.

Read these articles from the Santa Clara University Center for Applied Ethics:

Making an Ethical Decision: https://www.scu.edu/media/ethics-center/resources/making.pdf (Links to an external site.)

A Framework for Ethical Decision Making : https://www.scu.edu/ethics/ethics-resources/ethical-decision-making/a-framework-for-ethical-decision-making/ (Links to an external site.)

  • The Utilitarian Approach
  • The Rights Approach
  • The Fairness or Justice Approach
  • The Common Good Approach
  • The Virtue Approach

Scroll down to the Approaches to Ethical Decision Making section in https://www.scu.edu/ethics/ethics-resources/ethical-decision-making/ (Links to an external site.)to learn about each particular test to that approach.

  1. Select one of the five approaches. Summarize the approach at the beginning of your discussion. Summarize it in a minimum of one complete sentence. 
  2. Provide an example (good or bad) that relates to an actual IM, IS, or IT-related ethical situation at your company or another company. Describe the situation clearly.
  3. Describe the approach that you feel the organization used to resolve the situation. Describe it clearly in a minimum of one full paragraph consisting of three to four sentences.
  4. Answer this question: Was the approach used appropriate or not.? Your answer should be a full paragraph consisting of three to four sentences.
  5. Respond to at least one other student's posting with your comments. Use a complete paragraph to describe your response.

Your discussion score is based on ability to provide appropriate examples, provide appropriate feedback on another discussion, and your written communication skills (spelling, grammar, punctuation, etc.). Proofread carefully.

Grading:

7 pts. Original posting
3 pts. Response posting

Without conducting any research or Internet searches, list ethics you believe you should follow with the following people you interact with. Copy this text  into your response and then replace the "Xs" with your ethic. Use complete sentences.

Example: Your Clients

1. I will interact with my clients in an open and honest manner.

2. I will not "overstate" or "over promise" when working on a client's project. 

Your Clients

  1. X

  2. X

Your Supervisor/Employer

  1. X

  2. X

Your Peers/Colleagues

  1. X

  2. X

End Users at Your Company

  1. X

  2. X

Other Types of People You Interact With

  1. X

  2. X

Download the Code of Ethics Relationships Assignment file. 

Use the Codes of Ethics you were asked to read in this module or a Code of Ethics from a professional organization to apply a code of ethics for each professional relationship you will encounter in your career. You will need to provide one code of ethics and the name of the professional organization (such as SANS). Then you should describe an IT/IS/IM situation that reflects your relationship to that person. Do not repeat codes or situations.  Answer the questions in the blanks below the document in the space provided below each question. Use complete sentences, correct grammar, punctuation, spelling, and writing style. Prove quality depth when answering the questions. Below is an example of a professional relationship with employers.

Relationship 1:                                             Employers

Code of Ethics related to Employer:        In recognition of my obligation to my employer I shall: Make every effort to ensure that I have the most current knowledge and that the proper expertise is available when needed.

Professional Organization for Code:       AITP Code of Ethics & Standards of Conduct

Situation Reflecting Code #1:                   Because of COVID-19, UVU sought to protect students, faculty, and staff from the virus by instituting new policies (https://www.uvu.edu/safety/coronavirus/). As a faculty member, I needed to review the policies that protect students and ensure that I use proper safety procedures. Along with knowing the procedures to protect others, however, I needed to learn new ways to make my courses effective for students as classes went online. My employer provided trainings, Teams meetings, and references so I could have current knowledge. It was my responsibility to utilize the materials provided to me.

Resume and Cover Letter Assignment

Find a job that you are interested in and feel qualified to be hired. Scan an image (or take a cell phone photo) and upload the image here of the advertisement that shows the job title, company, responsibilities, qualifications, etc.

Prepare a cover letter and resume for that particular position. Use information provided in class and on Canvas as guidelines for preparing these two documents. Submit the cover letter and resume in Microsoft Word  format (2 document files+advertisement image). The grading rubric link is included in this module.

Name your three files with this syntax, substituting your last name for Krebs:

  • Buckway_Job (image file of description, bmp, jpeg, or png)
  • Buckway_Letter (Word document)
  • Buckway_Resume (Word document)

Do not combine all three documents into one file. Do not upload PDF for the resume and cover letter.

Cover Letter:

  • block or modified block style (be consistent; don't mix)
  • Times New Roman 12 point (no smaller than 11 point)
  • formats in the Paragraph dialog box: single-spacing and 0 pt spacing between paragraphs
  • return address and date (enter 4X after)
  • inside address (enter 2X after)
  • salutation with colon (enter 2x after)
  • 1st paragraph: state position, position number (if applicable), where learned of position, interest in the position (enter 2X after)
  • Middle paragraphs: emphasize credentials and experience that relate directly to the job for which you are applying; provide example of how you are qualified for the job (enter 2X after)
  • Last paragraph: express interest in interview (enter 2X after)
  • Complimentary closing with comma (enter 4x after)
  • Name (and address if didn't put return address before the date)

Resume:

  • Times New Roman 12-pt or 11-pt font for the body; larger font size/bold for headings
  • Consistent formatting: proper spacing, indenting, bold, italic, font, font color, etc.
  • Name, address, email address, and phone number(s)
  • Education, degree, date if not completed yet, emphasis, institution, optional GPA
  • Applicable work experience, job title, organization, dates employed, bulleted list of job duties (starting with action verbs)
  • Other applicable credentials, such as certifications, languages spoken, etc.

Writing requirements for the high-stake global papers will be discussed with the students before the first paper is submitted at midterm. Each student will meet with the instructor to select the student’s country and review the Network Readiness Index for that country.  This will be done via email for this online class.  The student will also view the lecture covering writing requirements for the global papers and study the Canvas links provided to help the student’s writing skills. Please see Week 6 video instructions.

The country must be listed in the NRI-2023 PDF found in the Week 6 module. The country index will also be listed there. 

Each of you will need to choose a unique country due this week.  Please submit your top 5 country choices to the assignment.  This will be done first come first serve as explained in the assignment video instructions. I will reply in the assignment comments in Canvas approving one of the countries you requested.

Refer to the course schedule for the due dates of the rough draft and the final draft.  You may start these assignments at any time.

Please find additional paper details in Week 7, Global Paper 1: Draft Instructions (rough draft), and Week 10, Global Paper 1: Culture and Education (final draft), respectively.

I encourage you to contact me with any questions along the way.

After creating a rough draft, the student again meets with the faculty member (via email). During the second meeting, the instructor reviews the student’s writing as well as the student’s application of course content.  Please submit your draft to the assignment submission area.  I will review it and make comments.  You then can reply with any other questions you might have.  There is no limit to how many times you can submit your file. You can also request a Teams meeting if this would be helpful for you.  I want to make sure you understand the mechanics of the paper so you will be prepared for the final Global Paper submission. This draft is worth 10% of the paper's score.  It will be added on the paper score sheet.

You will then complete the final draft and submit it.  Please see Week 6 or Week 10 for paper details. See Week 10 for details regarding the final draft.

This research paper focuses on a particular country assigned by your professor. This assignment should describe the culture of the particular country and the quality of education. Pay close attention to the Grading section at the end of this assignment as well as the grading point sheet.

Open this file _G1 Culture and Education Template_2022.docx

and save it in this syntax, Buckway_Global1, substituting your last name for Buckway. Click the Review tab and change Simple Markup to All Markup to see the comments on the last page. Replace the placeholder running head, headings, and paragraphs with your research.

Grading:

This is the file the professor will use to grade your paper on content and other factors. Use it as a guide and checklist as you prepare and finalize your paper.  Your final submission must be submitted in MS Word format.

_G1 Grading Point Sheet 2022.xlsx

Download _G1 Grading Point Sheet 2019.xlsx

Sources:

Conduct research to obtain information on cultural issues (specified in the template) for the country that is assigned to you. You should have at least five (5) sources, including the NRI 2022 and 2023 reports.

Use reliable sources. Do not use blogs, discussion boards, Wikipedia, or travel web sites as citations. Those sites may give you ideas for furthering your research, but they are not appropriate for citations in an academic paper.

Content (Information, Evidence, Citations):

Describe the primary cultural aspects that would be important to know for an organization considering opening an IT business in that country. In particular, you will address language, holidays observed and other events impacting work (such as weekend work, holy days, start/end times, etc.), and business etiquette/work-related behavior. For example, this web site provides good information on business etiquette and protocol: http://www.commisceo-global.com/country-guides/canada-guide (Links to an external site.).

The education section addresses two indicators (quality of education and R&D by Government and Higher Education) of the Network Readiness Index, using the 2022 and 2023 reports. Include the ranking and score for each indicator. Compare the scores and rankings between the two reports to see if the quality of education and higher education rates improved, decreased, or stayed the same. In addition, describe the types and quality of higher education computing programs, such as IT.

Edit the main title (first-level heading) to include the name of the country you are researching and edit the running head in all capital letters to match the main heading.

Include a short introductory paragraph (about three sentences) after the (main) first-level heading. The second-level headings are included in the template for you. Provide specific evidence to substantiate your discussion. Include statistics and measurable data from reliable sources.  Include internal citations in APA format (7th edition).

The content should be about four pages double-spaced.

Reference Page:

Sample references are included on the Reference page. Read the comments and apply the rules when entering your sources in APA format (7th edition). Use hanging indents, arrange the sources in alphabetical order by authors' last names, and double-space the sources. Delete the comments and sample sources.

Refer to the two videos in Canvas regarding the references. Refer to OWL for APA requirements. However, for the purposes of this paper, the formatting for web site references is slightly different. Treat the web page title as an article name, not a journal title. If an author is not available, include an editor's name. If that is not available, use the organization's name as the author when applicable.

Writing Style:

The writing style should be formal and objective. It should not sound like a casual conversation. Do not use first-person pronouns (I or we) or second-person pronouns (you).

Formatting:

  • Times New Roman 12 point font
  • Double-spaced with 0 pt spacing after paragraphs
  • First line of each paragraph indented
  • Left alignment
  • Running head per APA style for the body of the report (includes title and page number)
  • First-level heading and second-level headings formatted in APA style for headings
  • Internal citations according to APA style (7th edition)

Refer to the Purdue Online Writing Lab (OWL) for APA formatting guidelines: https://owl.purdue.edu/owl/research_and_citation/apa_style/apa_formatting_and_style_guide/general_format.html.  Pay close attention to line and paragraph spacing, running heads, first- and second-level headings, font size, etc.

assignment_name: Global Paper 2 (Final): Individual Usage and Social Impacts
description:
This second research paper focuses on a particular country assigned by your professor. This assignment addresses the sixth and tenth pillars of the NRI for that country.

Open this file _G2 Usage and Impact Template_2022.docx

and save it in this syntax, LastName_Global2, substituting your last name. Click the Review tab and change Simple Markup to All Markup to see the comments on the last page. Replace the placeholder running head, headings, and paragraphs with your research. Keep the page breaks intact between sections.

Grading:

Here is a detailed grading sheet. I use the Content section to assign points to the content. That number is divided by 100 to enter into the main weighted average worksheet. See the sample scores in the worksheet. The Other Details worksheet lists general things I look for when grading grammar, writing style, formatting, citations, and the reference page. This worksheet is similar to the one I provided for Global Paper 1.  Your final submission must be submitted in MS Word format.

_G2 Detailed Grading Point Sheet 2022.xlsx.Download _G2 Detailed Grading Point Sheet (2019).xlsx

Sources:

Conduct research to obtain information on indicators for the country assigned to you. You should have at least five (5) sources. National Readiness Index Reports PDFs count as two sources.

Use additional reliable sources. Do not use blogs, discussion boards, Wikipedia, or travel websites as citations. Those sites may stimulate ideas for furthering your research, but they are inappropriate for academic paper citations.

Content (Information, Evidence, Citations):

Using data from the National Readiness Index Reports, research these indicators:

  • 2.1.1 Individuals Using Internet
  • 1.1.3 Households with Internet Access
  • 2.1.3 Use of Virtual Social Networks
  • 1.1.7 Internet in Schools

For each indicator, include the following:

  • Indicator definition and scaling (see appendix ii of NRI for years reported, definitions, etc.)
  • Annual score, percentage, etc. 
  • Annual ranking 
  • Additional paragraph with related supplemental information from external sources.

Edit the main title (first-level heading) to include the name of the country you are researching, and edit the running head in all capital letters to match the main heading.

Include a short introductory paragraph (about 3-4 sentences) after the (main) first-level heading. The second-level headings are included in the template for you. Provide specific evidence to substantiate your discussion. Include statistics and measurable data from reliable sources.  Include internal citations in APA format.

The content should be at least four full or five pages double-spaced, including the conclusions and recommendations.

Conclusions and Recommendations:

Draw objective conclusions for each indicator based on the evidence provided by the NRI books and external sources. Do not simply summarize the data or repeat it. Conclusions provide analytical meaning to the evidence you previously presented. When writing conclusions, ask yourself:

  • What is the meaning of the data?
  • What trends can be identified?
  • What is the “bottom line” of the evidence?

Based on the conclusions, what recommendations do you have for the government? Recommendations are action items for the reader (the government, in this case) to address. Look for ways to improve the issues addressed by the indicators.

The recommendations should flow naturally from the conclusions. Each conclusion must be addressed with a respective recommendation.

Do not include statistics, quotations, references, or citations in the conclusions and recommendations sections. All evidence should be presented before the conclusions.

Reference Page:

Sample references are included on the Reference page. Read the comments and apply the rules when entering your sources in APA format(7th edition). Use hanging indents, arrange the sources alphabetically by authors' last names, and double-space the sources. Delete the comments and sample sources.

Refer to OWL for APA requirements. Refer to the two videos in Canvas regarding the references. The article name of a web page is treated as an article title, not a journal-title. If an author is not available, include an editor's name. If that is unavailable, use the organization's name as the author when applicable.

Writing Style:

The writing style should be formal and objective. It should not sound like a casual conversation. Do not use first-person pronouns (I or we) or second-person pronouns (you).

Formatting:

  • Times New Roman 12-point font
  • Double-spaced with 0 pt spacing after paragraphs
  • The first line of each paragraph indented
  • Left alignment
  • Running head per APA style for the body of the report (includes title and page number)
  • First-level headings and second-level headings formatted in APA style for headings
  • Internal citations according to APA style

Refer to the Purdue Online Writing Lab (OWL) for APA formatting guidelines: https://owl.purdue.edu/owl/research_and_citation/apa_style/apa_formatting_and_style_guide/general_format.html. Pay close attention to line and paragraph spacing, running heads, first- and second-level headings, font size, etc.

Write a short bio to introduce yourself to the class in one paragraph and respond to two other students' posts. You might respond to some of the following: Why are you taking this class? What are your career goals? What is one unique thing about you?

Tech in Fast Food

Fast Food is using data and IT to increase efficiency and effectiveness. Discuss how Panera Bread and McDonalds are using data and IT. What impresses you? What do you not like? How could other orgs use this? (1 post and 2 responses)

QUESTIONS To Think About (you don't have to answer all of them, just a starting point to help create a post): 
1. What were the process problems that Panera was trying to solve?
2. What were the various new elements of the "Panera 2.0" prototype store in Braintree, Mass.?
3. Online ordering eased the ordering bottleneck, but what other problems resulted that then also needed to be corrected?
4. Why did it take so long, 6 years?
5. How are Starbucks and McDonald's dealing with mobile ordering and delivery?

Some questions to think about as part of the discussion: (Remember that you do not have to answer all of these questions, just some that interest you.)
1. Why is software important to automobiles?

VW article questions: Based on the article, what seems to be the competitive advantage of Tesla? Which aspect of Tesla is hard for VW and other auto incumbents to match? “Over the past 20 years the auto industry became more integrators than developers,” said one quoted manager. What light does this quote shed on the competitive disadvantage of VW? What mistakes did VW make and how is VW attempting to learn from its mistakes? In retrospect, was Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess right in trying to compete head-on with Tesla? The aforementioned quoted manager says: “Software is written by suppliers. This was good for a while because it drives down costs but you lose control. That’s what the auto industry has to reverse now, bring in deep technical knowledge. That’s the hard part.” Does this quote summarize the basic dilemma that VW is facing? Or would you summarize the VW dilemma differently? 

Waymo questions: What is Waymo? Would you like a self-driving car? Why? Would you apply for the early rider program if offered in Utah county? https://waymo.com/apply/ (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.  Given Waymo's ultimate goals, what specific data would you like to capture about each test-driving experience? https://medium.com/waymo/apply-to-be-part-of-waymos-early-rider-program-5fd996c7a86f (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.    https://www.forbes.com/sites/samabuelsamid/2017/04/25/waymo-launches-early-rider-program-expands-self-driving-fleet-with-fiat-chrysler/#620134d3d1af (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site. Who are Waymo's competitors, and what are they up to? Problems with self driving cars: http://discovermagazine.com/2018/nov/baby-can-you-drive-my-car  Why is Waymo testing its driverless car flett in Chandler Arizona rather than Chicago Illinois? States and federal regulators are still trying to determine how to best oversee the technology to ensure safety while also encouraging its development. What are some guidelines to achieve these conflicting goals (safety vs development). Also, how much should governments be willing to trust autonomous car manufacturers?

assignment_name: 5. Discussion:  Social Media Censorship and International Governments
description:
Read the 2 short articles below and create 1 post and 2 comments (remember you don't need to answer every question, the questions are meant to give you some content to post about)

Article 1: 2021 India Facebook.pdf 

  • How is the national environment of India changing for Google, Facebook and Twitter? Why is it harder for them to do business there? Why are foreign Internet companies no longer as welcome in India as they once were?
  • WhatsApp seems to be of special interest to the Indian authorities. Why is that? Why is WhatsApp such a sensitive app?
  • What specifically are these Internet companies being asked to do? How reasonable are the government requests? What are the threatened sanctions for failing to abide?
  • What are the basic options that a company like Facebook now has in India? Of these options, which one do you think would be best?

Similar article on China: Twitter_and_Facebook_China_2019.pdf 

Article 2: Pinterest Blocks Vaccination Searches - WSJFeb20192.pdf

Do a Google search for "Non-traditional cures for cancer." As you review each result, what might be happening-or not happening-in the Google search algorithm to cause the result to be prioritized in the way they are.

Some questions to think about:

1. What change did Pinterest make to its platform?

2. What are other examples of steps that social media or search engine platforms are taking to reduce misinformation?

3. How do you feel about social media or search engine companies deciding to stop returning search results for specific subjects? What problems might result from this practice?

4. Why might Pinterest be interested in taking strong steps to reduce misinformation on its site at this particularly time?

Read the 2 short articles below and create 1 post and 2 comments

This week read and discuss the following articles:

Inside Google’s Team Fighting to Keep Your Data Safe From Hacke.pdf

If "tech giants' access to data and their huge user networks mean they are in some ways more effective in fighting intrusions than governments," what should be the proper balance in the U.S. between the government and private companies when it comes to protecting data and fighting bad actors in the digital world?

rsa-data-privacy-and-security-survey-2019.pdf

What affect do age and culture have on privacy and security expectations?

Read and post your thoughts on the following articles (remember 1 post and 2 responses required)

Some questions to think about: Big Tech has grown even more this past year. Is the power of Big Tech good or bad? Should the Big Tech companies be broken apart? Will the economic and societal forces propelling Big Tech to even higher heights outlast Covid-19? Why or why not? Who are the big losers of the pandemic? Who are the big winners of the pandemic? Judging by the articles, the US economy now seems less competitive. What evidence is there of this development? What does this say about the stock market rise?

2021 How Big Tech Got Even Bigger.docx

2020 Taking a chance with big tech monopolies.docx 

2020BigTechUniqueMonopolies.docx

Guest Speaker  

*Your group will invite a guest speaker to come on campus and present to the class.  You will need to make whatever arrangements she/he needs to be to class on time.  They have 25 minutes to present and 5 minutes for questions at the end of the presentation.

If we go to live streaming because of COVID during any time through out the semester:

COVID 19 Assignment update-----------------------

You will need to record the interview and post it to the discussion board for others to watch and comment on. The rest of the class will watch the interview and post responses in the discussion. I will create the discussion threads for each speaker.  ---------------------------

Speakers must be currently working in an IS, IT, or closely related field.

Presentation topics to  be discussed by the speaker (make sure you let the guest speaker know):
A. Share current employment responsibilities, educational background, certifications, and any other job experiences.
B. Tell a few war stories (tough situations)
C. Lessons learned in career path to date
D. Any recommendations you would offer to the students that would help them to be successful in their careers.
E. Time for Questions at the end of the presentation (Difficult during COVID, but if they left some kind of contact so that they could answer questions on email would be great!)

Group Outputs:

1. Group Summary Paper (instructions in Group Paper Assignment)

2. Personal Team Evaluation (instructions in Team Evaluation Assignment)

3. Thank you note or email to speaker (cc me or send copy to me)

Instructions for individual speaker responses for all students:

1.  Open Canvas and create a posting under the Guest Speaker Discussion for that speaker

2.  Take notes, write down your reactions to what is being said

3.  Once presentation is over, feel free to ask any questions (Is your company hiring, beginning salaries, does your company facilitate job shadowing, is there part time employment at your company, what skills are required to start at the bottom in your company, etc.)

4.  Post your comments - at least 3 things you learned or that you will use in the future.

Note:  Guest speakers often come with part-time and full-time job opportunities.  If you are interested in working for the company that the guest speaker is from, I strongly suggest that you take the time to get his/her contact information and ask at least one question.  Guest Speakers provide many opportunities for employment now or in the future.  Networking is very important.

*-----Pre-COVID Instructions: Invite, schedule, and make any other arrangements for a guest speaker to come and speak for 25 minutes and then answer questions for 5 minutes at the end. Example: Make parking arrangements, check to see what they need for their presentation, be prepared to introduce your guest speaker to the class.  When your guest speaker comes, all group members should be present to get credit for the assignment.  If you can not be there, I need to know why and have written documentation to support your good reason.  Medical, death in the family, or other extenuating circumstances or examples for not being there! Write a thank you note or email for the guest speaker and cc me or make a copy for me.-----

If you did the guest speaker assignment individually, instead of with a group, then write the summary paper individually and submit.

Output: link for group paper in Google Docs submitted here

Group Report: Summarize what you learned from the presenter and create a group report in short report format (Introduction, Findings, Discussion, Summary, References) in APA Style...don't forget the title page.  The document should be written as a group in Google Docs, share the link with me after it is written. I will be looking to see if all group members contributed. 

Group Report Example Format:

Title

Introduction  

restate the assignment

 

Findings

see presenter topics above and any bullets that you learned from his/her presentation

Discussion

discuss one or two of the findings that interested you

Summary

summarize what was important in your discussion

Reference

Individual citing...make sure to get all the information you need for this citing in APA style

Note: If you did the guest speaker assignment individually, instead of as a group, just write that and  assess yourself.

Team Evaluation: Individually create a document listing each group # and each group member's first and last name. Rate each student's contributions on a scale of 1 (did very little) to 10 (did more than their share) what each group member contributed to this assignment then list their contributions (be specific).  Please share any other comments that might help me assign the appropriate points for each group member.

This is an individual assignment not a group assignment.
Send your speaker a Thank You card or thank you email. Make a copy of the card and upload here or copy and paste the email in a Word doc and upload here. You will be graded on content and style.

description:
You may write a 1000 - 2000 (2-4 pages single spaced, 4-8 pages double spaced) word response paper targeted to what you will take away (implement in your life) based on the guest speakers presentations advice and everything you learned in this class. You will be graded 70% on content and 30% on style. Use APA style and short report format. Strongly suggest you use the template that we discussed in class!  Please be sure to use heading levels and citations from the guest speakers as well as possible external sources that might build upon what the guest speakers said. Remember that you already took some nice notes on each speaker in the discussions that you will find useful. I expect to see at least 5 citations from guest speakers and a reference for each guest speaker that you listed a bullet point in the Findings of your paper.

Some questions (among many) you might think about are:

What makes a person successful in their career? What should I do to be successful in a career in IT/IS etc?

What soft skills are important in an IS/IT career? How will I learn the soft skills I need?

What kind of career do I want? What is my passion?

How will I implement a work/life balance in my career?

What technical skills do I need/want in my career? How will I get the technical skills I need?

How will I continue to learn outside of school and after graduation?

What was the two best "golden nuggets" of advice you took away from listening to the guest speakers this semester? How will I use them in my career/life?
I will give a few bonus points if you fill out the SRI by Sunday April 2 and take a photo of your receipt (not the actual SRI) to prove you did it a submit here. Have a great summer!

The exams will be administered through Canvas using the built-in plugin, Proctorio. This software requires the Chrome browser, a web cam, and a mic. You will take these exams at home and you will be required to follow these rules:

  1. You must show the desktop, room, surroundings before the exam begins.
  2. You must be fully clothed.
  3. No other individuals can be in the room with you.
  4. You may not have help from others or use any resources (including notes, the book, calculators, etc.) on the exams.

 

There are no make-up exams unless you have an approved excuse prior to the due date.

MO1: Participation

For this assignment, you will be signing into your LinkedIn Learning account you created in the Course Information Module. If you have not completed this step, please do so now before moving on.

Git is a common tool used in software development. Specifically, it is a distributed version control system that can keep track of files, roll back changes, and record the editing history of a project. The primary purpose of this assignment is to familiarize you with Git and to show how Git can be used to manage source code.

This participation should take about an hour and a half to complete. Walkthrough videos are available at the bottom of this page.

Complete Training

To learn how to work with git and GitHub, watch the following training and complete the quizzes throughout the course if you haven't already:

https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learning-git-and-github  (Links to an external site.)

Note: You do NOT have to set up the website as shown in the videos (npm install, adding images, etc.)

After you are done, take a screenshot of the learning certificate awarded to you. You can download the certificate by clicking the download prompt shown to you after completing the course or by clicking the "Show All" link next to the "Certificates" file in the overview tab. You can keep this certificate for your own records and even add it to your LinkedIn profile!

Complete Tasks

After you have completed the LinkedIn Learning course, complete the following tasks:

Part 1

  1. Create a folder on your computer named "InitRepo"
  2. Add a text file to the folder named "InitFile.txt". Open the text file with your preferred text editor and add your first and last name to the file. Save and close the file after you are done.
  3. Open up Git and issue the "git init" command within the folder to turn it into a git repository
  4. Add the InitFile to the staging area with "git add ." and commit your changes with the "git commit -m" command. For the commit message, use the message "Initial commit".
  5. Run the command "git status" to check the status of your repo. This is useful to see if you need to commit or remove anything from the staging area.
  6. Open the "InitFile" again and add another line of text to it. It can be something like "Here's the second change" or "I love cats". Then save and close the file.
  7. Add the changes to the staging area with "git add ." and then commit them with "git commit -m". For the commit message, use something like "Second commit" or "Adds extra text to the file".
  8. Run the command "git log" to verify the commit
  9. Repeat steps 5-8 until you have at least 5 commits. This is to familiarize you with the general process of saving changes to a git repository.
  10. After you are done, execute the command "git log" to see your commit history
  11. Take a screenshot of the log and save it

Video Walkthrough

Part 2

  1. Make sure you are still in the "InitRepo" folder in Git
  2. Add a new branch named "changes" to the repo using the command "git branch changes"
  3. Switch to the branch you just created by issuing the command "git checkout changes"
  4. Add a new text file to the folder named "changes.txt"
  5. Add some text to the newly created file like "Look at me!" or something, then save the file
  6. Issue the "git status" command to view the status of the Git repo. You should see your recent change show up.
  7. Add and commit the change using "git add ." and "git commit -m". For the commit message, use something like "Adds the changes.txt file".
  8. Use the command "git checkout master" to return to the master branch
  9. Check the file explorer or type "ls" in the command line to view the contents of the master branch. Where did the "changes.txt" file go?
  10. Run the command "git merge changes". This will merge the contents of the master branch and the changes branch together.
  11. Now check the file explorer or type "ls" in the command line. Two files should now be present.
  12. Type the command "git log" to view the combined commits of the two branches. Take a screenshot of the combined log and save it.

Video Walkthrough

Submit

  • Screenshot of the learning certificate
  • Screenshot of the Git log from the InitRepo repository
  • Screenshot of the combined Git log from the InitRepo repository

 

5 Extra Credit Points

Connect your local repository to your GitHub online account

Add me as a collaborator: (My user name is "kodkal")

HINT: https://docs.github.com/en/github/importing-your-projects-to-github/importing-source-code-to-github/adding-an-existing-project-to-github-using-the-command-line

https://docs.github.com/en/github/authenticating-to-github/connecting-to-github-with-ssh/about-ssh

Permission Error?
https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/error-permission-denied-publickey

MO2: Participation

Before you do any of the exercises in this book, you need to install Python. In addition, you need to install the source code for this book.

 

Part 1 (Exercise 1-1) Experiment with IDLE's interactive shell

Complete the following steps using Exercise 1-1 in the textbook.

Step 1

  • Start IDLE. That should display a window for the interactive shell

  

 

Step 2

  • Enter the following functions and arithmetic expressions into the interactive console (replace FirstName and LastName with your first and last name):
    • print("FirstName Lastname") # Print my first and last name
    • print() # Print a blank line
    • 40 + 5 # Add 40 plus 5
    • 25 - 7 # Subtract 7 from 25
    • 7 * 3 # Multiply 7 and 3
    • 10 / 5 # Divide 10 by 5
    • 2 * 10 + 5 # Multiply 2 and 10, then add 5
    • 2 * (10 + 5) # Add 10 and 5, then multiply 2

Step 3

  • Take a Screenshot of your IDLE screen and put it in a word document

Step 4

  • Save your Word document as LastnameFirstnameParticipationMO2 (replace Lastname & Firstname with your name)

Step 5

  • Close your IDLE window and start a new IDLE shell and enter the following
    • print("FirstName Lastname") # Print my first and last name (replace FirstName $ LastName with your name)
    • # Create two variables
    • var1 = 25
    • var2 = 18
    • var1 + 14 # Add 14 to the first variable
    • var1 # Display value of first variable
    • var1 + var2 # Add both variables together
    • var_2 # Display unknown variable

Notice that you will get an error on the last input as var_2 has not been given a value.

Step 6

  • Take a Screenshot of the IDLE shell and paste it below your last screenshot in your word document.

 

Part 2 - Using IDLE to run a Python Program

Step 7

  • Download file: future_value.py  
  • Open the file in a text editor of your choice (notepadd++ and Visual Studio Code are a great choice).
  • Add these lines of code on the first line
    • print("FirstName Lastname") # Print my first and last name
    • print() # Print a blank line
  • Save the file and close the file

Step 8

  • Start IDLE and open the future_value.py file (Screenshots below show the process)

  

 

  

 

  

 

  

 

  

 

  

Step 9

  • Enter the following in the prompts
    • Monthly investment: 200
    • Yearly interest rate: .09
    • Number of years: 10
    • Continue? (y/n): n

(Hint: your future value should calculate as $24,109.22)

Step 10

  • Take a screenshot of the values entered into the IDLE shell with the results showing. Next, place that screenshot in the word document just under the Part 1 section.

 

Walkthrough Video

MO3: Participation

Before you do any of the exercises in this book, you need to install Python. In addition, you need to install the source code for this book.

In this participation, you will learn how to

  • test and modify existing code
  • gather input from the user
  • do basic math calculations

Hint: If you have any problems with you test your changes, please refer to figure 1-9 of chapter 1, which shows how to fix syntax and runtime errors.

Part 1 - (2-1) Modify the Miles Per Gallon Program

Complete the following steps using Exercise 2-1 in the textbook.

Step 1

  • Start the IDLE shell and open the following file: mpg.py  
  • Press F5 to compile and run the program. Then, enter valid values for miles driven and gallons used. This should display the miles per gallon
  • Test the program with invalid entries like spaces or letters. This should cause the program to crash and display error messages for the exceptions that occur

Step 2

  • Use the print function to add text on the second line of code just after the shebang line that displays your first and last name along with the text MPG App. Make sure to add pseudocode to the right. 
    • e.g., Kodey Crandall's MPG App

Step 3

  • Modify this program so the result is rounded to just one decimal place, then test this change.
  • Modify this program so the argument of the round() function is the arithmetic expression, then test this change.
  • Modify this program so it retrieves the cost of a gallon of gas as an entry from the user. Then, calculate the total gas cost and the cost per mile, and display the results on the console as shown in the example below:
Enter miles driven: 150
Enter gallons of gas used: 15
Enter cost per gallon: 3

Miles Per Gallon: 10.0
Total Gas Cost: 45.0
Cost Per Mile: 0.3
  • Take a Screenshot of the results in the IDLE Shell and paste it into a word document named: [LastName][FirstName]ParticipationM03.docx
  • Add pseudocode for EVERY line of source code
  • Save the file with a new name [LastName]_[FirstName]_MO3P1

Part 2 - (2-2) Modify the Test Scores Program

Part 2 will have you modify the Test Scores program in figure 2-16 of the textbook. When you're finished, the program will display the three scores entered by the user in a single line.

Step 4

  • Start the IDLE shell and open this file: test_scores.py  
  • Save this file with a new name (File->Save As): [LastName]_[FIrstName]_MO3P2
  • Press F5 to compile and run the program. Then, enter valid values for the three scores. This should display the results.

Step 5   

  • Use the print function to add text on the second line of code that displays your first and last name along with the text Test Scores App. Make sure to add pseudocode to the right. 
    • e.g., Kodey Crandall's Test Scores App

Step 6

  • Modify this program so it saves the three scores that are entered in variables named score1, score2, and score3.
  • Add these scores to the total_score variable, instead of adding the entries to the total_score variable without ever saving them.
  • Add a print function to display all individual scores just before the total score print function.
  • Add pseudocode for EVERY line of source code.

Step 7

  • Display the scores that have been entered before the other results, as shown below
Enter 3 test scores
=======================
Enter test score: 75
Enter test score: 85
Enter test score: 95
=======================
Your Scores: 75 85 95
Total Score: 255
Average Score: 85
  • Take a Screenshot of the results in the IDLE Shell and paste it into the same word document created in Part 1
  • Save the file.

Part 3 - Create a simple program

Copying and modifying an existing program is often a good way to start a new program. So in this, you'll copy and modify the MPG program so it gets the length and width of a rectangle from the user, calculates the area and the perimeter of the rectangle, and displays the results in the console

Step 8

  • Start the IDLE shell and open this file: mpg_model.py  
  • Save this file with a new name (File->Save As): [LastName]_[FIrstName]_MO3P3
  • Use the print function to add text on the second line of code that displays your first and last name along with the text Test Scores App. Make sure to add pseudocode to the right.
    • e.g., Kodey Crandall's Rectangle App
  • Modify the code for this program so it works for the new program. 
    • The area of a rectangle is length times width
    • Perimeter is 2 times length plus 2 times width
  • Add pseudocode for EVERY line of source code
  • Save the file

The output should look something like this

The area and perimeter program

Please enter the length: 25
Please enter the width: 10

Area = 250
Perimeter = 70

Thanks for using this program!
  • Take a Screenshot of the results in the IDLE Shell and paste it into the same word document created in Part 1

Submission:

  • Word document with all three screenshots
  • ALL THREE .py FILES in a SINGLE submission

MO4: Participation

Before you do any of the exercises in this book, you need to install Python. In addition, you need to install the source code for this book.

In this module, you have learned how to use the control statements that drive the logic of a program. You will now put your learning to test by creating a few simple applications using these key concepts:

  • Control statements
  • Relational operators
  • conditional expressions
  • if statements and elif clauses
  • while and for loops

Part 1 Enhance the Miles Per Gallon program

Complete the following steps using Exercise 3-1 in the textbook. Part 1 will enhance the Miles Per Gallon program shown in Figure 3-8 of the textbook.

Step 1

  • Download this file: mpg-1.py  
  • Open the IDLE shell and test the application with valid and invalid entries
  • Rename the file using the File>Save As... with the name [Firstname]_[Lastname]MO4ParticipationP1.py

Step 2

  • First start by modifying the first print() by replacing the word "The" with your first and last name so it prints something like this: Kodey Crandall's Miles Per Gallon application"
  • We will now enhance the application by allowing the user to enter more than one entry
  • Create a variable named another_trip and assign it the value of "y" just before the miles_driven pseudo code

  

Step 3

  • Just after your new variable, create a while loop that will continue while another_trip is equal to "y"
    • HINT: while another_trip == "y":
  • Tab to the right each line below the while statement except for the last line: print("Bye")
  • Create a cost_per_gallon variable that receives the user input for the cost per gallon with the text: Enter cost per gallon: [User Input]

Step 4

  • Add and elif after the gallons_used and before the else with the following condition
    • elif cost_per_gallon <= 0
  • Add a print() that shows the text: Cost per gallon must be greater than zero. Please try again.
    • This will show only if the statement is true
  • Calculate the total gas cost and put it in a variable named "total_gas_cost" (gallons of gas used * cost per gallon)
    • Display the total gas cost below the MPG print method.
  • Calculate the cost per mile and put it in a variable named "cost_per_mile" (total gas cost / miles driven)
    • Display the cost per mile under the total gas cost

Step 5

  • Just after the last else statement, receive the user's input using the text: Get entries for another trip (y/n)?
    • Store it in the another_trip variable created earlier
  • Add a line of pseudocode for EACH line of source code

Step 6

  • Save the file
  • Open the IDLE shell, run, and test the application with the following inputs:

Part 2 - Enhance the Future Value program

Part 2 of this participation will enhance the Future Value program.

Step 7

  • Download this file: future_value-1.py  
  • Open the IDLE shell and test the application with valid and invalid entries
    • Notice that this program does not have any validation, so you will get an error with invalid entries
  • Rename the file using the File>Save As... with the name [Firstname]_[Lastname]MO4ParticipationP2.py
  • First start by modifying the first print() by replacing the word "The" with your first and last name so it prints something like this: Welcome to Kodey Crandall's Future Value Calculator

Step 8    

  • Create a variable named is_valid just inside the while loop (before the monthly_investment statement) and set the value to False
  • Create another while loop that loops while the is_valid variable is False and put it on the next line of code (before the monthly_investment statement)
  • Tab to the right the monthly_investment = .... statement so it executes in the while loop
  • Create an if-else statement to validate the monthly_investment with the following conditions
    • the monthly_investment must be greater than 0
    • AND the monthly_investment must be less than OR equal to 1000
  • If the results are true, set is_valid = True
  • else print the following message: Entry must be greater than 0 and less than 1000. Please try again.
  • JUST OUTSIDE the while loop (Tabbed back to the left) set is_valid = False

Step 9

  • Create another while loop just before yearly_interest_rate = ... that loops while is_valid = False
  • Tab to the right the yearly_interest_rate = ... statement
  • Create an if-else statement to validate the yearly_interest_rate with the following conditions
    • the yearly_interest_rate must be greater than 0
    • AND the yearly_interest_rate must be less than OR equal to 15
  • If the results are true, set is_valid = True
  • else print the following message: Entry must be greater than 0 and less than 15. Please try again.
  • JUST OUTSIDE the while loop (Tabbed back to the left) set is_valid = False

Step 10

  • Repeat Step 9 but adapt it for the year = ... statement
  • The conditions for the year
    • Year must be greater than 0
    • AND the year must be less than or equal to 50

Step 11

  • Save the file
  • Open the IDLE shell and test the application with the following inputs

  • Add a line of pseudocode for EACH line of source code
  • Review and understand the code with the '%' and the '//' (These two operators WILL be used on the project)
if i % 12 == 0:
            print("Year = ", i // 12, "\tFuture Value = ", round(future_value, 2))

Submission:

MO5: Participation

Before you do any of the exercises in this book, you need to install Python. In addition, you need to install the source code for this book: Python Book Files 

 

Part 1 (Exercise 4-1) 

Complete the following steps using Exercise 4-1 in the textbook. This exercise will enhance the Future Value program in figure 3-17 of the textbook. It will validate the three user entries with messages if the user's input is incorrect.

Step 1

  • Start the IDLE shell and open the following file: future_value-2.py  do
  • Press F5 to compile, run, and test the program. Notice that it does not do any validation.

Step 2

  • To help you prepare the validation for this application, you will need to create a hierarchy chart or outline that includes a get_float() and a get_int(). The get_float() will test the user's input to see if the input is a value is a float and is between two values. The get_int() will check if the user's input is an integer and is between two values.
  • To create the hierarchy chart, open Word and create shapes using the insert shapes option:

  

 

  • First, create a "Main" square at the top. The main method is the parent to the get_float() and get_int() methods.
    • Remember the guidelines for creating hierarchy charts •
      • The names in a chart should start with a verb and give a good indication of what the function does. Then, the names can easily be converted to Python function names.
      • Each function should do everything that is related to the function name and nothing more.
  • Create two squares under the "Main" square that are side-by-side. One with the text "Get Float" and the other "Get Integer"
  • Connect the "Main" to the squares below with a line
  • Create two more squares, one under the "Get Float" and one under the "Get Integer"
  • For the square under the "Get Float" add the text "Display Valid Float" 
  • For the square under the "Get Integer" add the text "Display Valid Integer"
  • Connect the squares with a line
  • Save the Word document with the name [FirstName][LastName]MO5ParticipationP1

Step 3

  • Open your favorite text editor (notepad++, Visual Studio Code, etc.)
  • Create a new Python file with the name validate.py
  • On the first line, add a line of pseudocode: # [FirstName] [LastName] validation file for the Future Value App
  • Save it in the same directory as your future_value-2.py file

Step 4

  • Define a new method named get_float with three parameters: prompt, low, high
    • HINT: def get_float(prompt, low, high):
  • Create an infinite while loop that continues while true
    • HINT: while True:
  • Create a variable with the name "number" and assign it the value of a float from the user's input
    • HINT: number = float(input(prompt))
  • Check to see if the number is between the low and high values. If it is return the number, if not print an invalid entry message
    • HINT:
        if number > low and number <= high:
            return number
        else:
            print("Entry must be greater than", low,
                  "and less than or equal to", high)

Step 5

  • Repeat step 4 but for the get_int()

Step 6

  • Next, define a main method
  • Create a variable named "choice" and assign it a value of "y"
  • Create a while loop that goes until choice.lower() == "y"
    • HINT:     while choice.lower() == "y":
  • Create a variable named valid_number and assign it the value of the get_float()
    • HINT:         valid_number = get_float("Enter number: ", 0, 1000)
  • Print the valid number
    • HINT:         print("Valid number = ", valid_number)
  • Use the Print() to add space
  • Create a variable named valid_integer and assign it the value of the get_int()
    • HINT:         valid_integer = get_int("Enter integer: ", 0, 50)      
  • Print the valid integer
    • HINT:         print("Valid integer = ", valid_integer)
  • Use the Print() to add space
  • Set choice equal to the user's input
    • HINT:         choice = input("Repeat? (y/n): ")
  • If the user doesn't type a "y" or "Y", print the text "Bye!"
  • at the bottom of the file add the code 
if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
  • Save the file and close it

 

Step 7

  • Lastly, we need to import the validation file in the future_value-2.py
  • To do this, open the future_value-2.py in your favorite text editor
  • Import the validation by adding the following code on the first line of code
import validation as v
  • Print this text on the next line under the import code
    • [LastName]'s Validated Future Value App
  • Now, replace the float and int function calls with the get_float() and get_int() functions from the imported module
monthly_investment = v.get_float("Enter monthly investment:\t",1,1000)
  • Be sure to provide the proper arguments for the low and high parameters (monthly investment should be between 0 and 1000. The yearly interest needs to be between 0 and 15. Lastly, the years must be between 0 and 50).

Step 8    

  • Test your application with invalid entries by opening the IDLE shell and pressing F5
  • Enter the following inputs
Enter monthly investment: 0
Entry must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 1000 
Enter monthly investment: 100
Enter yearly interest rate:16
Entry must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 15 
Enter yearly interest rate: 12
Enter number of years: 100
Entry must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 50 
Enter number of years: 10

Future Value = Continue (y/n)? n

Bye!

  

Step 9

  • Save the file

Submission:

  • Upload the following files in a SINGLE submission
  • validate.py
  • future_value-2.py  
  • Word document with the hierarchy chart

MO7: Participation

Before you put a program into production, it is essential that thorough testing and debugging is conducted. While it is true that virtually every application created has "bugs" but the better you become and identifying issues and fixing them before they get into the hands of the user, the better the experience the user will have. This participation will have you put your knowledge into action by testing and debugging existing applications.

 

Part 1 (Exercise 5-1)  Test and debug a Test Scores program

Complete the following steps using Exercise 5-1 in the textbook.

Step 1

  • Create a new Word document with the name [FirstName][LastName]ParticipationM07.docx
  • Save the file in a place you can remember.
  • Start the IDLE shell and open the following file: test_scores-2.py 
  • Review the code thoroughly but do not correct any errors if you see any.

Step 2

  • Create a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet that has three test cases.
    • For example, you would have a spreadsheet that would look something like this:
    • Sample Spreadsheet
      Case Test 1 Score Test 2 Score Test 3 Score Total Score Average Prediction
      1 60 50 83 [Total of all scores] [Calc Average]
      2
      3
    • Make sure that at least one of the cases has invalid data (e.g., Test 2 Score: 190)
    • In the prediction column,  put some notes of what you expect to happen with the user's input values.

Step 3

  • Find and correct the logic errors in the application as the results will not be accurate.
  • Copy and paste your Excel table in the Word document that was created in step 1.
  • Run the application again and put the data back in from each of your cases and take a screenshot of IDLE shell.
  • Place the screenshot in the Word document and save it.

class FutureValueFrames(ttk.Frame):

        FutureValueFrame(parent).grid(row=0, column=1)

        # Add the Exit button        
        ttk.Button(parent, text="Exit", command=parent.destroy).grid(
            row=1, column=1, sticky=tk.E, padx=15, pady=10)
