MO1: Project

Assignment Overview:

GitHub Desktop is another tool that can help a team to share a repository of code or other documents (in our case, Python files).  Before making any changes to your programs, you will need to pull the latest version of the project from the shared repository to your local machine. You can then use your own local copy of the code to make changes, compile, and test it.  Then you can commit these changes first to the local Master. This will allow sharing online repositories by pushing the changes to others. 

GitHub Desktop provides a GUI version of this popular tool. The GitHub Desktop application will allow you to view your own local repositories.

Instructions:

Step 1. Register for GitHub.

Go to www.github.com and register for an account.  If you already have an account, you may use it for this assignment.

Step 2. The instructor adds you to the class repository.

Complete the GitHub Username survey so you can be added as a team member with access to the GitHub INFO1200Python/Fall2021 online repository. 

Wait...
Your instructor will now add you to the course repository. You will be sent an email invitation you need to respond to.  The email will be the email you used to register with GitHub.

Step 3. View INFO1200Python/Summer2022 repository

After accepting the email invitation you will be able to access the INFO1200Python/Summer2022 with write and read rights in the online github.com.

Step 4.  Download GitHub Desktop and Install

Download GitHub Desktop and install it on your local computer or VM. https://desktop.github.com/ (Links to an external site.)

Step 5. Open GitHub Desktop and SignIn.

Once you have installed the application, open GitHub Desktop on your local machine (I like to add the application to my taskbar). The first time you open GitHub Desktop, you will be prompted to sign in with your GitHub email and password. Then you will be asked to complete the Configure step by clicking Continue and then finally click the Finish button.

Step 6. Clone the Summer2022 repository

The GitHub Desktop opens with a screen that, in the middle, shows three options: Create a new repository, Add to an existing repository, or Clone a repository.  Choose to Clone a Repository.  Choose the INFO1200Python/Summer2022 repository and click the Clone button.  By default, the repository will be copied to your local machine, usually in C:\Users\Documents\GitHub\ folder.

Step 7. View Summer2022 repository in Explorer
In GitHub Desktop, you should now be able to view the Summer2022 repository in Explorer, or you can actually browse to your C:\Users\Documents\GitHub\  Find your local Summer2022 repository folder.  Open the folder.  Notice there may be two Github files added to your folder:  a .githubattributes and a .gitignore.  These are the files that link this local folder to the online Github repository.  Do not change or delete these files because this is how GitHub tracks changes in your project.

Step 8.  Create a new file in the repository.
Open the start.py file in your local repository by opening it in Notepad (or similar text editor. My favorite is VS Code) and do a SaveAs.  Save this file as FirstNameLastName.py.  (select All Files or will be a .txt file)  Modify the Python  name variable in your new file to include your full name (Replace Kodey Crandall with your name)
Save the FirstNameLastName.py file and close it.

Step 9.  Commit to Master (Save changes locally)
Go back to the GitHub Desktop local panel, and you will see you now have 1 changed file to your local version. In the bottom left, you will see Created FirstnameLastName.py and a Description for your changed file.  You can add a description saying you created this copy of the start file.  Then you need to click the Commit to Master button.  This will only save this change to your local repo.  You should now see 0 changed files in your GitHub Desktop panel.  This only commits these changes to your local repository.

Step 10.  Push Origin, Push changes to GitHub.com repository

To get your changes up to the class Github Fall2021 repository, you will need to click the Push origin link. You may be asked to first pull origin or fetch origin.  (Note: you may need to use the Repository menu->Pull before it lets you do a Push) After completing the push origin, this will push these local commits you made to your master to the online GitHub.com version of the Summer2022 repository.

Step 11.  Verify Changes in GitHub.com repository
Go back to the online repository in github.com.  Go to the INFO1200Python/Summer2022 project. In the Commits, you should be able to view your commit with the changes you made. Your instructor will check the list of commits to find your commit to the class repository when grading this assignment.

 

Summary:

I hope this tool helps you manage your source control for your project along with any other documents that need maintaining, sharing, and editing.

You are more than welcome to create your own repository in GitHub for your projects and assignments throughout the semester using this source control. This is also a great way to backup your work. As a student, you should be able to have a private repository from GitHub that you can use for your assignments if you wish.  Unfortunately, there is not enough space on our class repository to hold your projects. If you decide not to use GitHub, you should choose another method/tool to manage/backup your code.

 

Submission:

Submit the text "I have completed the MO1: Project GitHub assignment."
Your instructor will then check in the class GitHub Summer2022 repository to view the commit you have made with your name and date.  Make sure to use your complete name in the edited file so your instructor can give you credit for your work.

Assignment 1 - Introduction to Python

Overview

While there are many approaches to learning programming, this class will use a scaffolding approach to learning. Learn more about Instructional Scaffolding: https://iris.peabody.vanderbilt.edu/module/sca/cresource/q1/p01/. While I do much of the work with you in the participation assignments, you will be responsible for completing these project assignments primarily on your own. 

For this project, you will use the IDLE shell to explore Python with simple commands, then open an existing Python file, and finally, you will debug an existing Python file to discover existing errors. To help you complete this project, please refer to Chapter 1 in the textbook.

Assignment 2 - Coding Control Statements

Overview

Coding control statements is a critical component of programming. For this assignment, you will learn how to work with a variety of control statements such as if, while, for, break & continue, and pass statements.

Like always, you will need to use pseudocode to plan your program as well as explain the process you are taking to complete the application.

You will need to complete ALL three parts:

Part 1 - Letter Grade Converter

Part 2 - Tip Calculator

Part 3 - Change Calculator

 

Learning Objectives

  • Distinguish between a Boolean variable and a Boolean expression.
  • Describe the evaluation of a Boolean expression, including order of precedence and the use of parentheses.
  • Describe the sort sequence of string values and the use of the lower() or upper() method of a string for comparing two string values.
  • Describe the flow of control of an if statement that has both elif and else clauses.
  • Distinguish between the flow of control in a while loop and the flow of control in a for loop.
  • Describe the use of break and continue statements.
  • Describe the use of pseudocode for planning a program and its control statements.

MO8 - Right Triangle and Custom App 

Overview

Now that you have some experience creating Python applications with a GUI, it is now time to build one on your own. For this project, you will create two Python applications from scratch that have a GUI.

 

Part 1: Right Triangle Calculator

Create a GUI program that calculates the hypotenuse of a right triangle after the user enters the lengths of the two short sides and clicks the Calculate button.

Step 1

  • Use the Pythagorean Theorem to calculate the length of the third side. The Pythagorean Theorem states that the square of the hypotenuse of a right-triangle is equal to the sum of the squares of the opposite sides:

    • c2 = a2 + b2

  • As a result, you can calculate side C like this:

    •  c = square_root(a2 + b2)

Step 2

  • Side C should be rounded to a maximum of 3 decimal places

  • Make sure the user enters valid int values, and display any data validation messages in a message box.

  • Test this program and to find and fix all of the syntax, runtime, and logic errors that it contains.

Step 3

  • Add a line of pseudo-code for each line of source code
  • Save the file(s)

MO9 - The Wizard's Inventory 

Overview

For this application, you will need to create a Python application that allows a wizard to carry a magic item that is stored in a list. To help the user Create, Read, Update, and Delete (CRUD) the list items, you'll need to create a command menu (Step 1).

Assignment Specifications:

  • Use a list to store the items. Provide three starting items.
  • The wizard can only carry four items at a time.
  • For the edit and drop commands, display an error message if the user enters an invalid number for the item.
  • When you exit the program, all changes that you made to the inventory are lost.

 

Create the Command Menu

Step 1

  • Open your favorite text editor (I like Visual Studio Code)
    • Create a new .py file and save it with the name [FirstName][LastName]_MO9.py
    • Add the following pseudocode agreement on the first line
#Name: (First Name Last Name)
#Class: (INFO 1200)
#Section: (X01)
#Professor: (Crandall)
#Date:
#Project #: M09
#I declare that the source code contained in this assignment was written solely by me.
#I understand that copying any source code, in whole or in part, 
#constitutes cheating, and that I will receive a zero on this project
#if I am found in violation of this policy.
  • Define a display_title() function and have it
    • use the print() to show the text: [FirstName] [LastName]'s Wizard Inventory Game
      • Replace the placeholders with your own first and last name
    • add a space using the print()
  • Define a display_menu() function and have it
    • Use the print() function several times to show the following text with a space after:
COMMAND MENU

show - Show all items
grab - Grab an item
edit - Edit an item
drop - Drop an item
exit - Exit program

 

Step 2

  • Define a main() function

  • Call the display_title() function and the display_menu() function created in step 1.
    • Test the program to see if the functions work as expected. You should see the title and the command menu
  • Create an inventory list variable that has three items by default every time the user runs the application
    • be creative and come up with your own items for the user.
inventory = ["staff", "item2", "item3"]
  • Create a while loop that executes until the user types exit.
    • Inside the loop, store the user's input in a variable called "command"
    • Next, create an if, elif, elif,... for each of the command menu items
while True:        
        command = input("Command: ")        
        if command == "show":
            show(inventory)
        elif command == "grab":
            grab_item(inventory)
        elif command == "edit":
            edit_item(inventory)
        elif command == "drop":
            drop_item(inventory)
        elif command == "exit":
            break
        else:
            print("Not a valid command. Please try again.\n")
    print("Bye!")
    • HINT: Notice the show, grab_item, edit_item, and drop_item methods are not yet created. We will do this in the next few steps.
  • Add the following at the bottom of your code:
if __name__ == "__main__":  main()

 

Step 3

  • Create a show() function that receives the inventory as a parameter
  • In the show function, create a for loop that loops through all items that are held by the wizard
for number, item in enumerate(inventory, start=1):
        print(f"{number}. {item}")
  • Add a space after using the print() function

Step 4

  • Create a grab_item() function that receives the inventory as a parameter
  • If the number of items is more than or equal to 4, display the text "You can't carry any more items. Drop something first"
  • else, have the user type in the item name and store it in a variable named item
    • add the item to the inventory list
    • then, show the text {item} was added
if len(inventory) >= 4:
        print("You can't carry any more items. Drop something first.\n")
    else:
        item = input("Name: ")
        inventory.append(item)
        print(f"{item} was added.\n")

Step 5

  • Create an edit_item() function that receives the inventory as a parameter
  • Have the user enter in the item number he/she would like to edit and store it in a variable named "number"
  • Make sure the user types in a number that is 1 or more and less than the number of items in the inventory
  • If the number entered is invalid, show the text "Invalid item number"
  • else, have the user type in the new name for the item and show the text "Item {number} was updated"
number = int(input("Number: "))
    if number < 1 or number > len(inventory):
        print("Invalid item number.\n")
    else:
        item = input("Updated name: ")
        inventory[number-1] = item
        print(f"Item number {number} was updated.\n")

Step 6

  • Create the last function: drop_item() and pass in the inventory as a parameter
  • have the user enter the item number he/she would like to drop
  • if the number is a valid number, have that item be removed from the list.
  • if it is invalid, show the text "Invalid item number"
number = int(input("Number: "))
    if number < 1 or number > len(inventory):
        print("Invalid item number.\n")
    else:
        item = inventory.pop(number-1)
        print(f"{item} was dropped.\n")

Step 7

  • Add a line of pseudo-code for EACH line of source code you created.
  • Save the file.

  • Test the application to ensure everything works as expected with each of the buttons
  • Rename the file [FirstName][LastName]_MO9EXTRA.py

M01: Assignment 1 - The College Search Form and Console App

As people are considering going to college, they may ask themselves where the school is located. For this application, you will create both a Python application and C# console application to search the city of a given college. You may notice that I do not give you step-by-step instructions for most projects. You are to take your knowledge from the participation and apply what you have learned.

Overview Video

 

Part 1: Python

Using participation 1, create a python file that prompts a user to type in a college name. If the college is found in the database (.txt file) have the program respond with both the city and the college name. If it is not found, display an error message that states the college is not found in the database.

 

 

Part 2: C#

Create the same application as Part 1, but now use C#.

 

The output should look something like this:

 

 

 Finding a Random College

This feature will most likely take a significant amount of time. You'll need to research and find a solution for this additional feature:

If the user types "random", the system will select a random college and display the college name and city. The response from your program should use the Random class to select a random number between 0 and the size of the dictionary.

 

THIS FUNCTIONALITY WILL BE REQUIRED FOR BOTH THE C# AND PYTHON PROGRAMS

 

If you find yourself struggling for more than 1 hour, please signup for a time to meet with me during my posted office hours so I can give you some pointers. These projects are meant to stretch you but are not meant to be impossible.

 

Steps to complete the random college and city using C#:

  1. Create an instance of the Random class 
    • Random rand = new Random();
  2. Use the Count method of the dictionary to fetch the size of the dictionary. 
    • int totalColleges = rand.Next(collegeDict.Count);

  3. Next, retrieve a random "key" from the dictionary by using the ElementAt extension.

    • string randCollege = stateCapDict.ElementAt(totalColleges).Key;
  4. Lastly, display the college and city 
    • if (stateCapDict.TryGetValue(randCollege, out string city)) { 
      Console.WriteLine($"Random College: {randCollege},{city}"; });

 

After showing the college information, the program loop should continue prompting the user to ask for a college until the user types x to exit.

 

Example Colleges:

Utah Valley University,Orem
Brigham Young University,Provo
The University of Utah,Salt Lake City
...

Requirements:

First, you will need to read in a .txt file that has the colleges stored (you'll need to create this manually).

Each college will need to be stored in a dictionary.

The user's input will be the "key" to the dictionary, and the value pair will be returned if it is found.

For EACH line of source code, you will need to put a line of pseudo-code.

Assignment 2 - Multiform XAML Nutrition Tracking Application

Introduction

Calorie counting applications are a dime a dozen, but what about a nutrition tracking application? You decide not to limit yourself and set out to develop a prototype of an application that reads in foods with a total of 28 (that’s right) nutrition-related attributes. Attributes vary from food name and serving size, to protein grams and Vitamin B6 and C. In the first version of your application (this assignment), you will read the foods into a ComboBox.  When you select an item from the ComboBox, a second form will appear with all the nutrition details of that particular food item.  Figure 1 and Figure 2 show screenshots of the application in action.

 

PURPOSE

This assignment tests your ability to create and use multiple forms as well as collection classes (ArrayList and Dictionary).  The food items will be read from a text file into the ArrayList within the ComboBox as well as a Dictionary. The Dictionary will be used to "lookup" the food item when the user selects it from the GUI.

 

REQUIREMENTS

Your assignment will be made up of three classes: MainWindow, DetailWindow, and the Food class. You can ignore the App class. The classes are shown in the UML class diagram found in Figure 3.

 

Key Points to Consider:

  • The MainWindow will open, use, and close the data file (nutrition.txt).
    • Download the nutrition.txt  before you begin.
    • The file consists of all the food nutrition data for this program.
  • In the MainWindow constructor method, you should call a new method named OpenText.
    • The OpenText method will need to read the file and store its contents in a dictionary that can be used later to display the details of a selected food item.
    • As you read the file, add each food name to the dropdown list (Figure 1)
    • Also, on each iteration (line read from file), you should create an instance of the Food class and add it to the Dictionary, using the food name as the key in the dictionary.
  • When an item is selected on the MainWindow, the corresponding food object should be retrieved from the Dictionary, and that food object should be passed to the DetailWindow via a method called SetNutritionalValues(Food food) so it can be displayed.
    • Similar to the participation assignment for this module
    • The DetailWindow should be launched in a modal fashion, using the method ShowDialog().

 

The method SetNutritionalValues(Food food) in DetailWindow will be quite long as there are many details for each food item. This method receives a Food object and must assign all the property values from the Food object to

Figure 1 - The Window with the Combo Box

 

The Food details page is quite extensive. Therefore, I would like to provide you with the GUI so you can spend most of your time on this project understanding the logic and programming concepts: Details GUI

Figure 2 - The Window with the nutrition details showing for the selected food item

 

Figure 3 - Class Diagram for Nutrition Tracker, Assignment 2

 

The "Content" property of each label from the DetailWindow is designated to display values from the dictionary values. There will be 28 different assignments to get all the properties from Food, assigned to the Labels on DetailWindow. The assignment statements will vary depending on whether the Food property is a string or a double. The Content property of a Label can only display a string so if the property is a double, you must call the ToString() method on the property.

Figure 4 illustrates a couple of assignment statements to pull data from the properties in Food and assign the values to the Content property of the Label from DetailWindow.

lbFoodName.Content = food.FoodName;

lbFoodType.Content = food.FoodType;

lbServingSize.Content = food.ServingSize;

lbWeight.Content = food.Weight.ToString();

lbPercentWater.Content = food.PercentWater.ToString();

lbCalories.Content = food.Energy.ToString();

lbProtein.Content = food.Protein.ToString();

lbCarbohydrates.Content = food.Carbohydrate.ToString();

lbFiber.Content = food.Fiber.ToString();

Assignment 3 - Object-Oriented XAML Application

 

  1. Create a windows presentation foundation (WPF) application, shown in Figure 1. You can choose any three types of animals, real or mythical.
  2. Create an abstract Animal class with string properties for SkinType, FoodType, and methods called Eat(), Move(), and Reproduce() that all return strings. Make three virtual methods: Eat() and Reproduce() and make Move(). Add an abstract method called Unique() that returns a string. The Animal class should have a constructor with two arguments whose values are assigned SkinType and FoodType. The Eat(), Move(), and Reproduce() methods should just return a string of your choosing, for example:

 

public virtual string Eat()
{
     return "chomp chomp";
}

public virtual string Move()
{
     return "hippity hop";
}

public virtual string Reproduce()
{
     return "create offspring";
}

public abstract string Unique();

 

  1. Extend the Animal class and create 3 derived classes for any three animals. Derived classes should have a method called Unique that overrides the abstract Unique method declared in the base class. The derived classes should also override the virtual Move() method from the base class. The method called Unique should do something uniquely specific to the animal being created. For example, if you choose a dog, a Dog class might have a Unique method that returns "WagsTail" or "CatchesFrisbee".
  2. Add window controls to select any of the 3 animals
  3. Pictures of the animals should change when their radio button is selected.
  4. Add six buttons, two are for the properties SkinType and FoodType, three are for the methods and Eat, Move, and Reproduce, and one is for the Unique method as shown in Figure 1.
  5. When each button is clicked, display text (returned from the methods) in a label showing that the animal can access its inherited properties and methods. When the unique attribute button is clicked, populate the label showing your animal can perform its unique method as shown at the bottom of Figure 1.
  6. Create a SINGLE Animal object in the class and give it the type once the radio button is selected. 
Animal animal;

      9. Then, assign the correct derived type animal once the radio button is selected. For example (Remember to pass in the correct parameters):

animal = new Dog("",""); // if dog radio button is selected

 

Now that the derived classes are encapsulated by the base class, the unique method will access the string from the correct derived class method (polymorphism). At compile time, the object is of data type Animal and the Unique method is abstract. At runtime, a Dog object, a Cat object, and a Chicken object are instantiated and assigned to the Animal object once the radio button is selected. C# is compiled-time typed, except in the case of polymorphism where the runtime calls the correct version of Unique depending on the type of object that is assigned to the animal variables at runtime.

Figure 1 - The WPF application AnimalFarm

 

Make the project your own. Add in all the functionality based on the image above. Use the label at the bottom to display the results when each button is selected.

For Assignment 5, you are to create an application much like Assignment 4. The main difference between assignment 5, however, is that you are not allowed to use datasets. The JellyBelly table contains JellyBelly flavors from different categories. You will use Entity Framework to build your local database and use the text file below to insert the JellyBellies in your table. (We will not be using BigData1 for this assignment.

 

Create a new WindowsForm application using the .NETFramework and add a class that looks like this (be careful when copying this into the class page—you should NOT have a class within a class). You'll also need to add some assembly references to get rid of the errors—just hover over the errors to figure out what to add:

Assignment 6 Forms Application with Network Programming

Project Resources:

UVUCourseDescriptions.txt

UVUFacts.txt

uvu.ico

Overview

For assignment 6, you are to create a new client-server application. You will need to create 2 projects within 1 solution. For example, you could name your solution Assignment6CS and then name your client project ClientApplicationForm and your server project ServerApplication.

You will need to start the server application from the command line, while the client application can be started within Visual Studio. Figure 1 shows the GUI for the client application. The only new addition is the icon used on the form (upper left-hand corner). The icon is set using the Icon property of the form. You can create your own icon or use the one uploaded with the assignment.

The ReadOnly property on the textbox on the GUI should be set to true.  The textbox is grayed out because it is ReadOnly.  Also, the WordWrap and Multiline properties of the textbox should be set to true.  The scrollbar appears due to the Multiline property being set to true.

The GUI is separated into 2 sections by Group boxes.  There is a group box for the REQUEST information and a group box that displays the RESPONSE from the server.

 

Figure 1 – The client GUI

 

The server should be able to respond with a UVU fact, a UVU major, or simply echo back the text that was sent.  To get a fact back send the server the text ‘UVUFact’. To get a major, send the server the text ‘UVUMajor’.  If neither joke nor conspiracy is sent to the server, the server will just echo back what it was sent. Figure 2 shows an example of the server response when the text ‘UVUFact’ is sent to it.  Figure 3 shows an example of the server response when the text ‘UVUMajor’ is sent to it.

 

Figure 2 – The server’s response to a joke

 

Figure 3 – The server’s response to a conspiracy

 

The client is pretty simple.  Most of the client code involves setting up the GUI and then managing the connection to the server.

 

The server code has more responsibility.

  • The server must listen on port 11000 for a client request.
  • The server is a console application. 

The server after receiving a UVUFact request is shown in Figure 4.

Figure 4 – The UVUFact/UVUMajor server listening on port 11000

 

The server must listen on port 11000 for a synchronous client connection.  When the connection is established, the server must read the request text from the network stream.  If the text sent equals ‘UVUFact’, then the server must return a random fact.  If the text equals ‘UVUMajor’ then the server must return a random major. If the client did not send the text ‘UVUFact’ OR ‘UVUMajor’, then the server should just write back what text the client did send over.

The UVUFacts and the UVUMajors work the same way as Assignment 1.  A text file of UVU facts (UVUFacts.txt) and a text file of UVU majors (UVUCourseDescriptions.txt) have been uploaded to Canvas.  Save these files to the bin/Debug directory of the server project.  Create a class (let’s call it UVUResponse) that reads in the files when the class object is instantiated.  Each fact/major should be read into a separate List<string> data structure.  The UVUResponse class should have a method that returns a random fact and a method that returns a random major.

When the ServerApplication receives a response from the client, it should read the text from the NetworkStream.  If the text is equal to ‘UVUMajors’, then it should call the GetUVUMajor method of the UVUResponse class. If the text read is equal to ‘UVUFacts’, then it should call the GetUVUFact method of the UVUResponse class. If the client does not request a UVUFacts or UVUMajors, then return the text that was passed to the server. Once the server acquires its appropriate response text, then it should WriteLine the response back to the client and the client should display the response in the Multiline Textbox.

 

Lastly, put the UVU icon on the top left corner of the form.

 

Before you submit for grading:

  1. Does the application run and have the required functionality? (10 points)
  2. Is the application’s functionality correctly divided into 2 projects within a single solution? (5 points)
  3. Does the application have proper commenting? (5 points)

Earthquake API Assignment 7

Purpose

The purpose of this assignment is to help you as a student learn how to build a mobile application that interacts with an Application Program Interface (API). An API is a set of routines, protocols, and tools to help build application software that interacts with a given set of logical rules build by other developers. Most API requires an API key to interact with it so requests are tracked (mainly for security reasons). For example, Phillips Hue smart lights use an API (paired with a key) to send a request to change the color, brightness, and state (on/off) of the lights. This is accomplished by sending a request over a network and having the API do something with that request. The USGS Earthquake Catalog is another API that can be used to get earthquake details of a given location, earthquake size, date, and much more.

This project will have you use the Earthquake API (https://earthquake.usgs.gov/fdsnws/event/1/#callback) to get the current earthquake data based on the user input of a date range and magnitude of earthquakes. After the user provides the data, the API request will then return the most recent earthquake for the input provided.

 

Task

  1. Build a cross-platform application using Xamarin to interact with an API
  2. Use the https://earthquake.usgs.gov/fdsnws/event/1/#callback documentation to build an application that communicates with the API
  3. Requests will be sent to the Web API
  4. Responses from the API will be received
  5. The most recent earthquake will be displayed to the user

 

Criteria

Deliverables: A mobile application that interacts with the Earthquake API.

Grading:

  • Data received from the API is correctly displayed
  • One RANDOM earthquake is correctly formatted and displays the location and size.
  • All C# code is free from syntax errors
  • All C# code is free from logical errors
  • All C# code is commented (A line of pseudo-code above each line of source code and a block of pseudo-code above each method)
  • The project is turned in on time.

 

Step 1:  Create a single-page application that receives a date range and earthquake magnitude from the user to produce information for the results.

  • Read the API documentation (https://earthquake.usgs.gov/fdsnws/event/1/#callback

HINT: https://earthquake.usgs.gov/fdsnws/event/1/query?format=geojson&starttime=2014-01-01&endtime=2014-01-02

Figure 1: Mobile app landing page layout

Step 2: Connect to the API using C#

  • In C#, you will need to use WebClient. This class can be accessed using the using System.Net;

Example Code:

using (WebClient wc = new WebClient())
{
         wc.Headers[HttpRequestHeader.ContentType] = "application/x-www-form-urlencoded";
        string json = wc.DownloadString($"https://earthquake.usgs.gov/fdsnws/event/1/query?format=geojson&starttime={StartDate}&endtime={EndDate}&minmagnitude={EarthquakeSize}");
}   
  • Create a try-catch block to get each value out of the JSON received.

To process the JSON, you will need to store the values in JSON Objects. In C# this can be done using the JObject class (using Newtonsoft.Json.Linq;)

Example Code:

JObject jo = JObject.Parse(json);

JObject main = JObject.Parse(jo["metadata"].ToString());

 

Step 3: Create a class (does NOT have to be static) to store the values from the API

  • Create a new class called Earthquake.cs
  • Create public variables
    • public string EQLocation { get; set; }
    • public string EQSize { get; set; }
  • Store the values in the new class variables

 

Review the JSON code below and see the code sample on how to process the data. Notice how the first nodes are "type", "metadata", and "features".

To get the total number of earthquakes from the given input, you will need to process the first node of "metadata".

To get the features from each of the earthquakes, we will need to create an array of JSON objects (JArray). The reason we know this is the [ ] brackets immediately following the features node.  

Figure 2: JSON code

Example Code to process the JSON:

// Get the number of earthquakes
int count = 0;
int.TryParse(EQmetadata["count"].ToString(), out count);

// Creates a list of earthquakes and gets values from the API
List<Earthquake> eqList = new List<Earthquake>();
int idx = 1;
foreach (var eq in eQjArray)
{
  JObject eqJObj = JObject.Parse(eq["properties"].ToString());
  Earthquake earthquake = new Earthquake
  {
    EarthquakeId = idx,
    Magnitude = double.Parse(eqJObj["mag"].ToString()),
    Place = eqJObj["place"].ToString()
  };
  eqList.Add(earthquake);
}

Step 4: Display the results of ONE random earthquake from the list received

Random random = new Random();
int randeq = random.Next(1, eqList.Count + 1);
Earthquake displayEQ = eqList[randeq - 1];
lblResults.Text = $"There were {count} earthquakes during this time.\n\n" +
   $"Details of one of them:\nPlace: {displayEQ.Place}, \nMagnitude: {displayEQ.Magnitude}.";

 

Hint: The API may return a 400 error if there are too many earthquakes returned. You may want to try to put in the input below to see if you get the same number of earthquakes.

Participation 1

INFO 1200, Programming I for IS & IT is a required prerequisite for this course. That being said, students may notice INFO 1200 now uses Python as the primary language, AND this course mainly focuses on C#. This may sound troubling and some may wonder why it is if the languages are different. Well, if taught correctly, students should now have a base understanding of basic programming principles that can be integrated and applied to other similar programming languages. Wow... that's a lot of justification and explanation for why we are starting with an assignment like this.

For this participation, students will program in BOTH Python and C# to help familiarize themselves with both languages to see the similarities and differences and to be able to transition to C# (which is the primary language we will be working with this semester).

Students will begin by first creating a Python application (Part 1) to create a simple lookup game using the U.S. States and Capitals. In the console, the user will first enter a state, and the program will return one of two things: 1) the corresponding capital based on the State entered, or 2) a message that displays "The state {userinput} is not in the database".

try
{

  inputFile = File.OpenText("phones.txt");

  while (!inputFile.EndOfStream)

  {

    tempPhone = inputFile.ReadLine().Split(',');

    CbPhones.Items.Add(tempPhone[1]);

    phoneDict.Add(tempPhone[1], new Phone(tempPhone));

  }

  inputFile.Close();

}

catch (Exception ex)

{

  MessageBox.Show(ex.Message);

}

Getting a program to work is good, but making your code more efficient and having it function correctly is what we strive for in program development. One of the most common mistakes programmers make is developing code that is inefficient by having a lot of duplicated code. For this participation assignment, you will create an application that manages the details of stored plants. The objectives of this application are to help you understand the idea of encapsulation and inheritance to help you eliminate code duplication.

If you were asked, "Are all flowers plants?", you would say... yes!

If you were asked, "Are all trees plants?", you would say... yes!

but what if you were asked, "Are all flowers trees?" or "Are all trees flowers?" you would obviously say... no!

 

The concept of inheritance is that you can build a base (parent) class that holds all the attributes of its derived (child) class. Thus you wouldn't have to duplicate your code for objects that are both generic to flowers and trees.

 

Download Written Instructions

 

Step 0: Start a new C# WPF app (.NET Framework)

 

Step 1: Design the GUI

  • Build a landing page GUI that looks something like this:
    • It will have a grid with 3 columns 
      • First column 200 px wide
      • Second column 300 px wide
      • Third column * (Max width)
    • It will have a grid with 6 rows with all equal heights except the last row which will be 4 times larger than the others
    • Add a label to the first row that has a title with your name in it with the text "Favorite Plants" (e.g., Kodey's Favorite Plants)
    • Add the name, environment, and type labels in the first column with these attributes
      • Content with the correct text (e.g., Name:)
      • 1st column and (second, third, and fourth row respectively)
      • font-size: 20
      • Vertical alignment to the center
      • horizontal alignment to the right
    • Add a textbox in for the name with these attributes
      • 2nd row & 2nd column
      • font-size: 20
      • x:name of TxtBoxName
    • Add two combo boxes (environment and type) with these attributes
      • x:name of CbEnvironment and CbType respectively
      • Column 1 and rows three and four
      • font-size of 20
      • vertical alignment to the center
      • SelectedChanged event and make sure you choose the new event handler that shows up
    • Create a group box in the third column with a list box inside
      • Add a header attribute with the text All Plants
      • Add a column-span attribute of 2
      • Add a row-span attribute of 3
      • Add a margin of 10 px on all sides
    • Inside the group box, add a list box
      • Add an x:Name of LstBoxPlants
      • Add 5 px margins around all sides
    • Add two buttons (Add Plant and Show Details) to the 5th row
      • The Add Plant button will need to be spanned across 2 columns
      • Add a font size of 20
      • Add a good x:name (e.g., BtnPlant)
    • Add two image controls (Plant and Environment)
      • Download the following images:
        • flower
        • tree
        • shrub
        • desert
        • mountain
        • forest
      • Create a new "Images" directory in the solution explorer just inside the project
      • Add the two image controls to the 6th row
      • Give them a good x:name (e.g., ImgPlant), center them horizontally, and column span the left image

Walkthrough Video 1

Step 2: Build a Base Class

  • Create a new class in the project called Plant
    • Create public properties that identify ALL plants
      • Environment (string)
      • Type (string)
      • Name (string)
    • Create a constructor method
      • We will create a new plant every time it is called from the derived class. Thus we will need to pass in as parameters the name, environment, and type into the constructor method.
      • Next, set the default values to the backing fields to the parameters passed in.
public Plant(string name, string environment, string type)
{
  _environment = environment;
  _type = type;
  _name = name;
}
  • We can now ask ourselves, "Can I have a plant without creating it from a derived class?" or in other words "Is there such thing as a generic plant that doesn't come from a tree, flower, shrub, etc., etc.,?"... I would say no.
    • Thus, we can assume that we will never create a plant without creating it from a child class.
    • Therefore, we will need to make the class an abstract class. This means that a plant can only be created if it is created from a child class.
  • Add a method named Sniff and have it return a string. value of the smell of a plant. The derived classes will override this smell from the derived class. 

HINT: You may have a syntax error because a method cannot be generated in a base class if it is abstract and the method is not abstract. Thus we will need to make this method a "virtual" method. A virtual method means that you MUST override it from the derived class.

 

Step 3: Build 3 Derived Classes

  • Create three new classes (Tree, Flower, and Shrub)
    • Derive each class from the base (parent) class. 
    • Add a constructor method that receives the name, environment, and type as parameters for each class.
      • pass the parameters into the base constructor method.
    • Add a custom public property for each of the derived child) classes (e.g., public int TrunkSize { get; set; }).
  • Each class will also need a public sniff method.
    • This method will be a string returning method that would return the reaction if the plant was sniffed.
    • For example, the Tree sniff method might return "Cotton candy is my favorite tree smell".

Walkthrough Steps 2 and 3

Step 4: Load default values

  • In the MainWindow.xaml.cs file, create a void returning method named LoadPlants
    • In the constructor method, call the new LoadPlants method.
    • Inside the new method, add code that populates the combo boxes.

Example:

CbEnvironment.Items.Add("Desert")

 

Step 5: Plant Dictionary

To store the plant selected, we will need to create a Dictionary that holds a key/value pair of a string (plant name) for the key and a Plant (all other properties) as the value pair. The dictionary should be placed in the class so it can be accessed throughout the class.

Dictionary<string, Plant> plantsDict = new Dictionary<string, Plant>();

 

Step 6: Add Plants Click Event

When the add plants button is clicked, the system should validate the user's input to ensure that there is a plant name entered, a plant type is selected from the dropdown menu, and the plant environment is selected from its dropdown.

  • The system should not break if one of these checks fails but instead should help the user fill out the information correctly.
  • Once all checks are successful, add a switch case that changes on the plant type. If it's a flower, create a new flower with the name, environment, and type entered.
    • Then, add the plant to the dictionary
    • Add the plant name to the Listbox so the user can then select it and see its details.
    • The switch-case should also have a default case that displays the error message in a message box:
      • body text - "Unable to add the plant to the dictionary" 
      • title text - "Invalid Input"

Step 7: Update Images

Create a switch-case for each of the combo boxes that changes the image of the type if the type combo box is changed or the environment if the environment combo box is changed

Step 8: Create the Plant Details Window

Add a new window to the application and name it PlantDetailsWindow and add the following controls

Step 9: Show Details Click Event

The show details button will allow the user to select a stored plant and see its details. if no plant is selected, the system should not break, but instead should display a message to help the user select a stored plant first.

  • Check to make sure a plant is selected from the Listbox before displaying the details.
  • Create a new instance of a plant object (Plant plant;).
  • Search the dictionary for the plant and use the value selected in the Listbox as the key.
  • If the value pair is found store it in the plant object.
  • Create a new method on the Plant details page named UpdatePlantDetails and pass the plant object in as a parameter
    • Update each label from the plant class parameter
  • Show the plant details page as a modeless window

  Submit:

  1. A Word document with the following
    • Screenshots of each GUI you created
    • Code from each of the .cs files you created (please copy and paste the code as shown in the Assignment Submission Requirements (Projects & Participations)
  2. The project as a .zip file

assignment_name: MO4: Submit Participation 4 Working with Databases
description:
Working with Databases

Adding database functionality is vital for nearly all applications. This participation will introduce you to adding databases to your windows applications and show you how to manage data within the application. 

Step 0: Windows Form (.Net Framework) Application

  • Create a new project using the Windows Form (.Net Framework) application template.

 

Step 1: Create a new .mdf database file in the project

  • Add a new Master Database File (.mdf) used for Microsoft SQL Server to the project
    • right-click the project name
    • select add
    • select New Item

  • From the Data option on the left, select "Service-based Database"
    • Name the file LocalPhoneListDb.mdf

 

  • Once the file is created, open the server explorer and find the file.
    • Expand the file and you should see the Tables folder
    • Right-click the Tables folder and select Add Table
    • Using SQL below or the designer above, create the following table columns
      • PersonId (int) Primary Key
      • FirstName (nvarchar(50))
      • LastName (nvarchar(50))
      • PhoneNumber (nvarchar(10))
      • Age (int)
    • Run the SQL by clicking the green execute query button
    • Refresh the table folder by right-clicking it and selecting refresh
    • Add 4 to 5 entries by right-clicking the new table and selecting view table data
      • Notice you cannot enter the PersonId as it is the Identity for the table

 

Step 2: Create the Landing Form

  • For this project we will learn how to connect to databases in THREE different ways:
    • A New database file (first few steps)
    • Existing database file with data already in it
    • Online database (hosted on UVU servers)
  • Create a landing form that has four buttons as shown below

 

 

Step 3: Create a click event for the Local Phone Numbers button

  • Double-click the Local Phone Numbers button to create a click event.
  • We will connect this button up to a new form once we create it.

Step 4: Add the database to the Data Sources Window

  • Once the file is added and the data is in the database, open the Data Sources window on the left (If not visible, you'll need to find it in the "View" dropdown menu and it is in the Other Windows section).

  • Click the top-left "Add new data source" icon and follow these screenshots:

 

 

 

Step 5: Create a Local Phone Numbers Form

  • Using the screenshot below, create a new form with the following controls
    • GroupBox for the Search
    • Label for the first name
    • TextBox for the search
    • Search button
    • Sort by Last Name button
    • Average Age Button
    • Age > 30 button
    • Clear Button

  • The top section is created from the data sources section.
    • Drag from the data sources the PhoneNumber table as a DataGridView onto the designer
    • Once the data file has been added, you now have access to it and the ability to add data-bound controls to the Form.

 

 

Step 6: Adding the Search Query

  • Add a new query to the dataset by going to the Data Sources window, right-click on the database, and select "Edit DataSet with Designer"

  • Once in the designer, right-click the bottom section and select "Add Query"

  • Select "Use SQL statement" as we will be doing a select statement

 

  • Create the SQL Query (notice the @value refers to the value being passed into the query. This will come from the textbox on the windows form.) Then click next
SELECT PhoneNumberId, FirstName, LastName, PhoneNumber, Age
FROM PhoneNumber
WHERE (FirstName LIKE '%' + @value + '%')

  • Make sure you unselect the "Return a DataTable" because we already have a DataTable we will be updating. Change the name of the Method name to "FillByFirstNameSearch" and then click finish.

Step 7: Call the new query

  • Now that you have the method built, we can call it from the Windows Form application and pass in the user's input to receive the data from the database.
  • To do this, you will need to create a click event for the search button. Then add this code inside it.
this.phoneNumberTableAdapter.FillByFirstNameSearch(this.phoneListDbDataSet.PhoneNumber, TxtBoxFirstName.Text);

 

Step 8: Repeat for other queries

Follow the same steps to create a query for the Ages > or = to 30 and the Sort by last name buttons. 

 

Step 9: Next, do the same thing for the average age, but make sure to replace step 6 with "SELECT which returns a single value" when selecting the query type:

 

Step 10: Debug

  • Once you have created all the code for the Form, please test it and make sure it functions as expected.

 

Step 11: After all bugs are fixed, repeat the steps above for the local database file

  • Start by downloading the UVUPhoneNums.mdf 
  • Add the UVUPhoneNums.mdf file to the data sources window by clicking the Add Database button
  • Instead of showing the data in a DataGridView, display it in the Details view as shown below

Step 12: Online Database

  • Create a new form called OnlinePhoneNumsForm.cs
  • Add the connection to the online database by adding it to the data sources window by clicking the Add Database button (Step 4) but make sure you choose Microsoft SQL Server

  • Next, enter the correct information for the server name, user name, and password (See credentials below).
  • You will need access to data from an online SQL Server. We will do this by connecting to BigData1. You'll use the information below to access and add the connection. 

    • BigDataA.ad.uvu.edu

      • User: jbmuser

      • Password: jellybellymovie

  • YOU MUST BE CONNECTED THROUGH THE CAMPUS VPN.
    • Instructions for campus VPN access

  • Once you select INFO2200_Crandall from the dropdown list (only shows if the credentials are correct and you are connected through VPN), select "Yes, include sensitive data in the connection string"

  • Lastly, select the UVUPhoneNumsTable

  •  Complete the form and test it thoroughly

 

  Submission

  • Create a single word document with the following
    • Screenshot of the landing form running locally on your computer
    • Copy and paste the C# code in the LandingForm.cs (Please make sure you have commented each line of source code)
    • Screenshot of the Local Phone Number form running locally on your computer
    • Copy and paste the C# code in the LocalForm.cs (Please make sure you have commented each line of source code)
    • Screenshot of the Imported Phone Number form running locally on your computer
    • Copy and paste the C# code in the ImportedForm.cs (Please make sure you have commented each line of source code)
    • Screenshot of the Online Phone Number form running locally on your computer.
    • Copy and paste the C# code in the OnlinePhoneNumsForm.cs (Please make sure you have commented each line of source code)

assignment_name: MO5: Submit Participation 5 Entity, Linq, Database
description:
Entity, Linq, Database

This application will have you build an inventory management software for a clothing store.

The objectives:

  1.  Utilize Entity Framework
  2. Understand database-driven design
  3. Work with classes and entity relational models
  4. Use LINQ to build SQL statements using C#

Create a new Windows Form .NETApplication Application and design the MainForm using Figure 1.

Figure 1: MainForm

Image Resource:  before.jpg

 

Walkthrough Video

Part 1

 

Part 2

Download this Database and put it in your downloads folder: ProductDB.mdf

 

Add a new Windows Form to the project and design the GUI using Figure 2. Name the new form "ProductSearchForm".

Controls on the Form:

  1. DataGridView (Gray area)
  2. 2 labels (Product Description: & Product Id:)
  3. 1 TextBox (TxtBoxProductDescription)
  4. 2 Buttons (BtnAddProduct & BtnDeleteProduct)
  5. 1 ComboBox (CbDeleteProductId)

 

Figure 2: Product Search Form

 

Walkthrough Video for Part 2

 

Add another Form named "AddProductForm" and design the GUI using Figure 4. 

Figure 4: Add Product Form

Part 3 Walkthrough Video

 

Update the database

For this step, you'll need to update your database and add Entity Framework.

Because we are using an existing database (downloaded from part 2), you may find yourself wanting to update your code and add new columns of data.

When you imported your data file from part 2, it created a new Product.cs class. This class is your data model class that "links" to your database and manages the table structure. You will need to edit this file and add in a new column of data called "Category" which will be stored as a string.

Once you have done this complete the following steps:

  • Open the package manager console and type: enable-migrations
    • You may notice an error. This is because you added the database before adding the migrations. To fix this error, open the server explorer window and find the ProductDb database. Expand the database to find the Product table. Once there, right-click on the table and select "Show table data". Next copy all the data from the table, then delete the table.
  • Type in the package manager console again: enable-migrations
  • This will create a new Migrations folder in your solution explorer and will open a file. Set the AutomaticMigrations variable to true.
  • Type in the package manager console: update-database
    • This will recreate the table
    • Go to the Server Explorer window and refresh the tables in the database. Then right-click on the Product table and select show table data
    • Paste the data back in the table
  • Update the table data by adding in the Category for each row of data
    • e.g., Shirt, Pants, Jacket

Part 4 Walkthrough Video

 

Part 5

Add another Form named "CategoryForm" and design the GUI using Figure 3. This form will categorize all the products and count the number of products in each category.

Control: ListView

Figure 3: Category Form

 Part 5 Walkthrough Video

 

  Submit

In a single Word document:

  • Take a screenshot of each window running locally on your machine
  • Copy all .cs classes you modified (Ensure that EACH line of source code you created or modified has a line of pseudo-code above it. Also, each method needs to have a block of pseudo-code above it).

Zip the project and submit the .zip file as well

MO6: Submit Participation 6 - Client / Server

For this assignment, you will need to create a client application and a server application in the same solution. To do this, create TWO projects within ONE solution. For example, you could name your solution Assign6 and then name your client project ClientApplication and your server project ServerApplication.

This app will allow users to request a random joke or conspiracy from the server, and the server will then send back a response.

Step 1: Download Resources

jokes.txt

conspiracies.txt

ring.ico

 

Step 2: Build the Client Application

You will need to start the server application from the command line, while the client application can be started within Visual Studio. Figure 1 shows the GUI for the client application. The only new addition is the icon used on the form (upper left-hand corner). The icon is set using the Icon property of the form. You can create your own icon or use the one uploaded with the assignment.

The ReadOnly property on the textbox on the GUI should be set to true.  The textbox is grayed out because it is ReadOnly.  Also, the WordWrap and Multiline properties of the textbox should be set to true.  The scrollbar appears due to the Multiline property being set to true.

The GUI is separated into 2 sections by Group boxes (REQUEST and RESPONSE) as shown in Figure 1.  There is a group box for the REQUEST information and a group box that displays the RESPONSE from the server.

 

Figure 1 – The client GUI

Watch the following video to help you build the GUI

Step 3: Build the logic for the client

Though you have not yet set up the server, the next step is to build the logic as if there was a server. This will require you to create a network stream that will send a request on a given IP address and port. You will need to build a class object named SyncronousSocketClient.cs that will handle the network reading and writing.

Watch the following video to help you build the client logic

 

Step 4: Build a mockup of the server application

Before we build the server, you it may be advisable to build a mockup of the server. This may be a great approach to take first to ensure that the files you are reading for the jokes and conspiracies are loaded correctly. Download the jokes.txt and conspiracies.txt before you begin this section.

Watch the following video to help you complete the mockup of the server

 

Step 5: Replace the Mockup Server with the Actual Server

Now that you have tested the server, it is time to build the connection between the server and the client. You will need to listen on the same IP Address and port number as the client so a request can be received and a response can be sent back. You will need to build a new class object in the server application called SyncronousSocketListener.cs to build the logic.

The server must listen on port 11000 for a synchronous client connection.  When the connection is established, the server must read the request text from the network stream.  If the text sent equals ‘JOKE’, then the server must return a random joke.  If the text equals ‘CONSPIRACY’ then the server must return a random conspiracy. If the client did not send the text ‘CONSPIRACY’ OR ‘JOKE’, then the server should just write back what text the client did send over.

Watch the following video to help you complete the server logic

 

Step 6: Test the Application

The server should be able to respond with a conspiracy theory, a joke, or just the echo back of the message sent to it.  To get a joke back, send the server the text ‘JOKE’. To get a conspiracy theory, send the server the text ‘CONSPIRACY’.  If neither joke nor conspiracy is sent to the server, the server will just echo back what it was sent. Figure 2 shows an example of the server response when the text ‘JOKE’ is sent to it.  Figure 3 shows an example of the server response when the text ‘CONSPIRACY’ is sent to it.

Figure 2 – The server’s response to a joke

 

Figure 3 – The server’s response to a conspiracy

 

The server code has more responsibility. The server must listen on port 11000 for a client request. The server is a console application.  It is shown running in Figure 4.  Figure 5 shows the server after receiving a JOKE request. Figure 6 shows the server after receiving a CONSPIRACY request.

 

Figure 4 – The joke/conspiracy server listening on port 11000

 

Figure 5 – The joke/conspiracy server after receiving a JOKE request

 

Figure 6 – The joke/conspiracy server after receiving the CONSPIRACY request

 

If the client does not request a JOKE or CONSPIRACY, then return the text that was passed to the server. Once the server acquires its appropriate response text, then it should WriteLine the response back to the client and the client should display the response in the Multiline Textbox.

 

Step 7: Each line of source code needs a line of pseudocode.

 

  Submit

  1. A Word document with the following
    • Screenshots of each GUI you created
    • Code from each of the .cs files you created (please copy and paste the code as shown in the Assignment Submission Requirements (Projects & Participations)

assignment_name: MO7: Submit Participation 7 - Working with APIs (Weather App)
description:
OpenWeatherMap API Assignment

Purpose

The purpose of this assignment is to help you as a student learn how to build a mobile application that interacts with an Application Program Interface (API). An API is a set of routines, protocols, and tools to help build application software that interacts with a given set of logical rules build by other developers. Most API requires an API key to interact with it so requests are tracked (mainly for security reasons). For example, Phillips Hue smart lights use an API (paired with a key) to send a request to change the color, brightness, and state (on/off) of the lights. This is accomplished by sending a request over a network and having the API do something with that request. OpenWeatherMap is another API that can be used to get the current temperature, weather conditions, and much more of a given city or location.

This project will have you use the OpenWeatherMap API to get the current weather data of a given city by having the user enter in the desired zip code. After the user provides the zip code, the API request will then return all of the weather conditions of that city and display it to the user on the mobile device.

 

Task

  1. Build a cross-platform application using Xamarin to interact with an API
  2. Gain access to the OpenWeatherMap API by receiving an API key.
  3. Requests will be sent to the OpenWeatherMap API
  4. Responses from the OpenWeatherMap API will be received
  5. The current weather of a given city will be displayed to the user

 

Criteria

Deliverables: A mobile application that interacts with the OpenWeatherMap API.

Grading:

  • City zip code received from the OpenWeatherMap API is correctly displayed
  • The current temperature received from the OpenWeatherMap API is correctly formatted and displayed.
  • High and Low temperature received from the OpenWeatherMap API is correctly formatted and displayed
  • The temperature received from the OpenWeatherMap API is correctly formatted and displayed
  • The temp is displayed in Fahrenheit (You may need to do some searching in the API documentation).
  • All C# code is free from syntax errors
  • All C# code is free from logical errors
  • All C# code is commented (A line of pseudo-code above each line of source code and a block of pseudo-code above each method)
  • The project is turned in on time.

 

Step 1:  Create a landing page that will receive the zip code from the user to produce the results page.

Just so you are aware - Visual Studio NO LONGER has the preview window you see in the video. You'll need to test it on the emulator or an Android device

 

Step 2: Create an account with OpenWeatherMap and get your API key.

  • Create an account: https://openweathermap.org/api(Links to an external site.)
  • Get your API Key. To do this, you will need to sign in and click on the API Key

 

 

  • Create the code to find the current weather for that city.
  • Read the API documentation (https://openweathermap.org/api).
    • In the “show current temp” button click event, get the current weather for that city.

HINT: http://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?zip=_____________

 

Step 3: Connect to the API using C#

  • In C#, you will need to use WebClient. This class can be accessed using the using System.Net;

Example Code:

using (WebClient wc = new WebClient())
{
         wc.Headers[HttpRequestHeader.ContentType] = "application/x-www-form-urlencoded";
        string json = wc.DownloadString($"http://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?zip={EntryZipCode.Text}&appid={YOURAPIKEY}&units=imperial");
}   
  • Create a try-catch block to get each value out of the JSON received.

To process the JSON, you will need to store the values in JSON Objects. In C# this can be done using the JObject class (using Newtonsoft.Json.Linq;)

Example Code:

JObject jo = JObject.Parse(json);

JObject main = JObject.Parse(jo["main"].ToString());

 

Step 4: Create a Global Variable class to store the values from the API

  • Create a new class called WeatherGV.cs
  • Make the class static
  • Create 4 public static variables
    • public static string City { get; set; }
    • public static string CurTemp { get; set; }
    • public static string High { get; set; }
    • public static string Low { get; set; }
  • Store the values in the new class variables

Example Code:

WeatherGV.CityName = jo["name"].ToString();
WeatherGv.Temp = main["temp"].ToString();

 

Step 5: Display the results on the new WeatherPage

  • Go to the App.xaml.cs page and update the code to look like this:
MainPage = new NavigationPage(new MainPage());
  • Update the new page by adding the values from the API in the labels on the page

 

Screenshots of what your app should look like.

Landing Page

 

Current Weather Page

 

 

Step 6: Add pseudocode

For each line of source code, you will need to add a line of pseudocode.

 

  Submit

A Word document with the following

  • Screenshots of your code and the app running on your device and/or emulator for each of the .cs files / .xaml files you created (please copy and paste the code as shown in the Assignment Submission Requirements (Projects & Participations)
  • .zip file of your project

assignment_name: M03: Discuss Encapsulation Inheritance Polymorphism Abstract Classes
description:
Discuss

Polymorphism, Encapsulation, Inheritance, and Abstract Classes all seem like words that are from Mars. While these complex words sound extremely difficult, the concepts are quite straightforward. For this discussion, I would like you to create a short video explaining one of these concepts.

  1. Encapsulation
  2. Inheritance
  3. Polymorphism
  4. Abstract Classes

Make your original post by Thursday and follow-up comments by Sunday.

----------------------------------

Your video should either be of you or your screen explaining one concept listed above. The video only needs to be 3-5 minutes and can be a code sample using Visual Studio. If you need a screen recorder, there are plenty online for free (OBS, screencast-o-matic.com, etc.)

You will need to watch and respond to at least two other classmates posts

----------------------------------

See grading criteria by clicking on the show more icon in the upper right and selecting "Show Rubric."

Discuss

Building an application is a great start in learning programming. Adding a database to an application takes programming to a whole new level. For this discussion, I want you to build a very simple application that connects to a database and show it off to others in the class.

Make your original post by Thursday and follow-up comments by Sunday.

----------------------------------

You can choose the topic of the application and choose to build it however you would like. Once it is complete, take screenshots of your application and post them in this discussion.

Next, review and respond to at least 2 posts.

LINQ is a great approach to developing an application in C# and still having the flexibility to use SQL inside the application in C# syntax.

The purpose of this discussion is to help students gain a deeper understanding of how to apply LINQ.

description:
Discuss

  • Xamarin is a great tool to design and build cross-platform mobile applications. However, it is not the only one out there. 
  • Web APIs are developed for many reasons and help with processing information independent of the hardware requesting it.

 

Make your original post by Thursday and follow-up comments by Sunday.

----------------------------------

For this discussion, you will need to discover the other alternatives to Xamarin cross-platform development. Once you have identified some, post one alternative and explain some advantages and disadvantages to both Xamarin and the other you have found (2-3 sentence minimum for Pros and 2-3 sentence minimum for the Cons).

 

ALSO, you will need to explore and find at least 2 web APIs other than the Open Weather Map API we will be using for the assignment. Post a link to the documentation for each.

 

Read and respond to at least 3 classmates' posts.

Create an ERD in Visio for Vince's Vinyl.  Only this time assume that Vince doesn't sell used records.  He sells new ones.  He gets these from Vendors.  Therefore, quantity will come into play.

As we discussed in class....For the inventory table, write "view" above the table.  A view is stored sql.  (We'll get to that later).  For now, consider a view a table that is entirely dynamic - that is as an item is purchased for resale or sold to customers the inventory count will change automatically.  Inventory for a particular item is after all the difference the amount purchased and the amount sold.

The inventory view will connect to salesItem and purchaseItem tables.  In these tables you'll need price and quantity columns.   

Hint: SKU is what you want to use to describe an item.

Also you may want to use a compound primary key of PONUM, PO_Item for purchaseItems table & InvoiceNum, ItemNum for saleItem table.

Remember: You can design the ERD however you think best.  There are many ways to skin a cat, however, the design must work.  That is, it must model Vince's processes.

Exercises

1.  Database: AP 

Write a SELECT statement that returns three columns from the Vendors table: VendorContactFName, VendorContactLName, and VendorName. Sort the result set by last name, then by first name.

2.   Database: AP

Write a SELECT statement that returns four columns from the Invoices table, named Number, Total, Credits, and Balance: 

Number      Column alias for the InvoiceNumber column

Total          Column alias for the InvoiceTotal column

Credits       Sum of the PaymentTotal and CreditTotal columns

Balance      InvoiceTotal minus the sum of PaymentTotal and CreditTotal

a.   Use the AS keyword to assign column aliases.

3.   Database: AP

Write a SELECT statement that returns one column from the Vendors table named Full Name. Create this column from the VendorContactFName and VendorContactLName columns. Format it as follows: last name, comma, first name (for example, “Doe, John”). Sort the result set by last name, then by first name.

4. Database: AP  

Write a SELECT statement that returns three columns:

InvoiceTotal     From the Invoices table

10%                 10% of the value of InvoiceTotal

Plus 10%          The value of InvoiceTotal plus 10%

(For example, if InvoiceTotal is 100.0000, 10% is 10.0000, and Plus 10% is 110.0000.) Only return those rows with a balance due greater than 1000. Sort the result set by InvoiceTotal, with the largest invoice first.

5.   Database: AP

Modify the solution to exercise 2a to filter for invoices with an InvoiceTotal that’s greater than or equal to $500 but less than or equal to $10,000.

6.   Database: AP

Modify the solution to exercise 3 to filter for contacts whose last name begins with the letter A, B, C, or E.

7.   Database: AP

Write a SELECT statement that determines whether the PaymentDate column of the Invoices table has any invalid values. To be valid, PaymentDate must be a null value if there’s a balance due and a non-null value if there’s no balance due. Code a compound condition in the WHERE clause that tests for these conditions.

Hint: InvoiceTotal - PaymentTotal is the BalanceDue.

Another Hint: "where (<sql code>) or (<sql code>)

8.   Database: SPS

List all Customer info of all customers who have a 606 area code in their phone number.

9.   Database: SPS   

List all dogs which have a list price greater than $270.

10.  Database: SPS

List all birds with gold in their color.

Query 1: Use AP

Write a SELECT statement that returns all columns from the Vendors table inner-joined with the Invoices table

 

Query 2: Use AP

Write a SELECT statement that returns four columns:

VendorName: From the Vendors table

InvoiceNumber: From the Invoices table

InvoiceDate: From the Invoices table

Balance: InvoiceTotal minus the sum of PaymentTotal and CreditTotal

The result set should have one row for each invoice with a non-zero balance. Sort the result set by VendorName in ascending order.

 

Query 3: Use AP

Write a SELECT statement that returns three columns:

VendorName: From the Vendors table

DefaultAccountNo: From the Vendors table

AccountDescription: From the GLAccounts table

The result set should have one row for each vendor, with the account number and account description for that vendor’s default account number. Sort the result set by AccountDescription, then by VendorName.

 

Query 4: Use AP

Write a SELECT statement that returns five columns from three tables, all using column aliases:

Vendor           VendorName column

Date               InvoiceDate column

Number         InvoiceNumber column

#                      InvoiceSequence column

LineItem        InvoiceLineItemAmount column

Assign the following correlation names to the tables:

v                      Vendors table

i                       Invoices table

li                      InvoiceLineItems table

Sort the final result set by Vendor, Date, Number, and #.

 

Query 5: Use AP

Write a SELECT statement that returns three columns:

VendorID       From the Vendors table

VendorName From the Vendors table

Name             A concatenation of VendorContactFName and VendorContactLName, with a space in between

The result set should have one row for each vendor whose contact has the same first name as another vendor’s contact. Sort the final result set by Name.

        Hint: Use a self-join.

 

Query 6: Use AP

Write a SELECT statement that returns two columns from the GLAccounts table: AccountNo and AccountDescription. The result set should have one row for each account number that has never been used. Sort the final result set by AccountNo.

 Hint: Use an outer join to the InvoiceLineItems table.

 

Query 7: Use AP

Use the UNION operator to generate a result set consisting of two columns from the Vendors table: VendorName and VendorState. If the vendor is in California, the VendorState value should be “CA”; otherwise, the VendorState value should be “Outside CA.” Sort the final result set by VendorName.

 

Query 8: Use SPS
