Data  + Design : A simple introduction to preparing and visualizing information

Please read Chapter 1 before taking this quiz.

Data + Design: Basic Data Types

Submit

Individual Final Project

Assignment Overview:

Introduction:

In the Final Prep [External Trends and Marketing Analysis]  assignment you conducted an external analysis of bicycle sales trends and also identified some marketing strategies for this industry.  In the Final Prep [ Internal Demographics] assignment you examined Adventure Works customer demographics to try to identify what customer characteristics may lead to the greatest sales or profits.

In this final project, you will act as an analyst for the Marketing Manager of Adventure Works Cycles to make use of this interesting/significant information about current customers to help inform a marketing campaign in the Northwest and Southwest regions.

Make sure to read the online article MFinals: Read [Market Segmentation] before starting to create your customer segments.

Customer segmentation is the process of dividing customers into groups based on common characteristics so companies can market to each group effectively and appropriately.   

Focus on what you have learned about the Adventure Works customers to identify 2 customer segments based on criteria you discover that differentiates your current customers. You also need to justify your chosen customer segments based on the external industry trends and market analysis.   Using Adventure Works dimensions, measures and calculated fields, create charts and dashboards to illustrate your identified customer segments.  Also use dashboards to manage charts, text, images, links to sources that present a marketing strategy for each of these customer segements.

You will then make use of a Tableau Story to present your findings to the Marketing Manager and suggest a marketing campaign plan focused on those criteria that seem to differentiate your customers.  Should you focus on the best customers or the customers with highest potential to try to bring in more revenue?  Make your case in the story

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Identify 2 customer segments to assist with a targeted marketing campaign
    • Create a value-based customer segment using a calculated field to identify customers that contribute to the highest Sales Amount and/or Profit:  Gold/Silver/Bronze segment.
    • Create a demographic-based customer segment using a calculated field that will combine two or three demographic characteristics supported by the internal data and also supported by your external research.
  • Create other well-named calculated fields to extend the measures or dimensions that will be useful in your analysis of Adventure Works customers.
  • Use techniques such as filtering, sorting to narrow down the top customers in each of your customer segments for a targeted marketing campaign.
  • Add charts, text, images, links to Internet sources, and filters to create dashboards that should be used to justify and explain your customer segments.
  • Leverage external research on bicycle marketing strategy to suggest targeted marketing plans for each of your customer segments.
  • Organize a Tableau Story to explain your customer segments and marketing strategies to the Marketing Manager that could be used to inform a targeted marketing campaign.

Instructions:

Getting Started:

Step 1:  Open your Final Project workbook you started in the Final Prep: Internal Demographics assignment. 

Remember the user login information for the Adventure Works SQL Server data warehouse data source.

Server: bigdataa.ad.uvu.edu
Username: INFO4120
Password: Not2020!

Identify 2 Customer Segments:

As business data analyst for Adventure Works Cycle, you will be responsible for identifying 2 different customer segments and the criteria used to group customers into each of these segments. You must use calculated fields to identify these customer segments, rather than grouping, clustering or other means to determine these customer segments. 

One of these customer segments will be a value-based Gold/Silver/Bronze customer based on customers who bring in the most Sales Amount and/or Profit. 

The second customer segment you create must make use of actual customer demographic charts from your previous Final Prep assignment to help identify two or three characteristics that help to define and justify this segmentation. You will also need to make use of ideas gathered from your external industry trends and market outlook analysis to support this second customer segment. You will again use a calculated field to identify the customers in this demographic-based customer segment.

Using techniques you have learned this semester choose appropriate visualization charts, calculated fields, filters, sorting, and formatting to create worksheets and dashboards that identify, explain and justify your two customer segments.

Note:  Remember this is an individual project.  The customer segments, and organization of charts, calculated fields, etc. must be unique to you.

Create a Value-Based Customer Segment

Step 2.  Creating a value-based Gold/Silver/Bronze customer segment.

To get you started, the first customer segment you will create will be a value-based customer segment we will call the Gold/Silver/Bronze customer segment.  The range you set for Gold customers should be the very best customers, Silver customers are a step down from Gold, and Bronze customers are a step down from Silver.   You may choose to not include the lowest value customers in this segment.

You must use a single calculated field to identify the Gold/Silver/Bronze customer segment.  Do not create separate calculated fields for Gold, Silver and Bronze, but one Gold/Silver/Bronze calculated field.  Name the calculated field Gold/Silver/Bronze.

The value Measures (Sales Amount and/or Profit) and ranges of values you use to define this customer segment will be up to you to justify based on the which customers contribute to the highest Sales Amount and/or Profit. If you decide to include Profit as your value-based Measure, you will need to use a calculated field to add this to your Measures.

Suggestion: When deciding on the ranges for your customer segment, you may want to use a text table to order all customers by their Sales Amount or Profit and see where break points occur.  Make sure when you are identifying your Gold/Silver/Bronze segment you are filtering to only see customers in the Northwest and Southwest regions.   You will also probably want to use the DimCustomer Customer Key field to view customers as customer name fields are NULL for some customers.

Step 3.  Create a chart visualization to demonstrate your Gold/Silver/Bronze customer segment.

Create a chart visualization to make sure this value-based customer segment calculated field is working correctly.  Make sure to filter the chart to only show data from the Northwest and Southwest regions.  Apply sorting, filtering and formatting to your chart to make your visualization readable and understandable.

Provide a chart title that explains that this is the Gold/Silver/Bronze Customer segment.

Step 4.  Create a Text Table of your top Gold customers.

Create a Text Table chart showing contact information on your top Gold customers based on a value criteria that is important to the business.  You can show only Gold customers in this table by using a filter of your Gold/Silver/Bronze calculated field.  How may Gold customers can you afford to include in this campaign?  

In the Text Table, use the Customer Key together with the customer name ( some of which will be NULL), and other customer contact information useful for targeted marketing.

Make sure to show the value-based Measure (Sales Amount and/or Profit) as a filter so a user can choose how many of these Gold customers to show in the Text Table.

Provide a chart title that clearly explains the purpose of this Text Table.

Create a Demographic-Based Customer Segment

Step 5.  Creating a demographic-based customer segment.

As analyst, you must also identify one additional customer segment, based upon a combination of demographic characteristics of Adventure Works customers and also supported by your Internet industry trends and outlook research. You must use a calculated field to create this demographic-based customer segment.

Apply the KISS Principle:
Keep your demographic-based customer segment focused and based on two or three demographic criteria found in AdventureWorks data and also supported by your external research.  Do NOT combine too many attributes into this customer segment.  If you are trying to show correlations, adding too many attributes increases the permutation.  The easier it is to understand your customer segment, the more likely it will be to find and apply a good marketing strategy. An example of a demographic-based customer segment might be Women > 30 with no children.

This customer segment could be used to show characteristics of current customers, or to show characteristics that are missing in current customers that could be leveraged by targeted marketing to potential customers. You must use a calculated field to define this customer segment.  Do not use other techniques like grouping or clustering to create this segment.

Provide a meaningful name for this customer segment  and associated calculated field.  For example, a customer segment that selects females, with children at home > 0,  and according to external research showing that mothers are often concerned about safe bike riding, then you might call your customer segment : Safety Mom.

Step 6.  Create a chart visualization to demonstrate your second customer segment.

Show your demographic-based customer segment calculated field is working correctly by creating a chart visualization featuring this customer segment.  Make sure to filter the chart to only show data from the Northwest and Southwest regions.  Apply sorting, filtering, formatting, and a descriptive chart title to your chart to make your visualization of this demographic-based customer segment readable and understandable.

Step 7. Create a Text Table of your top customers in this second customer segment.

In a Text Table, use the Customer Key together with the customer name ( some of which will be NULL), and other contact information useful for targeted marketing.

In the chart, also show an additional business value-based Measure criteria as a filter so a user can choose how many customers to show. This value-based criteria might be something like Sales Amount, Profit , or Order Quantity.  

Provide a chart title that clearly explains how these customers were chosen

----------------------------------------------

Creating Dashboards for Explanation and Justification

Step 8.  Use dashboards to explain the two customer segments.

Gold/Silver/Bronze Dashboard: In this dashboard you should add charts, text and web URLs to demonstrate your Gold/Silver/Bronze customer segment.  You do not need to justify your Gold/Silver/Bronze segment with external research, but you do need explain how you chose which of the value-based criteria and range of values you used to create this segment.

Demographic-based customer segment Dashboard (use your meaningful segment name): In this dashboard you should add charts, text, images, and web URLs to demonstrate your demographic-based customer segment.  You should be able to explain your segmentation based on two or more demographic criteria in the Adventure Works data and also support your findings with information from your external industry trends and market analysis research.  

Customer Segment Dashboard Suggestions:
Use the following on your dashboards to explain and justify your customer segments:

  • Include chart(s) to illustrate your customer segment.
  • Add text, headings, images to help explain the customer segment.
  • You may quote pertinent sections of research source in a text area.
  • You may also add images to help explain or emphasize a point.
  • But you MUST make sure to include either a link and or web URL section to the evidence on a dashboard so the audience of the analysis can go to the source.

Create Dashboards to Present Marketing Strategies

Step 9.  Create a dashboard for each of your customer segments that proposes a marketing strategy.

Marketing Strategy Dashboard Suggestions:
Use the following on your dashboards to explain and justify the marketing strategy for each of your two customer segments:

  • Include the Text Table chart for the customer segment and show the filter so the user can narrow down the customers.
  • You may also include other related charts if they will help explain the marketing strategy.
  • Add text, headings, images to help explain the your marketing strategy. specific to the customer segment.
  • You may quote pertinent sections of  an Internet research source in a text area.
  • You may also add images to help explain or emphasize a point.
  • But you MUST make sure to include either a link and or web URL section to the external evidence to support your marketing strategy.

Note: The research you choose to use as support of your marketing strategy must be unique to your project.

Prepare a Marketing Campaign Story

You will make use of a Tableau Story to present your findings to the Marketing Manager of the Northwest and Southwest regions and suggest a marketing plan for each of your proposed customer segments.  Should you focus on the best current customers or the current customers with highest potential to try to bring in more revenue?  Make your case in the story. 

  1. The Story must contain at least 10 story points and no more than 15 story points.
  2. Keep the Story captions brief and concise.  Add additional Text areas if you need more explanation in a story point.
  3. First couple of story points should introduce the purpose of the analysis.
  4. Last few story points should make marketing recommendations specifically geared to each of your 2 customer segments and provide a conclusion.
  5. Do not waste story point with only text.  Support the text with charts, or evidence.  You have a limited number of story points," use them wisely".
  6. Explain the criteria you used to differentiate the value-based Gold, Silver and Bronze customers.
  7. Explain the criteria you used to differentiate the demographic-based customer segment ( use your meaningful name to refer to this segment).
  8. In the story points use of Worksheets, and Dashboards to explain your analysis , findings, research and marketing recommendations for each of the two customer segments.
  9. Provide filters, legends and controls where appropriate in Worksheets and Dashboards to allow the user to interact with the elements of the story.
  10. Format your Worksheets to use correct data formatting, use filtering, sorting and groups or sets to direct attention. 

---------------------------------------------

Potential Problems with this Analysis Project
(things that have caused student trouble in the past)

This is an Individual Project!!!  

While you may problem solve and share ideas with classmates, your charts, dashboards and story analysis in Tableau must be unique to you.  If your work is found to not be a unique solution, all students involved will receive a 0 on this assignment.

Some students have received a 0 score on this important project because they "shared" their entire project, or individual charts, customer segments, marketing strategies, external research with other students.  If your project has a very strong similarity in the charts, dashboards, calculated fields, or marketing strategies to another student, you will receive a 0 on the assignment.

Starting Late, Not Giving Enough Time and Effort:

Some students have waited until the last day or two to start the final project.  They ran out of time and did not have time to think through or refine their work.

The Final Prep assignments were created to help you start early on this project by doing the marketing analysis and also some work exploring the Adventure Works demographics ahead of time before beginning the final project.

Even with this preliminary work, the final project will take some time (shoot for around 10 hours, but may take longer.).  So be sure to not wait too late to get going.

Please ask for help if you are spinning your wheels or don't understand any of the steps or instructions.
Refer to the video overview for some guidance.

AdventureWorks DataSource - No Custom Queries or Datasource Filtering:

Do only the able joins on the AdventureWorks datasource  as described in the previous Final Prep assignment.  
Do NOT do any data source filtering, sorting or custom queries.  Your instructor needs to be able to ensure we are all working with the exact same data source when your work is evaluated.

Problems with Dates and Timelines - Don't use these in Customer analysis:

Because this Adventure Works data warehouse an older, artificial data warehouse made up by Microsoft, we have modified some of the date values to make them more current.  But there are still some problems with some of the dates. In this analysis you are being asked to do, we are interested in customer-related fields and values, not purchase trends, so stay clear of dates and timeline analyses.

Demographic-Based Customer Segment Too Complicated:

Apply KISS principles when creating and justifying the demographic-based customer segment.

Make sure the customer segment you defined is easy to understand and combines at most two or three criteria.  The ranges of values used for breakpoints or key values should be supported by the data and external research.  Explain and justify your decisions.

Some students in the past have just thrown together a laundry list of criteria: yearly income, marital status, number of children, gender, occupation, number of cars all in a single customer segment.  You can see first it would be impossible to manage the permutations of the values and ranges found in all these criteria.  Most importantly, it is not understandable, supportable with marketing strategies, and highly suspect as to its usefulness. 

Customer Segment Must be Supported by the Data:

The criteria you choose to use for defining a customer segment must be supported by the Adventure Works data and also external research.

For example, just saying that those with highest income are Gold customers could be a poor or misleading criteria for a customer segment if the data does not show this to be supported in sales or profit, two things the business cares about.

Another example, saying that Number of Children > 3 is criteria of a Prized Parent customer segment just because it sounds good, may not be supported by the data or external research.  Maybe those with 0 children bring in more sales or profit.

Show Evidence for External Sources:

You will be asked to find external sources to support your choices in your demographic-based customer segment and marketing strategies.  When you refer to these in your story, you must link to or show as web URL section in a dashboard.  You may choose to include short quotes from your sources.  Remember, you must provide the source of this citation with a link or web URL section.

You may also use images to illustrate your segmentation and marketing decisions.

Make Grading Easier (instructor is happy):

Please do NOT hide worksheets or dashboards in Tableau.
Use chart titles, text areas on dashboards, and very short captions in the story to explain and justify your decisions.

Submit Correct File Type (instructor is happy):

Make sure you submit a zip file of the entire project folder containing the Tableau workbook with the .twb extension and all graphics inserted into the story.
Do NOT submit a PDF file.
Do NOT submit just the Tableau workbook.
Do NOT submit a Tableau packaged workbook .twbx extension.

-----------------------------------------

Submission:

Submit your work as a zip file with your full name as in: JimBerryFinalProject.zip.  

No late projects will be accepted.

assignment_name: M14: Submit [Final Prep - Industry Trends and Marketing Strategies]
description:
Submit 

Final Prep - Industry Trends and Marketing Strategies

Assignment Overview:

Read the following article to prepare for this assignment:  M14: Read [How to Conduct a Marketing Analysis]

Know the Purpose of Your Analysis:

In the article How to Conduct a Market Analysis the Right Way, the first step of doing a Market Analysis is to 1) Determine the Purpose of Your Study. 

The Adventure Works company is a fictional online bicycle business.  In the upcoming Final Project you will be using the Adventure Works data warehouse to complete a data analysis for the Adventure Works Marketing Director of the Northwest and Southwest regions.  You have been asked to determine key current or potential customer segments and make recommendations for a targeted marketing campaign with a limited budget. 

This assignment will ask you to conduct some research on current Bicycle Industry Trends and Marketing Strategies for online Bicycle Shops.  This research will be incorporated into your Final Project.

This is an individual assignment and the specific articles, and summaries must be unique to you.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Conduct external research to uncover industry trends and outlook for use in the final project
  • Summarize the industry trends and outlook, and cite sources
  • Explore possible marketing strategies and tips for use in the final project
  • Summarize the marketing strategies and tips, and cite sources

Part A:  Find Biking Industry Trends 

Conduct some Internet research on the demographics of customers who are buying bicycles and trends of who are riding bicycles. Focus on recent bicycle sales or riding trends in the United States, and the Northwest and Southwest regions specifically. 

Adventure Works demographics for existing customers include: age, gender, marital status, income level, education level, location, commute distance, number of children, and number of children at home.  Focus your Internet research on these demographics related to who is buying bicycles and their riding trends in the Northwest and Southwest regions of the United States.

The goal is to find 4-5 online sources that show interesting trends and outlook in the online Bicycle industry related to the Adventure Works DimCustomer table customer demographics.  Show some breadth in your selections.  For example, don't have all your sources focus on Age.  

Some example search questions ( find your own trend questions) :
What are the age ranges of the best bicycle customers?
Has Covid 19 affected who is riding bikes? 
Are more families with young children riding bikes?
How to men differ in their bike buying habits from women? 
Do women focus more on bike safety?
Are bike commuters more likely to have lower income?  
Are people with college education more likely to wear helmets?
Do people buy more than one bike?
What age group are the largest bike riders in the Pacific Northwest?

Note: Adventure Works is a fictional business whose products do not include e-bikes or what are called “gravel” bikes.  While these are big trends in biking industry, with our existing data warehouse, these categories of bikes are not available, so please do not focus your Internet Search on types of bikes trending, rather focus on who is buying and riding bikes and what are their characteristics.

Summarize Your Industry Trends Findings:

In a Word file, provide a title and a link along with a paragraph or two summary and some short quotes or statistics for each article you have found.

Part B: Marketing Strategies and Tips for Bike Shops

Conduct some Internet research on most successful marketing tips or strategies for online bicycle sales for marketing managers.

The goal is to find 2-3 marketing strategies or tips based upon online sources that would be useful to an online bike shop marketing manager.  Show some breath in your selected marketing strategies.

Note:  In class this semester we have explored using digital marketing analysis tools like Google Analytics, but because this is not a real business with an e-commerce website or mobile app presence that we can interact with, please focus on finding articles that suggest more traditional marketing strategies like personalization, customer relationship marketing, referrals, social media, etc.

Some example search questions ( find your own marketing strategy questions) :
Would expert blogs be a way to attract customers to your online business?
How can customer demographics be used for targeted marketing of existing bicycle customers?
Can use of referrals work for an online bicycle shop?

Summarize Your Marketing Strategies:

Choose the best 2-3 sources you have found for marketing strategies/tips for online bicycle marketing managers. 

In the same Word file as used in Part A, provide a title, a link and a paragraph summary and some short quotes for each marketing strategy or tips article you have found. You will use this Internet research to support your marketing recommendations in your upcoming Final Project.  

Submission:

Save your Word file that contains your Part A:  4-5 Bicycle Customer Trends article summaries and your Part B:  2-3 Marketing Strategies article summaries with your initials as in: JimBerryFinalPrep.docx.  Submit this file by the assignment due date.

assignment_name: M04: Submit [GA2: Tracking Code and PageViews]
description:
Submit  

Google Analytics 2: Tracking Code and Page Views

Assignment Overview:

Google Analytics creates a unique code that allows tracking of pageviews and other events on your website.  This unique code is called the Traffic ID.

When you create a new Property in Google Analytics, this Traffic ID is generated.  A code snippet called the Traffic code is also generated for your website.  You will copy the Traffic code and place it on each page of your site. Google Analytics will update your website's Account traffic as users interact with your website.

In this assignment, you will create a MarioKart Stats Site.  Then you will create a new Account in Google Analytics and add the Traffic code to each page in your new MarioKart website.

Then we will generate some traffic on our site on the Internet and then view the traffic in the RealTime reports in Google Analytics.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Add Google Analytics Tracking Code to website pages
  • Create Pageview hits on website pages
  • View Pageviews and user tracking in Google Analytics

Instructions:

Part 1:   Upload MarioKart Stats to your Website

download the MarioKart Site zip file and extract its contents

mariokart_site.zip 

Open Github and launch your website in Visual Studio Code

Copy mariokart_site into visual studio code at the same level as your index.html page

Add the following line of code underneath the other page links so you can navigate between your site and your mariokart site

<a href="mariokart_site/">MarioKart Site</a>

 

Part 2:  Adding Tracking Code to Your MarioKart Site

Step 1. Sign into Google Analytics.

Go to http://www.google.com/analytics and under Sign In choose Analytics.
Note: Make Sure you are using the Google Account from the last assignment

Step 2. Create a new Google Analytics Property.

Once in Google Analytics, go to the Admin menu (left menu bottom gear icon),
Under Account choose: Create Property.  Choose Website. 
Set the Property Name to be mariokart_site. Click Next.
On the Business Information page select an Industry category, Business size, and GA categories.  Click on Create.

Now, you need to set up a data stream.  On this screen select Web.
Set the Website Name to also be mariokart_site.  Under Website URL choose https: and then set the URL to your mariokart site URL (without the https:// or the /index.html) so you will have for example ->  https://tylerbarty.github.io/TylersWebsite/mariokart_site/

Note your Measurement ID.  Click on the arrow next to Global site tag (gtag.js).  You will be shown the Tracking Code JavaScript snippet that includes your website Measurement ID (may be shown as gtag.js)  Copy this Website Tracking code snippet.

Step 3. Paste GA Tracking Code in your MarioKart Stats Site

Go back to your MarioKart Site in Visual Studio Code

paste the tracking code on every page of your mariokart_site under the first <head> tag

Step 4.  Commit Your Changes To Your Website

 

after waiting/checking that your site was pushed to Github, go to your site and make sure you can see the MarioKart Stats Site

Part 3:  Finishing Up

Step 1. Create some PageView hits on your MarioKart Site from Internet.

Open your MarioKart Site website from the Internet

Visit as many pages, using the back button, page refresh, completing and submitting the Contact Us form, Media Page, BI Visualization Page, etc.

You may consider reaching out to classmates and visiting each others sites page and going back and forth.  This will give you and your teammates Traffic/Pageviews.

Step 2.  Realtime->Overview Pageview Tracking in Google Analytics.

In Google Analytics, go the the left menu Real-Time icon (Clock icon) and choose Overview. You should see some Pageviews showing up in this report.

*** Take a screenshot of the Real-Time-> Overview report and paste it in a word file/google doc. Add a heading for the screenshot: Real-Time Overview Report. ***

Step 3. Engagement->Pages and Screens Tracking in Google Analytics.

Next go to theEngagement->Pages and Screens  report. Above the data area at the bottom of the report click on the Pageviews (last 30 min) link. 

***Take a screenshot of this report and paste it in the same Word file/google doc. Add a heading for the screenshot: Real-Time Pages Being Viewed. ***

Step 4.  Saving your Word file.

add your website url to your Word File / Google Doc with your initials as in: TJBTracking.docx

Submission:

 Submit the Word file with screenshots and screenshot headings before the due date. also include your website url

MAKE SURE YOU HAVE COMMITTED YOUR WEBSITE FILES TO YOUR GITHUB

Google Analytics 4: Using and Creating Reports

Assignment Overview:

This assignment will demonstrate how to do the following actions with Reports in Google Analytics:

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment, you will be able to:

  • Setting the Date Range on a report
  • Using Compare Dates on a report
  • Adding a Segment to a report
  • Adding a Secondary Dimension to a report
  • Using a Campaign URL Link for campaign tracking
  • Creating a custom report in Google Analytics

Instructions:

Modifying Existing Reports

Step 1.  Login into Demo Account
Login to your Google Analytics account.
Go to the Demo Account for the Google Merchandise Store, if it is not in your top left menu, you can select it by going to admin and selecting it there.

Step 2.  Comparing Date Ranges
Go to the Reports, in the life cycle section on the left, click Acquisition>Traffic Acquisition

in the top right, locate the date range, turn on the compare switch, then scroll down and hit custom

Set the blue Date Range to be August 15 -September 15 2022.
Set the yellow Date Range to be June 15-July 15 2022.

What is a problem that arises by comparing these two date ranges? notice that they do not compare number of days (june only has 30, july and august have 31)

Fix the date ranges to start both start on a Wednesday and end on a Friday.  This will make sure the days of the week are similar in both lines in the chart.

*** Take a screenshot of the Acquisition chart with these adjusted date ranges.
Paste the screenshot in a Word file. ***

Step 3. Fine-Tuning Reports in Google Analytics
Go to Reports > Life Cycle > Engagement > Engagement Overview

Adding New Comparison:
You can add comparison groups (segments of users or activities)

At the top of the report, click to Add Comparison.
Choose ad_frequency and include 2,3,4 and 8 (if you do not have ad_frequeny, just choose another metric)

Pages and screens now has the ad_freqeuncy comparison (in orange)

*** Scroll down just to show the table not the line chart. Take a screenshot of the modified Pages Report.  Paste the screenshot in your Word file. ***

Campaign Tracking

Step 1.  Add a Campaign Page to your Mario Kart Fan Site
Next, we will make use of Campaign links to track traffic from an email campaign.

First, we will be adding a new page to your BISampleSite.

Open your website files in Visual Studio Code.

download and add the following page to your mariokart site

Campaign.html 

COMMIT AND SYNC YOUR CHANGES TO YOUR GITHUB WEBSITE

Step 2.  Create the Campaign URL using a URL Builder
Next, we will use UTM codes to create a campaign link using a URL Builder tool.
A UTM (Urchin Tracking Module) a little bit of code appended to the end of a URL or link.

https://ga-dev-tools.appspot.com/campaign-url-builder/

Fill out the required fields (marked with *) in the form below, and once complete the full campaign URL will be generated for you.

Note: The generated URL is automatically updated as you make changes.

Website URL
https://tylerbarty.github.io/TylersWebsite/mariokart_site/Campaign.html
(use your own URL to your new Campaign.html page)
 
Campaign Source
email Newsletter
 
Campaign Medium
email

Campaign Name
INFO4120
 
Campaign Term
BI Campaign

Campaign Content
textlink
 
Copy the UTM link.
 
Step 3.  Send Yourself a Campaign Newsletter Email
Go to your email.  Send yourself a Campaign Newsletter email.  Create a link in your email and paste the UTM link as the link URL.
 
Send yourself the email.  Click on your campaign link.
This should open up your MarioKart Campaign page.
 
Step 4.  Check your Campaign Traffic in Google Analytics
Using the Admin menu option, change your Account in Google Analytics to be your Mario Kart Site.
Go to your Reports Snapshot, 
after what could take up to 24 hours, you will start to see something like this
*** Take a screenshot of this page and paste it into your Word file. ***

Creating a Custom Report

Creating a Custom Report

Step 1. Create a Custom Report
the Demo account does not allow for adding reports, so we will do this also in our BISample Site, but the data will not be as good
Still in your BISample Site, in the left navigation, Reports > Library then on the right side of the page there should be a "Create new report button "
Create overview report 
add 3 different type of cards to your table (pick different ones so that they are all not just bar charts)
click save
name your report : revenue by country (just for kicks)
do not worry about setting up to stream data

Step 2. Create New Collection.
Click create new collection
choose blank 
create topic, name it "Sales"
on the right hand column, choose Overview reports and search for your revenue by country report
drag and drop it into the sales topic
go back to the the library page, on your untitled collection, click the right hand 3 dots and click rename
rename collection to "Test Collection" and then click publish
you can now view your custom report, take a screenshot and upload that to your word document.

Submission:

Save your Word file with 4 screenshots and name the file with your initials as in: TJBReports.docx
Submit your Word file by the due date.

JavaScript 1: HighCharts

NOTE: You charts may differ from the video's charts, just change similar things. The professor know what all the charts look like, they will recognize your changes.

Assignment Overview:

In this assignment, we will explore a set of JavaScript and JQuery libraries called HighCharts.

What are HighCharts, HighStock and HighMaps?

Go to: http://www.highcharts.com/

HighCharts: A charting library written in JavaScript that offers an easy way to Interactive charts to a web site or to a web application. These charts work in all modern mobile and desktop browsers.
HighStock: Stock or general timeline charts to be used on the web with dynamically updated data and flags for key highlighting of information.
HighMaps: Interactive geo maps that can provide dynamic drown, rich information with click or tooltip.

If you want to use for your personal website, a school site, or non-profit organization you can download and use for free. You can also open the source under any license, free or not, and make your own edits.

HighCharts, HighStock and HighMaps take data in as a JavaScript array, which can be defined in the local configuration object, in a separate file, or even on a different site.

We will explore and modify some HighCharts and a HighMap using a code editor called JSFiddle.

 

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Preview a JavaScript set of libraries for data visualization
  • View the parts of a HighChart web page using JSFiddle
  • Edit the JavaScript, and HTML code of a HighChart visualization
  • Share your modified web page visualizations

Video Overview:  Introduction , Line Chart, Stacked Area Chart

Using JSFiddle for Editing:

Sign up for JSFiddle:
We will be editing the HighCharts in a tool called JSFiddle. The HighCharts demos are already integrated with JSFiddle.

To Sign Up for this tool, go to: https://jsfiddle.net/

This code editor can be used to write and edit HTML, CSS and JavaScript code is separate panels and then Run the code and view it in a Result panel. If you just want to run and test code, there is no need to save your fiddle files.

The files you create can be saved as a fiddle to your own library or you can share them. Your saved file will be given a unique URL. Updating an existing file will add a version number to the URL. You can collaborate on a fiddle file with another person, each making updates.

JavaScript code does not need to be wrapped in a <head> or <body> tag. HTML code does not need document level tags or a <body> tag.

 

Explorations with HighCharts:

Go to the HighCharts Demos: http://www.highcharts.com/demo

Line Chart with Data Labels:

Line Charts->Basic Line: Click the tabs to view different color themes. Hover mouse over point to see tooltip information.

Edit in JSFIDDLE:  

HTML: Notice that highchart scripts that are linked. Also a <div> tag is used to surround the container for the chart.

JavaScript: Change the title to include your name for the chart from text: ‘ Solar Employment Growth by Sector’   to text: “Kim’s Solar Employment Growth by Sector, 2010-2016”

Note: Change the ‘ ‘ to be “ “. Run to see the change.

The data is included in this source file. Notice the values for the X axis labels and Y axis labels.
Change the legend layout to layout: ‘horizontal’ and align: ‘center’ and verticalAlign: ‘bottom’ .
Run to see the legend layout position change.

Change the series data for Installation. Change the first value in the series from 43934 to 75000, the second value from 52503 to 40000. Run to see the change.  If you are satisfied with these changes, choose Save from the toolbar. Then to make this version the base version of your chart, choose Set as base from the toolbar.

Your account Your fiddles, you can see the fiddle you just saved. We will come back here to copy the URLs.

Return to: http://www.highcharts.com/demo

Stacked Area Chart:

Area Charts -> Stacked Area Chart
Click the tabs at the top of the chart to view different color themes. Hover mouse over point to see tooltip information.

Click the View Options Button to see the different ways this area chart could be configured. You can see the chart type, title, xAxis and yAxis labels, some tooltip and plotOptions. The data for each line is included in the file along with the names for the legend.
Close the preview window.

Edit in JSFIDDLE:

HTML: Add a style to the <div id="container> opening tag to include a red border around the container.

<div id="container" style="border: 2px solid red;">   Then Run to see this change.

JavaScript: Change the title of the yAxis to be ‘Billions and Billions’. In the xAxis change 1999 to be your birth year. Run to see the changes.

In the series for America change the name from America to be USA.   You may tweak some of the data values if you want. Run to see the changes.

If you are satisfied with these changes, choose Save from the toolbar. Then to make this version the base version of your chart, choose Set as base from the toolbar.

Return to: http://www.highcharts.com/demo

Video Overview: Bar Charts, Pie Charts, Gauge

Bar Chart with Negative Values:

Columns and Bar Charts-> Column with Negative Values:
Click the tabs to view different color themes. Hover mouse over point to see tooltip information.

Click the Dark UNICA tab.  Click the View Visual Theme Button: Notice each of these themes can be customized by changing the colors, backgroundColor, title formatting, xAxis and yAxis formatting, tooltip formatting, legend formatting, drilldown and navigation formatting, etc. Close the window. Go back to the Default tab.

Edit in JSFIDDLE:

JavaScript: In the xAxis, change the fruit names to be your favorite fruits. Notice if the fruit names are longer, it will automatically slant the alignment of the xAxis labels so they fit in the allowable width.

Change the name of the first series from John to your name-> ‘Kim’. Run to see change.
In your series of data, change the values, including negative, to reflect you views of these fruits.

If you are satisfied with these changes, choose Save from the toolbar. Then to make this version the base version of your chart, choose Set as base from the toolbar.

Return to: http://www.highcharts.com/demo

Pie Chart with Drilldown:

Pie Charts->Pie with drilldown:

Choose a theme from the tabs. Click on one area of the pie to drill down. Click the Back to Brands button to go back to the original pie.

Edit in JSFIDDLE:
Drag the left edge of the window to change the width of the Result panel to see the chart respond to the new width. 

JavaScript: In the series: Change the y value of Microsoft Internet Explorer from 7.23 -> 27.23. Change the y value of Chrome from 62.74 -> 42.74. The total of all these y values should be 100 %. Run to see the change.

If you are satisfied with these changes, choose Save from the toolbar. Then to make this version the base version of your chart, choose Set as base from the toolbar.

Gauge- Speedometer:

Gauges->Gauge Series  Speedometer

Notice the menu in the top right of the chart to Print the chart. Can also choose to Download as PNG, JEPG, PDF, or SVG file.

Edit in JSFIDDLE:

JavaScript: We will reverse the colors in the gauge, red being the bottom color and green the top color.

In the first plotBand, change the red -> green and third plotBand from green -> red.
In the first plotBand change the to value from 120 -> 60.
In the second plotBand, change the from value from 120 -> 60 and the to value from 160 to 120.
In the third plotBand, change the from value from 160 to 120. Run to see the change.

At the bottom of the JavaScript area, change the 3000 value to be 500. This changes the random update value from every 3 seconds to half a second.

If you are satisfied with these changes, choose Save from the toolbar. Then to make this version the base version of your chart, choose Set as base from the toolbar.

Return to: http://www.highcharts.com/demo

Video Overview: Spiderweb, HighMaps

Spiderweb:

More chart types-> Spiderweb
Tryout the various themes by clicking the tabs. Return to the default theme.

Edit in JSFIDDLE:

JavaScript: Modify the title from ‘Budget vs Spending’ to : ‘Budget vs Actual Spending’.
Change the category values from ‘Sales’ to ‘Donations’ and ‘Information Technology’ to ‘Security’

Change the last value in the series for Allocated Budget from 10000 -> 50000. Run to see the changes.

If you are satisfied with these changes, choose Save from the toolbar. Then to make this version the base version of your chart, choose Set as base from the toolbar.

Go to http://www.highcharts.com/maps/demo

HighMaps with Color Axis and Data Labels:

HighMaps Demos->General->Color axis and data labels

Edit in JSFIDDLE:

HTML: Notice that HighMaps make use of imported mapdata for example countries.

JavaScript:

In the JQuery function, the data for the map is a JSON file found at:

http://www.highcharts.com/samples/data/us-population-density.json

In the colorAxis change the minColor to be yellow and the maxColor to be blue.
Change the stops to be:

     [0, 'yellow'],
     [0.33, 'orange'],
     [0.66, 'green'],
     [1, 'blue']

Change the dataLables color from ‘#FFFFFF’ to ‘black’

Change the animation time from duration: 1000 to 3000.

If you are satisfied with these changes, choose Save from the toolbar. Then to make this version the base version of your chart, choose Set as base from the toolbar.

Integrate into Website for Submission:

Now that you have all your charts completed, the next step is to put them on your website for all to see!

The Following Video shows a walkthrough of how to add your JS Fiddle to a website, after you watch this, it is a part of the assignment for you to put all of your JS Fiddles on your site before submitting

 

This next Video Explains how to push all your changes on your site to Github to show up on your site,

I recommend that you have ported all your JS Fiddles to your code before attempting to push, so you only have to 

push your changes once.

Submit the link to your website for credit

Helpful Hint If your graphs don't show up correctly:

to make sure all your charts work, you will need to make sure you have all the right script source js files, otherwise your graphs may not show up correctly ( or show up at all!) replace your script files with the lines below, also they make not work if not in the right order.

JavaScript 2: JQWidgets

Assignment Overview:

In this assignment we will take a look at another JavaScript Visualization tool called JQWidgets.
Similar to the HighCharts libraries, the JQWidgets libraries allow you to add charts and other "widgets" or web controls like toolbars and drop down lists to a web page.  The charts have an animated feature as the web page displays.

The data source used in these JavaScript library charts can either be internal in the JavaScript code of the page or located in an external data source file.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Explore the JQWidgets charts and widgets
  • Modify charts and widgets to better understand the code and structure of the libraries

Instructions:

Part 1: Setting Up JQWidgets

Video: Getting Started with JQWidgets:

Getting Started Steps for JQWidgets:

Open Visual Studio Code.
We will be trying out some of the JQWidget demos and making some changes, similar to changes we made in the HighCharts demo files.

  • first open your website in vs code from the github window
  • open up your index.html page
  • paste the following lines of code under your <p> tag  (NOTE: The video tags may be out of date, the ones below are the correct ones)
<a href="jqwidgets-ver15.0.0/demos/Javascript%20%26%20JQuery/jqxchart/javascript_chart_combination_series.htm">Exercies Goals</a><br>

<a href="jqwidgets-ver15.0.0/demos/Javascript%20%26%20JQuery/jqxscheduler/scheduler-configure-scales.htm">Scheduler</a><br>

<a href="jqwidgets-ver15.0.0/demos/Javascript%20%26%20JQuery/jqxchart/javascript_chart_pie_series.htm">Desktop Browser Share</a><br>

<a href="jqwidgets-ver15.0.0/demos/Javascript%20%26%20JQuery/jqxtoolbar/javascript-toolbar-events.htm">Toolbar Tools</a><br>

<a href="jqwidgets-ver15.0.0/demos/Javascript%20%26%20JQuery/jqxdragdrop/defaultfunctionality.htm">Drag and Drop Functionality</a><br>
  • next download the zip folder below, unzip and stick inside your github repository at the same file level as your index.html
    • jqwidgets-ver15.0.0.zip 

You should now be able to view your website per

Part 2:  Explorations in JQWidgets

Combination Chart

in Visual Studio Code, open Combination Series Chart: jwidgets-ver15.0.0/JQWidgets/demos->Javascript&JQuery->jqxchart->javascript_chart_combination_series.htm
This combination series chart combines an area chart with a stacked column bar chart.
In Visual Studio Code, the sampleData is again an array.  This time an additional field has been added to each series, the goal value.
Modify the Goal for each day to be 60.
Modify the Title of the chart to include your name.
Save Your Changes

Scheduler

in Visual Studio Code, open Scheduler: jwidgets-ver15.0.0/JQWidgets/demos->Javascript&JQuery-> jqxscheduler->scheduler-configure-scales.htm

The jqxScheduler widget can display a set of Appointments in Day, Week, Month, Timeline Day, Timeline Week and Timeline Month views.
Select a range of cells on the calendar, right-click to make a new appointment and Save the appointment.
In VS Code, in the code editor,  notice the data type of the data is json.  The input is formatted as a json string.
Near the bottom of the <script> add a view for month:
    { type: "monthView", showWeekends: true, timeRuler: { scale: "quarterHour" } }
Add the comma before but not after this added view.

You should now see month button added to the scheduler.   Click on the month button. Add a new appointment.  Uncheck all day and see you can schedule to the quarter hour. 

Save Your Changes

 

Pie Chart

in Visual Studio Code, open Pie chart: jwidgets-ver15.0.0/JQWidgets/demos->Javascript&JQuery->jqxchart->javascript_chart_pie_series_legend.htm
You should see the Pie chart with a legend.
In VS Code, notice the source data type is csv. 
        url: '../../sampledata/desktop_browsers_share_dec2011.txt'

Change the chart title to be 
In VS Code, open jwidgets-ver15.0.0/JQWidgets/demos->sampledata->desktop_browsers_share_dec2011.txt
Change the Internet Explorer from 33.3 to 23.3
Change the Chrome browser from 25.4 to 35.4
Save Your Changes


Change the Title to to be Desktop Browser Share.
Change the colorScheme from 'scheme03' to 'scheme01'
Save Your Changes

 

Toolbar Tools

In Visual Studio Code, open Toolbar Tool Events: jwidgets-ver15.0.0/JQWidgets/demos->Javascript&JQuery->jqxtoolbar-> javascript-toolbar-events.htm
This toolbar has a set of tools the user can manipulate: width, height, shape and a color picker.
In VS Code, the jqxToolbar defines the tool types as input, input, dropdownlist, custom.
Each tool has its own case in the case statement. 
We are going to change the default color in the color picker tool in case 3 when the page loads to 00FF00, green.
After the cases, find the colorPicker.jqxColorPicker,  change the color: "0F2B70" to color: "00FF00"
Find the tool.jqxDropDownButton hex: "0F2B70" to hex: "00FF00"
In the <body> tag, find the <div id="shape"> change the background-color:##0F2B70; to background-color:#00FF00;

Save Your Changes

Drag and Drop Functionality

In Visual Studio Code, open Drag and Drop: jwidgets-ver15.0.0/JQWidgets/demos->Javascript&JQuery->jqxdragdrop->defaultfunctionality.htm

This example shows some images as objects that can be dragged and dropped into a Shopping Cart of an order.
In VS Code, notice the style sheet defines presentation of the areas on the page.
In the <script> notice the array of products. 
Change the product names to be shirt names you want.

Save Your Changes

Submission:

Make sure to push your changes to github

if you happened to not click commit and push, and just clicked the big commit button, don't worry down at the bottom of the page there is a commit button (the sync icon) click there and it will push your changes to your website

 

submit the link to your website for points

Advanced Assignment: Looker Studio Dashboard Project

NOTE: Google Recently Changed Data Studio to Looker Studio, as that is all that is different the video may mention Data Studio, they are functionally the same thing, so do not let this trip you up

Assignment Overview:

In this advanced assignment, you will be creating a Looker Studio dashboard report using one of the Sample datasets available.  You will have some requirements to meet, but you will be able to choose the dataset of most interest to you and format the report as you wish.

This is an individual assignment, so your dashboard report must be unique to you and different from the Audience Overview report you created using the Google Merchandise Store sample dataset.

Assignment Objectives: 

After completing this assignment you will know how to:

  • Create a new Looker Studio dashboard with a sample dataset
  • Explore the metrics and dimensions in the dataset
  • Find at least one image to include on the dashboard
  • Implement at least 5 different chart types to include in the dashboard
  • Add a Date Range and at least two other controls to the dashboard
  • Share the dashboard report with your instructor

Instructions:

 

Advanced Assignment: Dashboard Project (Video Overview)

Step 1. Create a new report in DataStudio. 

Choose of  one of the Sample Data Sources in DataStudio: [Sample] YouTube, [Sample] World Population,  [Sample] Google Ads, or [Sample] AdWords.  Do Not use the sample Google Analytics dataset we have used for the Merchandise Store.  Choose one of these other sample datasets. Title you Dashboard report with your full name as in: Kim Bartholomew World Population.

Step 2.  Explore the dimensions and metrics in your dataset.  

You can use a Table chart and other chart types and drop down list controls to explore the dimensions or metrics of your dataset.

Step 3. Dashboard chart requirements.

Make use of at least five different chart types. 
In addition, you will need to add a second chart of the same chart type with different fields.  For example, use two pie charts, or two maps.

Step 4.  Dashboard control requirements.

Make use of at least three different controls to add capability for use interaction on your dashbord report such as: Date Range, Drop-down list, Advanced Filter, etc.

Step 5.  Make use of design elements on your dashboard.

You must add the following features to the dashboard to create a more visually appealing dashboard:

  • Add at least one text area,
  • Add one or more images 
  • Add one or more shapes.

Step 7.  Fine-tune your report.

View your report to make sure it is readable, and presents some insight to your dataset.
Try out the controls to make sure they allow the user to interact with the data.

Step 8.  Share your dashboard report with you instructor.

Share your dashboard report with your instructor using the Invite people option.
Choose to allow Edit permission for your instructor.
Use your instructor's gmail address for the share link: tyler.barty@gmail.com.

Submission:

Make sure your report title includes your full name.
Make sure you have shared your report with your instructor using the Invite people option.

Use your instructor's gmail to share the report: tyler.barty@gmail.com.

submit a link to your Looker Studio dashboard

Your instructor will view the dashboard report you have shared and grade this assignment.

assignment_name: M15: Submit [ Final Prep- Explore Internal Demographics] - Video
description:
Submit

Final Prep - Explore Internal Demographics

Assignment Overview:

"Know your Customer!"  The purpose of this assignment is to help you get started on your Final Project analysis by asking you to explore the Adventure Works data warehouse customer demographic data so you can learn about the current Adventure Works customers. 

In this assignment, you will specifically examine Adventure Works customer demographic fields to determine what customer characteristics (demographics) contribute to the most Sales Amount or Profit (would need to be a calculated field if used). These two measures could be referred to as "value" metrics.

You will use this internal customer demographic information from this Final Prep assignment along with the external Industry Trends and Marketing Analysis you conducted in your first Final Prep assignment to help inform your Final Project analysis and reporting.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Start the Final Project Tableau workbook with the correctly structured Adventure Works data source
  • Examine the DimCustomer table, customer-specific dimensions and customer-specific measures to better understand what demographics show better Sales and/or Profit
  • Change customer measures that should not be aggregated to be dimensions
  • Filter all visualizations according to the required Sales Territory Regions: Northwest and Southwest regions.
  • Create visualizations to demonstrate key customer demographics with relation to SalesAmount and/or Profit

Instructions:

Final Prep: Explore Internal Demographics (Video Overview)

Part A: Setting Up your Final Project Tableau Workbook

Step 1.  Open your Tableau 2 Workbook.

You may start with your Tableau2 Assignment workbook for the SQL Server data source and table joins you already have done. 

You will be asked to login to the data source when you open the workbook. Note: The SQL Server login information has changed since the video overview was done.  Please use the login informtion found below.

Server: bigdataa.ad.uvu.edu
Database: AdventureWorksDW2019
Select the radiobutton: Use a specific username and password
Username: INFO4120
Password: Not2020!

In the Data Source, your Adventure Works table joins should be as shown in Fig. 1 below:

 Fig. 1.  AdventureWorks DW table structure

Step 2.  Do a Save As to rename your Tableau 2 Workbook.

Once you are in the workbook, you should do a Save As on your Tableau 2 workbook and save it with your initials as in: KBFinalProject.twb. 

Step 3.  Close data sources that are not needed.

Go to your first sheet in the workbook, in the Data pane in the upper left corner, you will see listed the data sources that were used in the Tableau 2 assignment.  We want to keep the only the FactInternetSales(AdventureWorksDW2019) data source.  Right-click and choose Close for each of the other data sources.

Step 4.  Delete sheets used in Tableau 2 assignment.

You can then delete the sheets from the Tableau 2 assignment.  Then you are ready to start your Final Prep assignment with the Adventure Works data source loaded and working.

Part B: Examine Adventure Works Measures and Dimensions

The main focus of your Final Project will be to act as an analyst of Adventure Works Cycles working for the Marketing Manager of the Southwest Region and the Northwest Region. 

In this Final Prep assignment, you have been asked to find out which of the Adventure Works customer demographics, found in the DimCustomer table, contribute to the most Sales and or Profits (Profit this measure would need to be calculated).  Do not spend time analyzing products or different regions. 

Examine Adventure Works Measures and Dimensions:

To get an initial understanding of the Dimensions and Measures related to customer demographics.  These Dimensions and Measures are located in the DimCustomer table.  

Step 1.  Change DimCustomer Measures to be Dimensions.

The Measures found in the DimCustomer table are numeric fields that should not have aggregated functions applied to them. For example, the Yearly Income should not have SUM(Yearly Income) applied to it because this would sum the Yearly Income for all the customer's orders. 

One way to prevent inappropriate aggregation applied to numeric fields is to change these Measures to Dimensions.

Change each numeric Measures found in the DimCustomer table to a Dimension, by right-clicking on the Measure and choosing Convert to Dimension.

Step 2.  Explore Customer Dimensions with chart visualizations.

Examine the DimCustomer Dimension fields. Many of these fields could be considered customer "demographics".  Some examples would be English Occupation, English Education, and Gender.  These fields will allow us to explore the internal customer demographics to find characteristics of our best Adventure Works customers.

In your workbook, use worksheets to create chart visualizations to help find which of the many Customer Dimensions/demographics show clear differences between the best customers, and not so good customers based on SalesAmount or Profit.  

Important: Also make sure the data you are looking at in your charts is filtered by the correct SalesTerritory Regions: Northwest and Southwest Regions only.  

You may create calculated fields to extend the available Measures and Dimensions.  For example, there is no Age Dimension in the data set, but there is a BirthDate field.  It would be easier for the audience to compare customer Ages on a chart or table than have to make the conversion of a BirthDate in their head.

Step 3.  Choose the 5 - 6 charts that clearly show "best" customers.

Narrow down your worksheets to the  5 - 6 charts that show you understand which of the Customer Dimensions/demographics show clear differences in customer characteristics based on the "value" metrics of SalesAmount or Profit.

Delete worksheets where the chart does not help differentiate between the most valuable customers and those who are not so valuable.

For example: If you created a chart of SalesAmount by Number of Children at Home and there are not any clear differences in SUM(SalesAmount) for the different Number of Children at Home, that Dimension/demographic should probably not be one you hang your hat on. You should delete that worksheet from your workbook.

Step 4.  Fine tune charts to make them readable and understandable.

Make sure you choose an appropriate chart type, add labels, add formatting of axes values and labels, set appropriate titles and sheet labels to support your analysis of what characteristics help identify who are the most valuable Adventure Works customers based on SalesAmount or Profit.

-----------------------------------

Potential Problems  with this Final Prep Project
(things that have caused student trouble in the past)

This is an Individual Project!!!  

Your work for this Final Prep assignment must be unique to you.  If your work is found to not be a unique solution, all students involved will receive a 0 on this assignment.

Adventure Works DataSource - No Custom Queries or Data source Filtering:

Do only the database joins on the Adventure Works datasource  as described in the Adventure Works data sources Instructions section above.  
Do NOT do any filtering or sorting or custom queries on the data source itself.  Your instructor needs to be able to ensure we are all working with the exact same data source when your work is evaluated.

Problems with Dates and Timelines - Don't use these in Customer analysis :

The FactInternetSales.OrderDate and FactInternetSales.OrderDate field values are not current dates. We are interested in DimCustomer, customer-related fields and values, not purchase trends over time, so stay clear of dates and timeline analyses. Instead focus analysis of customer characteristics that do not involve dates or trends over time.  The only date that is probably safe to use is BirthDate.

Submit Correct File Type (instructor is happy):

Make sure you submit a Tableau workbook with the .twb extension.
Do NOT submit a PDF file.
Do NOT submit a Tableau packaged workbook .twbx extension.

-----------------------------------------

Submission:

Submit your work as a Tableau Workbook file with your initials as in: TB_FinalPrep.twb.  
No late Final Prep projects will be accepted.

assignment_name: M05: Submit [Assign 2: Google Chrome Tag Assistant]
description:
Submit 

Google Analytics 5: Google Chrome Tag Assistant

Assignment Overview:

Google Tag Assistant is a Chrome Extension that can be used to help you verify that you have installed various Google tags correctly on your page. When you navigate to any web page that has Google Analytics Tracking code or gtag.js codes embedded, Google Tag Assistant will tell you which tags are present, report any errors found and suggest improvements that can be made to your implementation.

Use Google Tag Assistant Recording to record a typical user flow to and through your website and instantly validate, diagnose, and troubleshoot issues with your Google Analytics implementation.

Note:  This assignment is dependent upon your completion of GA2 assignment where events were added the Google Analytics Tracking code snippet to each page on your BISampleSite website.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Add the Google Chrome Tag Assistant Extension in Chrome Browser
  • Set needed Options for Google Chrome Tag Assistant
  • Begin a Recording in Google Chrome Tag Assistant
  • Record a pre-planned path through a website
  • Examine the Google Tag Assistant Report to uncover problems with Google Tracking codes
  • Demonstrate use of Google Tag Assistant

Instructions: 

Step 1. Adding Google Tag Assistant Extension

Click here to Get Tag Assistant Companion

it should look like the Image below, if it has legacy in the name, then you have the wrong one (just search on the chrome web store for the right one)

 

Go to the URL above, add Google Tag Assistant extension to your Chrome Browser.
Once added, Chrome will show you a message that the extension was successfully added.
Notice, the blue icon that will appear on your Chrome toolbar (I had to click on the extension icon and then pin the Google Tag Assistant icon to the Chrome toolbar to get it to stay showing.)

Clicking on this blue icon will open the Google Tag Assistant for the current page.

Step 2.  Enable Google Chrome Tag Assistant

after installing Tag Assistant, click on the extension, it will open in a new tab

grab your website URL and paste it in the spot and click connect.

NOTE on Tag Manager Icon Color

you may notice that you get a blue or green or yellow or red circle when launching tag manager, or even weirder, some random emoji like a dragon or a donut, just know that these are if you have multiple tabs open, you will know what tag references which tab.

Step 3.  What does Google Chrome Tag Assistant Track?

One Google Analytics tag should show up for your Homepage.  Under the tag you should see the Tracking ID for your BISampleSite website tied to a Google Analytics Account, you may have links for UA (universal analytics or Google Analytics)

you will see everything tracked in the left hand side, everything loaded, scrolled, linked etc.

Step 4.  Path for Page Visits

Complete the following steps:
      Go to the ContactUs page.
      Enter some information in the form and click Submit.
               (This should show the Thank_You page)
      Go to the Partners page.
      Go to your Media page.
      Go to your BI_Visualizations page
      Go to the Home page.
      Click the blue tag in the toolbar to open Google Tag Assistant and click the red Stop Recording button.

Step 5.  View Entire Summary and save work

you can click on summary in the tag assistant to see everything that has happend, including the tab on the right of the screen that helps you find any errors that are happening in your page. take a screenshot of your summary page

Step 6. Save all your work

take screenshots of your session (scroll through the left pane) and place them on a word doc for submission

Summary: 

The Google Tag Assistant extension for Chrome allows a marketer or analyst to view the Google Analytics tags on website pages to see if they are correctly formatted, and if they are tracking correctly on the site.  The Tag Assistant also allows you to record a sequence of pages and actions on the website and then view the recorded report for details on tags, events and other details of the website tags.

More information about the Google Tag Assistant can be found at this Help site:

https://support.google.com/tagassistant#topic=6000196 (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.

Submission:

Upload your Tag Assistant report document (your document with screenshots) before the due date and time include your website url.

assignment_name: M06: Submit [GTM1: Setting Up Google Tag Manager]
description:
Submit 

Google Tag Manager 1: Setting Up Google Tag Manager

Assignment Overview:

Google Tag Manager (GTM) is a tool that allows consolidating of website, and mobile analytics tagging into a more manageable format.

In this assignment we will create an account in GTM and connect it to our mariokart site

We will learn how to create tags, triggers and use variables to track Youtube Video usage, Form Submission, and links like an email link on your website.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Create an Account in GTM
  • Add the GTM two Tracking Code Snippets to a website
  • Add variables to a GTM Container
  • Add a Click Listener to your GTM Container
  • Connect your GTM Account to a new Google Analytics Account
  • View tags and triggers on web pages using the GTM Debugger

Instructions:

Creating an Account in GTM

Step 1.  Create an account in Google Tag Manager.

Go to your Google Analytics and Sign In to your account.

 In the upper right corner by the ? Help Menu, click on the 4 squares icon to Switch products.  Choose Google Tag Manager.


Step 2:  Add an account in GTM.

Click the blue link Create Account.  Set the Account name: MarioKartSiteGTM. 
Click Continue.
The Container name will also be: MarioKartSiteGTM.  Choose Web.
Click Save.

You can create different containers in the same account, but we will just use the one container.

Setup a New MarioKartGTM Website

Note: your mariokart site will stay the same, but we will be changing the google tags in it.

From now on your MarioKart website will be referred to as MarioKart GTM

Step 1.  Finding the GTM Tracking Code snippets.

In the GTM Overview Page, in the menu click on the blue link with your GTM-XXXXXXX Tracking Code. 

Notice there are two Tracking Code snippets we will need to copy to our website pages for GTM.

Step 2.  Copy the two GTM Tracking code snippets to Every .HTML Page (Replacing the Old Google Tracking Codes)

Next open your mariokart_site/index.html file in Visual Studio Code.

Go back to GTM and copy the first Tracking code snippet again.
Just below the <head> tag copy the GTM code snippet. (Replacing the Old Google Tracking Codes)

Go back to GTM and copy the second Tracking code snippet.

Just below the <body> tag copy the second GTM code snippet. (Before the Container Tag)

Save the index.html page and repeat for each webpage that you have.

Step 3.  Commit and Push Your Changes to Your Github Site

Adding Variables in GTM

Step 1.  Create an new Google Analytics MarioKartSiteGTM. account.

If you still do not have a Google Analytics tab, Click on your website project name on the top of the screen and right click on the google analytics logo to open an new tab to Google Analytics.

Go to the Admin menu. Create a new Account.
Set the Account name to be: MarioKartSiteGTM.

Website URL:
In your browser, go to your mariokart home page.

Set the website URL to be the home page of your new MarioKartSiteGTM.
Remember in the http/https  dropdown, to change to https://  Also remove the / from the end of the URL.

for example: my website is https://tylerbarty.github.io/TylersWebsite/  so I would fill out the field as tylerbarty.github.io/TylersWebsite

In your new Account, under Property Tracking ID, copy just the Google Analytics Tracking ID.

Step 2.  In GTM, Set a GA Settings to connect GA4

To create a Google Analytics 4 Configuration tag:

  1. Click Tags > New.
  2. Click Tag Configuration.
  3. Select Google Analytics: GA4 Configuration.
  4. Paste in your measurement ID
  5. in the top left Name your tag MarioKart GTM
  6. Click in the triggering section
  7. Click All Pages - Page View

Click Save.

Step 3.  Configure needed Built-In Variables in GTM.

GTM has a set of Built-In variables we can use as we create tags and triggers.

We will turn on ALL the Build-In Variables so they will be visible if we need them.

Click Variables from the GTM left menu.  Click the Configure button.
Check all the boxes to Configure the Build-In Variables.

Step 4.  Add a Click Listener Tag in GTM.

When users do a Pageview on your website, this Click Listener will send a Hit event back to Google Analytics.  We will have a PageURL and other information that we can use to track these Pageviews.

In GTM, click the Tag option in the left menu.  Click the New button.
Name the tag: Click Listener Tag. 
Click the Tag Configuration.  Choose Google Analytics:GA4 Event

Click Triggering (below)
Check All Pages.

Click Save.

NOTE: you must also submit your changes to your Google Tag Manger (see picture below)

you do this on the tag manager home screen

Using the GTM Tag Assistant

Step 1. Using GTM Preview mode and the Tag Assisant (GTM Debugger)

In GTM in the top menu, click the Preview button.

you will now need to connect Tag Assistant to your site, add your website url and click connect.

go back to the  tag assistant tab and you will see that your tag fired

*** Take a screenshot of a page on your website with the Tag Assistant showing.  Paste the screenshot in a Word file. ***

Step 2.  View GTM Page Views in Google Analytics.

Because we have tied our GTM Tag to the Google Analytics Tracking code of our new Account, when we do Pageview events on the website, these are tracked also in our Google Analytics account.

Visit several pages on your MarioKart website. you also visit on your phone to give more traffic to your site (you could even have a friend or family member visit it on their computer/phone)

Go to your MarioKartGTM Google Analytics account.  In the Reports -> Realtime, click to see the last 30 minutes. be patient, it could take awhile for traffic to start showing up.  You should see all the pages you viewed.

***Take a screenshot of this Real-Time Overview report.  Paste the screenshot in your assignment Word file***

Submission:

Save your Word file with your two screenshots:  the screenshot of the Tag Assistant and a screenshot of the Real Time Report.  Name the Word file with your initials as in: TJB_GTM.docx.

Submit your Word file before the due date.

assignment_name: M06: Submit [GTM2: Setting GTM Triggers and Tags]
description:
Submit

Google Tag Manager 2:  Setting Triggers and Tags in GTM

NOTE: This assignment is meant to be completed after Google Tag Manager First assignment, complete that one before proceeding here.

Assignment Overview:

There are many ways you can set up all of the various elements of your Google Tag Manager Workspaces and Containers.  We will create tags, and triggers to allow us to track YouTube Video usage, Form Submission, and Email link clicks.

In order to function, all tags have to have a trigger assigned to them.  Think of triggers like a tripwire that sets a tag we can track in Google Analytics.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Create a tag and trigger for a Youtube video progress on a website with GTM
  • Create a tag and trigger for tracking a form submission event on a website with GTM
  • Create a tag and trigger for an email link click even on a website with GTM
  • View GTM events in Google Analytics using Real-Time reports

Instructions

GTM1: Tags and Triggers in GTM (Video Overview)

Tracking Youtube Video Events with GTM

This example of setting up Youtube Video tracking will make use of triggers, variables and tags.  When a user comes to your landing page and clicks on your video, the trigger tells Google Tag Manager that someone has carried out an action worth tracking.  We will create two different triggers and a tag.

Step 1. Creating Youtube Video Start Trigger.

In GTM, click click the Trigger from the left menu. Click the New Button

Name the trigger: Trigger-Video Start.
Click Trigger Configuration.  Select User Engagement->YouTube Video.

We will only capture the Start event in this trigger.
Click the Start option.
Click to Add JavaScript API support to YouTube videos
Click Some Videos.

Fire this trigger when an Event...

Choose Page URL  contains  Media.html
Save the trigger.

Step 2.  Creating the Youtube Video Progress Trigger.

Add another New Trigger

name the trigger: Youtube Progress Trigger

Click the Trigger Configuration. Choose User Engagement->Youtube Video.

Check Complete and Progress.

Set the Percentages to be: 25, 50, 75, 100

Check Add JavaScript API support to all Youtube videos

Choose Some Videos

Save your trigger

Next we will set variables to allow this event tracking.

Step 3.  Create the Youtube Video Tag.

We are assuming all the Build-In variables are already checked from the previous GTM assignment.

Click Tags in the left GTM menu.  Click the New button.

Name the tag: GA-Video Tracking Tag.

Click in the Tag Configuration.

Choose  the tag type to be Google Analytics: GA4 Event

Select your previous Google analytics configuration tag

set Event name as  {{Page Hostname}} (include the double brackets on each side)

in the triggering section add Trigger-Video Start and Youtube Progress Trigger (note that these are the triggers that you just created)

click save.

Step 4.  Test your Youtube Video Tag and Triggers.

In GTM we will use the Preview and Debugging features of GTM to make sure our tag and triggers are working.  Click the Preview button at the top of your GTM Workspace. 

Using the Chrome Browser, view your MarioKartGTM website from the Internet.  You should now see the bottom half of the web page has the Tag Assistant Connected.

Go to the Media.html page.

Click on the Play button for the Youtube Video.  In the Tag Assistant Tab, you should now see that the Video Tracking Tag has fired.  Drag the video play until just before it finishes.  Allow the video to finish.

note that you have another user engagement in the tag assistant.

Take a screenshot of your tag assistant and paste it in a word file

in your Tag manager, submit your changes this far

Close Tag assistant and visit your website and play the video an incognito tab

Go to your MarioKartGTM Google Analytics account.  In Reports> Realtime there is an Events card you should see three Video events: start, progress and complete. to get more stats up, consider pulling out your smartphone or having a friend or a roommate or a family member visit your website

Take a screenshot of the events card in Reports>Realtime.  Paste the screenshot in a Word file.

Tracking Form Submission Events

For some businesses, form submission events are an important conversion event.  We will use GTM to help track when the user completes a form on our MarioKartGTM.

Step 1.  Creating a Form Submission Trigger.

In GTM, click the Trigger from the left menu.
Click the New button.

Name the Trigger: Trigger-Form Submission.

Click the Trigger Configuration.  Choose User Engagement->Form Submission.

Check for Check Validation.

Enable this trigger when...
Page URL contains  ContactUs.html.

Click Save.

Step 2.  Create the Form Submission Tag.

In GTM, click on Tag in the left menu.

Name the tag: GA-Form Submission Tag.

Click Tag Configuration.  Choose Google Analytics: GA4 Event

Select your configuration tag that you have made before.

Set event name to be {{Page Hostname}}

Set the Triggering (below)

Choose your Trigger-Form Submission

Click Save.

Step 3.  Test your Form Submission Tag and Triggers.

In GTM, Refresh the Previewing Workspace by clicking on the orange Refresh link.
