In Chrome, go back to your MariokartGTM website on the Internet.

Go to the Contact Us page.  Complete the Contact Us form.
Hold the Ctrl key and click the Submit button. 
This will open the Thank You page in a new tab and allow us to see the tags fired when the form was submitted.  Go to the Contact Us tab.  In the GTM Debugger you should see that the GA-Contact Us Form tag fired.

Go to your MarioKartGTM Google Analytics account.  In Reports> Realtime look for the events card you should see one Form Submission event

Take a screenshot of this Real-Time Events report.  Paste the screenshot in a Word file.

Tracking an Email Link Click Event

If you want to keep track of links users might click on and maybe track these as micro conversions on your site.  You can set up this tracking in GTM.  We will set up a click on an email link as an event through a tag.

Step 1.  Creating the Email Link Trigger.

Name the trigger: Trigger-Email Link

Set the Trigger Configuration to be Click->Just Links.

Check the Wait for Tags 2000 milliseconds.

Enable this trigger when Page URL  + matches RegEx   +  .*  (this will match all pages) see below for reference

Select Some Links
Fire this trigger when an event...

Page URL   contains   mailto:

Click Save.

Step 2.  Creating the Email Link Tag.

In GTM, click the left menu Tag.

 

Name the tag: GA-Email Link Click Tag

Click Tag Configuration.  Select Google Analytics- GA4 Event

click your configuration tag

event name set as {{Page Path}}

Set Triggering (below)

Choose Trigger Email Link

Click Save.

Step 3.  Test your Email Link Click Tag and Triggers.

In GTM, restart your preview from tag manager

In Chrome, go back to your MarioKartGTM website on the Internet.

Go to the Media page.  In the footer of the page, click on the mario@mushroomkingdom.com  link.   

In the GTM Debugger you should see that your GA-Email Link Click Tag was fired.

Close your Tag manager and submit your changes, view from mobile device or from incognito window

Go to your MarioKartGTM Google Analytics account.  In the Real-Time->Events report you should see one Mailto Link: click event.

***Take a screenshot of this Real-Time Events report.  Paste the screenshot in your assignment Word file.***

Submission:

Save your Word file with the three screenshots (Video tracking, Form Submission, Email link)  with your initials as in: TB_GTM2In-Class.docx.

Submit the Word file before the due date.

assignment_name: M07: Submit [DS1: Intro to Looker Studio] - Video
description:
Submit 

Looker Studio 1:  Intro to Looker Studio

NOTE: Google Recently Changed Data Studio to Looker Studio, as that is all that is different the video may mention Data Studio, they are functionally the same thing, so do not let this trip you up

Assignment Overview:

Looker Studio is a tool that allows you to create a dashboard report from website data obtained from Google Analytics tags or from other custom data sources.  The Looker Studio environment allows a wider variety of component charts as well some custom additions like a date range, drop down list, or a filter that allow your dashboard to be more interactive.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Create a dashboard in Looker Studio using the Google Analytics Merchandise Store demo dataset.
  • Add a scorecard, pie chart, bar chart, time series, and table components to a Looker Studio dashboard.
  • Add a control components like a Date Range, Drop Down List and Advanced Filter to a Looker Studio dashboard.
  • Add design elements like a shape, text and an image to a Looker Studio dashboard.
  • Share your dashboard with stakeholders.

Instructions:

 

Looker Studio 1:  Intro, Adding design elements, Scorecards, and Pie Chart (Video)

Step 1.  Create a Looker Studio Account.
Go to https://datastudio.google.com and login into Looker Studio using your Google Analytics login. 
You may be asked to accept conditions of use.

Once you have a Looker Studio account, you can go to Google Analytics, and in the 4 squares next to your profile image, choose Looker Studio.

Step 2.  Creating a Looker Studio Dashboard Report.

The home section has some templates and sample reports.  But we will click on the Blank report to start a new blank report.

Step 3. Add data to report.

A screen will appear that allows you to add data to your report.

Click on the My data sources tab.

We will use the [Sample] Google Analytics as the Data Source.  This is data from the Google Merchandise Store. 
Click the Add button and then Add to Report to add the dataset to your report.

Step 4. Title the report and set the layout.

By default, the report title is Untitled Report.  Change the title to include your own full name as in: Tyler Bartholomew Audience Overview. 

Click on the default table chart  that was placed on the report and delete it.

Click on Theme and Layout in the tool bar. You can find several different themes.  We will leave the Current Theme to be the Default

Click the Layout Tab in the Theme and Layout Panel, and set the Canvas size to be: US letter (4:3) Portrait.

Step 5.  Add design elements to the report.

Logo Images (zipped file)

We will add some design elements that will create a header area to the top of the report including a shape, text, and images.

Select the (shape icon) from the toolbar, and choose a rectangle. Click and drag a rectangle across the top width of the report to create a rectangular header area.  In the rectangle properties on the right, choose the background color you would like for the rectangle.

Click the text icon in the toolbar and drag a rectangular area in the left side of your header rectangle  Set the text to be your own first name and Audience Overview as in: Kim's Audience Overview.  You can format the text color and size in the Text properties panel on the right. Choose a text color that shows up well.  Increase the font size of the text. Position the text to center it vertically in the header.  

Download the Logo Images zipped file from above to your desktop.  Unzip the file to get the two logo images that will be added to the dashboard. 

Click the Image icon in the toolbar and browse to find the Google logo image.  Drag a rectangle in the middle of the header area for the image.  You can resize the image to fit in the header area. 

Add a second Image below the header in the upper left of report.  Browse to find the Google Merchandise logo image.  Again, you can position and resize this image.

To finish the header area, we will add from the Add a control drop down in the toolbar, choose a Date Range control.  Click in the right side of the header to add the Date Range control there.  In the right, in the Data panel, choose last 28 days from the drop down of the Default date range and Auto date range, and then Apply.

Step 6.  Add Scorecards to the report.

A Scorecard is a chart that displays the numeric value for a single metric.  Click the Add a chart drop down list and choose Scorecard. Place the Scorecard in the the upper left of the canvas.  On the right, in the Data panel, you can see the metric of Sessions is the default metric. Change the metric to be Users. Using the search box can speed up finding a metric.  You may have to scroll down to see Users. The metric displayed on the Scorecard should now to show the Users metric.

In the Data Panel, we also want to have the Scorecard show a date comparison. Click where the Data Comparison shows None and choose previous year as the Data Comparison.  

Click on Style Panel to show detail, uncheck the Hide Comparison Label to show the date comparison detail.  The Users Scorecard should now show the previous year's value as a negative or positive value.

Step 7.  Add  four more Scorecards.

Copy and paste t the Users Scorecard four more times.  Line up the four new Scorecards below the Users Score card to form a square.

Change the metric of the four new Scorecards to show these metrics: PageViews, Bounce Rate, Pages/Sessions and Avg. Session Duration. Use the search box to help find these metrics.  Align the four Scorecards as a 4 square below the Users Scorecard.

Step 8.  Add a new Pie chart. 

In the Add a chart drop down list, choose a Pie Chart.  In the right Data panel, change the dimension to be Default Channel Groupings.

Click on Style and reduce number of slices of the pie to only show 6 slices.  Drag the slider to make the pie chart a donut chart.  Position the pie chart to the top right side of the canvas.

Use the Text icon in the toolbar, to add a text area above the Pie Chart.  Set the text to be: Top 5 Default Channed Groupings. Position this text area above the Pie Chart.

 

Looker Studio 1: Adding a Bar Chart, Time Series, Table, and Sharing the Dashboard (VIdeo)

Step 9.  Add a new Bar Chart.

In the Add a chart drop down list, choose a bar with horizontal bars.  Add the bar chart on the right below the Pie chart. 

In the right Data panel, change the dimension to be Device Category.  Make sure the metric used for the Bar Chart is Sessions.

In the Style panel, under the Legend section, click to have None. 

Copy the Pie Chart text area and move it above the Bar Chart.  Change the text to be: Sessions by Device Category.

Step 10.  Add a Time Series Chart.   

Use the Add a control drop down list to add a Time Series Chart.  Position the Time Series to be to the right of the Bar Chart in the canvas.

In the right Data panel, change the metric for the Time Series to be Users.  Add Comparison date range of the Previous Year. 

Step 11.  Add a Table chart. 

In the Add a chart drop down list, choose a Table Chart.  Drag the rectangular area for the Table to be across the width near the bottom of the canvas.

In the right Data panel, change the dimension to be Page.

Set the metric to be Pageviews, Add an additional metric to be Bounce Rate.

In Style panel, for the Pageviews which is in Column 1, you can click on Bar.  and check to Show number.

For the Bounce Rate which is Column 2, change to Heat map.  Change the color of the Heat map to be a red.   Note: Setting the Heat map to use shades of red implies to viewers that high Bounce Rates are bad.  If your metric is something like Revenue, you might want a Heat map to be shades of green, for good.

The Table chart should now show the Pageviews as bars with numbers and the Bounce Rate as Heat map. 

Step 12.  Adding a Drop-down List and Advanced Filter controls.

Next, you will add a Drop-down list control that will allow viewers to choose an Age for the dashboard.  By default, the data for all ages are shown in the report.   In the toolbar, using the Add a control drop down list, choose the Drop-down list.  Position this Drop Down List above the Time Series Chart. In the Data panel on the right, set the Control field for this control to be Age.  This control will allow the viewer to filter the dashboard data by the Age.

You will also add an Advanced Filter control to allow viewers to filter the report to show only data from a specified Country.  In the toolbar, using the Add a control drop down list, choose Advanced Filter.  Position the Advanced Filter above the Pie Chart.  You may have to move the chart and text area down.  In the Data panel on the right, set the Control field of the Advanced Filter to be Country.  
When the report is viewed, the user can then filter the report by a specific Country.  The Search options can also be selected by the user.  The default search option will be Equals. 

Step 13  Viewing the Dashboard report.

The dashboard report can be viewed by clicking the View button in the upper right corner.
Try out the interactive elements of the dashboard:  the Age drop-down list, the Country advanced filter, and the Data Range control.

Switch back to edit mode by clicking the Edit blue button.

Once in edit mode again, dashboard components can be repositioned until you are happy with the final look of the report.

Step 14.  Sharing a dashboard report. 

There are several ways to share a dashboard report with stakeholders or team members.

For a team member who has permissions to the report, you can choose from the Share drop-down list in the upper right and choose a Get report link.  Once a team member has a link, they can view a report.

You can also email a PDF of the report by choosing Schedule email delivery.  This share option allows you to schedule how often you want to schedule the frequency of an email report to the recipient.

To share this report with your instructor, you will choose the Invite people.  This option will allow your dashboard report to appear in the person's Looker Studio account.  You can determine whether they have permission to View or edit the report (just like a google doc).  Choose to Invite People, and use your instructor's gmail:  tyler.barty@gmail.com.  Allow your instructor to Edit the report.

Submission:

Make sure you have set your Dashboard report title to include your full name.

Make sure your have also shared your Audience View dashboard with your instructor's gmail account: tyler.barty@gmail.com.

Submit A link to your Looker Studio Dashboard.  Your instructor will go to Looker Studio and view your Dasbhoard and grade this assignment.

Submit 

Tableau 1: Intro to Tableau

The Best Boring Book Ever for Tableau for Heathcare: Chapter 2: Getting Started In Tableau

Assignment Overview:

This assignment provides an introduction to the Tableau user interface, connecting with a data source, creating a bar chart using data source Dimensions and Measures, formatting a chart, saving a Tableau workbook and exporting the worksheets as a PDF file.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Connect to a Tableau data source
  • Use Dimensions and Measures on Rows and Columns Shelves to create a bar chart
  • Format the bar chart values as currency
  • Save a Tableau workbook
  • Export Tableau worksheets as a PDF file

Needed Resources:

For most of the Tableau assignments this semester, you will be using data sources that you have copied or are already available in your Tableau Repository.

The Excel data source Sample-Superstore that will be used in this assignment is provided in your Tableau Repository with your installation of Tableau. It can be located by browsing in your computer to This PC/Documents/My Tableau Repository/Datasources/2020.3/en_US-US/ (Path May Be Different for a Mac, but should still be in your Documents Folder)

Instructions:

 

Tableau 1: Creating a Workbook, Exploring the Interface (Video Overview)

Part A: Creating a Workbook

Step 1.  Choosing a Data Source.

Open Tableau.  Under Connect, in the left column, choose Microsoft Excel as the DataSource.

Browse and choose to Open the Sample-Superstore from your My Tableau Repository folder
This PC/Documents/My Tableau Repository/Datasources/2020.3/en_US-US/ (Path May Be Different for a Mac, but should still be in your Documents Folder)

From the left Sheets area, drag the Orders table to the "Drag tables here" area.
This adds the Superstore Orders table to your Data source that will be available for analysis. 

You should now see the data displayed showing the field names and row data for the Orders table in this Excel spreadsheet.

Part B: Exploring the Tableau Interface

Step 2: Renaming Sheet Tab

Click on the Sheet 1 tab at the bottom left to go to your first worksheet.  By default worksheets or sheets for short (similar to Excel worksheets) are named sequentially, Sheet 1, Sheet 2, etc. 

Double-click on the Sheet 1 tab at the bottom of the screen and rename the sheet: Category Sales.

Best practice: Give sheets a "meaningful" short and concise name.

Step 3:  Examining the Menu and Toolbar

The Tableau menu options allows you to add, modify and manage different aspects of your Tableau worksheet.   The menu options are contextual, in that some options may be grayed out if they are not available in your current context.  For example: On this current worksheet, the only Story option available is New Story because a worksheet is not a story.

The Tableau toolbar has options for some of the most frequently used actions.  Some of options you will use often are the Undo, Redo, Save,  Swap rows and columns .Sort ascending, Sort descending and Show Me.

The Show Me tool provides a list of chart types based upon the current Dimensions and Measures on the Rows and Columns shelves.  This is a short hand tool that will save you a lot of time as we learn more about creating visualizations in Tableau.

Step 4.  Data Pane and Analytics Pane

The Data Pane on the left shows the Dimensions and Measures in your active data source.

Dimensions are fields that are categories or other fields that cannot be aggregated like: Product Name, Categories, and Region.

Measures are quanitative fields that have numeric values like: Sales, Profit, and Quantity.  Measures can be used for mathematical operations or calculations.

When a data source is brought into Tableau, the fields are grouped into Dimensions and Measures.  If Tableau makes a determination that is not correct about this classification, you can convert a field from a Measure or Dimension to the other type.

The Analytics Pane can be used to apply advanced analysis features to a chart such as: trend lines, reference lines, forecasts and clustering.

Step 5.  Shelves and Cards

Shelves:  A shelf are areas in Tableau where you can drop fields so that the data is used to build a visualization.

  • The Rows Shelf creates Rows of a table. 
  • The Columns shelf creates columns of a table. 
  • The Pages shelf allows you to break a view or chart into a series of pages.
  • The Filters shelf allows you to select criteria to limit or narrow down the data.  

Take your Pill:  When a Dimension is placed on a shelf, it will appear as a blue pill-shaped oval.  When a Measure is placed on a shelf, it will appear as a green pill-shaped oval.  We sometimes refer to the Dimension or Measure on a shelf as a "pill" because of this.

Marks Card:  The Marks card is a place where you place fields to apply different properties to the data.  The Marks that can be applied to multiple fields are: Label, Tooltip, and Color.  The Size and Shape can be only applied to one field at a time.

 

Tableau 1: Creating a Chart, Formatting a Chart, Saving and Exporting (Video Overview)

Part C: Creating a Chart in Tableau

Step 6.  Creating a Bar Chart.

There are several ways to select the Dimensions and Measures you would like for a visualization. You can drag fields to shelves or cards to build the structure of your visualization.  You can also double-click on a Dimension or Measure and Tableau will apply it to the Row or Columns shelf.

We will use the double-click method in creating a bar chart.

Double-click the Sales Measure - Adds Sales to the Rows shelf (You could also drag the Sales to the Rows shelf)
Double-click the Category Dimension - Adds Category to the Columns Shelf
Double-click the Sub-Category Dimension - Adds Sub-Category to the Columns Shelf

A vertical bar chart is created by default by Tableau.

Drag Region to the Color Marks card.

This now changes the bar chart to be a stacked bar chart.

Use the Swap Rows and Columns icon from the Toolbar to make the bar chart a horizontal bar chart.

Best Practice: If you have long column labels in a vertical bar chart, the chart will be more readable with these long labels as row labels in horizontal bar chart.

Part D: Formatting a Chart

Step 7.  Changing a Chart Title.

Be default, the chart title has the same text as the worksheet tab.  Often it is beneficial to have a more descriptive title.  

Double-click the title above the bar chart.  You can see by default <Sheet Name> is the text of the title.

Change the title to be: Categories by Sum of Sales.

Change the formatting of the title by choosing a different color and font size.

Best Practice:  Always provide a descriptive title for a chart visualization. Keep your target audience and what questions the visualization will answer in mind when providing a title.

Step 8.  Formatting the Bar Chart.

Once you are happy with the Dimensions and Measures used in the chart and the chart type.  You may apply also apply Marks properties like color or shape to add depth and detail to the chart.  

A final step that should be completed it to examine your text in the x-axis, x-axis or labels that appear on the chart.  If the text does not represent the correct data type, needs to be shortened, or otherwise changed to be more readable, you can format the values.

Notice the values on the x-axis for (SUM) Sales are not formatted as currency. 
Right-click on the (SUM)Sales pill in the Columns shelf and choose Format.

The Format Pane appears.  In the Axis tab, under Scale, change the Numbers to be Currency (Custom).  Set the Decimal Place to be 0. Change the Units to be Thousands.

Click the X at the top of the Format Pane to close it.

Best Practice:  Always check the text labels, and axes labels on a visualization to make sure they are formatted appropriately.

Part E: Saving and Exporting Your Workbook

Step 9. Saving your Workbook.

Save your file as a Tableau Workbook with your intitals to the desktop as in: KBTableau1.twb

This will save your workbook by default in the My Tableau Repository/Workbooks folder.  A Tableau Workbook file only has the visualization information in the file, not the data source.

If you want to package the data source with a workbook you would choose to save the workbook as Packaged Workbook.  The advantage of this file format is that someone who does not have access to the data source has it as part of the workbook.  The disadvantage is that a Packaged Workbook file could be very large.

Step 10.  Submitting your Workbook.

In the File menu, Print to PDF. 

Select the Range of Whole workbook.
Select Paper Size as Unspecified.  This will help in putting one chart on one page in the PDF file.

Also choose Landscape mode. 

Name your PDF file with your initials: KBTableau1.pdf
Save the PDF.  By default it will be saved in your Documents folder.

Note:  Pay close attention to assignment instructions as to how your assignment should saved, exported and submitted.

Fig. 1:  Completed Category Sales worksheet

Submission:

Submit the PDF file showing all worksheets for this assignment by the due date.

Submit

Tableau 5: Tableau Table Lens

The Best Boring Book Ever of Healthcare for Tableau: Chapter 8- Table Lens

Assignment Overview:

What is a table lens chart? 

The Table Lens can provide a viewer with a quick way to see any potential correlations and possible outliers in a multivariate dataset.  It contains a series of side-by-side horizontal bar charts that share the same categorical variable but the charts showing different quantitative variables usually ranked low to high or high to low.

Make sure to read the M11: Read [ Table Lens Example] article for an excellent introduction to the Table Lens visualization type.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Read a Table Lens visualization to uncover potential correlations and identify outliers
  • Build a Table Lens chart to compare many Measures by one Dimension
  • Filter a Table Lens to narrow the scope of the Dimension
  • Create a set to group rows of a Table Lens and color the set to draw attention

Needed Resources: 

Download the WHO Life Expectancy, Mortality, & Health Expenditure Excel file.
Copy this file to your Computer:

Documents/My Tableau Repository/DataSources/2020.3/en-US-US/

Instructions:

 

Tableau 5: Table Lens Intro and Creating a Table Lens (Video Overview)

Part A: Healthcare Variables Table Lens

In this exercise we will build a table lens to help compare life expectancy at birth, neonatal mortality rate, under-five mortality rate, and per capita health spending by Country.

Step 1. Open Tableau and create a new worksheet.
Connect to the Microsoft Excel WHO Life Expectancy, Mortality, & Health Expenditure Data source.

Rename the Sheet1 Worksheet tab: Table Lens: Healthcare Variables.

Step 2. Create a Table Lens Chart.

Drag the following Measures onto the Columns shelf:
   Life Expectancy at Birth (years) (2015)
   Neonatal Mortality Rate (per 1,000 live births) (2015)
   Under-Five Mortality Rate (Probability of Dying by the Age of 5 per 1,000 live births)
   Health Expenditure per Capita (US$) (2014)

Drag the Country from the Dimensions onto the Rows shelf.

Click the T icon from the toolbar to add labels to the bars in the chart.

Step 3. Sort the Data.

 Highlight the first column in the header area (Life Expectancy at Birth..)  
 The Sort icon appears when hovering over the first header.
 Click the Sort icon to sort in descending order.

Step 4.  Filter the Data

  Drag the WHO region dimension to the Filter shelf.
  Click the Africa checkbox and then OK.

To show the filter that allows the viewer to choose a filter value, click the down arrow of the Who region in the Filter shelf and choose Show Filter.  You may have to hide the Show Me panel to see the filter.

Step 5.  Edit the axes

 If two measures have the same unit type, in order to make sure the length of bars are proportional, you may have to change the range of the axes.

Right-click the Under-Five Mortality Rate header and choose Edit Axis.    Choose Fixed Range and set the Fixed end to be the nearest whole number (200).
Right-click the  Neonatal Mortality Rate header and choose Edit Axis.  Choose the Fixed Range and set the same Fixed end value (200).
This will make both column bars proportional to the max range.

Step 6.  Format the Chart.

For each of the first three columns in the table lens, right-click the pill in the Columns shelf and format the values.  Choose Format ->Number(Custom).  Change Decimal places to 0.

For the Health Expenditures... column, right-click the pill in the Columns shelf and format the values. 
Choose Format -> Currency(Custom).  Change Decimal places to 0.

Right-click on the x-axis of the Health Expenditures column, choose Format-> Currency (Custom), Change Decimal places to 0.

 Adjust the height of the x axis to display the entire title of each section.
 Hide the Country row header by right-clicking and choosing: Hide Field Labels for Rows.
 Change the size of the view of the chart by using the drop-down arrow in the menu from Standard to Entire View.

Hover over the Who region in the right filter and using the down arrow select Customize. 
Uncheck the Show "All" Value to avoid the problem of compressing  the view too much.

Step 7. Creating a Set.

Because there are many countries in the rows of data, it could be helpful to create groupings or sets.

Hold down Control Key and click the row for Mauritania and South Africa to highlight.
A tooltip will appear,  Choose the Set Icon and select Create Set.  Name the set: Mauritania/South Africa.
Notice a new field is displayed in the Sets section below the Measures.  Drag the Mauritania/South Africa field to the Color Marks card.
Click the down carrot in the In/OUT(Mauritania/South Africa ) color legend and choose Edit Colors.  Change IN to be Orange and OUT to be Blue.

To hide the In/Out color legend hover over the color legend heading and choose the down arrow and "Hide Card".

Step 8.  Change the chart title.

Change the chart Title to be: WHO Life Expectancy, Neonatal Mortality, Under-Five Mortality, Health Expenditures by Country

The completed chart for Part A should resemble the image below:


Fig. 1.  Completed Healthcare Variables Table Lens for Part A.


Part B:  Healthcare Costs Table Lens

 

Tableau 5: Healthcare Costs Table Lens (Video Overview)

In Part B, you will complete a similar example of creating a Table Lens following the same steps as used in Part A.
You will use the Healthcare Costs Excel data source for this part of the assignment.

Step 1:  Add an new Worksheet.

Click to add a new Worksheet tab.

In the new Worksheet, choose a New Data Source from the Data menu, browse to find the Healthcare Costs Excel file.

Step 2:  Rename the Worksheet.

Rename the Worksheet tab: Table Lens: Healthcare Costs.

Step 3:  Create the Table Lens chart.

Add the Insurer Cost, Patient Cost, and Total Cost measures to the Columns shelf.

Add the Disease dimension to the Rows shelf.

Add labels to the table lens chart.

Step 4: Show a Filter for the chart.

Drag the Disease dimension to the Filter shelf.  Use the down arrow to Show Filter.

Step 5:  Sort the chart.

Sort the chart in descending order by the Total Cost column.

Step 6: Edit the axes.

 If two measures have the same unit type, in order to make sure the length of bars are proportional, you may have to change the range of the axes.  Notice the Patient Cost range is 0 - 60 million and the Insurer Cost and Total Cost columns range is about 0 - 600 million.  We need to normalize the range of the columns by changing the range of the Patient Cost column.

Right-click the Patient Cost header and choose Edit Axis.    Choose Fixed Range and set the Fixed end to be the nearest whole number (600,000,000).
Now all three column bars will be proportional with a max range of about 600,000,000.

Step 6:  Create a Set.
Create a set by highlighting the Osteoarthritus and Rheumatoid Arthritus rows with the Control key held down.  Name the set: Arthitus.  Drag the set to the Color marks card. 

Step 7.  Format the chart
Format the values in the pane, for the three columns as Custom currency with 0 Decimal places.

Format the values in the x-axis, for all three columns as Currency(Custom) with 0 Decimal places and Units Millions.

Step 8:  Change the chart title.

Change the chart title to: Healthcare Cost Comparisons.

The completed chart should resemble the image below:

Fig. 2.  Completed Healthcare Costs Table Lens for Part B.

Submission:

Print to PDF the Entire workbook.  You may want to change the layout to Landscape.
Set the Page Size: Unspecified.

Name your file with your initials: TB_Tableau5.pdf.

Submit by the due date for full credit.

Submit

Tableau 6- Histograms in Tableau

The Best Boring Book Ever of Healthcare for Tableau: Chapter 9- Histograms

Assignment Overview:

What is a Histogram?

A histogram is a vertical bar chart used to display the frequency distribution of data from an ordered range of values arranged in intervals called "bins".

Each bin contain a range of values of a measure, but the bins cannot be rearranged.

For more information on Histograms be sure to read M11: Read [ Review of Histograms] for two online articles on Histograms.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Provide examples of continuous Measures
  • Create (bin) from the continuous Measure to be used for the Histogram and set the bin size
  • Create a Histogram ( a type of vertical bar chart with no spaces between the bars)
  • Add alias labels to the Histogram to increase the readability

Needed Resources:

Download the Clinic Patients Metrics Excel Excel file.
Copy this file to your Computer:

Documents/My Tableau Repository/DataSources/2020.3/en-US-US/

Instructions:

 

Tableau 6: Histogram Intro and Patient Ages Histogram (Video Overview)

Part A- Patient Ages Histogram

 Step 1.  Create a new Workbook.
   Create a new Tableau Workbook.

Choose to Connect to a Microsoft Excel data source.
Connect to the Clinic Patients Metrics Excel file.

Change the Sheet1 tab to be: Histogram: Patient Ages.

Step 2. Creating Bins
   Note: When creating a bin be sure to choose a size of bin that provides a small enough  detailed distribution,  but not too small.
   In the Bin dialog, clicking on the Load button can provide you Min, Max and Diff values to help you choose a bin size.
   Right-click the Age in Measures data area and choose Create and select Bins.
   Change the Bin size to 10.  Then OK.

A new dimension should now be added called Age(bin).  A bin is a bucket or range of continuous values.

Step 3: Create the Histogram.

Drag the Age from Measures to the Rows shelf.  The default aggregation used for Age is SUM(Age).  We want to use the Count of the Age. In the Age pill on the Rows shelf, use the down arrow and go to Measure(Sum) and change to Count.  The pill should now show CNT(Age).

From the Show Me options, click the Histogram chart.  The Bar Chart should now be changed to a Histogram with your Age(bins) on the Column shelf and the CNT(Age) on the Row shelf.

The Histogram should not have any spaces between the bars.  

Step 4. Format the Histogram.

 It would be nice to show the age ranges on the X axis labels.  We can do this by creating Aliases for these labels.

Right-click the Age(bin) in the Dimensions and select Aliases.
You will see two columns.  The left column will be the original value the right column will hold the alias label.  Click each value and change the value in the right column  to be: 20-29, 30-39, 40-49, 50-59, 60-69, 70-79, 80+  then click OK.

Drag the Age(bin) Dimension to the Label Marks Card to add the alias labels to the Histogram.

Right-Click on the y axis and select Edit Axis.  Change the title to be: Number of Patients.

Right-click on X Axis and choose Edit Axis.  Delete the Age(bin) from the Title.

Step 5.  Set the Histogram Title.

 Change the Histogram title to be: Age Distribution of Clinic Patients.

 The completed Patient Ages Histogram should resemble the cart below:

 

Fig. 1.  Completed Patient Ages Histogram chart for Part A.


 

Tableau 6: Patient Weights Histogram (Video Overview)

Part B: On Your Own - Patient Weights Histogram

Step 1.  Add a Worksheet.
Add another Sheet to your workbook.  
This Histogram will use the same ClinicPatientsMetrics.xlsx data source as Part A. 

Set the Sheet tab name: Histogram: Patient Weights.

Step 2:  Creating the Histogram for Weight Distribution

Using the same process we did for the first Histogram, create a Histogram (not a bar chart) using the Weight(kg) Measure as our Continuous measure.

The resulting Histogram should not have any spaces between the bars.  

Step 3:  Format your Histogram.

Add Aliases to the histogram Weight (kg)(bin) Dimension.
Right-click the Weight (kg)(bin) in the Dimensions and select Aliases.
Add aliases as shown in the completed chart below.

Drag the Weight (kg)(bin) Dimension to the Label Marks Card to add the alias labels to the Histogram.

Change the y-axis header title to be: Number of Patients.

Right-click on X Axis and choose Edit Axis.  Delete the Weight(kg) (bin) from the Title.

Step 4.  Change the chart title.

Change the chart title to be: Distribution of Patient Weights (kg).

Your completed Patient Weights histogram chart should resemble the one below:

Fig. 2.  Completed Patient Weights histogram for Part B.

Submission:

Print to PDF the entire workbook.  
Set the Chart Size to be: Unspecified.
You may want to change the layout to landscape.

Name your file with your initials: KBTableau6.pdf.

Submit by the due date for full credit.

Submit 

Tableau 7 - Line Charts

The Best Boring Book Ever of Tableau for Healthcare: Chapter 10- Line Charts

Assignment Overview:

Line charts may be used to help visualize trends or distributions of data, or to forecast results.  A line chart can show a series of data points over time in order to display a distribution and trend of the points.

In this assignment we will use a line chart to show flu occurrences by year.  We will learn how to set the Fiscal Year to have the lines begin at the defined start of the Fiscal year instead of in January.  We will also add labels to the lines.  In the second line chart, we will use a line chart to represent Total Costs by Disease and Age.  The line chart will also be sorted, filtered and formatted to make it more clear and to fine-tune its message.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Create a line chart, and set the Fiscal Year attribute, add year labels, and format the y-axis as percentages
  • Create a line chart to show both Diseases and Age by Total Cost, sort, filter and format the chart

Needed Resources:

Download the FluOccurances.xlsx  Excel file.
Copy this file to your computer:

Documents/My Tableau Repository/DataSources/2020.3/en-US-US/

Instructions:

 

Tableau 7- Line Chart (Video Overview)

Part A - Flu Occurrences Line Chart

Step 1. Create a new Workbook.

Open a new Tableau Workbook.
Connect with a Microsoft Excel data source.
Browse to find the  FluOccurrences Excel file.

Change the Sheet1 Worksheet tab to be: Line: Flu Occurrences.
 
Step 2.  Create a Line Chart.

Drag Date from the Dimensions to the Columns shelf.
Click the + symbol in the left of the Year to add Quarter. 
Click the + symbol to the left of the Quarter to add Month.
Remove the Year(Date) and Quarter(Date) pills from the Columns shelf.

Drag the % Tests (+) for Influenza from the Measures to the Row shelf.

Step 3. Formatting the Line Chart.

Right-click the % Tests (+) for Influenza the Measures area and choose Default Properties.
Select Number Format. Select Percentage.  Change Decimal places to 0.

Drag Date from the Dimensions to the Color Marks card.
Right-click on Date from the Dimensions window and choose Default Properties.
Select Fiscal Year Start.  Select October.

Click on Year(Month) color legend down caret to open sub-menu.   
Select Edit Colors.  Select the Color Blind Palette. 
Leave 2013 orange.
Click FY2014 in the left column to highlight and select blue color square.
Click FY 2015 in the left column to highlight and select the gray color square. 
Click FY 2016 in the left column to highlight and select the brown color square. 
Click OK.

Right-click on Date field label at the top of the chart.  Select Hide Field Labels for Columns.

Step 4: Adding Labels to the Line Chart
To add labels to the lines, hold the Control Key and drag the Year(Date)  pill from the Color Marks card to the to the Label Marks card.

Click the Label on the Marks card. In the Options section click "Allow labels to overlap other marks."

The labels are all stacked on each other.  Click on one of the year labels on the chart.  It will highlight the line belonging to the year.  Drag each of the year labels to the high point for each line.

Step 5. Change the chart title.

Change the Chart Title to be: Flu Viral Surveillance: % Respiratory Specimens Positive for Influenza October - September for Flu Seasons 2013-2016

Your final chart should resemble:

 

Fig. 1.  Part A: Completed Flu Occurrences Line Chart

 

 

Tableau 7 - Part B (Video Overview)

Part B: Healthcare Costs Line Chart with Filtering and Sorting

We will use the Healthcare Costs Excel from a previous assignment as the data source to demonstrate how you can add filtering and sorting to a line chart.  This data source will use the Age measure as the continuous measure on the x axis of the line chart. 

Note:  Be careful because Tableau wants to apply the SUM aggregate function to Age, and the SUM of Ages is not meaningful in this context.  We will use the MAX aggregate instead to represent the max age of each patient record.

Step 1. Add a new Worksheet.

Add a new worksheet to the project.  In the Data menu choose Add New Data Source.
Select the Microsoft Excel data source and browse and find the HealthcareCosts excel file.

Name the worksheet: Line: Healthcare Costs.

Step 2.  Create a Chart.

From the Data menu, select Add new Data Source.  Choose the HealthcareCosts.xlsx from your MyTableau repository.
Add the Age measure to the Columns shelf.  Notice the aggregate measure in this pill is SUM.
Right-Click on the Age pill and select Measure(SUM) and change the aggregate function to MAX.
The Age pill should now show MAX(Age) on the Columns shelf.

Add the Total Cost measure to the Rows shelf.

Step 3.  Dis-aggregating Total Cost.

Notice there is just a single value on the chart for the Total Cost. 
If you hover your mouse on the circle you can see Tableau is
aggregating the Total Cost for all patient records into this one value.

Instead we want to show the Total Cost measure for each patient record on our chart so we will dis-aggregate the records.  From the Analysis menu, Click to un-check the Aggregate Measures.

Now we a circle for each of the 250 patient records.

Drag Disease to the Color Marks card.

Step 4.  Change chart to Line Chart.
Instead of seeing the chart as a Scatter Plot chart, we want to change it to a line chart.

In the Marks Card, where it is showing Automatic, in the drop down choose Line.

You should now see the line chart showing Total Cost by Age for each Disease.

Step 5.  Formatting and Sorting Line Chart.

In the Total Cost pill format the y axis to be Custom Currency with 0 Decimal places and Display units Millions.

If we want to see the Diseases in descending order of Total Costs, in the Disease Legend, select to Sort.

Select Sort Order: Descending, Field: Total Cost, Aggregation: Sum.

You should now see the Diseases sorted in descending order.

Step 6.  Filter to show Top 5 Diseases by Total Costs.

If we want to only show the Top 5 Disease by Total Costs, drag the Disease dimension to the Filter Mark card.

Set by field: Top 5, Total Cost, Sum.

Step 7.  Change the chart title.

Change the chart title to be: Top 5 Diseases by Total Costs and Age.

Your completed Healthcare Costs Line Chart should resemble:

Fig. 2. Part B: Healthcare Costs Line Chart with Sorting and Filtering.

Submission:

Print to PDF the entire workbook.  You may want to change the layout to landscape.
Set the Page Size to be: Unspecified.

Name your file with your initials: TB_Tableau7.pdf.

Submit by the due date for full credit.

assignment_name: xM12: Submit [Tableau 8- Sparklines, Area, Scatter Plot, Maps] - Video
description:
Submit

Tableau 8 - Sparklines, Area Charts, Scatter Plots, and Maps

The Best Boring Book Ever of Healthcare for Tableau: Chapters 14, 15, 16, and 18.

Assignment Overview:

In this assignment we will explore some of the lesser-known chart types: Sparklines, Area charts, Scatter Plots, Filled and Symbol Maps.

Sparklines allow several lines to be used near each other to create a group of information that belongs together and eases the burden of understanding. We will add reference bands to our patient vitals sparklines showing the normal range of values for each of the vital signs. Area charts can be used as a way to represent parts of the whole while keeping the area under the lines separate.  Scatter Plots show details in a grid where trend lines, and reference bands can be used to increase understanding.  Maps can help place information in its geographical location.  Tableau has Filled Maps and Symbol Maps.  We will also learn how to make use of layers in our maps.

For some extraordinary examples of maps read this online article: M12: Read [Maps- New Perspective].

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Create a Sparkline chart to represent patient vitals: reference bands are used to provide normal range for vital signs
  • Create an Area chart, sort the chart, and place labels for all lines on the chart
  • Create a Scatter Plot and use reference bands to illustrate range of obese and high BMI
  • Create a Filled Map with Min and Max cancer deaths, legend show low to high range of cancer deaths
  • Create Symbol Map with Min and Max cancer deaths, size of circles represents low to high range of cancer deaths, with layer for per capita income added

Needed Resources:

Download the following four Excel files to your computer shown below:
   Patient_24_Vital_Signs.xlsx
   USHealthcareExpenditures.xlsx
   Clinic_Patients_Metrics.xlsx
   Cancer_Death_Rates_By_State.xlsx

Documents/MyTableauRepository/DataSources/2020.3/en-US-US/

Instructions:

 

Tableau 8- Sparklines and Area Charts (Video Overview)

Part A:  Sparklines

Step 1.  Open a new Workbook.

Open Tableau and Connect to a Microsoft Excel file as the data source.

Browse to find the Patient_24_Vital_Signs Excel file as the data source.

Rename the Sheet1 Worksheet tab: Sparklines: Patient Vitals.

Step 2.  Create a Sparkline Chart.

Drag the Date/Time from the Dimensions to the Columns shelf.
Drag the following Measures to the Rows shelf in this order:

   Heart Rate
   Respiratory Rate
   Systolic BP
   Diastolic BP
   Oxygen Saturation

Right-click on Measure Oxygen Saturation and select Default Properties and Number Format change to Percentage and 0 Decimal places. 

Step 3.  Format axis date/time.

   Right-click on Time pill on Columns shelf, select Exact Date.

Step 4. Add Reference Bands.

   Normal ranges to be added:

      Heart Rate: 60-100
      Respiratory Rate: 12-18
      Systolic Blood Pressure: 90-120
      Diastolic Blood Pressure: 60-80
      Oxygen Saturation: .95 - 1.0

   Click on Analytics tab at the top of the Data Pane.
   Locate Reference Band in the Custom section and drag onto the workspace.
   In the dialog box, drop reference band into Pane column for SUM(Heart Rate).
   In Edit Reference Line, Band Box dialog box:

   Band From:
        Value: first select Constant then enter value of 60.
        Label: Value.

   Band To:
      Value: first select Constant then enter value of 100.
      Label: Value

   Fill: select a light gray shade

Close the dialog with the X.

Repeat these steps for the remaining vital signs, using ranges listed above.
For Oxygen Saturation, use values 0.95 and 1.0

Step 5. Format the Chart.

   Right-click in the middle of the chart.  Select Format.
   Select the Lines icon to format lines.
   For Gridlines, change to None.
   Right-click on the x axis. Uncheck the Show Header check mark.
   Right-click on the y axis for the Heart Rate Header.  Select Edit Axis. 
        In the General tab, edit Title to be:     HR
        Select Tick Marks tab. Change Major and Minor tick marks to None.
   Perform the same steps for each measure header on the Y axis.


   Use Control click to select each y axis heading. 
   Click Label selector on the Marks card.
          Check box next to Show mark labels.
          In the Marks to Labels section, click the Line Ends.
          In the Options section uncheck the  Label start of line.

Step 6. Change the chart title.

Set the chart Title to be: 24-Hour Patient Vital Signs.

Resulting chart should resemble:

Fig. 1 Part A: Completed Patient Vital Signs Sparklines Chart.

Part B:  Area Chart

Step 1.  Add a new Worksheet.

Add a new worksheet in your existing workbook.

In the Data menu, choose New Data Source.  Browse and find the  US Healthcare Expenditures Excel file as the data source.

  Set the sheet tab to be: Area Chart: Healthcare Expenditures.

Step 2. Create an Area Chart

 Hold down the Control Key and select the following:
       Date from Dimensions
       Cost ($) from Measures
   Go to Show Me and select Area Chart (discrete). Close Show Me.

Step 3. Color the chart.

Drag Types of Service/Sources of Funds from Dimensions to the Color Marks card.

Step 4. Filter the Data.

Drag the Categories from Dimensions onto the Filters shelf.
Check the National Health Expenditures checkbox and then Click OK.
Drag the Type of Service/Source of Funds from the Dimensions window to the Filters shelf. 
Click None to remove all checkmarks.
Click Exclude checkbox. Click all the checkboxes for fields that begin with "Total...". Click OK.

Step 5. Format the Chart.

Select Fit Width from the toolbar.

Sort the chart:
      Click caret right Type of Service/Source of Funds in the Color Marks card.
      From the drop down menu select Sort.
      Sort order: Ascending
      Sort by: select Field then Cost($). Under Aggregation select SUM.        

Close the dialog with the X.

Edit the colors:
      Click the down arrow in the legend and choose Edit Colors.
      Select Color Palette: Blue
      Click the Assign Palette button to assign colors.  
      Click OK.

Drag Types of Service/Source of Funds from Dimensions to the Label Marks card.
Because some of the areas are small, not all the labels are seen.  
Click on the Label in the Marks card.
In the Options section, click "Allow labels to overlap other marks."
To re-position labels, click and drag to desired position.

In the Year(Date) pill in the Columns shelf,  in the drop down arrow, select the second Year to allow continuous use of Year in the X axis.

Format X Axis Years of Date:
Right-click on X axis, select Edit Axis.
Delete the title.
In the Tick Marks tab:  Major tick marks, select Fixed.
Set to Every: 5 years.
Uncheck Include items.
Change Tick origin: 1/1/1980
Close the dialog with the X.

Right-Click on the Y axis and choose Format.  Format the axis as Currency(Custom) with 0 Decimal places and Units Billions.

Step 6. Change the chart title.

Change the chart title to be:
      US Healthcare Expenditures by Type of Service/Source of Funds

The resulting chart should resemble:

Fig. 2.  Part B:  Completed Healthcare Expenditures Area Chart.

 

Tableau 8: Scatter Plot, Filled Map and Symbol Map (Video Overview)

Part C:  Scatter Plot

Step 1.  Add new Worksheet.

Add a new worksheet. 
In the Data menu, choose New Data Source.
Choose a Microsoft Excel data source.
Browse and find the the Clinic_Patients_Metrics Excel file as the data source.

Rename the sheet tab: Scatter Plot: Patient Metrics.

Step 2.   Add a Calculated Field for Body Mass Index (BMI)

    We will add a calculated field to the Measures.
        Right-Click on Weight(kg) and choose Create-> Calculated Field
        Name the calculated field: BMI
        Enter the formula:  [Weight (kg)]/([Height (cm]/100)^2
        The calculation should be valid, click OK.
        Notice an new measure BMI has been added to the Measures.

Step 3: Create a Scatter Plot Chart.

   Hold down the Control key and click the following:

      Patient ID Dimension
       BMI Measure
       BP (systolic) Measure
   Click the Show Me tab and select highlighted Scatter Plot.
   Close the Show Me tab.

Step 4.  Add a Trend Line.

   Click the Analytics tab in the Data side bar.
   Locate Trend Line under Model.
   Click and drag onto the worksheet.
   Drag Trend Line over Linear and drop onto highlighted Linear icon.

Step 5.  Adding Reference Lines.
Obesity is classified as a BMI >= 30kg/m2.  High Blood Pressure is defined as a Systolic BP >= 140 and a Diastolic BP >= 90.  Reference lines could be added to the chart to help  show which patients fall in both the Obesity and High Blood Pressure categories.

Add Reference Lines:
Go to the Analytics tab.  Drag Reference Line to the chart area.
Drop under SUM (BMI) and Table.
Set Value as Constant and Label: Custom. 
Enter 30 for the value and Obese for the label.
Click OK. 

Add another Reference Line.  Drop under the SUM(BP(systolic) and Table.
Set the Value as a Constant and Label: Custom.  Enter 140 for the value and High Blood Pressure for the label.

Step 6.  Color-encode selected area.

You can color- encode the marks for Obesity BMI >= 30.
Right-Click the BMI in the Measures and choose Create->Calculated Field.
Set the name of the field: Obese?  The formula is [BMI] >= 30 
Click OK.
Notice in the Dimensions, the data type for the new Obese? dimension is T/F.

Now drag the Obese? Dimension to the Color Marks card.
Notice a second trend line has been added. 
To prevent the Trend Lines for each metric, Right-click either Trend line, select Edit Trend Line.
Uncheck "Allow a trend line per color."

You can edit the colors of the Obese? field.  Use the down arrow and choose Edit Colors.  Change the palette to Color Blind.  Set False to the Grey and change True to Dark Orange.

You can create Aliases for the True and False values of Obese?  In the Obese? Dimension use the down arrow and choose Aliases.  Set the Alias for False to be Not Obese and the Alias for True to be Obese.

Step 7.  Change the chart title.

Add the following title to the worksheet:
Correlation of Clinic Patients’ Body Mass Index (BMI) and Systolic Blood Pressure Obese vs. Not Obese

The resulting Scatter Plot should resemble:

Fig. 3.  Part C: Completed Patient Metrics Scatter Plot with Trend and Reference Lines.

Part D:  Filled Map

Step 1. Add a new Worksheet.

Add a new Worksheet.
In the Data Menu, choose Add New Data Source.
Choose a Microsoft Excel data source.
Browse to find the Cancer_Death_Rates _By_State Excel table as the data source.

Rename the sheet tab to be: Filled Map: Cancer Deaths.

Step 2.  Create a Filled Map.

Hold down the Control key and select:

   State Dimension
    Crude Death Rate
Open the Show Me panel and choose Maps.
Close the Show Me panel.

Step 3. Highlight Continental United States

To select this area only, hover cursor in top left corner of Map workspace to display five vertical icons.

Click the caret icon, then select Rectangular Selection icon.

Place cursor in upper left hand corner of continental US map.
While holding left mouse menu button down, draw cursor diagonally across US, toward Florida generating box in process.
Once box covers continental US, release mouse button.

Select Keep Only in pop-up menu.

Step 4. Format the Map.

Click the down caret to the right of SUM(Death Rate) color legend to open drop menu.
Select Edit Colors.  Click down caret menu and display Palette colors.
Choose color (example uses Blue).

Click Labels selector on the Marks card.
Ensure Show mark labels checkbox is selected.
In Marks to Label section, select Min/Max.
In Scope section, select Table.

Right-click on Crude Death Rate field in Measures area.

Click on Default Properties, Click on Numeric Format.
Choose Number(custom).  Decrease Decimal places to 0. Click OK.

From the menu choose Map->Map Layers. 
Uncheck all boxes except the Base.  This will hide all state names and other layer information.

Step 5. Change the chart title.

Set the chart title to be: 2013 Cancer Mortality Rates(per 100,000) by State, All Cancers, All Patients.

The resulting Filled Map should resemble:

Fig. 4.  Part D:  Completed Cancer Deaths Filled Map.

Part E:  Symbol Map

Step 1. Duplicate worksheet.

Duplicate your Filled Map: Cancer Deaths worksheet by right-clicking on it and choosing Duplicate Sheet.

Change the sheet name to be: Symbol Map: Cancer Deaths.

Step 2.  Change Map to Symbol Map

Click on the Show Me button and choose Symbol Map.  Close the Show Me panel.

Step 3. Format the Symbol Map.

We need to add in a map layer to our Symbol Map.
In the menu choose the Map->Map Layers.
Check the Light State/Province Borders layer.

Next we will adjust the size of the circle symbols so they don't all appear to be the same size.
Click on the down caret to right of SUM(Death Rate) size legend to open drop-down menu.
Select Edit Sizes. Change Sizes vary to By range.  Adjust  left side of the smallest Mark size range to increase the size of the smallest in the Sample legend.

Click Size selector on Marks card.
Adjust slider to right so symbols increase size (pay attention to Utah size).

Click Color selector on Marks card.
Under Effects, change Border to Black.
If symbols are too bright, adjust Transparency to your preference.

Drag Crude Death Rate from Measures onto Label Marks card.

Click on the Label selector to open.
Change the font size to 10 and add Bold.

For Marks to Label, select Min/Max.  For Scope, select Table.

Step 4. Add Data Layer.

Click Map on the Menu bar. Select Map Layers. At the bottom of Map Options in Data Layer section, click caret in space to right of:
  In US Occupations section select Per Capita Income.
   By: and select State.
   Using: and select Blue-Green Sequential.

Step 5. Change the chart title.

   Adjust the chart title to be: 2013 Cancer Mortality Rates (per 100,000) by State All Cancers, All Patients Overlaid on 2017 Per Capita Income by State

The resulting Symbol Map should resemble:

Fig. 5.  Part E: Completed Cancer Deaths Symbol Map.

Submission:

Print to PDF the entire workbook.  You may want to change the layout to landscape.
Set the Page Size to be: Unspecified.

Name your file with your initials: TB_Tableau8.pdf.

Submit by the due date for full credit.

assignment_name: M13: Submit [Tableau 10 - Other Chart Types] - Video
description:
Submit

Tableau 10: Other Chart Types

Assignment Overview: 

This assignment will introduce some chart types not included in our textbook, The Best Boring Book Ever of Healthcare for Tableau.

You may want to make use of these chart types in your final project.  We will introduce Pie Charts, Donut Chart, Word Clouds, and Tree Maps and Packed Bubble Charts.  We will also make use of filtering, sorting, and labels with these charts.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Create a Pie Chart, filter and format the chart
  • Create a Donut Chart using dual axis feature, filter and format the chart
  • Create a Packed Bubble Chart, add labels, filter and format the chart
  • Create a Word Cloud using the Text Marks Card
  • Create a Tree Map, add labels, and format the chart

Needed Resources:

If you do not already have the HealthcareCosts.xlsx Excel file, used previously in other assignments.

Instructions:

 

Tableau 10: Pie Chart and Donut Chart (Video Overview)

Part A:  Pie Charts:

Pie Charts may be out of favor with many of the Data Analytics gurus, but many managers and clients still want to see them as an option in a presentation or dashboard.  Make sure you limit how many pie slices you show, add legible labels, and look at showing values as Percent of Total.

Step 1. Create a Pie Chart
In Tableau connect to the HealthcareCosts Excel file in your Tableau Repository. 
Rename Sheet 1: Pie Chart: Healthcare Costs
Hold Control down and click on Disease from Dimensions and Total Costs from Measures.  In the Show me choose Pie Chart.

From the Toolbar change from Standard View to Entire View to increase the size of the Pie Chart.

Step 2: Format the Pie Chart
Drag Total Cost to Label Mark.
In the Label Mark, in the Sum(Total Cost), add the Quick Calculation -> Percent of Total.
In the Label Mark, in the Sum(Total Cost) pill, format it to be Percent with 1 Decimal place.
While still in the formatting pane format the Label text by bolding it and increasing the size to 10.

Step 3:  Sort and Filter the Pie Chart
Sort the Pie Chart in descending order by Total Cost by choosing the descending sort icon from the Toolbar.
The Pie Chart sections should now be arranged in descending order.
Drag the Disease Dimension to the Filters Mark.
    Go to the Top tab.  Click by Field, change to Top 7, by Total Cost Sum.  Click OK.
    You should now see your Pie Chart limited to only showing the Top 7 sections.

Step 4:  Complete Pie Chart Fine Tuning
Hide the SUM(Total Cost) Legend by choosing Hide Card from the down arrow menu.
For each Pie section.  Click the section and move the label onto the section.
In the Size Mark, use the slider to increase the size of the Pie Chart.
Rename the Chart Title: Diseases by Top 7 Total Costs.

Your final Pie chart should resemble this chart below:

 

Fig. 1. Pie Chart: Diseases by Top 7 Total Costs

Part B: Donut Chart

Tableau does not include a version of the Pie Chart known as a Donut Chart as one of the build-in chart types available in the Show Me options.  We will use two Pie Charts and Dual Axis to create a Donut Chart affect.  The same recommendations given for best practices with Pie Charts apply to Donut Charts.

Step 1. Duplicate the Pie Chart
Duplicate the Pie Chart: Healthcare Costs.
Rename the new Sheet: Donut Chart: Healhcare Costs.

Step 2: Create new Number of Records calculated field.

Problem:  There is no longer a Number of Records measure generated for us to use in current Tableau version.
You will need to create a new calculated field for the Number of Records.
In the Analysis menu, choose Create Calculated Field.
Name your calculated field 'Number of Records'.
In the calculation box enter the number 1.
You should get 'The calculation is valid' message.
Click OK.  

Fig. 2. New Number of Records calculated field.


The Number of Records measure should now be available for your to use.

Step 3: Create Two Pie Charts

Drag the Number of Records from Measures to the Rows shelf. Using the drop down arrow change the Measure (Sum) to be Measure (Min).
Again, Drag the Number of Records from Measures to the Rows shelf. Using the drop down arrow change the Measure (Sum) to be Measure (Min).
You should now see two versions of the Pie Chart as shown in the image below:

Fig. 3: Creating a Donut Chart: Starting with two pie charts

Step 4: Change the second Pie Chart to a circle.

In the Marks card, click the Min(Number of Records (2).  Do all the following with this second chart selected.
     Remove the Disease pill from the Color Mark.
     Remove the Total Cost pill from the Size Mark.
     Click the Size Mark and using the slider make the circle smaller.

     On Rows shelf, right-click the second instance of Min(Number or Records) pill and select Dual Axis.

     The chart should now resemble the image below:

Fig. 4: Creating a Donut Chart: Change Pie Chart to a Circle 

     Still with the second (Min(Number of Records) pill selected..
     Click the Color Mark and then choose White color as the background color.
     Remove the Sum(Total Cost) pill from the Label Mark.

Step 5:  Finishing the Donut Chart.
Right-click the y axis and uncheck Show Header.
You can increase the Size Mark slider for each of the Min(Number of Records) pills on the Rows shelf if you want to increase the overall size of the Donut.
Edit the Disease pill in the Filter Mark to only show the Top 5 Diseases by Total Cost Sum.
Format the Label Mark of the first Min(Number of records) chart to only show 0 Decimals in the Percentage.
Rename the chart title: Diseases by Top 5 Total Cost.

Your final chart should be similar to this:

 

Fig. 5: Creating a Donut Chart: Diseases by Top 5 Total Costs

 

Tableau 10: Packed Bubble, Word Cloud and Tree Map (Video Overview)

Part C:  Packed Bubble Chart

A Packed Bubble chart can be used to show a Dimension by one or more Measure.  One of the Measures will determine the size of the bubbles.  The other Measures will appear as Label information on the bubbles.  This type of chart cannot represent negative Measures.  If the bubble sizes are too small, the labels will not appear. Similar to Pie and Donut Charts, you may want to limit the number of bubbles you display. You may want to add additional Measures as Labels to increase the information at a glance.

Step 1.  Creating a Packed Bubble Chart.

Add another Sheet: Packed Bubble: Healthcare Costs.
Use Control and select Disease Dimension and Per Patient Cost Measure.  From the Show Me options select a Packed Bubble chart.

Step 2.  Adding Labels to Packed Bubbles.

Drag the Per Patient Cost measure to the Label Mark.  Format the Label in the Pane to be Currency (Custom) 0 Decimals, and Units Thousands.
Drag the Total Cost Measure to the Label Mark, Format this Label in the Pane to be Currency (Custom) 0 Decimals, and Units Thousands.

Step 3: Filter the Packed Bubbles.

Notice now all the labels do not display on the Packed Bubbles.
Drag Disease Dimension to the Filters Mark.
Click on Top tab and choose By Field.  Set Top 7 by Per Patient Cost Sum.  Click OK.

Step 4:  Complete the Chart.
Change the title to be: Disease by Top 7 Per Patient Costs.

The resulting Bubble Chart should resemble:

 

Fig. 6. Packed Bubble Chart: Disease by Top 7 Patient Costs

 Part D: Word Cloud (Wordle) Chart

A Word Cloud or Wordle is a chart where the size of words is used to represent the frequency or size of the corresponding Dimension.  We can create a Word Cloud in Tableau from a Table or Pie Chart where a Dimension and Measure are used together. 

Step 1.  Duplicate the Pie Chart Worksheet. 
Rename the sheet: Word Cloud: Healthcare Costs.
Step 2.  Change the Label.
Drag the Disease Dimension to the Label Mark card.  Remove the Total Costs from the Label Mark card.

Step 3: Creating the Word Cloud.
In the Marks Card use the drop down arrow by the Pie symbol and change to Text.
This will change the chart to a Text or Word Cloud.  The Word Labels will be Disease sized by the Sum (Total Costs).
Format the Sum(Total Cost) pill in the Size Mark to be Currency (Custom) with 0 Decimal places and Units Millions. 
This will format the Total Cost that appears in the Tooltip.

Step 4: Final Formatting.
If you want to change the colors of the Diseases in the Legend so some of the words are not so light, you can do that.
Set the title to be: Diseases by Total Cost.
You can modify the Title Formatting so it stands out from the Words in the chart.
Right-Click on the Title and choose Format Title.  Add a color for shading.
Right-Click the Title and choose Edit Title to change the font color to white and bold and increase the size of the font.

The resulting Word Cloud should resemble:

 

Fig. 7. Word Chart: Disease by Total Cost

Part E: Tree Map 

Tree Maps can be used to represent data with nested rectangles.  Similar to Packed Bubbles, the rectangles in a Treemap are a Dimension that is sized by a Measure.  You can add multiple Measure Labels to display more values in the rectangles, but they are only sized by one Measures.  Also similar to Packed Bubbles and Pie Charts, a Tree Map cannot display negative values in the sizing Measure.  To compensate for this, Tableau uses a rectangle with a Lable summarizing the number of negative values.

Step 1: Creating a Tree Map.
Add a new Sheet and rename the tab: Tree Map: Healthcare Costs.
Use Control and select Disease Dimension and Total Costs Measure. 
From the Show Me options select the Tree Map Chart type.

Step 2:  Adding Labels to the Tree Map.
Drag the Total Cost Measure to the Label Mark.
Drag the Insurer Cost Measure to the Label Mark.
Drag the Patient Cost Measure to the Label Mark.
Rearrange the Label pills with Patient Cost first, then Insurer Cost and finally the Total Cost.

Step 3. Formatting the Tree Map.
Format each of these Labels as Currency (Custom) with 0 Decimal places and Units Millions.
Add additional text information to the Labels by clicking on the Label Mark.
In the Text area click the ... to open the Edit Label dialog.  Add the field information in front of the default values for all labels except the Disease label as shown below. 

Fig. 8. Tree Map: Formatting Labels

Now the additional text will appear in the labels of the rectangles in the Tree Map along with the values.
You can also add additional text to the Tooltip.  You can click on the Tooltip Mark to bring up the Edit Tooltip dialog.

Add additional text in front of the Field names in the dialog as shown in the image below. 

Fig. 9.  Tree Map: Completing Label Formatting

This Text will then appear in the Tooltip when you mouse over the rectangle in the Tree map.

Step 4.  Final changes to the Tree Map.

You can change the color used for the Tree Map in the legend.  Change the color to something besides Blue.  I used green in this example.
Change the chart title to be: Diseases by Total Costs.

Your final Tree Map should resemble:

Fig. 10.  Tree Map: Diseases by Total Cost

Submission:

Save your assignment with your initials as in: TJB_TableauInClass10.twb.
Export workbook using Print to PDF.  Submit your Workbook PDF in Canvas by the due date.

assignment_name: M13: Submit [Tableau 9- Table Calculations and Dashboards] - Video
description:
Submit

Tableau 9: Table Calculations and Dashboards

The Best Boring Book Ever of Healthcare for Tableau: Chapter 20 and Chapter 24 - Table Calculations and Dashboards

Assignment Overview:

Tableau has built-in Table Calculations for frequently used calculations.  We will be using the Percent of Total and Running Calculations.

Dashboards are a go-to tool for data analysts.  Dashboards have many uses in an organization.  Most often we think of monitoring dashboards used to inform users if a critical problem is detected in the organization. But dashboards can also be used to share analysis explorations known as faceted analysis.

Tableau has a powerful dashboard feature that allows for adding worksheets, text, images, URL links, and interactive controls.  We will use existing worksheets in the packaged workbook to create a dashboard with several worksheets, and filters and legends modified to act as interactive controls.

For additional background on creating well-designed dashboards read this online article: M13: Read [Dashboard Best Practices].

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Find where built-in Table calculations are located in the Tableau interface
  • Add and use the Percent of Total calculation
  • Add and use the Running Total calculation
  • Create a new dashboard and set its size
  • Add worksheets and arrange them in the dashboard
  • Modify a legend to float it, and place it on the dashboard
  • Modify filters to act as interactive controls

Needed Resources:

Save in your MyTableau Workbooks folder on your Computer the Tableau_InClass9.twbx which is a Packaged Workbook for this assignment.

We will use this for Chapter 20 and Chapter 24 work.  This packaged workbook includes data sources and some completed workbooks needed for Part A and Part B of this assignment.

Instructions:

 

Tableau 9: Table Calculations (Video Overview)

Part A: Table Calculations

Table Calculation: Percent of Total

Step 1.  Adding a Data Source to the Percent of Total Worksheet.

Browse and find Tableau_InClass9.twbx packaged workbook and open it.

The Percent of Total Worksheet already exists in the workbook.

Choose the Department FTE Counts Excel file in the Data area in the upper left corner as the data source for this Worksheet..

Step 2. Percent of Total Chart.

Create a Chart.

Hold down the Control key and select:

   Department from Dimensions
   Actual FTE from Measures

Using Show Me select the Horizontal Bars tab.  Close the Show Me panel.
Click the Descending Sort icon from the Toolbar to sort the chart in descending order.
Click the T Labels icon from the Toolbar to add Labels.

Step 3.  Perform Quick Table Calculations.

Right-click on the SUM(Actual FTE) pill on the Columns shelf. 
Click on Quick Table Calculations, select Percent of Total.
Right-Click on SUM(Actual FTE)  pill in Columns shelf, click Compute Using from the drop down menu, choose Department.
Right-click on SUM(actual FTE) on the Column Shelf, choose to Format.
Select the Pane tab, in the Default section, click to the right of Numbers, select Percentage, set Decimal places to 1.

Step 4. Format the chart.

Right-click on Department header. Select Hide Field Labels for Rows.
Right-click on the x axis and uncheck Show Header.

Step 5. Confirm Calculation.

Click on Analytics tab at the left top.
Click and drag Totals onto the workspace. Drop Totals on to Column Grand Total image.
Click on Analysis in the Menu bar.  Click on Totals. Click on Show Grand Totals to unselect.

Step 6. Change the chart title.

Set the chart title to be: Department FTE - Percent Total.

The resulting worksheet should resemble:

Fig. 1.  Tableau 9 Part A: Running Total Calculation

Table Calculation: Running Total 

Step 1. Adding a Data Source to the Running Total Worksheet.

Choose the WHO Under 5 Mortality Results Excel file in the Data area in the upper left corner as the data source for this Worksheet.

Step 2.  Create a Running Total chart.

Drag the WHO Region from Dimensions onto the Columns shelf.
Drag the Year from the Dimensions onto the Rows shelf.

Drag the Numeric Value from the Measures onto the Workspace.

Step 3. Filter the data.

While holding down the Control key, drag and drop the WHO Region pill from the Columns shelf onto the Filters shelf.

Click the None button to remove all checkmarks. Click the Exclude checkbox.
Click the Global checkbox. Click OK.

Drag the Indicator from the Dimensions onto the Filters shelf.
Check the box next to Number of under-five deaths (thousands) to filter for this value. Click OK.

Step 4. Show Grand Totals.

Click on the Analytics tab in the left pane, Drag the Totals onto the workspace to open the image display, drop the Totals onto the Column Grand Totals image.

Step 5. Perform the Quick Table Calculations.

To perform the Running Total:
   Right-click on the SUM(Numeric Value) pill on the Marks card.  Click on Quick Table Calculation. 
   Select the Running total.
   Right-click on the SUM(Numeric Value) pill again.  Click on Compute Using. Select Year.

 Double-check Running calculation.
    Drag the Numeric Value from the measures to the workspace area.
    Drag and drop Measure Names pill from Rows shelf to the Columns shelf.
    Drag and drop the SUM(Numeric Value) without the triangle, off the Measure Values shelf.

Step 6. Format the chart.

Hide headers and Column Field Labels:
   Right-click on the Year of Year column header. And select Hide Field Labels for Rows.
   Right-click on WHO Region header, select Hide Field Labels for Columns.

Hide Grand Total:
   Click on the Analysis on the Menu bar.  Click on Totals and uncheck Show Column Grand Totals.

Adjust the size of the chart:

   Hover the cursor over right edge of the chart until it changes to a bidirectional arrow.
   Drag border to the desired width.

Step 7.  Add a chart Title and Worksheet name.

Set the chart title to be: Running total of mortality (in thousands) of children under five years of age 1990 to 2010 by WHO Region.

Set the Worksheet name in the tab to be: Running Total Calculation.

The resulting worksheet should resemble:

 Fig. 2 Tableau 9 Part A: Running Total Calculation

Part B: Dashboards

 

Dashboards (Video Overview)

Step 1.  Open a new dashboard
(default tab label is Dashboard 2).
Click Dashboard on the menu and choose New Dashboard or click the Dashboard icon at far right of bottom row of tabs.

Step 2. Add worksheets to dashboard.

Locate worksheet Case Count & Minutes and drag and drop it onto the Dashboard.

Drag worksheet Cases Trend onto Dashboard workspace and drop to right of Case Count & Minutes worksheet.

Drag and drop the Sched v Actual In Room Min worksheet onto Dashboard in gray highlighted section below two worksheets.

Step 3. Adjust dashboard display size.

At the top of Dashboard window find Size.  Click caret to right of work Desktop to view display-size options. Select appropriate size for intended audience (use Fixed Size) for this example, Click the caret to right of lower Desktop Browser and select Letter Landscape 1100x 850.

Step 4. Format dashboard.

Click Surgical Case Count & Minutes worksheet to highlight.  Click caret to display drop-down menu. Select Fit.  Select Entire View.

Preform same steps for Surgical Case & Minutes Trend worksheet.

For the Total in Room Minutes by Surgeon worksheet choose Fit Width.

Click Hospital color legend to highlight.  Click X in top right corner to delete.
Click Scheduled less Actual color legend to highlight.  Click caret from menu select Floating. 
Click dotted bar at top of floated color legend.  Drag and drop color legend to a spot just above orange and blue bars of Scheduled less Actual (min) portion of bottom worksheet.

Click caret on floated color legend.  Uncheck the Show Title option.
Click caret on floated color legend again, select Arrange Items, select Single Row.

Hover on right border of floated color legend until bidirectional arrow appears, click and drag border to appropriate width.  Adjust width, height, and location of color legend to desired proportions.
Click anywhere outside of Dashboard workspace to de-select floated color legend.

Click Surgical Case Count & Minutes worksheet to highlight.
Hover cursor on right border until it changes to bidirectional arrow, click and drag border to desired width.

Step 5. Format worksheet Titles on the Dashboard:

Click Surgical Case Count & Minutes worksheet to highlight.  Right-click title. Select Edit Title, change font color to Blue. Choose Center alignment.  Click OK.

Right-click Title location again (title invisible due to white font color).
Select Format Title… Under Shading, select light blue square from color palette.

Perform same steps for remaining worksheets on Dashboard.  To close Format window click the x in its upper right corner.

Step 6. Add Dashboard Title and Dashboard Tab.

Drag and drop Text box from Dashboard window to top of Dashboard sheet.
In Edit Text dialog box, enter title: Surgical Volume Dashboard / Dates of Operation: 9/2016- 11/2016.
Choose font type and size, Click OK.

Rename the Dashboard tab: Surgical Volume Dashboard.

The completed Basic Dashboard should resemble:

Fig. 3. Tableau 9 Part B: Surgical Volume Dashboard.

Dashboard –Adding Basic Interactivity

Step 1. Insert and Format Hospital Quick Filter

Click on the Surgical Care Count & Minutes worksheet on the Dashboard to highlight

Click caret top right, select Filters and select Hospital.

Find the Quick Filter on the right and click to highlight, click the down caret and choose Apply to Worksheets, and then select Selected Worksheets…
Click boxes next to each worksheet, or Click All on Dashboard button.  Click OK.

Select one hospital (e.g. Hospital A) and observe how filter displays data for selected hospital.

Step 2. Insert and format Date Quick Filter.

A Date Filter can be used to allow the user to choose a specific day, week or month, etc. of data.

Hover over top right corner of Surgical Case Count & Minutes worksheet.  Click small box with arrow to navigate to corresponding worksheet.

In the Surgical Case Count & Minutes worksheet, Drag and Drop In Room Date from the Dimensions to the Filters shelf, and select Month/Year,  Click Next, then Click the All button, and Click OK.

Return to the Surgical Volume Dashboard.
  In the Surgical Case Count & Minutes click the caret that appears in the highlighted worksheet.
Click Filters, Select Month, Year of In Room Date.  

Highlight the Month,Year of In Room Date Filter, Click the caret and Apply to Worksheets.  Select Selected Worksheets, Click the All on Dashboards button then OK.

The dashboard now displays data for all or some of the Month, Year as selected by this filter.

Step 3. Format the Dashboard.

Click Hospital Filter to highlight. Use the filter caret and choose Floating. 
Hover cursor over top center border until cursor changes to cross shape,.  Drag the Filter box to the right of the Dashboard Title and release to the right of the title. Click the Hospital filter caret again and choose Multiple Values dropdown.

Click the Month, Year of In Room Date Filter to highlight.
The title of the Month, Year of In Room Date filter should also be shortened to Date by Editing the Title with the down caret to just Date. 
Use the filter caret and choose Floating. 
Hover cursor over top center border until cursor changes to cross shape,.  Drag the Filter box to the right of the Dashboard Title and release to the right of the title. Click the Date Filter caret and choose Multiple Values dropdown.

Double-click the Dashboard Title and right justify it.  Also force the title to be on two lines by hitting a hard return after the comma.
Adjust the widths of the drop down filters as needed. 
Position the drop down filters to the righ-side of the Dashboard Title.

Test these filters to make sure they modify the worksheets in the dashboard accordingly.

The final dashboard should resemble:

Fig. 4.  Tableau 9 Part B: Dashboard- Adding Basic Interactivity

Submission:
