New Type of Submission: Save your as a Packaged workbook with your initials as in : TB_TableauInClass9.twbx.

Submit the packaged workbook for this assignment by the due date.

Submit

Tableau 11: Calculated Fields

The Best Boring Book Ever for Tableau Healthcare:  Chapter 26: Calculated Fields and Advanced Calculations

Assignment Overview:

Read this online article M14: Read [Creating and Using Calculated Fields] to help understand how calculated fields are used in Tableau.

Some Calculated Field Basics:

Creating calculated fields can allow you to extend the capability of your analysis and go beyond simple use of dimensions and measures.  You can begin a new calculated field by just opening the dialog Calculated fields allows you to extend by looking at these types of Calculated Fields:

Logical Functions
Number Functions
Date Functions
String Functions
Type Conversion
Aggregated Functions

Naming the Calculated Field:

Replace the default calculated field name Calculation 1 with a meaningful calculation name. The newly created calculated field will be added to either the Dimensions or Measures, so giving it a meaningful name will help define its future use. 

Formulas:

The formula editor box is where you construct the formula for a calculated field.  It includes a validation tool that will let you know if your formula is valid or there is an error.  The text in your formula is also color coded to help you to decode the parts of your formula.
You can click the left arrow on the right margin to expand to see the Function choices.  You can see All the built-in functions or choose a category of functions to see.  A nice description of the parameters for each of the functions is also shown.

Field Names:
You can make use of Fields in building a calculation.  Either type the field name or drag it from the Dimensions or Measures area into your calculation.  You can right-click on a field you want to use and choose Create->Calculated Field and it will automatically include that field in the calculation.

Field names are Orange in the formulas.
Field Names are included in [ ].

Operators:
Type any necessary operator into your formula.  All standard operators such as addition (+), subtraction (-), multiplication (*), and division (/) are supported.
Operators are colored Black in the formula.

Functions:
There are many build-in functions available in Tableau.  You can click the right caret at the right edge of the calculation editor to expose the list of build-in functions and calculation categories. Functions are Blue in the formula.

Comments:
To add a comment to a calculation, type two forward slash characters into the formula pane.  Comments are Gray in the formula.
//Example Comment

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Build your skill and confidence in writing user-defined calculated fields in Tableau
    • Create a numeric calculated field: Shipping Wait Time
    • Create a String calculated field using concatenation: Full Name
    • Create a String calculated field using StARTSWITH function: Full Name A?
    • Create a date calculated field using DATEDIFF and the Birth Date field: Age
    • Create a logical calculalted field using IF-THEN logic: Quantity High/Low
    • Create a logical calculated field using IF-ELSEIF-ELSE logic: Customer Segment

Resources Needed: 

Data files for this assignment:  CustomerData.xlsx   Excel file.  Save this in your My Tableau Repository DataSources area.
We will also use the Sample-Superstore Excel  file that should be already found in your My Tableau Repository.

Instructions:

 

Tableau 11: Part A and Part B (Video Overview)

Part A:  Number Functions

Step 1.  Setting up the Datasource.

Open Tableau with a Microsoft Excel Datasource.  Browse to find the Sample-Superstore Excel file in your Tableau Repository.

Drag the Orders Query into the Drag Sheet Here area to select this Query result.

Rename Sheet1: Number Function: Wait Time

Step 2.  Calculating Wait Time using a Date Fields

We will create a Calculated field by subtracting the Order Date from the Ship Date.   
This is a row calculation in that the value is calculated for each row in the data set.
Right-click on the Ship Date Dimension and choose Create-> Calculated Field.
Set the calculated field name : Wait Time
Calculation formula will be: [Ship Date] - [Order Date]

Note: If the calculation is correct you will receive a message "The calculation is valid.".  Otherwise you will receive the message "Calculation contains errors" which means there is some syntax error that must be fixed.

 The new calculated field will be placed as a Measure,  Drag the Wait Time from Measures area to Dimensions area.

Step 3.  Creating a Text Table that uses the Wait Time calculated field.

Drag the Order ID Dimension to Rows shelf.  If asked choose to Add all members.
Drag the Wait Time Dimension to the Rows shelf to the right of the Order ID.
Drag the Sales Measure to the Label Mark card.  Format the Sum(Sales) as Currency.

Drag Order ID Dimension to the Filters Mark.  Sort the Order ID in Descending order by Field and choose Wait Time as set the Aggregation to be Maximum.  

Set the Text Table title to be: Order Sales by Longest Wait Time.

The text table should resemble:

Fig. 1. Number Functions: Wait Time

Part B:  String Functions

Step 1. Open Tableau with a Microsoft Excel Datasource and Browse to find the CustomerData.xlsx file.

Rename the first Sheet 1: String Function: Concatenation

Step 2: String Concatenation

If you want to combine the parts of a name into one string, you can use the '+' concatenation operator to join fields into one string.  String concatenation can only be done on string data types.  So for example, if you are trying to concatenate a city and zipcode together, you may have to change the data type of the zip code if it is a number before you can concatenate it to the city.

There are several ways you could combine parts of a name.  First Name space Last Name.  Last Name coma space First Name, etc.  Our first string calculation will combine First and Last Name.
Right-Click on First Name field in Dimensions and choose Create->Calculated Field.  This will bring up the edit Calculation dialog.  Now we can concatenate the First Name which is a string to the Last Name.

Set the calculated field name: Full Name
Calculation formula will be: [First Name]+ "  "+[Last Name]

Notice now there is a new Dimension called Full Name. 
Drag the Full Name Dimension to the Rows shelf.   Click to Add All Members. 
You can now see the Full Name as a combined string of First Name and Last Name separated by a space.

Step 2: Create a Text Table that uses the Full Name calculated field.

Drag the Yearly Income Measure to the Label Mark.  In the Show Me options change the chart type to be Text Table.
Change the Aggregate Function in the Label Mark Sum(Yearly Income) pill  to be Measure(Sum) -> Maximum.  This now shows the Full Name of the customers by their Max(Yearly Income).

Format the Max(Yearly Income) Label to be Currency(Custom) with 0 Decimal places.

Sort the Full Name pill on the Rows shelf to be descending order by the Field  Yearly Income by Aggregation Maximum.

Change the title of the table: Customers by Maximum Yearly Income.

Your table chart should resemble:

Fig. 2. String Function: Concatenation

Step 3:  STARTSWITH String Calculation

Add a new Worksheet and name the tab: String Function: STARTSWITH.
Still using the CustomerData as the DataSource for this Worksheet.

You can test to see if a string field begins with alphabetical match using the STARTSWITH function. 
While this calculation is done on a string it actually returns a boolean result. The calculation will return True if the string starts with the letter or string given or False otherwise.  The matching test is case-insensitive.
Right-click on the Full Name Dimension and chose Create->Calculated Field.
In front of the field add the function STARTSWITH and provide a single letter or string for a match.

Set the name of the calculated field: Full Name A?
Calculation formula will be: STARTSWITH([Full Name],"A")

Step 4:  Create a Text Table that uses the Full Name A? calculated field.
Drag the Full Name Dimension to the Rows shelf.
Drag the Full Name A? Dimension to the Rows shelf to the right of the Full Name pill.
Drag the Gender Dimension to the Columns shelf.
Choose the Text Table from the Show Me options.
Drag the Gender Dimension to the Label Marks card.

Change the chart title to be: Customers by Gender and First Names Starting with A True/False
The completed Text Table should resemble:

Fig. 3. String Function STARTSWITH

 

 

Tableau 11: Part C and Part D (Video Overview)

Part C:  Date Functions

Step 1.  Date Calculation with DATEDIFF

Add a new Worksheet with the tab name: Date Function: DATEDIFF.
Still using the CustomerData as the DataSource for this Worksheet.

Dates have different date parts including: day, month and year.  We can calculate an Age in years from a Birth Date  by using the DATEDIFF Date function.  This function subtracts a start_date from an end_date.  Our parameters are DATEDIFF(datepart , start_date, end_date).  We will also use a build-in function to find the current date TODAY() and use this for the end_date.

Right-click on the Birth Date Dimension and choose Create->Calculated Field.
Name the new calculated field: Age
Calculation will be: DATEDIFF('year', [Birthdate], TODAY())

You should now see a new Dimension called Age.

Step 2.  Create a Text Table that uses the Age calculated field.

Drag the Full Name Dimension to the Rows shelf.
Drag the Birthdate Dimension to the Rows shelf.
Drag the Age Dimension to the Label Mark shelf.

Without the age, the user might be required to do the Age calculation given the Birth year in their head.  Not very user friendly.  With the Age calculated field, the Birth year becomes unnecessary.

Change the chart title: Customer by Birth Year and Age

Your final Text Table should resemble:

Fig. 4. Date Function: DATEDIFF

Part D:   Logical Functions

Step 1: Setting up the Datasource.
Add a new Worksheet with the tab name: Logical Functions: IF-ELSE
Select the Orders(Sample-Superstore) as the Datasource.
 
Step 2: Creating a Quantity High/Low calculated field.
We will use an IF-ELSE logical syntax to create a Quantity High/Low calculated field.
Right-Click on the Quantity Measure and choose Create->Calculated Field.
 
Set the calculated field name: Quantity High/Low
Calculated formula is:
IF[Quantity]> 2 THEN "High"
ELSE "Low"
END
You should now see a new Quantity High/Low field added in the Dimensions.
 
Step 3:  Create Text Table that uses the Quantity High/Low calculated field.
Drag Order ID Dimension to Rows shelf.  Click to Add all members.
Add Sales Measure to Label Marks card.
Drag the Quantity High/Low Dimension to Rows shelf after Order ID.
 
Format the Sum(Sales) in the Label Marks card as Currency(Custom).
Set the Text Table title to be: Order Sales by Quantity High/Low  True or False

Your final Text Table should resemble:
Fig. 6. Logical Functions: IF-ELSE
 
Step 4. Creating a Customer Segment calculated field.
Add a new Worksheet with the tab name: Logical Functions: IF-ELSEIF-ELSE
Select the Orders(Sample-Superstore) as the Datasource.
 
We will use an IF-ELSEIF-ELSE logical syntax to create a Customer Segment calculated field.
Right-Click on the Sales Measure and choose Create->Calculated Field.
 
Set the calculated field name: Customer Segment
Calculated formula is:
IF SUM([Sales]) > 500 THEN "Big Spender"
ELSEIF
    SUM([Sales]) >= 200
     THEN "Small Spender"
ELSE "New Spender"
END
You should now see a new Customer Segment field added in the Measures.
 
Step 3:  Create Text Table that uses the Customer Segment calculated field.
Drag Order ID Dimension to Rows shelf.  Click to Add all members.
Add Sales Measure to Label Marks card.
Drag the Customer Segment Measure to Rows shelf after Order ID.
 
Format the Sum(Sales) in the Label Marks card as Currency(Custom).
Set the Text Table title to be: Order Sales by Customer Segment

Your final Text Table should resemble:
Fig. 7.  Logical Functions: IF-ELSE IF- ELSE
 

Submission:

Save your Tableau workbook with your initials as in: TJB_TableauInClass11.twb.
Please submit your Tableau workbook file with the .twb extension for this assignment so your instructor can examine your calculated fields.

Submit

Tableau 12: Tableau Story

The Best Boring Book Ever of Tableau for Healthcare: Chapter 25 Tableau Story.

Assignment Overview:

What are Tableau Stories??

In order to structure the sheets in your final project in Tableau, you will make use of story points to organize your message to the target audience.

Story Points allow the analyst to create a compelling, interactive, data-driven story.  Stories are made up of specific views or dashboards in a sequential presentation.

One use of a story would be to walk the audience through the process you used to arrive a final visualization or dashboard.  Dashboards can tell you the what, Stories can help explain the why.

In this assignment you will create several charts and include them in a Tableau story.  

Read the online article M14: Read [Tableau Story Best Practices and Example]  for some best practices in organizing your Tableau story and some helpful examples.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Create a Tableau story by adding worksheets or dashboards
  • Organize story points to explain an analysis
  • Write short concise story captions
  • Add text areas to add further explanation
  • Follow best practice patterns for a Tableau story

Needed Resources:

The Sample-Superstore Microsoft Excel you can find in your My Tableau Repository will be used as the data source for this assignment.

Instructions:

 

Tableau 12: Tableau Story (Video Overview)

Create Charts to use in a Story

Step 1: Open Tableau and Connect to a data source.

Open Tableau and choose to Connect to a Microsoft Excel file.
Choose the Sample-Superstore Excel as the data source. 

Drag the Orders table to the orders area.

Next, we will create some Worksheets that we will use in a Tableau Story.

Step 2: Sales & Profit Worksheet.

 Begin by naming Sheet 1: Sales & Profit. 

Double click State, brings up a Symbol Map.

Drag Category to the Filter Card.  Select All.
     Right Click the Category in Filter to Show Filter. 
      Move the Category Filter to just below the marks cards.

 Drag Profit to the Color Marks card.
    Drag sales to the Size Marks card.

Step 3: Regional Products Worksheet
Add a new worksheet: Regional Products
   Drag Category -> Rows shelf.
   Drag Sub-category to Rows shelf to the right of Category.
  Drag Region ->Columns shelf. 
  Drag Sales -> Columns shelf to the right of Region.
  Swap axes using the tool from the toolbar.
   Add Profit to Color Marks card.
   Add Region to Filters Marks card.  Select All.
   Right click on Region filter to Show Filter.
   Format Sales in Rows Shelf Axis as currency with 0 decimals and units thousands.

Step 4: ShipMode/Sales/Profit Worksheet

Add new worksheet: ShipMode/Sales/Profit:
Drag Sales to ->Columns.  Drag  Profit to->Rows 

Format the y-axis Profit and x-axis Sales as currency with 0 decimal places. 
Drag Ship Mode -> Color Marks card.  Drag Profit- >Size marks card.
Drag Ship Mode-> to Filter, select All.

Step 5: Profit by Category Worksheet.

Add new worksheet: Profit by Category.
Drag Profit to -> Columns. Drag  Category to-> Rows
Show Me -> Tree Map View
Drag Profit -> Color Marks card 
Drag Profit-> Size Marks card
Drag Sub-Category -> Label Marks card.

Create a Tableau Story
Step 6: Creating a New Story. 
From Story menu, choose New Story.

Name the story in the tab: Sales/Profit Story

Step 7: Modify the Story

Double click the Title to modify the story title:
Superstore Sales and Profit Examples
On the left, Set the story Size:  Laptop Browser.

Step 8.  Adding Story Points

Drag the Sales&Profit worksheet to the sheet area of the story.
The caption is a box with this default text: Add the caption
Modify the caption to be: Are all product lines profitable?

Step 9. Duplicate a Story Point

Save your story.  Then Duplicate the story Point by clicking the Duplicate button on the left.
Filter the Categories to only show the Furniture.
Modify the caption to be: Filtered by Furniture.
Click the little Update symbol above the caption to save these changes in the story point.

Step 9.  Adding more Story Points

Click the Blank button to add a new story point.
Drag the Regional Products worksheet to the sheet area of the story.
Filter Region to select South and West.
Modify the caption to be: Sales by South and West Regions.
Drag a Text area from the left to just below the Region filter in your story area.
Add the following text: You may select different regions.
Update the story point by clicking the Update symbol above the caption.

Click Blank button to add another story point.
Drag the Ship/Sales/Profit worksheet to the sheet area of the story.
Modify the caption to be: Standard Class is the most profitable ship mode. 
Drag the caption to increase the width or height of the caption as needed.
Select the Standard Class circle in the chart.
Click the Update symbol above the caption to update this story point.

Click Blank button to add another story point.
Drag the Profit by Category worksheet to the sheet area of the story.
Modify the caption to be: Profit by Category and Sub Category (3 negative values)

Step 10. Reordering Story Points
In the Story Point navigation, drag the Standard Class Ship Mode most profitable caption to be after the Profit by Category and Sub Category caption.  This reorders the story points. When you are fine tuning your story, it is often helpful to rearrange the order of the story points.

 Step 11.  Presenting a Story

Move the story progress bar back to the first caption using slider or use the left arrow to rewind the story to the first story point.
Click the Presentation Mode icon in the Toolbar to run the story in presentation mode.
Use the forward and back arrows to navigate the story.
Hit the ESC button to leave presentation mode.

Submission:

Using File->Save As menu, export your workbook as a packaged workbook.
Name the file with your initials as in: TB_Story.twbx.

Submit the packaged workbook with the .twbx extension for this assignment by the due date.

assignment_name: M09: Submit [Tableau 2: Data Sources in Tableau] - Video
description:
Submit

Tableau 2: Data Sources in Tableau

The Best Boring Book Ever of Tableau for Healthcare: Chapter 3: Data Connection Examples and the Data Interpreter Tools

Assignment Overview:

One of the most powerful features of Tableau is that it allows you to connect to a wide variety of data sources.  In this assignment you will connect to an Excel file, an Access database, and a SQL Server data warehouse.  Tableau also has built-in Data Interpreter tools that allow you to clean up "untidy" Excel files so they can be better used as a Tableau data source.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Connect succesfully to an Access database as a data source and create a Packed Bubble chart
  • Connect successfully to a SQL Server data warehouse, join tables needed for analysis and create a Symbol Map chart
  • Use the Tableau Interpreter Tool on an Excel data source to clean up table headings, swap rows and columns, and split columns to allow data source to be used for analysis

Needed Resources:

Download the Sample Coffee Chain Access File (MDB)

Then move the MDB file to this folder on your Computer:
This PC/Documents/My Tableau Repository/Datasources/2020.3/en_US-US/ (Path May Be Different for a Mac, but should still be in your Documents Folder)

Download the WHO Death Projections.xlsx file and place it in your Tableau folder on your Computer at this location

This PC/Documents/My Tableau Repository/Datasources/2020.3/en_US-US/ (Path May Be Different for a Mac, but should still be in your Documents Folder)

You will also be connecting to a SQL Server data warehouse later in the assignment.

Instructions:

 

Tableau 2: Microsoft Access and SQL Server Data Sources (Video Overview)

Part A: Using a Microsoft Access Data Source

Step 1. Using the Access Data Source.
Open Tableau and in the Connect area choose Access.  Browse into the 2020.3/en_US-US folder and choose your Sample-Coffee Chain file. Click Open.  As this data source has no authentication required, It should open the data source for you.

In the Data area drag the CoffeeChainQuery to the right area that says "Drag tables here".

Step 2. Building a Bar Chart with the CoffeeChain Data Source.

Click on the Sheet 1 tab at the bottom of Tableau and rename it as: Access Data Source.

Make sure the CoffeeChain Query is selected as the data source
You should see your Dimensions and Measures loaded in the Data area from the Coffee Chain DataSource.

Drag the Sales Measure to the Rows Shelf.
Drag the Product Dimension to the Columns Shelf.

Open the Show Me - Change chart type to a Packed Bubble Chart.

Drag the Sales Measure to the Label Marks card.
Drag the Profit Measure to the Label Marks card.

Right-click on the Text SUM(Sales) pill in the Marks area and choose to Format.  Change the Default Numbers: to be Currency(Custom) with 0 decimal places.

Right-click on the Text SUM(Profit) pill in the Marks area and choose to Format.  Change the Default Numbers: to be Currency(Custom) with 0 decimal places.

Step 3:  Change the Bubble Chart title. 
Double-click the title. Set the title to be: Product Sales and Profit Comparison.  Modify the color, size and font as you want.

Fig. 1.  Packed Bubble Chart with Access Data Source.

Part B: Using a SQL Server Data Source

Step 4. Connecting to SQL Server Data Source.

Another data source you can connect to with Tableau is a Microsoft SQL Server data source file.

Add a new sheet to your workbook.  Rename the sheet as SQL Server Data Source

From the Data menu, choose New Data Source.
Choose Microsoft Sql Server as the data source.

Use Sql Server Authentication
Server: bigdataa.ad.uvu.edu
Username: INFO4120
Password: Not2020!

Choose the $AdventureWorksDW2019 database

Adventure Works is an online Bicycle Store.  We are interested in Customers, their Geography, their Internet Sales and the Products, and Product Categories they buy.

Join the tables shown as shown below:

It should join all these tables using an inner join.

 Step 5.  Building a Symbol Map using the Microsoft SQL Server DataSource

From the Fact InternetSales Measure Drag the Sales Amount to the Rows Shelf

From the DimGeography Dimension drag the English County Region Name to the Columns Shelf.

From Show Me choose the Symbol Map.

Drag the Measures Sales Amount to the Text Marks Card.

Format the Sum(Sales) pill in the Marks card to be Currency(Custom) with 0 decimal places. Change the Units to be Thousands.

Step 6.  change the default title of the map chart.
Double-click on the map title and change it to: Sales by Country.

Fig. 2.  Symbol Map created with a SQL Server data warehouse data source

 

 
Tableau 2:  Untidy Excel Data Source (Video Overview)

Part C:  Cleaning Up an Untidy Excel Data Source

Step 6.  Using Data Interpreter, Pivot, and Column Splitting on an Untidy Excel File.

Sometimes Excel files are not in the proper format to be used as a table in Tableau.  Tableau can make use of a Data Interpreter to help resolve some of these Excel file formatting issues.

Step 7. Connect to an Excel data source

On the Tableau start page, under the Connect header, choose Excel. Select the WHO Death Projections Excel file and click Open. Worksheets in Excel are treated as tables in a database. The preview area will populate the data without having to drag and drop anything.

Step 8.  In the left column, click the checkbox for the Data Interpreter Tool. Clicking on the Review the results link will open the Excel file.
The first tab is the key to the Data Interpreter.
The second worksheet displays the actual changes to the file using the key as a reference.
Close the Excel file as the file is now properly formatted.

Step 9. While the Data Interpreter correctly formats the table and flattens multi-line headers, this does not mean  that the data is optimally structured. The table layout is in a cross-tab format which is useful for reporting but not for data analysis.  To pivot wide columns into tall rows use the Pivot Tool.
Click the second column header to select the second column.
Scroll all the way to the right and while holding down the Shift key, click the last column header.  This will highlight all the columns.
Hover over a highlighted column header to make the caret visible.  Click the caret to display the submenu.  Select "Pivot".
Pivoting turns multiple wide columns into two tall columns:Pivot Field Names and Pivot Field Values.

Step 10. Notice the Pivot Field Names column contains multiple values in the one column. This column can be split into three columns: Year, Gender, and Age. To split the column, right-click the Pivot Field Names and choose "Custom Split". 
Place the cursor in the "Use this Separator" box and press the Space Bar. This action removes all the greyed out separators and replaces them with a single blank space to use as the separator.
For the "Split off" select "Last" and "4" columns.
Right-click the F1 column header and choose "rename" from the submenu.  Rename as "Cause of Death".
Rename the resulting columns as: "Year", "Gender", and "Age Group(years)".
Right-click and hide the Pivot Field Names column.
Hide the Pivot Field Name column displaying the word "years" in every row.
Rename the Pivot field values to "Projected Deaths per 100,000".
Click "Go to Worksheet" to begin analysis.

Step 11. Rename the worksheet: Untidy Excel Datasource
Add the Age Group Dimension to the Columns shelf.
Add the Projected Deaths per 100,000 Measure to the Rows shelf.

Drag the Gender Dimension to the Color mark.
Drag the Projected Deaths per 100,000 to the Label mark.
Title the sheet: Projected Deaths by Age Group.

Fig. 3.  Stacked bar chart created with a cleaned Excel data source

Submission:

Print to PDF your workbook to include all Worksheets. 
Choose Print Size as Unspecified, Landscape mode.

Name your file with your initials: TB_Tableau2.pdf.

Submit by the due date for full credit.

Submit

Tableau 3: Text Tables in Tableau

The Best Boring Book Ever of Healthcare for Tableau: Chapter 4 - Text Tables

Assignment Overview:

Text tables are very underrated chart visualizations.  Most analysts and business managers have experience with tabluar formatted data from working in Excel. For some types on analysis, tablular format can organize data into a format that is easily sorted, filtered and formatted.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Choose a Text Table as the appropriate visualization based on the data qualities and audience expectations
  • Create a Text Table chart using an Excel data source
  • Filter the Text Table to show selected columns
  • Sort the Text Table using a field in descending order
  • Order the columns as required
  • Set a meaningful chart title

Needed Resources:

Download the Chapter 4 Preoperative Risk Factors Excel spreadsheet and place it in the folder on your computer
This PC/Documents/My Tableau Repository/Datasources/2020.3/en-US-US/

Download the  HealthcareCosts.xlsx spreadsheet and place it in the folder on your computer
This PC/Documents/My Tableau Repository/Datasources/2020.3/en-US-US/

Instructions:

 

Tableau 3: Intro, Tips for Text Tables (Video Overview)

Part A: Text Tables

 

Tableau 3: Part A (Video Overview)

Step 1. Create a new worksheet in tableau. 

Rename the Sheet 1 tab: Text: Preop Risk Factors

Changing Chart Title:
By default a chart title will have the Worksheet title.  Right click the chart title to Edit Title. Delete the <Sheet Name> and set the new title to: Preoperative Risk-Factor Rates: Hospital v. Comparison. You can change the font color, font name and size.  Select the title text and change format the title.  Click OK.

Step 2. Starting the Analysis.

We will create a Text Table using this data about preoperative risk factors.

From the Dimensions, double-click the Measure Names.  This will place the name of each measure as a column heading.

From the Dimensions, double-click the Preoperative Risk Factors.  This will add this to the Rows shelf.

Use the Show Me tool to change the chart type to a Text Table with rows and columns.

Step 3. Filtering columns

There are several columns we are not really interested in: for example Count of Sheet 1.
To Filter these columns out of the table, drag the Measure Names from the Dimensions  to the Filters box.

Right click and choose Edit Filter. Unselect all checkboxes except Hospital % and Comparison %.  Then OK.

Step 4. Ordering Columns

If we want we can reorder the Hospital and Comparison columns by moving the pills in the Measure Values so the SUM(Hospital %) is above the SUM(Comparison %) pill.

Step 5. Sorting Columns

By default the table is sorted by the Preoperative Risk Factors in alphabetical order.

To resort by Hospital % move your cursor to the Hospital % column heading and a small sort icon will appear.  If you click on it you can toggle sorting in ascending or descending order.  Notice sorting by Hospital % changes the other two columns.  To resort by Preoperative Risk Factors ascending alphabetical click the sort icon in that column heading.

Your completed exercise Part A should look like this:

 

Part B: On Your Own - Text Tables

 

Tableau 3: Part 2 (Video Overview)

Step 1:  Adding a new worksheet.

Add a new Worksheet to your Tableau Workbook.  Name the Worksheet tab: Text: Healthcare Costs.

Step 2: Create the Text Table.

Add the Disease dimension to the Rows Shelf.
Add the Insurer Costs measure to the Columns Shelf.
Add the Patient Costs measure to the Columns Shelf.
Add the Total Costs measure to the Column Shelf.

Using the Show Me options, change the chart type to be a Text Table.

Step 3:  Sort the Text Table by Total Costs
Sort the Text Table in descending order by Total Costs.

Step 4:  Format the Text Table

Format each of the Measure Values in the Pane area of the Text Table as Currency with 0 Decimal places.

Step 5.  Change the Chart Title.

Change the chart title to be: Total Healthcare Costs

Your final chart for Part B should resemble the image below:

Submission: 

Save your workbook as a  Tableau Workbook with your initials as in : TB_Tableau3.twb

From the File menu, Print to PDF.  Include all worksheets and set to Landscape.  Upload the PDF file here by the due date.

Submit

Tableau 4: Bar Charts in Tableau

The Best Boring Book Ever of Healthcare for Tableau: Chapter 5- Bar Charts

Assignment Overview:

Bar charts are one of the most frequently used visualizations.  They can be used to trends over time, comparison of different categories, or parts of a whole (stacked bar charts) which are often preferred over pie charts.  Bar charts are often aligned either vertically or horizontally. Vertical bar charts are often used when showing trends over time.  Horizontal bar charts can be used when differentiating between categories, especially categories with long headings.  Stacked bar charts can be used to explore parts of a whole relationships.  In this assignment you will make use of each of these types of bar charts and also side by side bar charts.

Assignment Objectives:

Upon completion of this class assignment you will be able to:

  • Present the origins of bar charts and differentiate between different types of bar charts
  • Create a horizontal bar chart using one Dimension and one Measure
  • Format the horizontal bar chart by adding lables, and setting the number of decimal places
  • Sort the horizontal bar chart in descending order
  • Create a side by side bar chart using one Dimension and two Measures
  • Sort the side by side bar chart on the required Measure in descending order
  • Create a stacked bar chart by modifying a side by side bar chart
  • Add labels and sort the stacked bar chart on the required Measure in descending order

Needed Resources:

Download the PatientFalls_SingleHospital Excel file to your computer
This PC/Documents/My Tableau Repository/Datasources/2020.3/en_US-US folder.

If you have not already downloaded the Healthcare Costs Excel file from Tableau 3 you may do so and place the file in your computer
This PC/Documents/My Tableau Repository/Datasources/2020.3/en_US-US folder.

Instructions:

 

Tableau 4: Intro and Tips for Bar Charts, Part A (Video Overview)

Part A - A Horizontal Bar Chart

In this section, you will be building a Bar chart to compare rates of patient falls per 1,000 patient days across types of care for a single hospital.

Step 1. Create a new Tableau Workbook.
Open Tableau, choose a Microsoft Excel data source.
Browse and find the Patient Falls_SingleHospital Microsoft Excel spreadsheet.

Go to Sheet 1.  Double-click in the tab for Sheet 1 to rename it: Bar Chart: Patient Falls.

Step 2.  Creating a Bar Chart.

Drag the Type of Care Dimension to the Rows shelf.

Drag the Total Patient Falls Rate Measure to the Columns shelf.

A horizontal bar chart has been created.

Step 3. Sort and Format the chart.

Click on the Sort Descending icon on the toolbar to change from ascending sort to descending sort.

Drag the Total Patient Falls Rate from Measures to the Label Marks card.

Format the Total Patient Falls Rate by right-clicking on the pill on the Columns shelf and choosing Format.  On the Pane tab in the Default area select Numbers and choose Number (Custom) and set Decimal places to 1.  

To hide headers, Right-click on the x axis and uncheck Show Headers.  Right-click on the y axis header Type of Care and choose Hide Field Labels for Rows.

Step 4. Add a Title.

Double-click the chart title.  Change the title to be:  Rate of Patient Falls (per 1,000 patient days) by Type of Care for FY2017

Final worksheet should resemble this chart:

 

Tableau 4: Part B, Part C, Part D (Video Overview)

Part B: A Side-by-Side Bar Chart

In this section, we will create a side-by-side bar chart using the Patient Falls data source.

Step 1. Add a new worksheet to your workbook.

Add a new worksheet.  Rename the worksheet: Side-by-Side Bar: Patient Falls.

Again, Connect to the PatientFalls_SingleHospital Excel file.

Holding down the Control key, click on the Type of Care Dimension and the Patient Falls No Injury Rate and the Patient Falls With Injury Rate in the Measures.  Open the Show Me and choose Side-by-Side bar chart.

Step 2. Sort the Side-by-Side Bar Chart

To sort by only one measure rather than the total of the columns, right-click on the Types of Care pill.  Select Sort.  Click the Field in the drop down  in the Sort by section.  From the Field Names drop down list choose Patient Falls with Injury Rates.  Click Descending in the sort order section.  Close the dialog with the X in the upper right corner

Step 3.  Format the Side-by-Side Bar Chart.

Notice the y axis just has the header title of Value.  Right-click the y axis and choose Edit Axis.
Change the title to be: Rate of Patient Falls (per 1,000 patient days).

Widen the columns labels in the x axis so the header titles are completely visible.  This may cause a scrollbar on the x axis to appear.

Hide the x axis header by Right-clicking on Type of Care and choosing Hide Field Labels for Columns.

Step 4. Change the chart Title.

Change the Chart Title to: Rate of Patient Falls (per 1,000 patient days)- No Injury vs Injury by Type of care FY2017.

Final worksheet for the Side-by-Side bar chart should resemble:

Part C: A Stacked Bar Chart

In this section we will dulicate the side-by-side bar chart to create a Stacked Bar Chart.

Step 1. Duplicate the Side-By-Side Bar Chart.

Right-Click on the tab for the Side-by-Side Bar and choose Duplicate Sheet,
Rename new sheet: Stacked Bar: Patient Falls.

Step 2. Create Stacked Bar Chart.

Drag the Measure Names pill off the Columns shelf.

Step 3. Add Labels and format the chart
Add Labels to the chart by clicking on the Labels or T icon on the menu.

In each of the Measure Values pills, format the Labels in Pane tab as Number (Custom) with Decimal place set to 1.

Widen the column headers on the x axis so the header text is visible.

Step 4.  Set the chart title.

Set the title of the chart to be: Rate of Patient Falls (per 1,000 patient days)- No Injury vs Injury by Type of Care sorted by injury, for FY2017.


Part D: Your Own Bar Chart

You will use the Healthcare Costs Excel file we placed in the Tableau Repository in Tableau In-Class 3 to create a bar chart on your own.

Step 1. Add a new worksheet.

Add a new sheet. Name this tab: Bar: Healthcare Costs.

Step 2. Add a new data source.

Using the Data menu, choose a New Data Source. Browse to find the HealthcareCosts Excel file in your Tableau Repository DataSource area.

Step 3.  Create a horizontal bar chart.

Add Disease Dimension to the Rows shelf. 

Add Total Costs Measure to the Columns shelf.

Add Disease to the Color Marks card.

Drag Total Costs to the Label Marks Card.  

Step 5. Format the chart.

To format the Total Costs labels in the Pane area of the chart, right-click the Total Costs pill in the column shelf  and choose Format.  In the Pane tab in the Formatting Panel, choose Currency(Custom)  and set 0 decimal places and units of Millions.

To format the Total Cost values on the x axis, right-click on the x axis and choose Format. Choose Currency (Custom) with 0 decimal places and units  of Millions.

Finally, to hide the Disease header on the y axis, right-click on the y axis.  Choose Hide Field Label for the Rows.

Step 6.  Sort the chart.

Click the Sort descending icon on the toolbar to sort the bar chart Total Costs in descending order.

Step 8:  Change the chart title.

Change the title of the bar chart to be: Total Healhcare Costs by Disease.

Your final bar chart should be similar to:

Submission:

Save the Tableau file with your initials as in: TB_TableauInClass4.twb.
Using File->Print to PDF,  export your entire workbook as a PDF file.: TB_TableauInClass4.pdf.
Submit the PDF file that includes the four worksheets for this assignment by the due date.
EMC Module 1 Asg.docx

Do an ideation envisioning exercise as shown in Charpter 7 "Understanding the Value Creation Process" of Bill Schmarzo's Big Data book for a project at your company or one of the organizations you used for Module 1 Asg. Submit here.739570 Big Data Envisioning Worksheet.docx

assignment_name: Think Like a Data Scientist Analysis Process Asg
description:
Think Like a Data Scientist (Analysis) Process Assignment based on work of Bill Schmarzo

Choose a company, maybe the company you work for, or the company you might like to work for, and perform the data science analysis suggested by Schmarzo. In a Word doc (you can use this template as a start if you would like Think like A Data Scientist Asg.docx) identify the company and do the steps below: 

  1. Identify Key Business Initiatives (at least 2)
  2. Identify Key Business Stakeholders that either impact or are impacted by the targeted business initiative, and develop personas (at least 2) for each (including Key Decisions, Supporting Business Questions, and Pain Points).
  3. Identify Business Entities we might want to uncover or quantify analytic insights (at least 4).
  4. Capture and validate key business decisions (at least 2).
  5. Create (brainstorm) business questions (descriptive, predictive, and prescriptive) (at least 2 each).
  6. Identify the dimensions and metrics needed to answer the business questions (at least 5).
  7. Create actionable scores (at least 1).
  8. Map recommendations and scores to decisions (at least 1).

You might find these sources helpful: EMC-Data Scientist-Schmarzo_WB_spreads_r4 (3).pdf and think-like-a-data-scientist-schmarzo-workbook.pdf

assignment_name: Practice Automatic Exploratory Data Analysis in Python Asg
description:
Follow the video and perform an Exploratory Data Analysis on the tips dataset (or the contrib.csv dataset), write up the analysis in Word, and submit here.

Auto EDA Example (script, dataset, videos):

Exploratory Data Analysis of XYZ.docx

contrib.csv

In Python you can use sweetviz to EDA tips data in seaborn:

https://pypi.org/project/sweetviz/

pip install sweetviz #only if you have not yet installed it in python

import sweetviz as sv

import seaborn as sns

tips = sns.load_dataset("tips")

print(tips)

my_report = sv.analyze(tips)

my_report.show_html()

my_report2 = sv.analyze(tips,"tip") #with a target variable

my_report2.show_html()

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Not Required: An optional R example with some really nice tools

AutoEDAContrib.R

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Not Required: Old Manual Method Example in R:

Exploratory Data Analysis Asg.docx

EDA Contrib Script.docx

Do a Neural Network Analysis of the following dataset, write it up in short report format using the analysis template in Word and submit here. Do at least 3 topologies. 

whitewines.csv

Exploratory Data Analysis Report

Use R or Python (not RapidMiner) to perform an exploratory data analysis of one of the following data sets: insurance, airquality, or diamonds (insurance is in the data links below, airquality is in R base, diamonds is in the package ggplot2 so library(ggplot2) will load diamonds into memory or if using python download diamonds from web). Write a short report in Word covering your analysis and submit here. After each visualization in the report be sure to write a couple of sentences describing what each visualization shows you about the variables. (The practice assignments and the notes from the R books contain examples of everything. The video Part 2 of the Practice Auto EDA assignment shows me writing a report. Nice resources are also: see chapter 7 in https://r4ds.had.co.nz/exploratory-data-analysis.html#variation and Graphing Data with R Notes.docx)

Do both a univariate analysis of each variable and a multivariate analysis of each combination of variables.  Exploratory Data Analysis of XYZ.docx

For the univariate try to answer the following questions:

Typical vs Unusual

Which values are the most common? Why?

Which values are rare? Why? Does that match your expectations?

Can you see any unusual patterns? What might explain them?

Are there Subgroups?

How are the observations within each groups similar to each other?

How are the observations in separate groups different from each other?

How can you explain or describe the groups?

Why might the appearance of groups be misleading?

For the multivariate answer the following questions:

Patterns: if you spot a pattern, ask yourself:

Could this pattern be due to coincidence (i.e. random chance)?

How can you describe the relationship implied by the pattern?

How strong is the relationship implied by the pattern?

What other variables might affect the relationship?

Does the relationship change if you look at individual subgroups of the data?

Dataset Links:

insurance.csv

R Dataset / Package datasets / airquality | R Datasets (pmagunia.com)

ggplot2/diamonds.csv at main · tidyverse/ggplot2 · GitHub

Use Python and the following data set protein.csv to perform a Clustering Analysis. Write a short report in Word and submit here. Use the report template: AnalysisTemplate.docx 

The data set lists the protein consumption of 25 European countries in percent (Austria gets 8.9% of its protein from red mean, 19.9% from milk, and so on. You boss is interested in reducing the marketing costs in Europe by changing target marketing each individual country to groups of countries that are similar in their consumption behaviors.  You should obtain the following information:

1. Which countries protein consumption is similar (clusters). Descriptively label the clusters.

2. Which is the most representative country for each cluster (k-medoids).

Required: Include the following in the report: Descriptive Statistics, K-Means Model, K-Mediods Model, Hierarchical Model, tables/visualizations/plots of the Results, Within groups sum of squares plot (elbow plot).

Optional: Your boss would also like to optimize distribution locations. Using a map of Europe, mark coordinates for each country, and do either a k-mean and/or k-mediods on the best countries for a distribution center based on both geographic location and cluster.

Hints:

1. This dataset has no missing items, the data is also already of the same scale (so it does not need to be standardized). However, it does have a first column with names of countries that you might want to remove before doing the clustering. 

2. When deciding on the business value of clustering it is good to run several different solutions (3, 4, 5 and 6 cluster models) to see if we can find differences in the clusters that have business value. It is all about interpretation and business value. Always put your business hat on and ask does this model help my business.

3. Here is an example analysis done with a different (more complex) dataset you may find useful (it includes useful R code). mtcars Clustering Analysis.docx 

5. Here are some code hints you may find useful:

The practice asg has useful code. 

-----

#to get a subset
protein2 = protein.drop(["Country"], axis=1) 
-----
# to chart the different clusters for profiling
df = pd.DataFrame(data=centroids, index=['C0','C1','C3','C4'])

assignment_name: Short Python Seaborn Univariate and Multivariate Plot Practice Asg
description:
Run the following code in Python jupyter notebook (there is also a notebook file if you prefer). Repeat every command I did with the tips dataset using the variables from the penguins dataset. Download the file as a PDF via HTML and submit here.

The notebook file: SeabornUnivariateandMultivariatePlots.ipynb

Or the raw code:

# Seaborn Univariate and Multivariate Plots
import seaborn as sns
tips = sns.load_dataset("tips")
print(tips)
penguins = sns.loag_dataset("penguins")
print(penguins)


# Visualizing Distributions
## Histograms and Density Plots to visualize univariate distributions
sns.displot(tips['total_bill']) # a figure-level function
sns.displot(tips['total_bill'], binwidth=2) # a figure-level function with diff binwidth
sns.displot(tips['total_bill'], bins=50) # a figure-level function with diff number of bins
sns.histplot(tips['total_bill']) # an axes-level function the same as the default sns.displot
sns.displot(tips['total_bill'], kind='kde') # a figure-level function same as sns.kdeplot(...)
sns.displot(data=tips, x="total_bill", kind="kde") # a figure-level function, kernal density plot, defined x separately

## Adding another variable with hue (color)
sns.displot(data=tips, x="total_bill", hue="sex", multiple="stack") # a figure-level function
sns.displot(data=tips, x="total_bill", hue="sex", multiple="stack", kind="kde") # a figure-level function

## Facet across the columns
sns.displot(data=tips, x="total_bill", hue="sex", col="sex") # a figure-level function
sns.displot(data=tips, x="total_bill", hue="day", col="day") # a figure-level function

# Visualizing Bivariate Distributions
## Bivariate Histogram
sns.displot(data=tips, x="total_bill", y="tip")  # here we specify both the x and the y
sns.displot(data=tips, x="total_bill", y="tip", kind="kde") # same as above as a density plot instead of histogram
sns.displot(data=tips, x="total_bill", y="tip", hue="sex", kind="kde") # adding a 3rd variable as a color

# Visualizing the relationship between Multiple Variables with Scatter Plots
sns.relplot(data=tips, x="total_bill", y="tip", hue="sex") # similar to above but uses a cloud of points instead of density plot
sns.relplot(data=tips, x="total_bill", y="tip", hue="sex", style="sex") # adding marker styles
sns.relplot(data=tips, x="total_bill", y="tip", hue="size") # added color as a numeric variable instead of categorical
sns.relplot(data=tips, x="total_bill", y="tip", hue="size", palette="ch:r=.2") #change color palette with cubehelix_palette()
sns.lmplot(data=tips, x="total_bill", y="tip", col="time", hue="sex") # including a linear regression model in the plot

## Combination Plots - Scatter Plots with Distribution Plots
sns.jointplot(data=tips, x="total_bill", y="tip", hue="sex")

## Line Plots - visualizing variables over time

dj = sns.load_dataset("dowjones") # load new data set with time as an x variable
print(dj)
sns.relplot(data=dj, x="Date", y="Price", kind="line")

# Categorical Plots
sns.catplot(data=tips, x="day", y="total_bill", hue="sex")
sns.catplot(data=tips, x="day", y="total_bill", hue="sex", kind="violin")

# Pairplot
sns.pairplot(data=tips, hue="sex")

assignment_name: Decision Making Context for DS Quiz
Business Aspects of Data Science Quiz

description:
We assess courses to fulfill ABET Accreditation requirements and to help improve our classes.

Please choose how well you feel we have achieved the following criteria in this class.

For the final exam you will do a data science project. You will present your project to the class (short 5 minutes max) during the final exam time Wednesday Dec 13 5:00-7:00. If you cannot make it to class (since we have been doing a combo face-to-face and online), record your presentation and upload the video to the discussion- Video of Final Presentation to share with the class by 7:00 pm Dec 13.

Data Science Project

Project Requirements:

1. Choose some data that is meaningful to you. I have had many project where students did an analysis with real data for their jobs. Or you could do something that you could use as part of your professional portfolio to be used in job searching. There are thousands of datasets here- Important Data Sets and Sites. Your dataset should be substantial (of at least one hundred rows, prefer many hundreds or thousands of rows). Your dataset must be approved by me (no Titanic survivor prediction, no house price prediction, no salary prediction). You may use this dataset if you like.  Data: TripAdvisorLasVegasReviews.csv     Data description: TripAdvisor Review Project for Las Vegas Hotels.docx

There are also many good project options on Kaggle.com including current competitions that have prize money attached such as NFL Big Data Bowl 2024 $100K prizes.  Some students have analyzed their Spotify accounts. https://onezero.medium.com/how-spotifys-algorithm-knows-exactly-what-you-want-to-listen-to-4b6991462c5c 

2. You may only use Python or Orange to do the analysis.

3. Do at least 2 analyses on the data:

a. one unsupervised (clustering or association)

b. one supervised (either classification or estimation)

       A) classification: decision tree, logistic regression, naïve bayes, ensemble

       B) estimation: decision tree, regression, neural net, ensemble

4. Write up a report and present your analysis. The report format that should consist of:

     1. the analytic plan (what you hoped to find and why it is valuable)

     2. the executive summary (sponsor report)

     3. the analytics report (the code and results)

     OR follow the report format we used in class, but show all code.

     Both the report and presentation will be graded on content 70% and style 30%.

Please take a minute to complete the course evaluation and submit your SRI Receipt (NOT the actual evaluation) for 1 percentage point (extra credit) to be added to your overall course grade.

In order to receive the extra credit, you must complete and submit the evaluation by 11:59 pm on Tuesday 4/30.

assignment_name: Download and Import/Create the Virtual Machines
description:
Submit  

Learning Objectives

  • Set up the Virtual Environment (virtual machines)

Resources Needed

Download the following files1 to your host machine:

  • Oracle VirtualBox that is compatible with your host system (Windows or Mac OS). VirtualBox can be downloaded from here:
    • Download Oracle VirtualBox
  • A pre-made image of Windows 10. A VirtualBox-compatible pre-made image can be downloaded from the following link
    • Pre-made image of Windows 10
    • Pre-made Image of Windows (Additional Link)
  • A pre-made image of Kali Linux. A VirtualBox-compatible pre-made image can be downloaded from the following link:
    • Pre-made Image of Kali Linux
  • A pre-made image of Ubuntu SEED. A VirtualBox-compatible pre-made image can be downloaded from the following link:
    • Pre-made Image of Ubuntu SEED

Task at Hand:

  • For this assignment, you need to download and import/create three virtual machines (Windows 10, Kali Linux, and Ubuntu) into VirtualBox.

Submission Guidelines:

  •  Upload [attach] your file to Canvas under the appropriate ‘Assignment’ link before the deadline.

Instructions:

  1. If you have not done so, please watch the first 3 video recordings on this Virtual Environment Setup for a detailed walkthrough of setting up the virtual environment with the 3 virtual machines. You just need to watch the recordings and follow along to set up the 3 virtual machines.
  2. Once you are done setting up the 3 VMs, start them (for this activity, you do NOT need all 3 VMs running concurrently) and complete the following steps paying attention to the screenshots you need to capture and submit:
    1. Complete the following on your Windows 10 VM:
      1. Log into the Windows 10 with the default credentials (Username IEUser; Password: Passw0rd!)
      2. Open a command prompt
      3. In the command prompt, enter your name by typing the following command, making sure to replace FirstName and LastName with your actual first and last names: 
        • echo FirstName LastName            (in my case, echo Jeff George)
      4. In the command prompt, enter the time of completing the assignment by typing the following command:
        • time /t
      5. In the command prompt, enter the date of completing the assignment by typing the following command:
        • date /t
      6. Take a screenshot of your command terminal showing your name, the time, and date of completing the assignment. Insert the screenshot into a Word document.
    2. Complete the following on your Ubuntu VM:
      1. Log into the Ubuntu VM. If needed, the username is seed and the password is dees
      2. Open a terminal
      3. In the terminal, enter your name by typing the following command, making sure to replace FirstName and LastName with your actual first and last names:
        • echo FirstName LastName  (in my case, echo Jeff George)
      4. In the terminal, enter the date by typing the following command:
        • date
      5. Take a screenshot of your command terminal showing your name, time and date of completing the assignment. Insert the screenshot into the Word document.
    3. Complete the following on your Kali Linux VM
      1. Log into the Kali Linux VM. If needed, the username/password combination is kali/kali
      2. Open a terminal
      3. In the terminal, enter your name by typing the following command, making sure to replace FirstName and LastName with your actual first and last names:
        • echo FirstName LastName  (in my case, echo Jeff George)
      4. In the terminal, enter the date by typing the following command:
        • date
      5. Take a screenshot of your command terminal showing your name, and time and date of completing the assignment. Insert the screenshot into the Word document.

Notes:

  • The download links to download these files could become broken at anytime. If that's the case, perform a simple Google search to identify new download links. That's exactly what I did in the recordings that I shared with you.
  • As you set up your virtual environment, make sure to review the the information on this link Common Virtual Machines Issues/Fixes for common virtual machines issues and suggested fixes.

assignment_name: Create a NAT Network and Configure the VMs with Static IP Addresses
description:
Submit  

Learning Objectives

  • Set up the Virtual Environment (Virtual NAT Network and static IP addresses)

Pre-requisite

  • Complete the Download and Import/Create the Virtual Machines assignment prior to working on the current assignment. 

Resources Needed

  • A host machine (Windows or MacOS) with VirtualBox pre-installed and the required 3 virtual machines (Windows 10, Kali Linux, and Ubuntu SEED) pre-configured.

Task at Hand:

  • For this assignment, you need to create a NAT Network in VirtualBox, attach the virtual machines to the newly-created network, and configure the virtual machines with static IP addresses as listed below.
    • Windows 10: 192.168.150.150
    • Kali Linux: 192.168.150.175
    • Ubuntu SEED: 192.168.150.200

Instructions:

  • If you have not done so, watch the last (4th) video recordings on the Virtual Environment Setup page for a detailed walkthrough of creating/configuring a NAT Network in VirtualBox, attaching the virtual machines to it, and configuring the virtual machines with the required static IP addresses.
  • For the Kali Linux VM, and rather than typing the directives into the interfaces file (at /etc/network/interfaces), you may empty the file (delete its original content) and copy/paste the following into it:
# This file describes the network interfaces available on your system

# and how to activate them. For more information, see interfaces(5).

source /etc/network/interfaces.d/*

# The loopback network interface

auto lo

iface lo inet loopback

# Modified by Jeff George

auto eth0

iface eth0 inet static 

address 192.168.150.175

netmask 255.255.255.0

gateway 192.168.150.1

dns-nameservers 1.1.1.1

dns-nameservers 8.8.8.8
  • For the Ubuntu SEED virtual machine, and rather than typing the directives into the interfaces file (at /etc/network/interfaces), you may empty the file (delete its original content) and copy/paste the following into it:
# This file describes the network interfaces available on your system

# and how to activate them. For more information, see interfaces(5).

source /etc/network/interfaces.d/*

# The loopback network interface

auto lo

iface lo inet loopback

# Modified by Jeff George 

auto enp0s3

iface enp0s3 inet static 

address 192.168.150.200

netmask 255.255.255.0

gateway 192.168.150.1

dns-nameservers 1.1.1.1

dns-nameservers 8.8.8.8
  • Once you are done setting up the 3 VMs with static IP addresses, complete the following steps paying attention to the screenshots you need to capture and submit:
    1. Complete the following on your Windows 10 VM:
      1. Log into the Windows 10 with the default credentials (Username: IEUser; Password: Passw0rd!)
      2. Open a command prompt
      3. In the command prompt, type the following command to get the IP address (note: if configured successfully, the Windows 10 VM should have an IP address: 192.168.150.150)
        • ipconfig
      4. In the command prompt, enter your name by typing the following command, making sure to replace FirstName and LastName with your actual first and last names: 
        • echo FirstName LastName            (in my case, echo Jeff George)
      5. In the command prompt, enter the time of completing the assignment by typing the following command:
        • time /t
      6. In the command prompt, enter the date of completing the assignment by typing the following command:
        • date /t
      7. Take a screenshot of your command terminal showing your name, the time, and date of completing the assignment. Insert the screenshot into a Word document.
    2. Complete the following on your Kali Linux VM
        1. Log into the Kali Linux VM. If needed, the username/password combination is kali/kali
        2. Open a terminal
        3. In the terminal, type the following command to get the IP address (note: if configured successfully, the Kali Linux VM should have an IP address: 192.168.150.175)
          • ifconfig
        4. In the terminal, enter your name by typing the following command, making sure to replace FirstName and LastName with your actual first and last names:
          • echo FirstName LastName  (in my case, echo Jeff George)
        5. In the terminal, enter the date by typing the following command:
          • date
        6. Take a screenshot of your command terminal showing your name, and time and date of completing the assignment. Insert the screenshot into the Word document
    3. Complete the following on your Ubuntu VM:
      1. Log into the Ubuntu VM. If needed, the username is seed and the password is dees
      2. Open a terminal
      3. In the terminal, type the following command to get the IP address (note: if configured successfully, the Ubuntu VM should have an IP address: 192.168.150.200)
        • ifconfig
      4. In the terminal, enter your name by typing the following command, making sure to replace FirstName and LastName with your actual first and last names:
        • echo FirstName LastName  (in my case, echo Jeff George)
      5. In the terminal, enter the date by typing the following command:
        • date
      6. Take a screenshot of your command terminal showing your name, time and date of completing the assignment. Insert the screenshot into the Word document.

Submission Guidelines:

  •  Upload [attach] your file to Canvas under this ‘Assignment’ link before the deadline.
