Hello Everyone,

With this being an online/synchronous course, I would like for us all to introduce ourselves and get to know each other a little bit. Please take a few minutes to create a short video to introduce yourself mentioning who you are, your major/emphasis, what you do for living if employed, any relevant IT/cybersecurity experiences, what you expect/like to learn from this course, your hobbies/ activities, and anything you would like to share with the class.

Note: editing or production-style quality is not at all expected. This is a "friendly" assignment and is meant to be casual, we just want to hear from you (so answer the questions, but don't spend time trying to make it fancy as there aren't any bonus points for that).

Looking forward to hearing from you,
Jeff

In class you will be given access to a Windows Virtual Machine (VM). You should use this for in class activities and assignments.

On the virtual machine you will download the necessary install media for SQL Server and MySQL (installed via XAMPP). For this Hybrid Activity, install one instance of SQL Server Developer and one instance of MySQL. Complete the following steps, documenting your work with screenshots in a Word document. Clearly label each step.

SQL Server:

  1. Download the SQL Server ISO installer from the Azure link provided on Canvas under the Lesson 1 In Class module.
  2. Install a named instance called INFO4410_HW. Include only the database engine. Make sure that you are installing the Developer edition.
  3. As you complete the installation steps, include Dr. Sharp (AD\11017270) as an administrator on your instance.
  4. If you have not done so already, download and install the latest version of SQL Server Management Studio.
  5. Put a screenshot of Management Studio, connected to your INFO4410_HW instance, into a Word document that you will submit. Label all screenshots appropriately.

MySQL:

  1. Download and run the XAMPP installer. Do not include the following: FileZilla, Mercury Mail, Tomcat, Perl, Fake Sendmail.
  2. Download and install MySQL Workbench.
  3. Use the XAMPP Control Panel (hint: run it as Administrator) to start the MySQL database instance.
  4. Connect to your MySQL instance through Workbench.
  5. Put a screenshot in your Word document showing that you connected to MySQL. Label all screenshots appropriately.

Once you've documented your experience of installing these DBMSs by placing screenshots into a Word document, upload the document to Canvas.

Database Administrators may end up working with a variety of different software systems and database platforms. The purpose of this Hybrid Activity is allow you to research and learn a little bit about the similarities and differences between SQL Server and other relational database management systems (RDBMS). It will be helpful for you to familiarize yourself with an RDBMS other than the ones we use in class (SQL Server and MySQL)

To complete this Hybrid Activity, prepare a document addressing the following points.

1) Pick one of the following RDBMSs to research: Oracle, PostgreSQL, IBM DB2, FileMaker Pro, SAP Adaptive Server Enterprise, Informix.

2) Identify different editions or version of your chosen database. For example, SQL Server has Express, Developer, Professional, Enterprise, etc. What about the one you chose? Briefly describe what each edition is intended for.

3) What is your chosen database's equivalent of Management Studio (e.g. MySQL's equivalent is Workbench)?

4) How broadly is your chosen RDBMS used? Your answer to this may be geographic or scale-related or both (e.g. worldwide, millions of installations).

5) What are two or three main strengths or benefits promoted by the maker of your RDBMS? What sets their database apart (at least in their eyes) from the competition?

6) What are your RDBMS's major drawbacks or weaknesses? (e.g. MySQL's community edition is free and open source, and therefore, does not include any support from a company).

Complete your written explanation of approximately one page and submit it to Canvas by the due date. Please do not just copy and paste from sources (i.e., websites, documents, etc.).

Assignment #1: Managing Databases

This assignment assumes that you completed the hybrid activity in Lesson 1. If you have not done that, you will need to complete it before doing this assignment. Open a new Word document and place your name and the course number at the top. Save the document. Use labeled screenshots to document completion of each step below. Use your INFO4410_HW instance of SQL Server.

1) Download the AdventureWorks database file from the Microsoft SQL Server website. Be sure to get the OLTP database file, not the data warehouse or the lightweight database. Using SQL Server Management Studio, restore the AdventureWorks database into your HW instance. There are instructions on the Microsoft site linked above. Display the list of databases in your instance to demonstrate that AdventureWorks was attached correctly.

2) Identify the operating system of the server that your instance is running on.

3) Set the instance to log both successful and failed login attempts.

4) Set the instance so that it will use at least 2GB of RAM for Server Memory.

5) Set the instance so that if a query from a remote connection runs for more than one minute, it is timed out. 

6) Set the instance so that if a user enters a date value as '6/12/53', it will be interpreted as June 12th, 2053, rather than as June 12th, 1953. If a user enters a date value as '11/2/54', this date should be interpreted as November 2nd, 1954, not November 2nd, 2054.

7) Set the instance's server agent to log errors, warnings and information notifications. (Hint: You'll need to configure the Error Logs under SQL Agent).

8) Create an alert on your instance that would occur if the AdventureWorks database's active transactions ever exceed 30 at any given time. You do not need to configure Database Mail so that it would actually send, just create the alert.

9) Enable the Resource Governor and ensure that your default resource pool can use no more than 80% of your CPU and no more than 65% of your RAM.

10) View your current server log and identify how long your instance has been running. That is, what is the date when the instance was last started?

Be sure that you have clearly labeled all of your screen shots to correspond with the steps above. Submit your Word document to Canvas under Assignment #1.

assignment_name: SUBMIT HA: Creating Users in MySQL
description:
To complete this Hybrid Activity, do the following steps using your MySQL database instance. Use the PHPMyAdmin interface, NOT MySQL Workbench. Do not attempt to complete steps 1 through 4 using MySQL Workbench--it won't work because of the MariaDB database variant in XAMPP. Use screenshots in a Word document to demonstrate your completion of each task.

1) Create a new user named WebApps. Set the WebApps user so that it can only log in on the localhost machine.

2) Make the password for the WebApps user: M0unt4in$

3) Make a new MySQL database called PhoneLog by writing a CREATE DATABASE statement. Create two tables, one called PhoneUsers and one called PhoneCalls. These two tables relate to each other in a one-to-many fashion.

  • PhoneUsers should have columns UserID INT (PK) and PersonName VARCHAR(25).
  • PhoneCalls should have columns CallID INT (PK), CallToNumber VARCHAR(14), StartDateTime DATETIME, EndDateTime DATETIME and UserID INT (FK).
  • INSERT a few rows of data in each table. You can just make these up.

4) Set the database permissions so that WebApps can only SELECT and UPDATE on the two tables in the PhoneLog database. Make sure that the permissions prevent WebApps from doing *anything* in the database globally. 

5) Log into your MySQL database as the user WebApps to show that your user and permissions configuration work correctly. You can log into MySQL from MySQL Workbench, or from PHPMyAdmin. Make sure you've modified PHPMyAdmin's config.inc.php file to require a username and password if you want to log in and test your WebApps user account using PHPMyAdmin. In the document you submit for this activity, provide clear documentation that you have logged into the database successfully.

6) Attempt to violate the permissions that you've set up for the WebApps user account by writing SQL statements that try to do things WebApps is not allowed to do, such as create a table, or drop the PhoneLog database, or create a new user. Include multiple screenshots that prove that you can only SELECT or UPDATE on the PhoneLog database.

Submit your documentation to Canvas by the due date.

Assignment #2: SQL Logins, Roles and Users

This assignment assumes you completed the previous assignment, which required you to load the AdventureWorks database to your HW instance. If you haven't done that, do it now.

Open a new Word document and save it. Use screenshots to document completion of each step below, and clearly label each step.

1) Set your HW instance to allow both Windows and SQL Server authentication. 

2) Write a SQL statement that will create a new view named PersonAddresses. Use this web site if you need help with the CREATE VIEW syntax. The view should include the following attributes:

  • BusinessEntityID
  • PersonName (this is a concatenation of LastName, FirstName MiddleName from the Person table)
  • PhoneNumber
  • PersonAddress (this is a concatenation of AddressLine1, City, StateProvinceCode CountryRegionCode PostalCode)
    • Note that you'll need to access PersonPhone, BusinessEntityAddress, Address and StateProvince in the Person schema to build this concatenation.

It may help to look at the AdventureWorks ER diagram, which is available on the Internet. Here is one spot you can see it: https://txtrainingstore.blob.core.windows.net/db-backup-aw2019/AdventureWorksERD 

All needed tables are in the Person schema. Beyond just the ER diagram, here are some additional helps to get the joins that you need set up when creating the view:

  • The Person table and the PersonPhone table relate on the BusinessEntityID keys.
  • The Person table and the BusinessEntityAddress table relate on the BusinessEntityID keys.
  • The BusinessEntityAddress table and the Address table relate on the AddressID keys.
  • The Address table and the StateProvince table relate on the StateProvinceID keys.

Run the code to create the view and take a screenshot showing successful creation. SELECT * from the view and take another screenshot showing successful retrieval of data. It should look similar to this:

Add all needed screenshots to your Word document and label them. Include the full SQL code you wrote to make the view.

3) Create a new Login for your instance. The Login name will be IndividualDataAccess and the password will be $ecretP4ssw0rd

Do not enforce the Windows password policy. Set the default database to be AdventureWorks. Do not grant any server roles or map any databases. Take a screenshot to document the creation of the Login and place it in your Word document. Label the screenshot.

4) Create a new SQL User that uses the Login that you just set up for the AdventureWorks database. The name for this User must match the Login's name. Do not grant the user any ownership, membership or permission at this time. Take a screenshot and place it in your Word document. Label the screenshot.

5) Create a new Role for the AdventureWorks database. The name for this Role will be PersonViewAccess. Configure this role so that the only thing it can do is issue SELECT statements against the PersonAddresses view. Add the IndividualDataAccess User to this Role. Take screenshots showing the Role and its assigned User, and its sole permission. Place all of these into your Word document and label them appropriately.

6) Disconnect from your HW SQL Server instance in SSMS, and then reconnect using the login IndividualDataAccess with password $ecretP4ssw0rd and ensure that the Object Explorer is visible to show the current logged in User. Write a query to SELECT * from the PersonAddresses view. Take a screenshot, ensuring that you include the Object Explorer with the current logged in user showing, the SQL query and the results below. Include a screenshot showing that your newly created User was able to log in and select from the newly created view. Label this screenshot appropriately.

7) Write a SQL query to attempt to select, update, insert or delete on any other table or view in the AdventureWorks database. If your Login, User and Role are configured correctly, you should get a "permission denied" error when you attempt to do *anything* other than select from the PersonAddresses view. Take a screenshot showing your attempt and permission denied. Place these screenshots into your Word document and label them appropriately.

Submit your Word document to Canvas by the due date.

assignment_name: SUBMIT HA: Recommend Application Layer Improvements
description:
To complete this Hybrid Activity, use the attached PHP script to evaluate the various interactions with the database. Note that I am not asking you to be intimately familiar with the PHP or HTML code, nor with the function of the script itself. I am asking you to use what you have learned, and should learn from the reading (especially Chapter 6), to find and understand red flags in an application layer's interface to a back-end database.

Look at it through the eyes of a DBA and address each of the following three questions:
1) Are there components that are inefficient?
2) Are there security risks in the script?
3) What other issues that might be of concern to a DBA?

Make a list of three recommendations for improvement, one for each of the three questions above. For each recommendation, explain (and be specific) what you recommend changing, how you recommend changing it, and why. Be sure to clearly label all nine of the requirements -- for example:

Question 1, What Change I Recommend
Question 1, How I Recommend Changing It
Question 1, Why I Recommend This Change

Question 2, What Change I Recommend, etc....

Place your list of recommendations and remediation in a Word document named LastNameFirstName_HA04 (use your last name and first name) and upload to Canvas by the due date.

assignment_name: SUBMIT HA: Terminating Sessions and Processes
description:
This week's hybrid activity is called Terminating Sessions and Processes because I want you to learn how to find and kill processes in PostgreSQL and Oracle. Although we do not work with either of these RDBMS software products in INFO 4410, there is a great likelihood that you will encounter one or the other of these in your future work. This hybrid activity will give you some exposure to how you might work with these software products if you work for a company that uses them.

Conduct research on how to kill processes on PostgreSQL. Thoroughly explain the steps what you would take if you needed to kill a PostgreSQL process, citing your sources of information. Repeat this explanation for Oracle databases. There are multiple ways to do kill processes in Oracle; you need only find and document one way.

Make sure you cite all sources of information that you used.

Submit your document to Canvas by the due date.

Assignment #3: Transaction Management

Open a new Word document and place your name and the course number at the top. Save the document as LastnameFirstname_A03. You will need the Transactions.sql script for this assignment. Complete the following steps, showing images and labels for each  one:

1) Connect to your HW instance of SQL Server on your VM. You need to have the AdventureWorks database. 

2) Configure a Performance Monitor window with the following counters added: Memory: Available MBytes; Memory: Pages/sec; Processor: %Processor Time; <Your HW Instance of SQL Server>: Databases: Transactions/sec. Make sure the scale setting for all of your counters is 1.0. Run the Transactions.sql script. While the Transactions script is executing, view the Performance Monitor window. Using screenshots and written explanations, identify how the database, and the work you're having it do when you execute Transactions.sql, impact your VM's server performance. Be specific! Be thorough!

3) Create a new SQL Server Profiler trace. Run the Transactions.sql script and then show the results of your Profiler trace. Take a screenshot and include it in your report. Write a summary of behavior captured by the trace. 

4) Run the Activity Monitor on your instance. Run the Transactions.sql script again and take screenshots of interesting/notable observations in the Activity Monitor. Summarize your observations in writing.

5) Run the Transactions.sql script again. While it is executing, generate the "All Transactions" report in Management Studio. This is found by right clicking on the AdventureWorks database, and the selecting Reports > Standard Reports > All Transactions. Expand the report sections by clicking the plus signs under "State", "Session ID", etc. Identify the details of the script's transactions in the database, making sure to specify all objects that are locked including the lock type and the lock mode for each resource that is locked. Use both screenshots and written text to explain what is locked and how. Be specific! Identify the session ID that is executing the transactions. Kill the process that left the transaction (and its locks) open. Document your work using screenshots and explain the process of killing an open transaction. Once you've killed the process, re-run the All Transactions report, showing that there are now no open transactions or lingering locks. Document this in your assignment submission.

Submit your Word document to Canvas by the due date.

One of the best ways to reduce query cost is to create indexes on table columns to reduce seek times. Using your textbook and Internet resources . . .

  • Read about the concept of B-Tree indexes
  • In two paragraphs or more, explain what a B-Tree is and thoroughly discuss why B-Trees are so valuable in databases.
  • Explain why other types of index techniques are less effective in databases.
  • Explain how B-Trees change over time and why they must.
  • Cite all sources of information used in preparing your response.

Save responses in a Word document entitled, LastNameFirstName_HA06, and submit in Canvas.

Using the script linked below this assignment, complete the following tasks:

1) Log into your HW instance of SQL Server, it should have the AdventureWorks database on it. As you complete each step below, give specific cost values for each measurement you complete, either through screenshots or transcribing the cost values from the Actual Execution Plan in SQL Server.

2) Write two queries. The first query will return a person's FirstName, MiddleName and LastName from the Person.Person table. The second query will return all of the items from the first query, plus AddressLine1, City, and PostalCode from the Person.Address table (which will have to be joined via the Person.BusinessEntityAddress table). Run each of the queries and measure their costs. Document the costs in a Word document with written explanations and screenshots, making comparisons specifically about how joins affect query cost.

3) Write two more queries. The first should use JOINs to display a distinct list of the names of all customers in Person.Person whose address is in StateProvinceID 79.  The second should do the same, only using subqueries instead of JOINs. (Hint: Use Person.Person, Person.BusinessEntityAddress and Person.Address). Run each of the queries and measure their costs. Document the costs in a Word document with written explanations and screenshots, making comparisons specifically about whether it is more cost efficient to use JOINs or subqueries.

4) Using the Production.WorkOrder table, write a query to SUM the OrderQty and GROUP BY the ProductID. Measure the cost of the query. Add a HAVING clause (you can determine the criteria). Run the query again and examine the cost of using HAVING. Add a WHERE clause (you can determine the criteria again) and again examine the impact on cost. Add an ORDER BY clause and document the additional cost. Document in your Word document the final version of your query, with written explanation of the impacts on cost for each incremental addition to your query.

5) Write a query to join Production.WorkOrder and Production.WorkOrderRouting. Add the resulting records into a single temp table. Compare the cost of running the the query that populates your temp table to the cost of populating and then selecting * from your temp table. Document your results, explaining the circumstances under which you would see use of a temp table as advantageous, based on cost analysis of both creating and querying the temp table, versus just re-running the query multiple times.

You should compare total costs. You are looking for the total cost of creating, populating and retrieving data from the temp table versus just repeatedly running the join query over and over again. The question you should answer is: at what point (number of query executions) is it more cost-effective to create a temp table and populate it, and then repeatedly select * from that table, than it would be to keep running the join query each time you need to retrieve that same data? Be clear about calculating and specifying the "break even" point for the cost of creating, populating, and using a temp table.

Submit your Word document to Canvas by the due date.

Online proctoring is NOT required. You may take the exam at your convenience at the time and location of your choice during the exam period. The Midterm Exam will be available from Thursday, October 12, 8:00a (MT) until Tuesday, October 17, 11:59p (MT).

Time Length: You will have 90 minutes to complete the exam once you begin. Once you begin the exam you MUST complete it in one sitting.

Format and Content: Consists of 11 questions covering both terminology and application of material covered up to this point in the semester. Focus will be placed on the following:

  • Calculate cost savings by altering the queries.
  • Evaluate and analyze unnecessary inefficiencies in SQL queries and calculate the cost savings when inefficiencies are removed.
  • Explain what happens when changes are made related to dates based upon the Two Year Digit Cutoff setting.
  • Compare SQL queries and determine cost differences and explain the reason for the differences.
  • Identify which database resources will be locked and the lock type while a query is executed and what the response of the query will be.
  • Identify field name(s) for recommended indexes using the Actual Execution Plan tool.
  • Identify server connection error and explain ways to fix the error.
  • List the specific steps to take to move (not copy) a database to production.
  • Identify lock type and request mode for a given SQL query.
  • Identify security concerns from the perspective of a DBA and provide a way to better address the concerns when provided database settings and a scenario.

Use of Resources: You may use your Textbook (hard copy or electronic) and/or PowerPoint slides from Chapter Modules. You may use your own hybrid activities and completed assignments. You may NOT use hybrid activities and completed assignments from other students in the class or otherwise. You may use Internet searches specifically related to help with exam topics (no use of Chegg.com or similar services, no use of ChatGPT or other related AI platforms). No other websites, programs, or files should be open.

This is an INDIVIDUAL exam so you may NOT correspond or work with any other students or individuals when completing the exam.

The policy on Academic Honesty will be strictly enforced.

The use of services such as Chegg, Course Hero, Bartleby, and etc. and/or Generative Artificial Intelligence platforms such as ChatGPT, Google Bard, Bing Chat, etc. for the completion of course requirements is a violation of the Academic Honesty Policy. The occurrence of such violations will result in the penalties provided under the Academic Honesty section of the Course Syllabus.

Assignment #5: Indexes

Open a new Word document and place your name and the course number at the top. Save the document as LastNameFirstName_A05. Use your HW SQL Server instance with the AdventureWorks database to complete the following steps. Use screenshots, labels and text descriptions to demonstrate completion.

1) With the Actual Execution Plan turned on, write queries on two different tables: Sales.SalesOrderHeader and Sales.SalesOrderDetail. Make the queries that you write be of sufficient complexity (e.g. WHERE, GROUP BY, ORDER BY, etc.) that the execution plan produced index recommendations. Place the SQL you wrote, and the a screenshot of the execution plan indicating recommended indexes, into your Word document. Be sure to record the costs of your two queries prior to implementing indexes on the recommended columns.

2) Run the Database Tuning Advisor on the two tables listed above. Place a screenshot of the recommended indexes in your Word document. 

3) Create the indexes identified in steps 1 and 2 above. Provide evidence you've created them through screenshots of the creation process. Be detailed with each step. In a written explanation, outline why adding these indexes should be helpful in enhancing database performance for your two queries. Discuss in writing any possible drawbacks you see to adding the indexes.

4) With the indexes created, re-run your queries from step 1 above with the execution plan turned on. Report the cost savings achieved, if any, through creation of your indexes. Be specific about cost improvement by comparing with the pre-index cost data.

5) Add the Full-text Indexes and Semantic Search feature to the database instance you're using. Provide evidence that you've done it through screenshots documenting the addition of the feature..

6) Write a query on the Sales.SpecialOffer table that includes the Category, Type, and Description columns. Use at least one of these columns in a WHERE clause in your query. Record and report the cost of this query in your assignment. Create a full-text index on the Category, Type, and Description columns on the Sales.SpecialOffer table in the AdventureWorks database. Provide evidence you've created the index through screenshots of the process. Re-run your query and examine, interpret and report your findings, including performance improvements, if any, that result from having the full-text index.

Submit your Word document to Canvas under Assignment #5.

To complete this hybrid activity,  do the following:

Open a new Word document and place your name and the course number at the top. Save the document as LastNameFirstName_HA07. Connect to your HW instance of SQL Server on your VM. You will use the AdventureWorks database to complete this hybrid activity.

1) Write a script that will add a new unicode data typed column to the HumanResources.EmployeePayHistory table called EncryptedRate. Create a new symmetric key that will do encryption by password and open the key. Write a SQL statement that will copy the values from the Rate column into the new EncryptedRate column, ensuring that the Rate values will be converted into a unicode format and encrypted using the new a symmetric key. To demonstrate that your encryption worked, write a SELECT SQL statement that displays all table columns, including the decrypted values in the EncryptedRate column. Copy and paste all of your SQL code into your Word document as Step 1. Close the symmetric key when you are finished.

2) Create a new asymmetric key that will do encryption by password. Write SQL that will add unicode data typed columns VacationHours2 and SickLeaveHours2 to the HumanResources.Employee table. Write SQL that will copy the Vacation and Sick Hours data in the Employee table into the new unicode columns, ensuring the values are converted to unicode and encrypted using the new asymmetric key. To demonstrate that your encryption worked, write a SELECT SQL statement that displays all table columns, including the decrypted values in the VacationHours2 and SickLeaveHours2 columns. Copy and paste all of your SQL code into your Word document as Step 2.

3) Write SQL that will add a unicode data typed column called EmpPassword to the Person.EmailAddress table. Write SQL to set everyone's email password to be D4t4b&se, in a hash+salt format. The salt will be the last six characters of each record's Rowguid, in reverse order. Add the reversed six characters to the beginning of the password, then hash the whole string. Write a SELECT SQL statement that will select all columns of the EmailAddress table except the EmpPassword column. Ensure that the WHERE clause is configured to successfully challenge the hash+salt passwords stored in EmpPass. Copy and paste all of your SQL code into your Word document as Step 3.

Submit your Word document to Canvas by the due date.

The past decade has produced a myriad of technologies to enhance and ensure database continuity under a variety of conditions. For this hybrid activity, you will research one high availability technology for any major database platform. Please do NOT select SQL Server Replication since we will examine this one in detail in class and in your homework assignment. Be sure to cite all sources of information you use in responding to the following steps:

1.Open a new Word document and save it as LastNameFirstName_HA08.

2. Write a summary of your chosen high availability technology. Be sure to identify the database platform the technology is for (e.g. Oracle, SQL Server, etc.), and if it is made by the database company or a different party.

2. Discuss the product's features. How does it work to ensure high availability? Does it have the ability to leave the database online even during maintenance?

3. Discuss any risks or drawbacks identified with the technology.

4. How much does the product cost? Does it have both up front and ongoing costs, or is it simply an included feature that is covered in the cost of the RDBMS?

5. Does the technology have any special administrative requirements associated with its use? Discuss special training, hardware, networking or software that may be required of an organization that decides to adopt the technology.

Upload your document addressing all five of these points by the due date.

Assignment #6: Replication

Before starting this assignment, please review this Word document.

Complete the following steps:

1) Open a new Word document and place your name and the course number at the top. Save the document as LastNameFirstName_Assignment06. As you add content to the document in the steps below, label things clearly.

2) Connect to the HW instance of SQL Server on your VM. Take screenshots to document each step and paste these into your Word document with descriptive text for each screenshot.

3) Install the Replication feature on your HW SQL Server instance and re-start the instance. Use the Installed Features Discovery Report to show the SQL Server Replication feature installed correctly.

4) Create a Transactional publication to share the following content from the AdventureWorks Database (Sales.SalesOrderHeader table):

  • SalesOrderID
  • OrderDate, DueDate, ShipDate
  • CustomerID, SalesPersonID
  • Subtotal, TaxAmt, Freight, TotalDue

Only publish data for the year 2014. When you set up the replication, set it to recur every minute for an hour. Take screenshots and label these in your Word document to describe the process of creating your publication. Make sure you document *every* requirement listed above, so I can tell that you did all of them.

5) Create a new subscriber database called AWSales. Set this database up to subscribe to the publication you created in Step 4. Set the subscription to run continuously. Take screenshots and label these in your Word document to describe the creation of your subscription.

6) SalesOrderID 68135 was priced 20% below the correct amount. Write an UPDATE to correct the Subtotal, Tax, Freight and Total amounts in the AdventureWorks database.  Write a SELECT statement in the AWSales database to show that the corrected prices for this SalesOrderID have been updated in the subscription database. All of the activities in this step must be documented by labeled screenshots in your Word document, showing that your production database (AdventureWorks) and subscriber database (AWSales) have data that matches.

7) Add (INSERT) a record in the AdventureWorks table. Show that the subscribed database has been kept in sync with the production database. Document this with labeled screenshots.

Submit your Word document to Canvas by the due date.

assignment_name: SUBMIT HA: Automated Backup of MySQL
description:
To complete this hybrid activity, open a new Word document named LastNameFirstName_HA09, and complete the following steps:

1. Conduct research to determine how to automate a backup of MySQL databases.

2. Write a batch (.bat) script for Windows that will backup the PhoneLog database in your MySQL instance.

  • If you don't have a PhoneLog database in MySQL, make one and put a couple of tables in it with a few records in each table.
  • Write your batch script such that the backup file will be stored in a folder located at c:\MySQL_Backups. Store your batch file in this folder.
  • Each new backup file that is generated should have a file name conforming to this format: PhoneLogBackup_YYYYMMDD-HHmmss.sql
  • Run your batch file manually a few times over the course of a few minutes by double clicking on it. Check your backup folder to make sure files are being created and that they contain back up scripts for your database.

3. Create a Windows Scheduled Task to run your batch file to back up your PhoneLog MySQL database.

  • You can do this with "Create a Basic Task"
  • You will need to set it up to trigger daily, and then you should edit the trigger to repeat every 5 minutes for 1 day.
  • Use screenshots to provide evidence that the backup is successfully occurring every five minutes. Demonstrate that the backup files are not empty and that each new backup file is being created with the appropriate file name containing an accurate date and time.

Submit to Canvas both your batch file and a document with screenshot evidence showing that your scheduled task was set up (show every step!) and is working correctly.

assignment_name: SUBMIT HA: Convert Relational Design to Document Store (NoSQL)
description:
To complete this Hybrid Activity, convert this relational ER diagram to a JSON file for a NoSQL database.

The base-level key is Patients. You need only set up the JSON document structure with keys; you do not need to put any data into the document. Use these points to help you organize your JSON:

  • Each patient is a string object with six elements.
  • Each patient will have an array of appointments.
  • Each appointment will have one, and only one, doctor. Doctors are string objects with three elements. The same doctor can appear many times throughout the JSON document, but only one doctor is associated with each Appointment.
  • Each appointment will have an array of bills. Each bills will have four elements, and an array of payments. Payments will have four elements.

Save your JSON script as a text file or in a Word document named LastNameFirstName_HA10 and upload it to Canvas by the due date.

Using the editor of your choice complete this assignment, do the following.

1) Write a MongoDB script that will create a new NoSQL database called Restaurants.

2) Add three restaurants to your database. Write one insert statement for each of your restaurants. Conform to the following data needs:

  • Each restaurant will have only one type (e.g. fast food, ethnic, fine dining, etc.)
  • Every restaurant has a name. Some restaurants are single location, and others (e.g. Outback Steakhouse, Applebee's, etc.) have more than one location. Design your insert statements to allow each restaurant to have as many locations as necessary. Make sure that at least one of the three restaurants you add has more than one location.
  • Each location will have a unique address, city, state, ZIP code and phone number.
  • Each restaurant will have a menu with multiple menu items. All locations of a restaurant will use the same menu. Menu items have an ID, item name, item description and price.
  • Each location will have many reviews (think Yelp or Google Review). Each review will have an ID, title, reviewer, review date and reviewer comments.

Save the file as LastNameFirstName_Assignment07 and submit your script to Canvas by the due date.

Assignment #8: NoSQL Scripting

Using the In Class Products MongoDB database, write a script that contains the following five queries:

1) Find all products that cost more than $15. Display all fields.

2) Display only the product name, product description, and supplier for all products with a review that contains the word "nulla", whether those letters are in upper or lower case. You must search for the string, not an object identifier, in case other products are later added that should also return in this query.

3) Display all fields for all products that have ten or more reviews. Again, write this so that even if there were millions of products in the database, all that have more than ten reviews would be displayed..

4) Ice Cream is on sale for $2.99. This applies to any products with 'ice cream' in the product name. Write an update query to change the price for all ice cream products.

Hint: see https://www.simplilearn.com/tutorials/mongodb-tutorial/mongodb-update-document, "How to Update Multiple Documents?" as well as implementing the updateMany() method.

5) We will no longer sell products with 'Oil' in their names. Write a query that will remove them from your database.

Copy and paste all of your Assignment #8 statements into a script file (.docx or .txt is fine) named LastNameFirstName_Assignment08 and submit it.

Submit your assignment to Canvas by the due date.

Assignment Objectives:

You own a House Painting company of three people.  In this assignment you will practice estimating the amount of work needed to complete the painting job for a new house project. 

Estimating in Scrum:

In Scrum, we estimate user stories to help determine how many user stories can be accomplished in our Sprint time frams.  Over time a Scrum team will become better at knowing their velocity (how many user stories they can complete in a Sprint).

Scrum teams use different units to help them estimate: story points, T-shirt sizes, even Gummi Bears. We will use T-shirt size estimates (XS, S, M, L etc.) to help us estimate our House Painting Project because most of us have bought a T-shirt and understand this type of ordering.   

The estimating process asks you to compare user stories against each other by level of difficulty or how hard or easy they will be for the team to complete.  The very most basic/simple user story might be an XS, while the very most complex/hardest might be an XXL.  In this House Painting Project, we are comparing different rooms in a house by their level of difficulty to paint.  The most simple room to paint might be a hallway (XS) while the most complex might be a room like a kitchen that required lots of taking and care (XXL).  How does a basic bedroom compare to a hallway or a kitchen?  Probably somewhere in between these in difficulty.

Work to be estimated:

Painting each room will require each of these tasks: Room Prep (covering carpet and furniture, taping ceilings and baseboards, and removing outlet covers), painting the room, and room clean-up.

You will paint the following rooms: 

Main Bathroom (10x8)

Main Bedroom (15x18) and on suite bathroom (10x12)

Kids Bathroom (8x8)

Bedroom 1 (10x14)

Bedroom 2 (12x13)

Kitchen (18x21)

Hallway (6x10)

Livingroom (20x16)

Two-car Garage (20x35)

Create T-Shirt Estimate Labels

For each room, estimate the amount of work needed to complete the task using the t-shirt labels: XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL.

Assignment Objectives:

You own a House Painting company of three people.  In this assignment you will think through what it means for a room to be completely done. 

Definition of Done:

In Scrum, the definition of done is used as a checklist of all of the tasks that must be completed for work to be done. It is a tool to help all team members understand what it means for a task to be completed. In Scrum, "done means done". In other words, before a team member can say that a task is "done" all of the items in the checklist must be 100% completed. In part 1 of this assignment, you estimated how much effort would be required to complete each of the following rooms:

Main Bathroom (10x8)

Main Bedroom (15x18) and on suite bathroom (10x12)

Kids Bathroom (8x8)

Bedroom 1 (10x14)

Bedroom 2 (12x13)

Kitchen (18x21)

Hallway (6x10)

Livingroom (20x16)

Two-car Garage (20x35)

In this project you need to come up with the definition of done for your business. Think through what it means for a room to be completely done in a painting job. Create your definition of done checklist and submit it for grading.

Assignment Objectives:

You own a House Painting company of three people.  In this assignment you will build a Burndown chart for your project. 

Burndown Chart:

In Scrum, a Burndown chart is used to communicate progress during the execution of a sprint. In part 1 of this assignment, you estimated how much effort would be required to complete each of the following rooms. Assume the following times to complete each of the rooms.

Room Estimated Hours
Main Bathroom (10x8) 6 hours
Main Bedroom (15x18) and on suite bathroom (10x12) 12 hours
Kids Bathroom (8x8) 6 hours
Bedroom 1 (10x14) 8 hours
Bedroom 2 (12x13) 8 hours
Kitchen (18x21) 16 hours
Hallway (6x10) 4 hours
Livingroom (20x16) 10 hours
Two-car Garage (20x35) 6 hours

You sent a two person crew to complete the job. Each person works an eight hour day, so you expected the home to be completed in a week. The table below contains the expected amount of work remaining after each of the five work days. It also contains an the estimates made at the end of each day of the remaining hours to complete the house. 

Expected Hours Remaining Daily Estimated Hours Remaining
Day 1 64 61
Day 2 48 48
Day 3 32 35
Day 4 16 18
Day 5 0 0

Construct a Burndown chart to highlight the project progress. You may upload either an image of your chart or the complete workbook.

Description

There are a number of loose ends that need to be tied up before we begin the semester. In this assignment, I need you to submit to me the following:

1 - A list of all of the members in your group.

2 - Your intentions for a project (this can be as simple as that you plan to complete the project from 3430). If you plan to complete your 3430 project, give me a one sentence description of that project. If you plan to propose a new project, please give me a little more information about what you'd like to do.

3 - Tell me who your client is. If you are completing the PA Project, I am your client.

4 - Tell me who your group leader is. If you plan to share this role, let me know how you plan to share it.

5 - Describe what you would like installed on your virtual machine for the semester.

Dust off the user stories that you created for your project in the INFO 3430 class. Review the user stories knowing what you now know about the project. Add to your list as needed to develop a comprehensive set of stories that represent the full set of features needed for the project. When you are done, share hand them and share them with your client.

Assignment Overview:

In this assignment, your team will decide on a Definition of Done (DoD) that will help to ensure you are implementing your user stories with high quality.  The DoD belongs to your whole team, so this is a team decision.  

For this assignment, your team will make an initial attempt at identifying the steps or tasks needed to complete a generic user story,  Think back to the House Painting Project where the DoD contained steps for completing the painting of a room with high quality.  For your team DoD the major parts of implementing a user story might be: Design Checklist, Build Checklist, Integrate Checklist, and maybe a Test & Document Checklist.   As your team completes the tasks in each of the checklists you will have a user story that is "Done" and has been implemented with high quality.  Think of the DoD as defining the "full stack" development of a user story that contains the front-end and back-end development.

So just what are the checklists you will need for your unique project.  That is the purpose of this assignment.  Your team will try to set these checklists as best you know at this point in the project.

Over time a team will fine-tune their DoD as part of the team's efforts at continuous improvement.

Instructions:

Create a definition of done document. Suggested areas for your checklist are:

Design:
Add tasks that might be needed to complete design of a user story.
Suggested tasks might include:
Design database elements and script database test data,
Mockup GUI following style guide
Pseodocode for server-side or JavaScript code
Test plans: Code test plan, security test plan, usability test plan etc.

Build:
Add tasks that might be needed to code user story.
Suggested tasks might include:
Add needed database elements and test data
Code GUI following style guide
Write well-documented code
Unit Testing
Apply needed security measures

Integrate:
Add tasks that might be needed to integrate the feature with the system.
Suggested tasks might include:
Merge feature into system.
Update database script.
Test system for security issues
Usability testing

Documentation:
Add tasks that might be needed to document the feature with the system.
Suggested tasks might include:
Add training documentation
Add System Admin documentation

Your team should fine tune these steps to be acceptable to your team and client needs.
Depending on your system, development tools, and processes you may want to make changes to these checklists.  After each sprint of development, the team will again have an opportunity to modify the DoD.

Submission:

Upload your definition of done document to this assignment in Canvas.

After receiving feedback from the professor and your client, revise your list of user stories.

Please submit your revised user stories to this assignment.

Assignment Overview:

Before Sprint Planning begins take a few minutes and estimate the effort required to complete your user stories. Working with your team Product Owner, and looking at the highest priority of user stories on the Product Backlog, your team will set a Sprint Goal.  This should be a short phrase to describe the overall goal of the Sprint.

Next, your team determines the number of user stories they think can be completed in the time-frame of the Sprint. These user stories are placed on the Sprint 1 Backlog.  Then your team will add a Description and Acceptance Criteria to each user story card.

Next, generate a set of tasks associated with each of the user stories in the sprint backlog.

Lastly team members will sign up as owners of tasks related to the items in the Sprint Backlog.  To do this team members should add a team member's initials or first name to each task in the backlog.  When you sign up for a task, you are committing to the team that you will complete this task.  More than one team member can sign up to work on a task.  Do not sign up at the user story level but at a task level.

Note: Best practice says that more than one person should work on a user story if you want it to have high quality.  For example, the person who codes the user story should not conduct all the QA tests on the user story. 

Instructions:

Sprint 1 Planning should include the following steps:

Step 1.  Set a sprint goal.
The team and Product Owner should look at the top user stories in the Product Backlog and  decide on a short phrase or sentence that might define an over-arching goal for Sprint 1. 

Step 2.  Select the user stores for the sprint backlog.
Edit each user story and provide a sentence or two Description and a list of Acceptance Criteria (steps team might use to demonstrate to the client that the story is completed) in the Description area of the card.  Add any attachments or documents that will help describe the story. 

Step 3.  Determine the tasks associated with each backlog item and assign team members to each task.

  1. For each backlog item determine the high-level tasks that must be completed to complete the item.
  2. As a team, decided which of the tasks each team member will complete during the sprint. As you complete the sprint, you may decide to change these assignments.

Submission:

Submit your sprint goal, list of sprint backlog items, list of tasks for those items, and team member assignments to this Canvas assignment.

Assignment Overview:

For this assignment you will reflect on the success of the sprint. 

Instructions:

The sprint review should include the following steps:

Step 1.  Review the sprint goal.
Review the goal you created for the sprint. In one or two sentences, reflect on the progress your team made toward accomplishing that goal.

Step 2.  Review the completion of each sprint backlog item.
List each sprint backlog item. If an item is "done" (meets your team's definition of done), note that it is done. If a task is not done, it will be placed back in the project backlog where it will be selected for completion in a future sprint. If the backlog items needs to be modified or split into multiple items, now is a good time to do that.

Submission:

Submit your sprint goal, list of sprint backlog items, list of tasks for those items, and team member assignments to this Canvas assignment.

Assignment Overview:

The retrospective in an opportunity for the team to reflect on their group processes. Here you will discuss what went well and what your group could improve upon for the next sprint. This is not a time to discuss what you completed during the sprint. That will happen during the review. 

Instructions:

Please report on the following:

Step 1.  Briefly reflect on your group process.
Make two lists. The first list should outline the things your group did well during the sprint. The second list should include those things that you would like to change or improve on for the next sprint.

Step 2.  Make a specific plan for improvement.

Select one or two items from the "improvement" list you generated in step 1 that you will work on during the next sprint. During the next retrospective, you will be asked to reflect on how well your team addressed this improvement item during sprint 2.

Submission:

Submit your retrospective to this Canvas assignment. Only one retrospective submission is required of each team.

Please report on the following:

Step 1. Discuss improvement over sprint 3.

List the item(s) of improvement you identified in the last sprint retrospective. How well did your team make improvements in these areas during sprint 3.

Step 2.  Briefly reflect on your group process.
Make two lists. The first list should outline the things your group did well during the sprint. The second list should include those things that you would like to change or improve on for the next sprint.

Step 3.  Make a specific plan for improvement.

Select one or two items from the "improvement" list you generated in step 2 that you will work on during the next sprint. During the next retrospective, you will be asked to reflect on how well your team addressed this improvement item during sprint 4.

Submission:

Submit your retrospective to this Canvas assignment. Only one retrospective submission is required of each team.

Assignment Overview:

For this assignment you will reflect on the success of the sprint. 

Instructions:

The sprint review should include the following steps:

Step 1.  Review the sprint goal.
Review the goal you created for the sprint. In one or two sentences, reflect on the progress your team made toward accomplishing that goal.

Step 2.  Review the completion of each sprint backlog item.
List each sprint backlog item. If an item is "done" (meets your team's definition of done), note that it is done. If a task is not done, it will be placed back in the project backlog where it will be selected for completion in a future sprint. If the backlog items needs to be modified or split into multiple items, now is a good time to do that.

Submission:

Submit your sprint goal, list of sprint backlog items, list of tasks for those items, and team member assignments to this Canvas assignment.

Assignment Overview:

Before Sprint Planning begins take a few minutes and estimate the effort required to complete your user stories. Working with your team Product Owner, and looking at the highest priority of user stories on the Product Backlog, your team will set a Sprint Goal.  This should be a short phrase to describe the overall goal of the Sprint.

Next, your team determines the number of user stories they think can be completed in the time-frame of the Sprint. These user stories are placed on the Sprint 4 Backlog.  Then your team will add a Description and Acceptance Criteria to each user story card.

Next, generate a set of tasks associated with each of the user stories in the sprint backlog.

Lastly team members will sign up as owners of tasks related to the items in the Sprint Backlog.  To do this team members should add a team member's initials or first name to each task in the backlog.  When you sign up for a task, you are committing to the team that you will complete this task.  More than one team member can sign up to work on a task.  Do not sign up at the user story level but at a task level.

Note: Best practice says that more than one person should work on a user story if you want it to have high quality.  For example, the person who codes the user story should not conduct all the QA tests on the user story. 

Instructions:

Sprint 1 Planning should include the following steps:

Step 1.  Set a sprint goal.
The team and Product Owner should look at the top user stories in the Product Backlog and  decide on a short phrase or sentence that might define an over-arching goal for Sprint 4. 

Step 2.  Select the user stores for the sprint backlog.
Edit each user story and provide a sentence or two Description and a list of Acceptance Criteria (steps team might use to demonstrate to the client that the story is completed) in the Description area of the card.  Add any attachments or documents that will help describe the story. 

Step 3.  Determine the tasks associated with each backlog item and assign team members to each task.

  1. For each backlog item determine the high-level tasks that must be completed to complete the item.
  2. As a team, decided which of the tasks each team member will complete during the sprint. As you complete the sprint, you may decide to change these assignments.

Submission:

Submit your sprint goal, list of sprint backlog items, list of tasks for those items, and team member assignments to this Canvas assignment.

Team Final Acceptance and Deployment

The Acceptance and Deployment document is like a final review for the entire project.

Your client will be asked to approve or waive the functional requirements for the system.

Your client will sign off on user documentation, and system administration and maintenance documentation that was delivered to them.

Your client will sign off on how your team delivered the system, and the system deployment plan.  Please provide a paragraph of information that details whether or not the system will be deployed and its future use.

Note: Your team should review this document with your client during your Sprint 3 Review meeting and get needed signatures.

Instructions:

The scrum master must sign and submit the completed Acceptance Document with signatures in this assignment.  The user and system administration documentation must also be submitted with this assignment.  Do not submit a video for this assignment.  The Acceptance and Deployment document review should be part of the Team Sprint 3 Review video.

Sample Acceptance and Deployment Document

The Acceptance document should contain the following:

  • Client/ Primary Stakeholder name
  • List of System requirements, each with an accepted or waived field, a client  signature, and date and room for a comments if needed.
  • User Documentation and System Administration/Maintenance Documentation received and approval signature, and date
  • System Turn Over and Deployment
    Provide a paragraph description of the system deployment status, if deployed who will be responsible for maintenance of the system.  If the system will not be deployed, explanation should be provided.  Provide client approval signature, and date, or if deployment is waived, comments and date
  • Training conducted - signature and date
  • Scrum Master signature and date

Submission:

Submit the signed Acceptance and Deployment document.  
Create a copy of the user documentation and system administration/maintenance documentation and attach it to this assignment.  Do not link to the documentation, please provide a copy that you submit.

Carefully check that your team has included all the components required in the grading rubric for this assignment.

Note: Do not attach a video for this assignment.  Go over this document and get signatures as part of the Sprint 3 Review meeting with your client.

Team System Video Walk-Through

Purpose:

(used for project archival, program marketing and accreditation purposes)

Guidelines:

Create a video screencast that summarizes your system project. 

  1. You may have one or more team members do the recording.  All team members should participate in planning the video.
  2. Assume a non-technical target audience:  may be IS&T program stakeholders, future students, advisory board members, your grandmother...
  3. Length of the video 5 minutes 
  4. Keep the tone professional.
  5. You will probably want to create a script to guide your screencast. 
  6. Must demonstrate working system, not just use screenshots.
  7. To save time, you can pause and restart while filling out forms or changing screens.
  8. Do an audio test to make sure audio is in a mid range.
  9. May use tool like: Microsoft Teams

Required Video Organization:

  1. Introduce the team, must include photo of the team.
  2. Introduce the client and their problem/need
  3. Discuss tools and methods used to develop the system
  4. Demonstrate key system features, forms and reports
  5. Discuss lessons learned or challenges overcome by the team
  6. Provide a conclusion where you discuss the deployment and future of project

Submission:

Upload the video file (not just a link) in this assignment by the due date.

For this assignment you will reflect on your role in the the success of the sprint.

Write two or three sentences describing the contributions you made to your team's efforts during this sprint.

Step 2.  List the specific backlog items you worked on during the sprint.

Therefore, it is not expected that you played a role in completing all of the backlog items. It is ok to state that you did not work on all items, but you should have made at least some contribution on or more items in the backlog.

Task 6 —Making VMs easier to identify

Throughout the class you will be using the VMs quite a lot, to make them easier to identify I have created a couple of graphics that you can use as the desktop wallpaper to make the VMs a bit easier to identify.  You will download the images and set them as your wallpaper.

Steps

  1. From your, Debian-1 VM open the web browser (probably firefox). After you double-click on the desktop icon just wait, you probably won’t see an hourglass or indicator that it is starting, just be patient.  If it doesn’t start after a couple of minutes try again. [If you are still having problems make sure that they are on the NAT adapter and click on the WICD to disconnect and reconnect--you might also try rebooting the machine]
  2. You should have an internet connection if all went well.
  3. Enter is.gd/IT2600 or go to canvas and your login credentials navigate to IT2600>files>T01 History and VMs 
  4. Right-click on the appropriate file png and select download or save link as depending on your version of browser
  5. Accept the default location and filename click Save.
  6. Now set the image as your desktop wallpaper.
    1. right-click on your VMs desktop
    2. Select Desktop Preferences
    3. Click on the little folder by the wallpaper name
    4. Navigate to root/downloads then select png
    5. Click Open
    6. Now click Close to close the desktop preferences dialog
  7. Repeat this procedure for Debian 2 and 3 using the appropriate images.

assignment_name: 2: IT2600 Lab Exploring Network Segments (Layer 2 Data Link Layer)
description:
Layer 2: Data Link Layer (from wikipedia)

The data link layer provides node-to-node data transfer—a link between two directly connected nodes. It detects and possibly corrects errors that may occur in the physical layer. It defines the protocol to establish and terminate a connection between two physically connected devices. It also defines the protocol for flow control between them.

IEEE 802 divides the data link layer into two sublayers:[21]

  • Medium access control (MAC) layer – responsible for controlling how devices in a network gain access to a medium and permission to transmit data.
  • Logical link control (LLC) layer – responsible for identifying and encapsulating network layer protocols, and controls error checking and frame synchronization.

The MAC and LLC layers of IEEE 802 networks such as 802.3 Ethernet, 802.11 Wi-Fi, and 802.15.4 ZigBee operate at the data link layer.

The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) is a data link layer protocol that can operate over several different physical layers, such as synchronous and asynchronous serial lines.

The ITU-T G.hn standard, which provides high-speed local area networking over existing wires (power lines, phone lines and coaxial cables), includes a complete data link layer that provides both error correction and flow control by means of a selective-repeat sliding-window protocol.

Security, specifically (authenticated) encryption, at this layer can be applied with MACSec.

IT2600 Lab Exploring Network Segments (Layer 2 Data Link Layer)

Complete lab Lab 02-Exploring Network Segments.docx

Helpful resources in understanding this lab:

Dr. Lotfy Data Link Layer

IEEE 802  divides the data link layer into two sublayers: [21]

  • Medium access control  (MAC) layer – responsible for controlling how devices in a network gain access to a medium and permission to transmit data.
  • Logical link control  (LLC) layer – responsible for identifying and encapsulating network layer protocols, and controls error checking and frame synchronization.

The MAC and LLC layers of IEEE 802 networks such as  802.3   Ethernet,  802.11   Wi-Fi, and  802.15.4   ZigBee  operate at the data link layer.

The  Point-to-Point Protocol  (PPP) is a data link layer protocol that can operate over several different physical layers, such as  synchronous  and  asynchronous  serial lines.

The  ITU-T   G.hn  standard, which provides high-speed local area networking over existing wires (power lines, phone lines and coaxial cables), includes a complete data link layer that provides both  error correction  and flow control by means of a  selective-repeat   sliding-window protocol.

assignment_name: 5: IT2600 Lab Routing Task 1 Default Routes

5: IT2600 Lab Routing Task 4 Making Routes Persistent
5: IT2600 Lab Routing Task 5 Thinking it through
description:
Thinking it through

As your network is currently configured, if Debian-1 sends data to a device on the 192.168.2.0 or 192.168.3.0 networks it sends the data to its default gateway (the pfsense box) then pfsense forwards it to Router-1, which means that the traffic destined for those two networks will cross the 192.168.1.0 network twice.  What would you have to do to prevent this inefficiency?  Please give me a word document or pdf.

Current configuration routing causes the video files stored on Debian1 to travel to Debian 3 network like so:

Debian1->pfsense->router1->router2->Debian3

Here is what the traceroute could change to be current is the first one and desired is the second one:

Since rewiring is very expensive and time-consuming is there something that can be done in software to remedy having it repeated twice (Debian1 and Pfsense sending the same message on the same LAN)

If you are still having problems figuring out how routing works look at the IT2600 Lab Routing Explanation Document found in the files section of the course to make sure you understand what is happening with the routing.  This document shows the routing from Debian3 out....think it through what happens with the Routing as Debian 1 tries to talk with Debian2 or Debian3.

I am not asking you to go to the expense of rewiring the network.  Physically you have to get the wires through.  For example, pfsense is located where the ISP enters the building in the basement networking closet.  Debian1 is the network on the first floor and Debian2 is on the network on the second.  Router 2 is a WAP located on the third floor.  Debian3 is a network of laptops used by executives.   It would require rewiring and a lot of expense to hook up the WAP on the 3rd floor directly to Pfsense down the basement.  It is much easier/cost-effective to wire it to the 2nd floor router.

I am looking for a software solution using something that you have learned in this lab.  I have highlighted the routing I would like you to be able to change.  What commands have you learned to work with routing is other tasks in this lab?

assignment_name: 13: IT2600 Lab Microsoft Azure Fundamentals of Computer Networking
description:
You'll review the fundamental principles of computer networking

In this module, you will:

  • List the different network protocols and network standards.
  • List the different network types and topologies.
  • List the different types of network devices used in a network.
  • Describe network communication principles like TCP/IP, DNS, and ports.
  • Describe how these core components map to Azure networking.

You will need to sign in with an email address to get your badge.  

You do not need to read all the material as you have had this information in the course.  Just look through the material and read the portions you would like to review or expand your knowledge on.

assignment_name: 13: IT2600 Lab Microsoft Fundamentals of Network Security
description:
Explore the fundamentals of computer networking security and monitoring.

In this module, you will learn how to:

  • Describe the client-server network model.
  • Describe the difference between authentication and authorization.
  • List the different network firewall types.
  • List the types of items to monitor in a network.
  • Map core network components to Azure networking.

You will need to sign in with an email address to get your badge.  

You do not need to read all the material as you have had this information in the course.  Just look through the material and read the portions you would like to review or expand your knowledge on.  

Complete https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/network-fundamentals-2/

and upload a screenshot with the following here on canvas:

Please include your name and the badge or other evidence of completing this learning.

Here is a video of one way of doing this:

You will have less than 5 minutes to stand in front of the class and present a current topic in networking.  If you are in an online-only course you will have to do this virtually by being in front of a webcam or cell phone and upload the video file. To select a topic, start in an area you know very well and find out what has just happened or what is about to happen.  For example, if I know about IPv6  but I do not know about network cabling then I should pick a topic such as the conversion to IPv6  to share rather than new innovations to IEEE standards.  

You may use slides, powerpoints, short video clips, anything you can make work in front of the class--such as writing on the whiteboard or bringing in equipment or a picture.

 In your five-minute presentation you should use the following language (where X is your topic):

“X is important because…”

“What I learned about X is…”

“Some other topics that are related to X are…”

"In the last month this is what has happened with X...."  use a news source to answer this question

"People who understand X have ... jobs and make ... salary"  use indeed.com or similar site to answer this question

After completing this assignment the student should be able to:

  • recognize important current topics in networking
  • gather and organize information
  • present information to colleagues

description:
20 big points for completing the student evaluation!  Submit your receipt as proof of completion.

Students can complete any open surveys through myUVU by following the steps below.

  1. Login to myUVU using your UV ID and password.
  2. Click on the Student tab. In the menu on the left side.
  3. Click on "My Academics."
  4. Under the heading "Current Semester Information" click on the "Rate Your Instructors" link.
  5. A list of your current registrations will come up. When the SRI surveys are open, a link to rate your instructor will appear on the bottom left side next to the Course Evaluation title.
  6. Once you have responded to each item on the survey, you MUST click on the "Submit Evaluation" link at the bottom of the page to submit your responses.
  7. You will see a confirmation receipt. You can print this page, if needed, and close the window. To repeat the process for a different course, click on that courses link in myUVU.

If you have problems with the automated survey Email, or logging into myUVU, please call the UVU IT Service Desk at 801-863-8888. For questions or suggestions regarding the survey please email sri@uvu.edu.

Welcome to IT-2700!  Please post the following information about yourself:

  • Name you want us to call you
  • Where you are from
  • Tell us of any experience you may have in network administration or in CyberSecurity. (Many students have none. Some students are already working in the field. Tell us where you fit in the spectrum!)
  • Some good advice that you have received in your life

Please post your initial reply as soon as possible and return this week to comment on your classmates' posts.  Let's get to know each other!

assignment_name: Discuss: Final Review (CLOSES WEDNESDAY, Note multiple deadlines!)
description:
Discuss

This discussion is designed to help you get ready to take your Final.

As a way to help you prepare for the exam, please write two (2) multiple choice questions (with 4-6 choices as possible answers) from each chapter covered in the exam.  You will need to post these in a SINGLE post by 5 PM Monday evening. Do not include the answer at this time. (You may not use questions from the quizzes, Review Questions, or Knowledge Checks in the textbook.) You will not be able to see the posts from other students until after you have posted your submission. Please write your questions carefully so the answer is not obvious, nor so obscure or ambiguous to be unclear. Hopefully some of your questions will be good enough to be used in the exam in future semesters.

Between 5 PM and midnight Tuesday, post the answers to your questions. You should also then go through and comment on others submissions until midnight Wednesday.  Do not be afraid to ask questions or give your opinions. 

Thursday Aug 11 or Friday Aug 12 you should take the Final exam!

Grading Criteria:

  • 30 points for two properly written multiple-choice questions
  • 10 points for posting during the correct time frames
  • 10 points for commenting or questioning on other submissions.  I am looking for at least two relevant comments.
    (You will not get credit for comments like 'Great job' or 'I really like your question'.)

Instructions:

  • Download (or create) a Windows VM for use this semester in completing your lab assignments.  I recommend using VirtualBox. You may use VMWare if you prefer, but you will need the full VMWare Workstation (not just the player) to complete the assignments.
    • This VM should run Windows 10 with MSEdge browser.
    • You may download this VM from Microsoft Edge Developer: Virtual Machines
  • You will need to install VirtualBox if you are doing this on your own computer. Take note of the default username and password, and then load the Win10 VM.
  • Once the VM is running, create a new user, named your first name.  (I would create a user named George.) 
    • Assign a 4 character password to each user.
  • Then create a second user, named your last name. (I would create a user named Hickman.)
  • Then create a third user, named InfoSec.
  • Take a screen shot of the users pane in Control Panel showing a list of users and paste it into a word processing document containing your name, HO-Lab 00, and the date.
    • George Hickman
      HO-Lab 0
      January 1, 2000
  • Submit a PDF file of the document to Canvas by the due date.

assignment_name: Hands-On Project Lab 1-1: Examine Data Breaches -- Visual
description:
Submit

Hands-On Project 1-1 from the book. (ALWAYS Hands-On Project, NEVER Case Project!)

Deliverables for Book Lab assignments include a written description of what you did, what you learned in the experience (especially if you had to vary from the published directions), and screenshots of any responses or reports generated.  If the report is long, you do NOT need to include the whole thing, just a representative part of at the start will be fine. (You may take a screenshot of the active window in Windows by pressing Alt-Printscreen.)  The image can then be pasted in your word processor and saved.  I am not looking for a travel log here (Don't say 'I clicked this, I saw this, here’s a photo'.) I am specifically looking for you to tell me what assignments were things you had not known about or done before, your reactions to the lab, and what value or applicability you find in the exercise.

Instructions:

  • Complete HO Lab 1-1
  • Create a written description of your experience, including screenshots
  • Export and upload a PDF to this assignment.
    • Your submission must be turned in with a .PDF format. I don't mind what program you use to create it, but make sure you export is as a PDF to turn in.

Grading Criteria:

  • 3 points for Screenshot, 2 points for typed description
    • Full credit if you follow lab instructions, include a screenshot, and have a typed response
    • Partial credit if turned in late or doesn't contain a screenshot or description.

Here's an example if you need one.

assignment_name: Introductions Discussion Board (Initial Video due Thursday, August 25. Responses to at least 2 peers due Tuesday, August 30.)
description:
Introductions (Initial video due Thursday, August 25, 11:59pm. Responses to at least 2 other students due Tuesday, August 30, 11:59pm.)

02 unread replie111 replies.

Hi everyone!

This is a discussion board for us to introduce ourselves to each other.  I'm super excited about teaching Business Stats this semester and can't wait to get to know all of you.

Please record a short video of you introducing yourself.  You can capture video right from your Discussion Board post the Rich Content Editor. This initial post is due by Thursday, August 25, 11:59pm. (I enter this as the due date in Canvas just so you don't forget to post your initial video on time.)

 

Be sure to answer the following questions in your initial video:

1 - Name that you preferred to be called.

2 - Major and how you think Statistics can be applied to your career choice (or business in general).

3 - Dream vacation spot.

Respond to at least two of your peers' posts no later than Monday, August 30, 11:59pm. (You can just write your responses - they do not need to be a video.)

 

Discussion Board Guidelines

What is a “Substantive” Response?

Substantive responses to most discussion questions should require a paragraph or two sometimes more—not simply a “yes,” “no” or one sentence answer. Feel free to agree or disagree with others, raise objections, ask questions of them, etc., but please do so with respect. Please also use supporting documentation and research to support statements and claims where appropriate. And while we always want to be cordial in our class communications, let’s avoid posting simple messages such as “yes,” “I agree,” or “thank you.” This will keep the forum less cluttered and ensure that viewed responses are substantive. 

 

Communicating in a Professional Manner:

A posting to a discussion forum constitutes formal written communication. As such, postings should follow the conventions of the English language. Proper grammar should be used and postings should be checked for spelling. It is recommended that you proofread your postings before they are submitted to the forum.

Unit 1 Discussion Day and Reflection

Reflection Due Tuesday, September 6, 11:59pm (minimum 300 words)

FYI: The Reflection submission will be checked through a plagiarism review software, so make sure to use your own thoughts and ideas. Resubmission is allowed.

 

Our Unit 1 Discussion Day will be in class on Wednesday, September 7.  Write a reflection on the topic prior to class that day so you are prepared to discuss the topic in class.  For the reflection, respond to the following questions in the textbox provided (minimum 300 words).

  1. What does “statistically literate” mean and why is it important to be “statistically literate?” Discuss this from the viewpoint of a citizen of a community and within a business context.
  2. The numerical aspect of statistics can be described as “numbers with social context.”  What does this mean to you?  Does this meaning change when specifically discussing business statistics?
