assignment_name: Unit 3 Discussion Day Reflection and Participation
description:
Read the following and respond to all three prompts in the space provided for your Reflection.

The Reflection is due Thursday, November 3, 11:59PM.

Our Discussion Day will be in class on Friday, November 4. Come prepared to discuss your Reflection.

 

(You do not need to read this article, but it’s here in case you want to review it.)

Bessant, K. C. (1992).  Instructional design and the development of statistical literacy.  Teaching Sociology, 20, 143-149.

 

The above article is an argument for the best way to teach statistics to sociology students.  Let’s discuss if some of their tenets apply to the business world as well.

 

Bessant claims that once students are in the workplace “the final analysis statistics courses are less important to students than basic reasoning skills and commonsense analysis… [S]tatistical procedures themselves are based on reason and assist us in refining [our] thinking” (p. 148-149).  

 

(1) Briefly (2-3 sentences) respond to the following:  Do you agree?  Do you think that basic reasoning skills and commonsense are more important than skilled statistical analysis?  Do you think that you can have a full understanding of one without some understanding of the other?  Why or why not?

 

Bessant further argues that the best way to teach these basic reasoning skills and commonsense analysis is “through very simple discussions of when and how certain statistics are to be employed in research or occupational settings” (p. 148).

 

“This does not mean that all [businesspersons] must become empiricists to serve their [organization]; rather we must understand statistical processes to defend… against the misuse of quantitative analysis.  Statistics students should be obliged to acquire a working knowledge of such procedures and how they can be applied to help support or disqualify one's own and others' contentions about…reality” (p. 149, edited to adjust for a business organization paradigm, rather than sociological).

 

With this argument in mind, you will create a scenario in a fictitious workplace in which a statistical analysis could be used inappropriately.  For example:

  • a statistical analysis that might include explicit or implicit biases,
  • a statistical analysis is used to penalize coworkers or employees unjustly,
  • a statistical analysis is used to construct unrealistic goals for the organization, or
  • a statistical analysis is supports current structures of inequality.

 

(2) Briefly (2-3 sentences) describe the fictitious workplace and the research that was performed (this does not need to include any of the specific statistical analyses, just include important elements such as the population or sample that was studied, the fictitious findings of the research, or anything that helps you to explain why the research was used inappropriately.)  I really do want this part to be brief – I want the focus of your reflection to be on the positivity of the third (3) prompt.

 

(3) Then discuss at least one way in which that same statistical analysis might be used to improve the employee experience or move the workplace culture in a positive direction.  This should be the bulk of your reflection and is what we will discussed in class. Be creative!  Be as idealistic as you want to be!  If you feel like your reflection sounds cheesy - you're on the right track!

assignment_name: Unit 4 Discussion Day Reflection and Participation
description:
In-Class Discussion Day Friday, December 2!

 

Corporate Social Responsibility

Let’s discuss Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR).  What is it?  Is it important?  Why or why not?  What does this have to do with stats?

Here’s an article to cover the basics of CSR.

https://www.newsweek.com/2019/11/29/corporate-social-responsibility-good-bad-1473934.html (Links to an external site.)

There are plenty of other things to read on the web about corporate social responsibility.  Read as much or as little as you want, just make sure you are prepared to have a discussion on the topic.

So, how does statistics relate to CSR?

And the real question:  How can statistics improve CSR?  This is what you will discuss in your Reflection. 

I don’t want to put too many limits on your initial post, but here are some questions to get you started:

(300 word minimum)

Is CSR important?  Why or why not?

How could CSR be implemented in your future profession?

How could statistics be used to improve the culture of CSR?

Describe a specific example (real or fiction) of using business statistics to contribute to CSR.

Unit 1 Project

Due Friday, September 9, 11:59pm.

This project is an examination of the change in home values in 2007. 

 

 Instructions: Download THREE Files

The following data set provides the home values in Fort Myers, Florida in January 2007 and then again in July 2007. 

-Fort_Myers_Sales.xlsx

Download Fort_Myers_Sales-1.xlsx

Download and open the following Word document.  This document contains the details of the project. You will report the results of your statistical analyses in this document. You will enter numbers into tables, copy images of graphs and charts from your R file, and answer questions in the provided spaces.Actions

-Unit 1 RStudio Project for Students.docx

When you have finished the project, please upload your completed Word document and the HTML R file (you do not need to upload the .Rmd file).

Tips:

Answer all questions in complete sentences!  Be thorough, clear, and specific.

Keep your R file organized. Input R chunks for each step in the appropriate place so that I can find your work easily.

Preview your R HTML file before you submit it.  Make sure that it shows all of the outputs, graphs, charts, etc.

If you are unclear about any instructions - ask me!  That's what I'm here for.

 

 

HINT: Creating a New Variable in R Studio

Unit 2 Project

Download the following data set.

Body_Temp.xlsx

 

Download the following Word document.

Complete your calculations in R Studio, but make sure that all of the questions are answered in the Word document. Please use complete sentences.

When your project is complete, upload both your completed Word document and your R HTML file for grading.

Unit 3 Project

 

  LastName,FirstName U3P.docx (Identical to what is here in Canvas, but in a Word document if you want it.)

 

Sample Unit 3 Project.docx   (Sample of what your project could look like and what content you could include. The numbers and responses in here are incorrect and incomplete. This is just to give you an idea of what I'm looking for.)

 

Description of Project

For this project, you will write a brief report on presidential approval rating trends for the first year in office.

You will find two 90% confidence intervals for the approval rating of each of the past four presidents, one when they first took office, and one for November of their first year in office.

 

Go to https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/other/president-biden-job-approval-7320.html and find the approval rating for when the President Biden first assumed office in 2021. (Hover your cursor over the line chart.) Construct the 90% confidence interval for the approval rating assuming that the sample size is 600 randomly chosen American citizens. Next find an approval rating for President Biden from November 2021 and construct another confidence interval for the approval rating using a sample size of 600. Comment on the changes between the intervals and provide possible causes for the changes, citing at least one source per president. Repeat this process with Trump, Obama, and Bush, finding an approval rating from when they first took office and then again from November of their first year in office.

 

Overall Design of Report

The overall design of your report should be professional, organized, thorough, and visually easy to follow. Your final report should be submitted into Canvas in a Word document (it does not need to be limited to 1 page). Feel free to use text boxes, shapes, flow charts, graphics, etc. to make your report have a professional appearance and well organized. You do not need to go overboard with the look of the report – it’s the content that matters most. Below are the five sections that must be included in your report (Research Design, Statistical Results, Discussion, Conclusion, References – you do not have to use these exact titles for your sections as long as each is clearly represented) along with the specific content needed in each section.

 

The entire report (other than the Statistical Results section) must be in complete sentences.

Please proofread your writing to ensure professional quality.

 

Sources

You will need to find some resources to back up your reasonings, justifications, and conclusions. I anticipate that most sources will be news articles, so make sure they come from a reputable journalistic organization. I’m not concerned about how you format your citations or references list, just be consistent. Include in-text citations and if you directly quote from a source, be sure to use quotation marks. You will also create a References section.

 

Research Design (20 points)

  1. What is the population being studied? What is the sample? (4 points)
  2. Are these sampling distributions of sample means or sample proportions? (4 points)
  3. Can we assume that the sampling distribution is normally distributed? Why or why not? (6 points)
  4. When finding these confidence intervals, will you use the critical z-score or critical t-score? Explain why one is used in this case and the other is not. (6 points)

 

Statistical Results (20 points)

This is the only section that does not need complete sentences. Please report each the following information for each confidence interval in a clear and organized manner such as a list or table. (2.5 points per CI)

President Name Initial/November Approval Rating

90% CI [lower bound, upper bound]

n = 600

p̅ = sample approval rating

sample date

 

Discussion (30 points)

For each of the past four presidents (Biden, Trump, Obama, and Bush) include the following in your report.

  1. Confidence intervals (restated from the Statistical Results section, but in sentence form) and findings including the sample approval rating and sample date for both the initial and November approval rating. (12 points)
  2. Describe the change in confidence intervals – did the approval rating increase, decrease, or remain about the same? Discuss whether the confidence intervals overlap and how this affects your analysis. (6 points)
  3. Discuss a possible cause, or causes, for the increase, decrease, or stagnation of the approval rating. This will require some speculation but cite at least one source as a basis for your reasoning. Be sure to use quotation marks for any direct quotes. (12 points)

 

Conclusion (20 points)

  1. Is there a general trend for approval ratings for the first year in office of a president? Did all four of these presidents’ approval rating in this report behave the same way? (10 points)
  2. What are some circumstances that might cause a president’s approval rating to go against this trend? (10 points)
  3. Include 1-2 sources to back up your conclusions about presidential approval ratings. Be sure to use quotation marks for any direct quotes.

 

References (10 points)

Include a works cited page with the necessary details of your sources. You can use whatever format you choose for your references, just be consistent and organized. Please include authors, dates, titles, organizations, and any URLs. I should be able to find your sources easily from your references list.

 

 

Final Submission (2 documents)

Please submit your Word document with your completed report and the R HTML document to show your work creating the confidence intervals.

 

Please let me know if you have any questions!

assignment_name: 1, 2, 3B Quiz (This quiz is in Canvas, not Connect)

description:
This task has two parts:

  1. Create a team ePortfolio using Google Sites.
  2. Create a team charter and put it on the home page of your Google Sites website.

You will add to this team ePortfolio throughout the course.

Google Sites ePortfolio Set Up

The platform you will use for your blogs is Google Sites. Review the tutorial (Links to an external site.) or the cheat sheet  (Links to an external site.)or jump right in by logging into your Google account with your UVU gmail, going  to Google Drive, and clicking on "+ New," and "Google Sites." One person on your team needs to create the website and give editing rights to the other team members. Anyone on your team can do this - just take the initiative. (The tutorial explains the options for sharing). 

Use your UVU gmail accounts - UVUID@my.uvu.edu so that each team member can access the site and edit the pages. Please also share your site with me at 10008795@my.uvu.edu. (I don't need editing privileges). You also need to share the site publicly in order for other teams to review it. A major advantage of Google sites is that you will be able to work on your page at the same time as other members of your team and see by name who is working on what in the same way you do with Google docs.

To view who is on your team, go to People in the left-hand menu bar of Canvas, and click on Groups. You will see all the teams and team members listed. 

Home Page - Team Charter

For your first assignment, create a home page for your consulting team and include an About Us section. Coordinate with each other on what you need to do for this assignment, your roles, and who is responsible for what. In essence, you are  are creating a team charter to guide your team's processes throughout the semester. Communicate your ideas using text, graphics, images, and multimedia. Provide the following information.

Vision and mission - What do you want to achieve as a team in terms of learning about organizational behavior theories, how to use them, and how to share your expertise with others?

Roles - What are your team roles and responsibilities? See ideas below. You can create your own roles and your own names for roles. You can also rotate roles to benefit from each other’s skills or develop new skills.

CEO – the team leader determines what needs to be done, directs the work, and keeps the team on track. The leader collaborates with team members to plan and organize tasks, distribute tasks, and ensure work is done on time and done well. The leader makes decisions in collaboration with the team, is responsible for communicating, addresses problems, and helps motivate team members. The leader facilitates teamwork.

Content Contributors – content contributors identify possible topics and scenarios for the team to consider. They generate discussion around ideas and push the team’s thinking in original and creative ways. Different types of content contributors are possible such as a resource contributor who identifies possible topics and scenarios and needed sources of information; an ideas contributor who suggests ways to solve problems, new methods for accomplishing tasks, or creative ways to present information; an analysis contributor who engages team members in critical analysis of ideas to consider them more carefully and make them stronger; this person ensures that all possibilities have been considered and the team’s ideas are solid and well thought out.

Specialists – specialists oversee areas such as synthesizing the content, editing and proofreading, page design, and multimedia selection. You could also have an evaluator responsible for generating discussion around ways in which the team needs to improve or a troubleshooter to focus on technical or even people issues.

Organizational culture. Determine what you want your organization (e.g., team) to look like—organizational culture is the underlying rules in an organization or how things get done. What behaviors do you expect of each other in terms of communication, contributions, responsibilities, completion of work, decision-making, discussion, and feedback? How will you work out personality differences and resolve problems?

Communication and contact. What is the best way each team member can be contacted? What tools will you use to collaborate and communicate—Google drive & docs; MS Teams, Google Meet (Links to an external site, or Zoom (Links to an external site.) for virtual team meetings (see suggestions in the Meet Your Team assignment)? What are your meeting dates and times? The better your plan and organize, the more successful you will be. 

Submission

When you complete your page, you need to publish it.

You can then preview it to make sure it looks the way you want it to.

Submit the URL for your ePortfolio home page for this assignment by clicking on the copy link icon. 

Only one person on your team needs to submit the URL. Also post your team URL on this page under your team name.

To get full points for this task, make sure you have all the required information for the home page, thoughtful and detailed explanations, an effective page design, and carefully edited writing. Please view the rubric for specifics.

This discussion involves only those on your assigned team. There are four parts to this assignment (see below). Continue to post and respond to posts throughout the week to make sure you have connected with everyone on your team and have established clear methods of communication.

  1. Share an image of something that represents you - explain why. See how to embed an image in this discussion.
  2. Review the information about effective teams that follows. Post a short paragraph about how you can apply this information to work effectively as a team. Focus specifically on the principles and theories mentioned, not just your own opinion. Here are couple of good examples:

    I believe that norms in a group are important for success like the video talks about. These informal rules will really help us know our roles and take a step back when we need to.  Sometimes different people will be the leader different times, and we can adapt and follow. I believe that conflict is important because it can be positive if it makes something better. Resolving conflict in a mature and factual way will really help us when we do have disagreements or opposing views.

    After watching the video, some of the things that I learned was that forming a charter is a great way to establish ground rules to help the team later on in the process. It talks about student project groups fall in to punctuated equilibrium, which means initially focused but end up waiting until the deadline to rush and get things done. In order to avoid that we as a group should stick to the team formation cycle of forming, storming, norming, performing, and adjourning. A final interesting point in the video that I liked was when it talks about the performing stage where the productivity is at its best and every has a good feel for how everyone else works.

  3. Set up communication and collaboration methods for your team assignments. Hold your first weekly team meeting (more information on this assignment is on the next page in the module) to get a system in place so that you can complete your first team assignment -Team ePortfolio & Charter  Schedule your weekly virtual team meetings. (These can also be recorded for those unable to attend.) Possible communication and collaboration tools include -
    •  (Links to an external Google Meet - hold meetings, share your screen, and chat. See more ideas at Google strategies & tools for virtual teams (Links to an external site.).
    • Zoom (Links to an external site.) – sign up for a free account; set up a team meeting, and send team members the link.
    • Microsoft Teams - schedule a virtual meeting directly from Canvas. See the tutorial called Scheduling a Remote Class With Teams. 
    • Google Drive, Google Docs, Google Spreadsheets, Google Slides, and other tools to share documents (Links to an external site.) with your team.(Links to an external site.) - 
    • Group Home Page in Canvas - post announcements, create collaboration pages, set up discussions, and share files. (Note - the instruction at the link was created by a different university but the information is applicable to UVU). The Group Home Page is helpful for organizing and tracking team discussions and communications in one place. 

4. Share your contact information (e.g., UVU gmail address (UVUID@my.uvu.edu), cell phone number, etc.)

To find your team members, go to People in the left-hand navigation menu, and then to Groups. 

Effective Teams

Properties

  • Norms: informal rules a group adopts to regulate group members’ behavior
  • Cohesiveness: ability of the group to collaborate, be in unity, and contribute to the team's goal
  • Conformity: degree to which the members of the group accept and abide by the norms

Resolving Conflict

Conflict in  itself is not negative. How we handle conflict resolution can be negative or positive, and can dramatically impact our work, organizations, and, ultimately, our success.  Learning to resolve conflict in a positive manner is a key skill for managers. The most common tendency is to ignore and or avoid conflict. 

It is important to be clear about the specific source of the conflict. Personality differences between two team members are quite different than disagreement about how to complete an assignment or project. 

Whatever the difference, it is helpful to frame the resolution in terms of being an effective and successful team. For example, how can our differences make our project better?  How can we best complete the project?  Remember that team work takes cooperation, which means compromise. Use differences to make your team and your work even stronger. 

The first step is to specifically identify the nature or source of the conflict. The next step is dialogue, to talk through the problem. If two people are having personality differences, they should first try to work it among themselves, followed by meeting with another team member or the whole team.

Characteristics of High-Performance Teams 

  • Common Purpose - a shared vision of the team's mission
  • Common Performance Goals - clear and consistent performance goals
  • Common Working Approach - issues related to work ethic, norms, roles, etc.
  • Mutual Accountability - willing to sacrifice personal interests for the team's goals and trust in team members
  • Complementary Skills - right skills mix to accomplish the goals
  • Small Size - the least important of the 6 factors, but 4-10 people is usually ideal

Stages of Team Formation

Stages of Team Formation

For this task, you will work with your team to apply the concepts and theories you are learning to solve a management challenge. You will do this by creating a blog  in your team ePortfolio. Follow the steps below:

  • Choose one of the management challenges for the eBook topics you have completed. You can find the management challenges under the Apply section - Synthesize what you have learned to solve a management challenge - for each eBook topic.
  • Choose a focus for the blog – discuss the questions associated with the challenge you selected; choose ONE theory referred to in the questions that provides insights into the challenge presented.
  • Create the blog – describe the situation in the challenge, the theory, and how it can be applied to resolve the issues in the challenge. Identify 2 or 3 specific actions. Draw conclusions about the value of the theory generally and how it can help managers be effective. Use headings, graphics, multimedia, text boxes, font, color, and spacing to organize and communicate your ideas. Keep your content and design clear and simple.

Here is an example of how one team introduced the management challenge in their blog.

Here are some examples of professional blogs on organizational behavior topics—managing conflict (Links to an external site.), job satisfaction (Links to an external site.), types of leaders,  (Links to an external site.) motivation. (Links to an external site.) The purpose of these blogs is to help managers understand and use various theories. 

  • Create a new page on your website and give it a heading so that it can be easily identified.
  • Please refer to this Blog Template - it shows you how to structure your blog and the content you need.

What the Blog Is and Isn't

    • The goal isn't to summarize content from the eBook or just answer the discussion questions.
    • The goal isn't to find and summarize interesting ideas from the internet.
    • The goal is to choose a theory or concept from the eBook and show how it can be applied to the challenge you selected. 
    • The goal is to be conversational, share your insights, and inspire managers to be better at what they do.
    • The goal is to be creative about how you present your insights.
    • The goal is to make sure your content is accurate and clearly explained.
    • The goal is to organize your ideas clearly - introduce the topic, use headings for each section, wrap up at the end.
    • The goal is to cite sources correctly. 

One person on the team needs to submit the URL for the assignment and it will submit for the entire team. (Please make sure you have also shared your website URL here.)

Grading

You will be graded as follows:

  • Blog shares insights on an idea or theory to resolve the scenario in the challenge and help managers be more effective. 
  • Content is accurate and clearly explained. 
  • Writing is clear with few errors. Sources are cited correctly. 
  • Information is well organized with a clear beginning, middle, and end. 
  • Page design effectively uses headings, graphics, multimedia, text boxes, font, color, and spacing.

Be creative in how you present the issues, theories, recommendations, and reflection. There is no set way to do it--but be sure your content is strong and your writing and organization are clear and effective. 

Plagiarism & Copyright

Be very careful not to plagiarize. You can't copy information from the textbook or the internet and not provide the source. 

If you summarize information from the trainings, cite the source - an in-text citation would look like this (Andrade, 2019). This needs to be included directly after each idea taken from this source.

If you use a quotation, you need quotation marks and the page number - (Andrade, 2019, p. 6). If there is no page number, use the paragraph number - (Andrade, 2019, para. 5)

Use APA (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site. for your reference list. The reference would look like this if you are citing the eBook trainings.

Andrade, M. S. (2019). Organizational behavior in practice. Dubuque, IA: Great River Learning.

Citing your sources adds credibility. 

Make sure also to use copyright-free images - the ones from Google Sites should be copyright-free.

For this task, you will work with your team to apply the concepts and theories you are learning to solve a management challenge. You will do this by creating a blog  in your team ePortfolio. Follow the steps below:

  • Choose one of the management challenges for the eBook topics you have completed. You can find the management challenges under the Apply section - Synthesize what you have learned to solve a management challenge - for each eBook topic.
  • Choose a focus for the blog – discuss the questions associated with the challenge you selected; choose ONE theory referred to in the questions that provides insights into the challenge presented.
  • Create the blog – describe the situation in the challenge, the theory, and how it can be applied to resolve the issues in the challenge. Identify 2 or 3 specific actions. Draw conclusions about the value of the theory generally and how it can help managers be effective. Use headings, graphics, multimedia, text boxes, font, color, and spacing to organize and communicate your ideas. Keep your content and design clear and simple.

Here is an example of how one team introduced the management challenge in their blog.

Here are some examples of professional blogs on organizational behavior topics—managing conflict (Links to an external site.), job satisfaction (Links to an external site.), types of leaders,  (Links to an external site.) motivation. (Links to an external site.) The purpose of these blogs is to help managers understand and use various theories. 

  • Create a new page on your website and give it a heading so that it can be easily identified.
  • Please refer to this Blog Template - it shows you how to structure your blog and the content you need.

What the Blog Is and Isn't

    • The goal isn't to summarize content from the eBook or just answer the discussion questions.
    • The goal isn't to find and summarize interesting ideas from the internet.
    • The goal is to choose a theory or concept from the eBook and show how it can be applied to the challenge you selected. 
    • The goal is to be conversational, share your insights, and inspire managers to be better at what they do.
    • The goal is to be creative about how you present your insights.
    • The goal is to make sure your content is accurate and clearly explained.
    • The goal is to organize your ideas clearly - introduce the topic, use headings for each section, wrap up at the end.
    • The goal is to cite sources correctly. 

One person on the team needs to submit the URL to the blog post AND post the URL in the upcoming Review & Reflect task.

Grading

You will be graded as follows:

  • Blog shares insights on an idea or theory to resolve the scenario in the challenge and help managers be more effective. 
  • Content is accurate and clearly explained. 
  • Writing is clear with few errors. Sources are cited correctly. 
  • Information is well organized with a clear beginning, middle, and end. 
  • Page design effectively uses headings, graphics, multimedia, text boxes, font, color, and spacing.

Be creative in how you present the issues, theories, recommendations, and reflection. There is no set way to do it--but be sure your content is strong and your writing and organization are clear and effective. 

Plagiarism & Copyright

Be very careful not to plagiarize. You can't copy information from the textbook or the internet and not provide the source. 

If you summarize information from the trainings, cite the source - an in-text citation would look like this (Andrade, 2019). This needs to be included directly after each idea taken from this source.

If you use a quotation, you need quotation marks and the page number - (Andrade, 2019, p. 6). If there is no page number, use the paragraph number - (Andrade, 2020, para. 5)

Use APA (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site. for your reference list. The reference would look like this if you are citing the eBook trainings.

Andrade, M. S. (2020). Organizational behavior in practice. Dubuque, IA: Great River Learning.

Citing your sources adds credibility. 

Make sure also to use copyright-free images - the ones from Google Sites should be copyright-free.

Employers highly value effective written communication skills. As such, the Woodbury School of Business wants students to develop these skills as part of their coursework. To measure our success related to this goal, and to assist us in maintaining our professional accreditation (AACSB) as a business school, we are requesting that you provide us with a 20-minute writing sample. When you open the assignment, you will be given a specific topic to write about. Thanks very much for your help.

Review the teamwork rubric to guide your evaluation and discussion. Being an Effective Group Member also provides helpful guiding questions and checklists to assist with your evaluation.

  • Discuss the following questions with your team. 

What is working well ? What needs to be improved? How can you make these improvements (e.g., setting goals, making changes to your charter, applying course concepts)?  Reflect on what you have you learned as a team about the course concepts and teamwork.

Create an blog on your web page that reflects your discussion and submit the URL.

You will be graded as follows:

  • Thorough reflection on teamwork and learning with support and examples. Concrete plans for improvement as needed. 
  • Effective design (graphics, pictures, colors, style), organization, and presentation of content. Professional level writing.

The purpose of this survey is to get your perspective on the team ePortfolio you created in Google Sites. The survey asks you to identify what you learned by creating artifacts (the survey may refer to them as blog posts) and compiling them into an ePortfolio in Google Sites. Please read and consider each question carefully.

Please assign a score out of 50 to yourself and each of your team members for your contributions to the team assignments this semester. Please also provide a rationale for each of your scores. Your ratings and comments will be confidential.

As you reflect on your performance and that of your team members, consider the following criteria.

Participation in generating ideas, organizing tasks, and decision-making.

Completion of work in a timely manner and by agreed-upon due date.

Timely and effective communication with other team members.

Quality of contributions.

Overall contribution to the team.

Base your ratings on the scoring guide below. The percentage is provided to give you an idea of the grade associated with the point ranges. Use the points for your ratings, not percentages.

    0-10 (0-20%) = minimal or no participation

  30-34.5 (60-69%) = weak performance; very little demonstration of teamwork skills

  35-39.5 (70-79%) = somewhat satisfactory performance; still developing teamwork skills

  40-44.5 (80-89%) = good performance; several teamwork competencies demonstrated 

  45-46.5 (90-93%) = strong performance; competent in most aspects of teamwork

 47-50 (94-100%) = exemplary performance; strong and fully contributing team member

Before you submit, make sure you have one score out of 50 for yourself and each team member and have given reasons for each of your scores. Include your team number in your submission and list the first and last names of each team member.

Note - if you do not submit this assignment and submit it on time, you will receive 0 points.

For this project, you will act as a team of consultants to a local business in the community. Your goal is to provide recommendations to your client about how to solve an organizational behavior problem that the company is experiencing (e.g., motivation, job satisfaction, conflict, change), and most importantly, why your recommendations will work based on the theories and concepts you are learning. Be sure to consider current issues such as those related to COVID-19, diversity and inclusion, or to ethical issues.

For this assignment, you will submit a proposal for your project. Complete Steps 1 and 2 ONLY. Review these Project Proposal Examples.

Project Steps

Step 1

Identify a company and get permission to do the project.

The company you consult with can be a family business, a business where you or one of your team members works now or a business where you or a team member has worked in the past, a business where a family member works, or any company where you have a connection. Talk to the owner or manager, explain the assignment, identify a "people" issue the company is experiencing, and get permission to do the project. Work with the owner/manager throughout the project and provide regular updates. 

Step 2 

Submit a proposal for approval by your instructor. 

Create a blog post in your ePortfolio website for the proposal. One person on the team needs to submit the URL to your page. Include the following information.

    • Background information about the organization (size, purpose, location, number of employees, etc.).
    • A general description of the problem (through your contact at the organization and your own experience if applicable). Provide enough detail for me to determine that the problem is related to organizational behavior.
    • Your ideas for data collection (e.g., interviews, focus groups, observations, surveys) to identify the cause of the problem and possible solutions. 
    • A proposed timeline with steps and due dates. Steps might include reviewing theories, preparing interview questions, conducting interviews, analyzing data, drafting content, designing the blog page, etc. Refer to the due dates for various aspects of the project.
    • How you will delegate tasks to team members - who will be doing what.

The proposal will be tentative and things may change. Think about what needs to be done to have a successful project. See the rubric for how you will be graded on the proposal.

Step 3

Receive approval from your instructor to proceed. After you receive approval, complete the remaining steps. 

Step 4

Gain an understanding of the problem by talking to people, observing, interviewing, conducting focus groups, examining documents, or conducting surveys. This can be done virtually. Get perspectives on the problem from a range of different people and enough people that you can identify what is happening and why. 

Step 5

Consider different theories you have studied and find one that is most applicable to resolving the key issues. Identify 2-3 specific recommendations based on the theory. Explain why these recommendations will work. To do this, you will need to help your client understand the theory on which the recommendations are based.

Step 6

Present your final report as a blog post on your website ePortfolio. Please note that there are a variety of ways to organize and present the information. See these examples: Example 1; Example 2; Example 3; Example 4. These are examples only. They are not templates for how you should do it. They can give you some ideas, though. Please see Project Peer Review Draft & Post for information on how you will be graded so that you know what you are working toward. You will get feedback from other teams on your draft and also from the WSB writing tutors before you submit it for a grade.

Create a page in your ePortfolio for the first draft of your report. You can duplicate the page you created for your proposal and modify and add to the content as needed.

Remember that your goal is to provide recommendations to your client about how to solve an organizational behavior problem and explain why your recommendations will work based on the theories you are learning.

To do this, you will need to:

  1. Show that you understand the company and its purpose (e.g., provide background information about the company and its mission/goals). You can use the same information you created for your project proposal - just update it as needed.
  2. Explain the problem, what you did to understand it better (e.g., interviews, observations, documents, surveys), and your findings. 
  3. Make 2-3 recommendations and explain why they will work. To do this, you will need to help your client understand the theory that supports the recommendations. Make your recommendations specific enough that your client can easily implement them.

 Include the following information.

  • Context - provide relevant background information such as the organization's name, purpose, location, size (# of employees). 
  • Problem - explain the issues.
  • Data & analysis - describe the data you have collected (observations, interviews, surveys, documents, etc.), plans for further data collection, and what you have learned so far.
  • Theory - suggest one or two organizational behavior theories that may be relevant. Refer to specific theories (e.g., Herzberg's Two Factor Theory, McClellan's Needs Theory, transformational leadership) rather than topics (e.g., motivation, leadership, communication).
  • Recommendations - explain how you think the theory applies and how it might lead to specific recommendations.

Use the ePortfolio format to its advantage; rather than dense amounts of text, use bullet points, graphics, tables, pictures, and other design elements to effectively convey the information. 

Include as much information as you have. If some parts are still in progress, please indicate this.

Carefully review and follow this information on citing sources.

For a comprehensive overview of the steps in the project, examples of projects, a checklist for drafting you paper, and information on tutoring, please see Consulting Project.

Submission and Scoring

Note that while you will receive points for this assignment - you are also posting your draft so that other teams can review it and give you feedback and to prepare you for your writing tutor appointments. The rubric for the final project is included so that you can see what you are working toward.

This is an individual assignment.

Each person will submit a comment to the team assigned to your team. Team assignments are listed below and the URL’s for each team can be found here. (Links to an external site.)

Please give specific and constructive feedback. Students have commented on how valuable this feedback is in helping them create more effective artifacts about their learning. 

Review and make comments on your assigned team's final project post as follows:

  1. Identify aspects of the content the team did well, and make at least one specific recommendation for improving the content. (2 points)
  2. Identify aspects of the design the team did well, and at least one specific recommendation to improve the design. (2 points)

  3. How well did the team explain the theory and show how to use it? What could be improved? (2 points)

  4.  What did you learn from this team's project? (2 points)

  5. Post must be at least 400 words. (2 points)

These comments are due on Saturday at 11:59 pm.

assignment_name: Tutor 1 (Slots are assigned for Nov 14 - Nov 18)
description:
WSB tutors are available to help with the written content of your consulting project blog. Teams who meet with the tutors typically increase their scores by at least a full grade. 

Two tutoring appointments are required with improvements made on drafts between appointments.

Sign Up for a WSB Writing Tutor Appointment

Use the checklist below to draft your project blog.

Checklist

Content. Sufficient information is provided about the company and the problem.

Content. Data collection and analysis provide insights into the problem.

Content. Recommendations are directly linked to the data analysis. Recommendations are clearly based on an organizational behavior theory. The theory is explained to provide understanding of why the recommendations will be effective.

Organization. Paragraphs are well-organized; ideas are connected across sections; appropriate headings and transitions are used.

Style. Design is professional; use of spacing, layout, color, graphics, and media contribute to the presentation of the information.

Style. Ideas are clear and writing is grammatically correct.

Citing Sources and Avoiding Plagiarism

Carefully review and these guidelines on citing sources and avoiding plagiarism.

Tutor Scoring

Please note that the tutors will report to me after both tutoring appointments have been completed. They will award points for each tutoring appointment as follows:

  • Items in checklist show best effort – 5 points
  • Required content is present (first draft) / Feedback has been followed; draft shows improvement (second draft) – 5 points

assignment_name: Extra Credit: Questions for Dr. Bishop (Up to 3 points)
description: For those of you who are interested in another extra credit opportunity, I am going to be conducting a Q&A session next month with Dr. Clark Bishop. He is a seasoned pulmonologist who has a lot of experience and background in organizational behavior from a very practical perspective as he has worked here in Utah. He has done this in my course before and has some fascinating insights to share, but he would prefer to also answer any questions you may have as a part of this discussion. Here is a previous video I shared to introduce Dr. Bishop and to give you some ideas on the kinds of questions you might want to ask him. Let me know if you have any questions about this. You can submit your questions here in the text box. Submitting questions will give you up to 3 points and there will be a follow up assignment that will be worth 7 points - for a total of 10 points of extra credit.

assignment_name: Week 16 EXTRA CREDIT - Reflection on Dr. Bishop's Presentation and Q&A (worth 7 points)
description:
Pulmonologist, Dr. Clark Bishop will be giving a presentation (Links to an external site.) specifically for our class based on the questions some of you submitted a few weeks ago. This will be held on Thursday, December 1 @ 7 pm. This is going to take the place of our regular eBook topic lectures, and you can receive extra credit by attending the presentation live or watching the recording and writing up a reflection based on the questions listed below. (Link to the recording is here - it starts at the 10 minute mark as there were some technical difficulties.) 

His presentation offers real insight into his experiences with organizational behavior and how it has impacted many facets of his life and work. Dr. Bishop's presentation may give you some great ideas in preparing for your final projects, so I think having early access will be useful. It will also give you more time to compile your thoughts for this assignment as it is worth more points and will require some additional time.

For this extra credit submission, you will be required to write or record a reflection on Dr. Bishop's presentation, commenting directly to him, if you would like. In your reflection: 1) highlight three distinct things you learned from his presentation, 2) describe why they were impactful for you and 3) explain how you would like to apply this in your own life/sphere(s) of influence. 

You must have written at least 500 words or have a 5-minute-long recording and answer all three points listed above to get the full points. 

*I will share your reflections with Dr. Bishop only if you request it in your submission.

Submit

Introductions Discussion Board (Initial video due Thursday, January 12. Responses to at least 2 peers due Tuesday, January 17.)
description:
Introductions (Initial video due Thursday, January 12, 11:59pm. Responses to at least 2 other students due Tuesday, January 17, 11:59pm.)

02 unread replie111 replies.

Hi everyone!

This is a discussion board for us to introduce ourselves to each other.  I'm super excited about teaching Business Stats this semester and can't wait to get to know all of you.

Please record a short video of you introducing yourself.  You can capture video right from your Discussion Board post the Rich Content Editor. This initial post is due by Thursday, January 12, 11:59pm. (I enter this as the due date in Canvas just so you don't forget to post your initial video on time.)

 

Be sure to answer the following questions in your initial video:

1 - Name that you preferred to be called.

2 - Major and how you think Statistics can be applied to your career choice (or business in general).

3 - Dream vacation spot.

Respond to at least two of your peers' posts no later than Tuesday, January 17, 11:59pm. (You can just write your responses - they do not need to be a video.)

 

Discussion Board Guidelines

What is a “Substantive” Response?

Substantive responses to most discussion questions should require a paragraph or two sometimes more—not simply a “yes,” “no” or one sentence answer. Feel free to agree or disagree with others, raise objections, ask questions of them, etc., but please do so with respect. Please also use supporting documentation and research to support statements and claims where appropriate. And while we always want to be cordial in our class communications, let’s avoid posting simple messages such as “yes,” “I agree,” or “thank you.” This will keep the forum less cluttered and ensure that viewed responses are substantive. 

 

Communicating in a Professional Manner:

A posting to a discussion forum constitutes formal written communication. As such, postings should follow the conventions of the English language. Proper grammar should be used and postings should be checked for spelling. It is recommended that you proofread your postings before they are submitted to the forum.

Get on the Gallup Poll website.  

www.gallup.com (Links to an external site.)

Pick an article/survey and discuss one or two of its results.  There is no need to discuss all the results.

You will need to choose an article or survey that includes an explanation of their survey methods.  The easiest way to do this is to enter "survey methods" into their search bar and then choosing an article from that very long list.

In your discussion, be sure to include a description of the survey methods.  

What does the 95% confidence interval mean?

 

Choose an article that you find interesting.  Also, please be respectful of others views in this discussion board.  There are many possible topics for people to choose, so respond to each other with a willingness to have an open mind and see another's perspective.  Refer to the Discussion Board Guidelines for more information.

assignment_name: Unit 4 Discussion Board (Initial Post due Wednesday, April 26, 11:59pm. Two responses to peers due Saturday, April 29, 11:59pm)
description:
Unit 4 Discussion Board

 

Corporate Social Responsibility

Let’s discuss Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR).  What is it?  Is it important?  Why or why not?  What does this have to do with stats?

Here’s an article to cover the basics of CSR.

https://www.newsweek.com/2019/11/29/corporate-social-responsibility-good-bad-1473934.html (Links to an external site.)

There are plenty of other things to read on the web about corporate social responsibility.  Read as much or as little as you want, just make sure you are prepared to have a discussion on the topic.

So, how does statistics relate to CSR?

And the real question:  How can statistics improve CSR?  This is what you will discuss in your Reflection. 

I don’t want to put too many limits on your initial post, but here are some questions to get you started:

(300 word minimum)

Is CSR important?  Why or why not?

How could CSR be implemented in your future profession?

How could statistics be used to improve the culture of CSR?

Describe a specific example (real or fiction) of using business statistics to contribute to CSR.

Unit 1 Project

For the Unit 1 Project, you will need to following Word document:

LastName, FirstName, 3345 U1P.docx

 

In this project, you will examine adjusted monthly returns for two of Fidelity's Information Technology Mutual Funds. (Scroll down to see video on how to gather this data.)

You will do all of your analyses in R Studio and then put all of your answers into the Word document. Please make sure that both your R file and Word document are neat and organized so that I can find what I need easily.

 

When you have finished the project, please upload your completed Word document and the HTML R file (you do not need to upload the .Rmd file).

Tips:

Answer all questions in complete sentences!  Be thorough, clear, and specific.

Keep your R file organized. Preview your R HTML file before you submit it.  Make sure that it shows all of the outputs, graphs, charts, etc.

If you are unclear about any instructions - ask me!  That's what I'm here for.

 

The following video will help you to gather the data that you will use.

 

The following video demonstrates how to create a histogram in R Studio.

R Code to create histogram:

hist(df$var,main = "Title", xlab = "xlabel", ylab = "ylabel", breaks = seq(min, max, bin width), col = "color")

 

 

 

R Code for frequency distribution chart with evenly split intervals:

TableName<-cut(df$var,breaks = seq(min, max, bin width))
tab1(TableName)

 

R Code for frequency distribution chart with unevenly split intervals:

TableName<-cut(df$var,breaks = c(list of cut-off points))
tab1(TableName)

Unit 3 Project

Due Friday, March 31, 11:59pm

According to United Nations estimates, more than half of the world population live in just seven countries, with China, closely followed by India, leading the pack. The other five countries on the list include the United States, Indonesia, Pakistan, Brazil, and Nigeria. It is believed that India will overtake China to become the world’s most populous nation much sooner than previously thought (CNN, June 2019). For this project, you will collect population data (in millions) from the World Bank for India and China from 1960 to 2021. You will use the sample information to explore linear and nonlinear trend regression models to capture the population trend for both China and India. You will then use the preferred model(s) to forecast the populations of China and India.

This Word document has the entire project. You will record responses and provide values in this Word document. Calculations and analyses will be completed in R Studio. I have created an R Notebook for you with labels to help keep your R HTML file neat and organized. You will submit the completed Word document, the R HTML file, and the Excel document with your population data for this assignment.

Unit 4 Project

Due Wednesday, May 3, 11:59pm

Amazon, Google, and Facebook are some of the most well-known internet companies in the world. The monthly adjusted stock price data from the last 5 years for these companies is provided. Calculate the monthly returns and real monthly returns as the percentage change in adjusted closing prices from the previous month. Use the sample information to calculate and interpret relevant summary measures for the returns of the two mutual funds. Using techniques that do not rely on stringent assumptions concerning the distribution of the underlying population, whether the median difference between returns differ from a given value, differ from each other, and whether they are correlated with each other.

This Word document has the entire project. You will record responses and provide values in this Word document. Calculations and analyses will be completed in R Studio. I have created an R Notebook for you with labels to help keep your R HTML file neat and organized. Use the data in the Excel file to calculate the nominal monthly returns and the real monthly returns. You will submit the completed Word document, the R HTML file, and the Excel document with your population data for this assignment.

 

USE THE 5% SIGNIFICANCE LEVEL FOR ALL TESTS.

Purpose. While many of you will be writing for business using American English patterns, and that is what our text teaches, it's important to be aware that other businesses and cultures in the world use different systems.

Task. Please complete the following tasks. 

  1. Read the following article: Building an Argument Across Cultures.  (Links to an external site.)
  2. Reflect on your writing abilities (or lack of) in another language, and consider the differences in writing patterns across cultures.
  3. Share your answers to one or more of the following questions in the discussion board.
    1. Have you ever received a message from a business outside of the United States and noticed the English used doesn’t meet your expectations for grammar and writing patterns?
    2. When doing business with companies or clients in a different language from American English, how important do you think it would be to use the most correct grammar and writing patterns expected in that language? What are some ways you can achieve that?

Criteria. To get full points, you need to post an original post according to the directions above and a reply to one of your classmates.

Original post- 10 points

One thoughtful and significant reply- 10 points

Total possible- 20 points

Discussion Guidelines

Discuss

Purpose. While we are learning to write for business communication in this course, it is important to recognize that this class is teaching American English and business standards, and other cultures and countries do things a little differently. The objectives of this assignment are in line with the weekly objectives found on the module overview page.

Task. Read, reflect, and discuss. 

  1. Read the following articles while thinking about what you expect to see in a business email:
    • “Email Etiquette in Different Countries”
    • “5 Things You Need to Know About International Email Etiquette”
    • “Bridging the Cross-Cultural Gap Through Global Business Email Etiquette”

  2. Reflect on the following questions:
    1. How did the cultural norms for email etiquette in the different countries you read about compare and contrast to what you expect in an email?
    2. Do you think it is important to know about differences in email etiquette across different cultures? Why or why not?

  3. Share your answers in your discussion post, and find a classmate’s post that hasn’t had a reply yet. (If they all have responses, choose the one with the least responses.) Read your classmate’s post thoroughly, and then respectfully reply to each point in the post.

Criteria. To get full points, you need to post an original post according to the directions above and a reply to your classmate.

Original post- 10 points
One thoughtful and significant reply- 10 points

Total possible- 20 points

Discussion Guidelines

Discuss

Purpose. We are learning to appeal to the reaction of the reader in this business writing course. Culture can play a large part in a reader’s expectations and reactions. 

Task. Read, reflect, and share.

  1. Read the following examples of cultural differences that could affect how you want to approach the reader:
      • Business Etiquette Around the World.
      • Cultural Differences in Business Communication.
  2. Reflect on your own culture and the expectations you have for business interactions. What were some similarities and differences between your expectations and that of the other cultures represented in the infographic from the first example?
  3. Share an example of how you can apply what you learned about high- vs. low-context communication when doing business with a company in a different country.

Criteria. To get full points, you need to post an original post according to the directions above and a reply to your classmate.

Original post- 10 points

One thoughtful and significant reply- 10 points

Total possible- 20 points

Task. Read, reflect, and share.

  1. Read this article in Forbes written by Jonathan Westover (UVU Woodbury School of Business Department Chair/Associate Professor of Organizational Leadership)
      • What A Korean Proverb Teaches Us About Diversity In The Workplace
  2. Reflect on your own "well," and answer the following questions:
      • In what ways have you climbed out of the well in your life so far?
      • What are benefits you have personally seen from getting out of the well? Were there drawbacks?
      • What are ways you can apply this article in your current work/school circumstances? 
  3. Share your answers and respond to at least one classmate

Discussion Guidelines

The main purpose of this assignment is to familiarize yourself with Peerceptiv. A secondary purpose is to begin thinking critically about business communication. You will click "Review Peer Submission" and see a sample business letter that a landlord is sending her tenants. You will answer the rubric questions about the letter, focusing on its content (message) and delivery (how that message is expressed). The rubric will ask you to make open-ended comments and also rate the quality of various aspects of the writing. Please think about each rubric item carefully and answer thoughtfully so you are a helpful and accurate reviewer.
Complete your Peerceptiv Feedback.
Complete your Peerceptiv Reviews.

Purpose. In professional settings, you will regularly be called upon to communicate neutral or positive information to a wide range of people such as colleagues, clients, and partners. Your readers need to understand what you are telling them and what, if anything, they need to do with that information. The goal of this message is to create an email that is easy to read and understand.

Skills. The purpose of this assignment is to help you practice the following skills essential to effective communication in the workplace:

  • Recognize which types of messages are categorized as good news/routine messages.
  • Evaluate the best approaches, and create appropriate, effective workplace communication (professional communication).

Knowledge. By writing a routine message, you will improve your skills in providing useable information in written form. This assignment will help you become familiar with the following content knowledge in this discipline:

  • GDP message format.
  • Proper email structure.

Task. Create a company-wide email as the task force chairperson for your company’s Safe-Return-to-the-Office Task Force.

Writing Prompt. Return to Work* 

You are letting employees know that the company is considering a few different return-to-work models and that employees’ input is required and highly sought-after. You need to inform all employees that they need to complete a lengthy survey about their experiences working from home over the past year.

The survey will ask about how they completed their work remotely and their feelings about working remotely. The survey will take about two hours to complete, and they are to complete it during normal working hours. All employees who complete their survey will be entered into a drawing for one of four $100 Amazon gift cards. Let them know when the deadline is. Let them know where to find the survey.

In your writing, show respect to valued employees by requesting action rather than demanding obedience. Show sensitivity to employees who have widely varying opinions about safety and workplace productivity.

Criteria for Success. Your writing will be evaluated according to the COS rubric. Remember to follow the recommended outline: Good news (main idea), Details, and Positive closing. Use the goodwill principles you have learned. Edit for punctuation and grammar.

This assignment is worth 100 points and will be computed within the Writing Assignments category of classwork.

*This writing prompt, as with others you will encounter in this class, is poorly written and incomplete. While writing prompts incorporate good punctuation and grammar, they are purposely written with poor you attitude, negative words, and questionable tone. That’s why you shouldn’t use the wording from the prompt. Your job is to use the information you’ve been given but to use your own words to respond to the prompt and to add any information that will help complete your message and convince your reader of your good intentions.
Complete your Peerceptiv Reviews of the bad-news assignment.

Purpose. Delivering indirect bad news in a way that maintains goodwill is a common business task you’ll encounter in your career. The goal of a bad-news message is for the reader to read, understand, and accept the bad news. The readers should feel if they were in your shoes, they would have made the same decision. 

Skills. You will write an indirect, bad-news message using the recommended outline, NEMO or BBBB. By writing well-considered bad-news messages, you will maintain the loyalty and respect of your employees and clients. This employee and client satisfaction can build goodwill and also positively impact your company’s bottom line.  

Knowledge. By writing an indirect bad-news message, you will know how to deliver bad news in a way that maintains goodwill. 

Writing Prompt: Double-booked Wedding Day

You work as an event planner for Florence Events Center, a beautiful venue that hosts weddings, family reunions, corporate meetings, parties, etc. The venue consists of a grand hall that can accommodate over 200 people as well as a beautiful garden area that is more fitting for smaller groups. To reserve either space, the client pays a $1,500 non-refundable deposit upon booking. 

While looking over the schedule for the next few months, you notice that the grand hall has accidentally been double-booked for two wedding ceremonies on July 17, 2022. You pull up the transaction record and notice that the accidental booking was made two weeks ago by a new front desk employee during his first day on the job. The new employee collected the $1,500 deposit from the unlucky bride-to-be, Ms. Olivia DeLeon, and promised her the grand hall for her ceremony. The notes indicate that the ceremony would include about 25 guests.  

Of course, you must email Ms. DeLeon immediately to let her know that you cannot honor the terms of her original booking because of the mistake. You understand how difficult this news might be for Ms. DeLeon to hear and want to be mindful of her feelings. 

Task: Write an indirect, bad-news email to Ms. Olivia DeLeon, letting her know about the double-booking and that you cannot honor her original request. However, what are some alternatives you could suggest to help remedy the situation and maintain goodwill? 

Criteria for success. As always, your writing will be evaluated according to the COS Rubric. Remember to follow the recommended outline (Neutral beginning, Explanation, Main idea [bad news], Original/positive ending OR Bond, Bridge, Bad-news, Build). Use the building goodwill principles you’ve learned, and as usual, edit for punctuation and grammar. 

This assignment is worth 100 points and will be computed within the Writing Assignments category of classwork.
Complete the feedback for the bad-news Peerceptiv assignment.
Complete the feedback for the Peerceptiv persuasive assignment.
Complete the peer reviews for the Peerceptiv persuasive assignment.

Purpose. In professional settings, you will need the ability to write persuasively and convincingly to a wide range of people such as colleagues, clients, and partners. You need to present your readers with a compelling argument as to why they should do what you ask. The goal of this assignment is to persuade your audience to complete your request.

Skills. The purpose of this assignment is to help you practice the following skills essential to effective communication in the workplace:

  • Recognize what types of messages are categorized as persuasive messages.
  • Evaluate the best approaches to individual writing situations and create appropriate, effective workplace communication (professional communication).

Knowledge. By writing a persuasive message, you will improve your skills in convincing your audience to comply with your requests. This assignment will help you become familiar with the following content knowledge in this discipline:

  • ANSA message format.
  • Proper formal business letter structure.

Task. For this assignment, you will write a formal business letter to a successful local company (you pick one) from the non-profit organization New Start Families. You are asking this company to commit to fill three entry-level positions with the adult family members you are housing in your family-only homeless shelter.

Companies support local non-profit organizations for many reasons. These reasons are often more related to the company reputation and branding than to pure, charitable motives. So rather than telling your audience that “stable, full-time employment combined with the resources and training offered by New Start Families has an 85 percent success rate for raising families permanently out of housing insecurity,” think about who your audience is, what they care about, and what is important to them. While that statistic is probably personally interesting and important to your readers, they are acting on behalf of a company and have responsibilities for how they allot corporate resources that are earmarked for community engagement or charitable donations. They are also responsible for hiring people who will advance the company’s best interests in productivity and profitability. Think about how you can appeal to the company’s priorities to convince them that filling three entry-level positions from people currently living in a homeless shelter will benefit them in some way.

Ask your target company for a specific commitment or action by a specific date. Tie your request back into the company’s push for community engagement. From this company’s perspective, what are their needs and how is your request a solution?

Within your letter, make reference to the following online article that discusses the benefits to corporations of giving back to their communities. Use this article to support your request, showing a potential benefit for your employer.

"Five Ways Supporting Charities Can Benefit Your Business" 

Criteria for Success. Your writing will be evaluated according to the COS rubric. Remember to follow the recommended outline: ANSA. Use the goodwill principles you have learned. Edit for punctuation and grammar.

This assignment is worth 100 points and will be computed within the Writing Assignments category of classwork.
Complete your Peerceptiv Feedback for the cover letter assignment.
Complete your Peerceptiv Reviews of the cover letters.

Purpose. A cover letter accompanies a resume. Well-written cover letters will provide more information about you as a candidate and will also demonstrate your writing skills. A cover letter is a persuasive document, the purpose of which is to convince the reader to interview you. 

Task. Write a formal business letter (three to four paragraphs maximum) to a specific organization (internship, part-time, or full-time position) that you are qualified for now. Use the persuasive outline ANSA. Use the header from your resume so the branding is consistent across your employment documents.

Criteria. Your cover letter will be evaluated based on the COS rubric. 

This assignment is worth 100 points and will be computed within the Writing Assignments category of classwork.
Complete your Peerceptiv Reviews for the resume assignment.

Purpose. A resume’s purpose is to persuade your audience in about 10 seconds to interview you. Resumes are a one-page summary of your education, experience, and accomplishments. Resumes use document design principles to create visual appeal and quick access to key information.

Task. Design a one-page resume to apply for a specific full-time job, part-time job, or internship that you qualify for now. Use the document design principles contrast, repetition, alignment, proximity, and space (CRAPS) to invite attention and make your information easy to scan. 

Criteria. Your resume will be evaluated based on the COS rubric with Style being the most important element: 30 points for Content, 30 points for Organization, and 40 points for Style.

This assignment is worth 100 points and will be computed within the Writing Assignments category of classwork.
Complete your Peerceptiv Feedback for the resume assignment.

This assignment is a reflection of your writing abilities. As such, you should complete it yourself, without assistance from the Writing Lab or any other outside source. You have one week to write, edit, and submit this assignment. 

Purpose. The purpose of this assignment is to apply the building goodwill principles and appropriate rhetorical strategies to a business writing scenario. 

Skills. You will demonstrate your business writing knowledge by using the following steps: 

  • Analyze a business scenario.
  • Evaluate options to address the scenario.
  • Apply appropriate rhetorical concepts (GDP, NEMO, ANSA) to the problem.
  • Organize information so it is accessible to the reader.
  • Demonstrate writing that is inclusive, informed, and respectful of intercultural audiences.

Task: Write a formal email to all employees of your international company outlining all of the training that is required and available. Include deadlines. Your email should not be more than a page long. Use graphics to make the information easy to scan. You will need to integrate all the rhetorical concepts we’ve learned this semester—good news, bad news, and persuasive—as this prompt requires elements of each. An international audience requires concrete, clear language that can be easily understood. You may want to use the writing process PASS from mcom320.net Chapter 3 to formulate your message.

Writing Prompt*: Training for All

You are the global training manager for GreenTrees International, a non-profit organization that promotes global reforestation and conservation. In addition to managing the company training website (www.GreenTrees.org/learn), you also write emails to the employees of your corporation to inform them about mandatory training requirements and optional training opportunities. 

Although your company is headquartered in Japan, you work at the GreenAmerica division in Salt Lake City, Utah, USA. Other main offices are in Paris, France; and Cape Town, South Africa; but you have satellite offices in 15 other countries. Because the global advisory board decided that English would be the official language of the company, your message will not be translated; therefore, it should be easily understood by the many employees for whom English is not their primary language. 

This year’s mandatory trainings include the following topics: Sexual Harassment, Defensive Driving, Cybersecurity, Workplace Conduct, and Discrimination Prevention. Supervisors must complete additional Non-Discrimination, Harassment, and Retaliation Trainings. All training is offered online in English, and subtitles are available in 12 languages. These training modules are mandatory and must be completed by December 1, 2021. The training videos range from 10 to 35 minutes each, so employees should expect to spend two to three hours to complete them all. To complete this requirement, employees must complete a quiz at the end of each training and get at least 80 percent of the questions correct. Employees can rewatch the videos and retake the quizzes as many times as needed. No exemptions will be given, so every employee must complete these training modules on time.

In addition, employees who participate in hiring committees should ensure their GreenHire certification is current. (Hiring training must be completed every two years.)

Optional trainings include (but are not limited to) employee development programs such as the GrowGreen Leadership training, GreenRoots Professional Development training, and GoGreen World Conservation training. Some of these are workshops that last several months and start at various times during the year. Employees can refer to the website for more details. 

Criteria. Your submission will be evaluated by your instructor based on the COS rubric. This assessment counts for nearly half of your “Exams” category, which is 20 percent of your grade.

*Remember, you should use your own words when composing your email. This prompt, while grammatically correct, doesn’t use you attitude principles and is quite wordy. Also, because so much detailed information needs to be conveyed, you could consider using appropriate formatting techniques to make your message accessible to the reader.

This is a timed, 50-question, open-book (but not "open internet"), multiple-choice exam that covers the reading assignments for the semester. You have 60 minutes and one attempt. You must use Google Chrome with the Proctorio add-in to access this exam.

Proposal. The purpose of this assignment is to introduce you to another type of persuasive document—proposals. Proposals are common business documents used to generate income, solve internal problems, or complete projects; proposals are often generated by a team made up of people with different areas of expertise. Proposals can also be part of the planning stage for a written report.

Task. Using the text box provided, prepare a brief proposal to write a newsletter based on one of the scenarios listed. Use informal email format, and address the email to me, your instructor. Include the following information.

  1. Purpose: Mention the topic of your newsletter (the scenario from the list of choices).
  2. Audience: Identify the audience for your newsletter. 
  3. Outline: Outline the topics that will be covered in your newsletter, and explain how these are relevant to your audience. 
  4. Qualifications: Tell who is in your group and what subtopic each person will research. 
  5. Call to Action: Ask for approval to complete the newsletter project. 

You may want to collaborate in Google Docs and copy/paste to Canvas. Submit one email per group.

*This is an individual assignment.*

Purpose. Writing an article based on research gives you the opportunity to gather, analyze, validate, synthesize, and summarize information in a short report. 

Task. Synthesize the information you obtained by completing the Critical Reading Skills and Proposal assignment into a one-page, single-spaced article with an attached bibliography—correctly formatted using APA style.

Upload your one-page, single-spaced article here. The second page will be your double-spaced, APA-formatted references.

This assignment is worth 50 points, which will count in the final project portion of your grade.

*This is a group assignment.*

Purpose. The purpose of this assignment is to research, analyze, synthesize, validate, write, picture, design, and contribute to a professional business document—a newsletter.

Task. Using each team member's article, create a two- or three-column newsletter for the company your team chose to work for. Use the document design principles and skills presented in Chapters 7 and 11. Include one references page for the whole newsletter that includes the sources used in the articles. 

Because you are a UVU student, you have access to the Microsoft Office 365 Suite and can download it for free on any device. This gives you access to Word, PowerPoint, Publisher, and other applications, which you can use to design your newsletter. Chapters 7 and 11 of the online slidebook also link you to design software, which you can use as well. Just remember the four basic document design principles: contrast, repetition, alignment, and proximity.

Adhere to the following guidelines. 

  • Create an original letterhead—logos are nice but are not required.
  • Create a second-page header that includes the page number, day, and date of publication on top of the inside pages.
  • Add a headline and byline for each article. (A byline names the author of the article. It can be added after the headline or at the end of the article.)
  • Prepare at least one appropriate chart, graph, info graph, picture, or table for each article.
  • Include at least one pull quote per page. (A pull quote is a key phrase or excerpt pulled from the article to persuade readers to read the article.)
  • Use the Old/New Principle to create cohesive and coherent sentences, paragraphs, and articles.
  • Include the why, what, where, when, and how in the introductory paragraph to serve readers who skim for information—about two sentences. Add the other details in the paragraphs following the introductory paragraph.
  • Write clearly, concisely, correctly, and courteously.
  • Eliminate all typos and errors in punctuation and grammar.
  • Cite sources for facts, quotations, and graphics.

This assignment is worth 100 points, which will be calculated into the final project portion of your grade.
