Chapter 8: Market Segmentation, Targeting, and Positioning

description:
You will formulate a marketing plan for an existing product/service of your choosing. You will rebrand and write a marketing plan for your chosen product/service.  The marketing plan is divided into four sections.  Please look closely at the attached assignment guidelines for the requirements and due dates for each section.

A marketing plan is the essential document that guides all marketing activity at any company. This document should be revised regularly. Marketing plans are specific to each business. As companies and products vary, marketing plan content changes to fit each company’s unique needs. However, for the purpose of this class, we will write a marketing plan using the following basic marketing plan outline. Please add additional plan elements if necessary, but remember to include these basic elements.  

Writing this plan will be a great experience because it is very practical in the business world. Learning to write a planning document is something you will do over and over. If you have questions, please email me.

MKTG 3600 Unit 1 Facebook Assignment.docx 

Introduction

Digital marketing promotes brands using all forms of digital technology which includes a variety of technologies like computers, tablets, smartphones, social media, and of course, the Internet.

In this class, you will gain some very basic digital marketing skills using the American Marketing Association Facebook page.

Digital Marketing is different from traditional marketing because you have an opportunity to heavily influence the buying process by engaging the people who influence the consumer. In the digital world, consumers are influenced by 3 groups: Referent Influencers, Expert Influencers, and Positional Influencers.

Referent Influencers – are the friends, classmates, roommates, and colleagues that influence your purchase

Expert Influencers – are the bloggers and other experts on the Internet that serve as a professionally qualified source that influence your decisions

Positional Influencers –are the people closest to you whose approval you seek. Usually this group of people is your family or very tight network.

Facebook Marketing Assignment

Unit #1 – Like, Comment, Share assignment

Welcome to your first Facebook Digital Marketing Assignment. Here are the steps to follow for this assignment.

Step 1: Like www.facebook.com/AmericanMarketing/ by clicking the “like” button on the page.

Step 2: Find a marketing article on the page

Step 3: Read the article

Step 4: Comment on the article in the comment line below the post. Share the article with a classmate, friend, or fellow student.

Step 5: Research 2 additional articles on the topic of the article and write a one-page single spaced summary of the three articles. Remember to include a work cited page where you give me the URLs for the articles. Submit the one-page single spaced articles using the assignment submission BUTTON in Canvas.

Remember the Digital Marketing Assignment is due at the end of Unit #1.

description: For this second part of the Marketing Plan, you will complete the "Marketing Mix Strategy" section of the Marketing Plan.  You will describe your product in detail, as well as the pricing strategy you plan to use and the place element of your plan.  For the Promotion section, you need to describe which mediums you will use for your rebranding campaign, including why you chose to utilize those mediums.  You should include at least three different mediums in the promotion section.

MKTG 3600 Unit 2 Facebook Assignment.docx 

Unit #2 – Facebook Groups/Clubs/Professional Organizations

Welcome to unit #2 Facebook Digital Marketing Assignment. An important part of college is determining what career you want when you graduate. A great way to learn about your future chosen profession is by learning about the professional organizations and clubs in your industry.

The American Marketing Association offers seminars, workshops, and events focused on the immediate needs of marketers, as well as on current trends.  The AMA is also the source for the field’s top magazines and journals.

This assignment helps you become aware of the professional association affiliated with the UVU Marketing Department and how Facebook is the promotion platform for the group.   

Here are the steps to follow for this assignment.

Step 1: Visit ama.org and click on “About AMA” at the bottom of the page.

Step 2: Read through this page and research how joining the AMA may be beneficial to a UVU business student.

Step 3: Go to https://m.facebook.com/AmericanMarketing/ and look for a post that promotes they AMA. You can  look for events, awards, articles, pics, videos etc.

Step 4: Engage with the post by commenting on it.

Step 5: Write a one-page single spaced summary explaining why a student should join a club or  professional organization at UVU. The paper should have the following headlines

  • Which club should I join? —research the best club or professional organization for your major
  • Why join a club? – highlight three benefits you might get from joining a club
  • Where is my club? – tell me who the club advisor is and what are the contact points (email, facebook, website) for the club

 Remember to submit your Digital Marketing Assignment in Canvas by the due date at the end of Unit #2.

assignment_name: Marketing Plan Part 4, Appendix and Executive Summary
description:
The appendix of the Marketing Plan is your opportunity to use your creativity.  You will develop the creative pieces for the advertising mediums you described in the Promotion section of the Marketing Mix Strategy. 

The Executive Summary is a one-page, high-level overview of the key points of your Marketing Plan.

Facebook Marketing Assignment

Unit #4 – Facebook Marketing Plan

Welcome to unit #4 Facebook Digital Marketing Assignment. It is time to do some Market Research and write a simple, one-page Marketing Plan.  The purpose of all marketing is to get consumers to buy something or to do something because it benefits the consumer and the producer. The UVU Marketing Department is the same as a business. The department wants to recruit more students to the Major by showing students the benefits --jobs, training, and community. Now you will be asked to work as a marketing consultant for the Department.

Step 1: Look at the posts on https://www.facebook.com/AmericanMarketing/

Step 2: Identify 3 different types of posts (articles, events, pics, awards, memes, information, club etc…) and leave a comment on 3 different types of posts. Remember to use #profmsteed at the end of your comment.

Step 3: Now that you have had a semester of experiencing the UVU Marketing Department Facebook page it is time for you to become a marketing consultant. Based on your experience with the UVU Marketing Department Facebook page and your knowledge in the class, please write a one-page marketing plan. The paper should have the following organization and headers:

  • Target Market —Who is the page trying to reach? Be specific by demographics, consumer behavior, and situation behavior.
  • Marketing Strategy—What should be the marketing strategy for the page? What is the page trying to persuade students to do? Is it effective? Why or Why not?
  • Content Strategy – What type of content should be on the page and what is the best posting schedule? How many posts, how often, and what is the best time of day for posting content?
  • Marketing Recommendation – Tell me one recommendation you have for recruiting more people to the Marketing Major.

 Remember to submit your Digital Marketing Assignment in Canvas by the due date at the end of Unit #4.

description:
Homework 2

Please refer to the two videos posted in this module before you begin working on the assignment. The two videos are "Homework 1_part 1_instructor explanation" and "Homework 1_part 2_instructor explanation."

Please use Google Data Studio to develop the following visualization. 

Time duration: January 1, 2017, to September 1, 2021

Use Region as an additional filter (click on "Add a control" then select "drop down list" and then select region under the control field in the set pane) and select Utah (when you download and submit your file)

  1. Number of sessions
  2. Number of new users
  3. Bounce rate
  4. A Geo Map showing number of new users
  5. A time series showing the average quantity
  6. A bar chart showing the average order value. This chart could show different sources (example, referral, paid search, etc.).
  7. A pie-chart showing the average order value for the device category

Please use the correct date range and include the region filter specified above.

Google data studio shows you a default table with labels such as page title, new users, etc. You may delete that table from your submission because it is not asked in the above questions. Further, it will allow you more space for the charts and metrics. Please submit your report in a pdf file which could be downloaded from Google Data Studio.

GRADING RUBRIC: Your assignment submission will be graded based on the following grading rubric. Google Data Studio Grading rubric.xlsx 

Instructor's EXPECTATIONS   of your assignment submissions.

  • Submit your assignment in one pdf file. This pdf file could be downloaded from Looker Studio (formerly known as Google Data Studio).
  • Include all the charts, metrics, filters, and date range as mentioned in the above question.
  • Submit your assignment on canvas by the submission due date for it to be considered for grading.

Areas where students lose points on this assignment. So, please watch out for these points when you work on this assignment.

  • Students generally leave out one or more charts/metrics.
  • Students sometimes select an incorrect date range and/or incorrect filter. As a result, all the metrics and charts are incorrect.
  • Students do not read the assignment questions thoroughly and thereby leave out important points in the submission.
  • Students begin working on the assignment near the submission deadline and submit an incorrect/incomplete assignment. 

Please let me know if you have any questions. Goodluck!

Thank you!

description:

If all the tick marks showing the completion of the topics do not fit into one screenshot, you can submit multiple screenshots covering the different topics as your submission.

Mobile apps are an integral component of owned media. Mobile app marketing technology tools collect critical digital marketing data. Armed with mobile app analytics data, analysts drive better results for businesses. For this assignment, you will explore the popular mobile app analytics tool Google Analytics 4 via a demo account. The demo account reports actual mobile app analytics data for the mobile app Flood It! (Android and iOS). For this assignment you would explore both the Google Analytics 4 demo account and the Flood It! mobile app to better understand how data flows from a mobile app into Google Analytics 4.

Google Analytics 4 demo account link: https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/6367342#access&zippy=%2Cin-this-article

(Select Google Analytics 4 property: Flood-It! (app and web data) in the "Access the Demo Account" section.

You have been hired as a digital marketing analyst for Flood It! Please get familiar with your employer by exploring their mobile app, Android and iOS.  Flood It! is a real puzzle game in which you have to flood the whole game board with one color in fewer than the allowed steps. Flood It! has Google Analytics 4 implemented. The mobile app data is flowing to the Google Analytics 4 demo project. The data available is typical of what you might see for a gaming app with in-app purchases.

Step 1

Gain access to a Google Analytics 4 demo accounts for Flood It!. Instructions for accessing this demo account are available from Google.  Make sure when you access the demo account you navigate to the Property "GA4 - Flood-It!." Please find the image below.

Step 2

Your manager is interested in the mobile app performance for Flood It!. When you open the Google Analytics 4 analytics dashboard, make sure you adjust the date filter in the upper right-hand corner to start on January 1, 2023, and end on June 30, 2023. Your manager has asked you to answer the questions in this assignment using data from the Google Analytics 4 demo account.

Please note there is no time limit for this assignment.

Now please answer the questions.

Funnel analysis

  • Assume that your manager/supervisor wants you to perform funnel analysis using Google Analytics 4 for a store's website using a date range of May 1, 2022 to April 30, 2023 OR September 1, 2022 to April 30, 2023.  (You may choose any of the two date ranges, as some students noticed an error with a specific date range on the Google Analytics 4 platform. So either of the two date ranges should work for the assignment.
  • The manager is interested in knowing how many people viewed a product on the website, of which how many added the product to the shopping cart, how many began the check-out process, and how many purchased the product. 
  • Further the manager wants you to perform country-wise analysis of the funnel. In addition, the manager also wants you to compare users from two segments, one segment that uses mobile phone and the other that uses tablets. (Please note that segment comparison is optional. If Google Analytics platform does not let you do the segment comparison, please do not worry about it. You won't  loose points for not including it in the assignment).
  • Based on the analysis, the manager wants you to write down your top 2 observations from the data and top 2 recommendations to improve the performance of the website. 

Please use Google Analysis 4 for this assignment. The following is the website link to the Google Analytics 4 demo account: https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/6367342?hl=en#zippy=%2Cin-this-article

After you click on the above website link scroll down a bit and then select "Google Analytics 4 property: Google Merchandise Store (web data)" to complete the assignment. For this assignment, assume that the store the Manager refers to is the Google Merchandise store website (https://shop.googlemerchandisestore.com/).

Please refer to the instructor video posted in the module before you begin with this assignment.

(Hint): When creating the report on Google Analytics 4 select the following steps by selecting the events option. However, please watch the instructor video for a detailed explanation.

  1. view_item: Users who viewed the item.
  2. add_to_cart: Users who added the product to the shopping cart.
  3. begin_checkout: Users who began the checkout process. 
  4. purchase: Users who purchased the product.

Assignment submission format

Please use the following submission template for submitting this assignment: Google Analytics practice Funnel analysis template.docx 

Page 1: Your name, student ID number, and course name.

Page 2: Picture of the front page of the funnel analysis.

Page 3: Half-page summary of your observation of the funnel analysis and Half page recommendations to the manager based on your analysis. 

Do not write just sentence observation and recommendation, even if that one sentence is long. Please be elaborate in your response to receive full points. Please use font size 12, Times New Roman, and single line spacing. 

Please note, there is no right observation and recommendation, and there is no wrong observation and recommendation. I am interested in how elaborately you explain YOUR observations and recommendations. Here, the idea is more about thinking critically, rather than limiting oneself to one right answer or a wrong answer.

Instructor's EXPECTATIONS  of your assignment submission.

  • Submit your assignment in one file.
  • Ensure your analysis is for the correct date range as specified above. 
  • Please ensure you have included a clear snapshot of the funnel analysis page in your submission file.
  • Please be elaborate in your responses when explaining the observations and recommendations based on the analysis. 
  • As stated in the question, include the countrywise analysis.
  • Submit your assignment on canvas by the submission due date for it to be considered for grading.

Areas where students generally lose points. So, please watch out for these points when you work on this assignment.

  • Students generally leave out one or more points about observations and recommendations.
  • Students sometimes select an incorrect date range and/or incorrect dimensions. As a result, all the metrics are incorrect.
  • Students do not read the assignment questions thoroughly and thereby leave out important points in the submission.
  • Students begin working on the assignment near the submission deadline and submit an incorrect/incomplete assignment. 

Your submissions will be graded based on the grading rubric shown below.

Funnel analysis (shown in the form of a picture) A picture of the funnel analysis is not provided. A picture of the funnel analysis is provided.

 Observation section The observation section is not mentioned  The observation section is superficially explained.  The observation section is explained with some lack of clarity and coherence. The observation section is explained elaborately with a clear rationale.

The report has some writing errors such as some spelling or grammatical errors. The report is somewhat difficult to understand. The report has few writing errors such as some spelling or grammatical errors. The report is somewhat easy to understand. The report has no spelling or grammatical errors The report is easy to understand.

Assume that your manager has asked you to analyze the performance of different channels from January 1, 2022, to December 31, 2022. Your company is planning to launch new merchandise in the market and is planning marketing activities for the next two quarters. The manager wants you to use attribution models through Google Analytics 4 to examine which channels to invest in the marketing efforts.

Please use Google Analysis 4 for this assignment. The following is the website link to the Google Analytics 4 demo account: https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/6367342?hl=en#zippy=%2Cin-this-articleLinks to an external site.

After you click on the above website link, scroll down a bit on the page and select "Google Analytics 4 property: Google Merchandise Store (web data)" to complete the assignment.

Hint: Compare the last-click attribution model with any two of the attribution models. Note down your observation in detail.

Next, examine the conversion paths. Note down your observations. The "Direct" channel may likely show the most conversions. Explain what that means. Further, apart from direct, explain what the remaining channels indicate. Then, provide your recommendations to the manager in detail. Specifically, your suggestions could be "Investing in x, y, z channels in a,b,c sequence would be beneficial because of p,q, r reasons. Considering the conversion paths so and so are recommended actions."

Please use the following submission template to submit the assignment: Google Analytics practice Attribution models template-1.docx 

Assignment submission instructions

Page 2: Picture of the front page of the attribution model table

Page 3: Half-page summary of your understanding and analysis of the attribution models and Half page recommendations to the manager based on your analysis. 

Please elaborate in your response. Please use font size 12, Times New Roman, and single-line spacing.

Please note there is no right observation and recommendation, and there is no wrong observation and recommendation. I am interested in how elaborately you explain your observations and recommendations.

The observation section is explained with two points but with some lack of clarity and coherence. The observation section is explained elaborately with two points and with a clear rationale.

Path analysis

  • Assume that your manager/supervisor wants you to perform path analysis using Google Analytics 4 for a store's website using a date range of January 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022. If this date range does not work, please try  March 1, 2022 to March 1, 2023 (You may choose any of the mentioned date ranges, as there could be an error with a specific date range on the Google Analytics 4 platform. So either of the date ranges should work for the assignment.)
  • IF THE ABOVE MENTIONED DATE RANGES DON'T WORK, PLEASE SELECT a date range of June 1, 2022 to May 31, 2023 OR July 1, 2022 to June 30, 2023 OR Select a date range of your choice. In any case, please specify in your assignment the date range that you selected. You won't lose any points for selecting a different date range. 
  • The manager wants you to examine the path users take starting from the bags page. 
  • Further the manager wants you to perform country-wise analysis of the path. In addition, the manager also wants you to examine the path of user segment that uses mobile phones.
  • Based on the analysis, the manager wants you to write down your top 2 observations from the data and top 2 recommendations to improve the performance of the website.

Please refer to the instructor video posted in the module before you begin with this assignment.

An outline for the analysis: Perform the following steps after selecting path exploration in Google Analytics 4.

  1. Click on start over (mostly on the top right corner of the page).

  4. Select the “mobile traffic” from the segments section, drag and drop it in the segments tab
  5. Observe the numbers, click on the different nodes to examine them and note down your observations.

assignment_name: CERTIFICATION: Submission_Google Tag Manager Certification and response to two questions
description:
Website link to begin with the certification: https://analytics.google.com/analytics/academy/course/5

Assignment submission template (please use this template for the assignment submission): Google Analytics Tag Manager certification_template-3-1.docx 

Sample response (to the two questions) from a previous student: Google Analytics Tag Manager certification_example from previous student.pdf 

Please refer the following sections before submitting your assignment.

Points structure for this assignment

This assignment is worth 100 points. Following is the breakdown of the points.

Certification submission: 75 points

Response to two questions: 25 points

Total: 75 + 25 = 100 points 

Instructor's expectations for this submission. What is it that you exactly need to do?

  • Complete the certification using the above-mentioned website link.
  • Download the submission template (posted above) and follow the format to answer the two questions. Also, refer to the grading rubric (shown below) to understand how your assignment will be graded.
  • Provide be elaborate in your responses. Do not write one-sentence responses (even if that one sentence is quite long). 
  • DO NOT WRITE A SINGLE PARAGRAPH WITH ALL POINTS MIXED INTO ONE.
  • Since the certification is about Google Tag Manager, please write about what you learned from Google Tag Manager certification and NOT from other analytics platforms. 
  • I expect you to explain your learned points and apply your understanding of the certification to different marketing contexts.
  • Label your document and upload the correct file before the submission due date. Your assignment submission will be a document that will contain a clear picture of the certificate (with YOUR name on it) and your response to the two questions.

Areas where students lose points in this assignment. So please keep these points in mind when completing this assignment.

  • Students upload an incorrect certificate, a picture of the scoring page (for example, 90/100), or a certificate with some other name (company's name, friend's name, partner's name, etc.) 
  • Students do not follow the attached submission template and do not refer to the grading rubric.
  • Students combine question 1 and question 2 in one response. In other words, they do not write separate responses. 
  • Students write one sentence (sometimes one long sentence) response to each point. In other words, they do not elaborate in their responses.
  • Students write only one learning point in question 1 and one application in question 2.
  • Students sometimes answer only one question and do not answer the second question.
  • Students sometimes write about some other certification or some other platform rather than writing about Tag Manager certification.
  • Students begin working on the assignment near the submission deadline and submit an incorrect/incomplete assignment. 

Instructor's expectations for this submission.

Your submission file should be formatted according to the above template.

Page 1: Your name, student ID number, and course name

Page 2: Picture of the completion certificate.

Page 3 & Page 4: Response to the top 3 points you learned in this certification. And how would you apply the knowledge of this certification to three different marketing contexts/departments? 

Please use font size 12, Times New Roman, and single-line spacing. 

The grading for the two questions will be based on how elaborately you explain the points. So, please elaborate in your response if you want to score high points on this assignment. Please use the submission template to complete the assignment and the example from previous student, to complete your assignment.

Grading Rubric

Your assignment submissions will be graded based on the grading rubric shown below. 

Criteria for each section of the assignment Below average Average Good Excellent TOTAL POINTS (100 POINTS)
Completion Certificate A clear picture of the completion certificate is not provided. (0 POINTS)     A clear picture of the certificate is provided. (75 POINTS) 75
Top 3 points that you learned in this certification. The section is not mentioned. (0 POINTS)  Only one learning point is mentioned. (2.5 POINTS) Two learning points are mentioned. (4 POINTS) Three learning points are mentioned. (5 POINTS) 5
Elaboration on the points learned in the certification The points are not at all elaborated. Mostly, each point is only a single sentence. (0 POINTS) The points are superficial. (2.5 POINTS) The points are somewhat superficial and not quite explained well. (4 POINTS) The points are elaborated and very well explained. (5 POINTS) 5
Application of the knowledge from this certification to different marketing contexts The section is not mentioned. (0 POINTS)  Only one application is mentioned. (2.5 POINTS) Two applications are mentioned (4 POINTS) Three applications are mentioned. (5 POINTS) 5
Elaboration on the points of application to different marketing contexts The points are not at all elaborated. Mostly, each point is only a single sentence. (0 POINTS) The points are superficial.  (2.5 POINTS) The points are somewhat superficial and not quite explained well. (4 POINTS) The points are elaborated and very well explained. (5 POINTS) 5
Writing and organization The report has multiple writing errors such as multiple spelling or grammatical errors.  The report is difficult to understand and is not organized. (0 POINTS) The report has some writing errors such as some spelling or grammatical errors. The report is somewhat difficult to understand. Or, the report is not organized. The organization of the report or the observation and recommendation sections are mixed together and/or are confusing. (2.5 POINTS) The report has few writing errors such as some spelling or grammatical errors. The report is somewhat easy to understand. Or, the report is organized in a slightly confusing manner. (4 POINTS) The report has no spelling or grammatical errors. Writing and organization The report has multiple writing errors such as multiple spelling or grammatical errors.  The report is difficult to understand and is not organized. (0 POINTS) The report has some writing errors such as some spelling or grammatical errors. The report is somewhat difficult to understand. Or, the report is not organized. The organization of the report or the observation and recommendation sections are mixed together and/or are confusing. (2.5 POINTS) The report has few writing errors such as some spelling or grammatical errors. The report is somewhat easy to understand. Or, the report is organized in a slightly confusing manner. (4 POINTS) The report has no spelling or grammatical errors. The report is easy to understand and well-organized. The observation and recommendation sections are separate (not mixed together) and are easy to understand ( 5 POINTS) 5

assignment_name: Discussion 5: Flexibility and Range of Motion
description:
While many people perceive flexibility as the ability to "touch your toes" or "do the splits", from a health perspective, flexibility refers to having a healthy range of motion throughout our joints.  According to UC Davis Health, inadequate flexibility will have a negative effect on the body in 3 significant ways:

  1. Joints that are unable to move through a full range of motion will not be able to maintain the health of cartilage and provide blood supply and nutrients. This effect can be particularly noticeable in weight bearing joints such as the hips and knees.
  2. Muscles that are inflexible tire more quickly, causing opposing muscle groups to work harder. For example, the hamstrings play a role in stabilizing the knee and preventing ACL tears.
  3. Decreased flexibility may also lead to abnormal stress on structures and tissues distant from the initial site of inflexibility. One example of this is that tendonitis in the knee can be related to calf tightness.

Within your discussion groups (they are already created, no need to sign up, just post below!), I would like you to discuss different methods of improving flexibility, joint range of motion, and core strength. Each group member will create an original post about a flexibility method (10 pts.), and respond to 2 of their peers' posts (5 pts.).

In your post, please describe:

  • your chosen modality and its definition/description
  • its claimed benefits
  • YOUR EXPERIENCE- share your detailed workout - post link, class, etc.
    • Describe your workout, what you liked about it, and what you found challenging
    • Would you recommend it? Why or why not?

You may use your OWN classes, routines, or resources, but here are some examples of modalities and resources for them:

  • Yoga
    • Do Yoga With Me
    • UVU Fitness
  • Pilates
    • UVU Fitness
    • Pilates classes online
  • Tai Chi
    • About: https://taichionlineclasses.com/
    • Beginner YouTube Channel
  • Myofascial release (i.e. foam rolling, lacrosse ball, etc.)
    • UVU Fitness class "Melt"
  • Static Stretching routines
    • example routine: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7FCNFuyyWTA
  • Dynamic Warmup/stretching prior to workouts
    • example routine: https://www.menshealth.com/fitness/a27482609/dynamic-stretches/
  • PNF "Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation" stretching
    • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HpatAJI0-pU

As part of the objectives for Chapter 6, you will learn how body composition affects overall health and wellness.  For this discussion, I would like you to review the Centers for Disease Prevention and Control: Overweight & Obesity website, containing current statistics, health implications, and preventative measures.  You will post THREE times for this assignment.

  1. I have create 5 SUBTOPICS for this discussion.  For your Post #1, you will respond to ME (one of MY subtopics), and give THREE facts or statistics on the topic that you found interesting and why!  Make sure your post information is ORGINAL and not repeating what other students have already posted.  Please provide a link or embed a photo (ie screenshot a table or a map!) for each/fact statistic. 8 pts.
  2. Post #2 - you will post on ANOTHER one of my subtopics (respond to me), same guidelines as above. (10) 8 pts. 
  3. Post #3 - you will RESPOND to a peer in a different subtopic (therefore, you will have interacted with 3 different subtopics) 4 pts.

SUBTOPICS ARE LISTED HERE - more details will be provided on my subtopic post.

  • Adult Obesity Facts
  • Childhood Obesity Facts
  • Physical Activity
  • Eating Disorders
  • OTHER - share other facts/ statistics that don't fit in with the other categories!

For this discussion, you will compare two "similar" food items in terms of nutritional value and determine which food is the "healthier" option (12 pts.).  You will then comment on one of your peer's comparisons about something you found interesting or which food you will choose to eat and why! (3 pts.)

For your comparison post:

  1. Choose two foods that are "similar" - i.e. skim milk vs. soy milk, Kraft vs. Annie's Organic Mac and Cheese, Regular Ranch Dressing vs. Fat-Free Ranch dressing, etc.
  2. Post the nutritional information side by side in a chart, or EMBED (don't just attach) the food label images.  Make sure the nutritional information contains the following information:
  4. Along with the nutritional information, highlight the major differences or surprising similarities.  Finally, give us your take on which food is "healthier" and WHY.
  5. Read your peers' comparisons, and comment on at least one:  Tell us what you found surprising, or tell us which food you will consume from now on and why!

Don't forget your technical support resources.) When I ask you to go back and correct your answers, do so in a different color. PART 2

Watch the following  4 videos. Be sure to take notes in your notebook for use on the exam.

What is a Valid Argument? (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.

What is a "STRONG" argument? (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=07mehbgE5jc (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.Identifying Premises and Conclusions (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.

1. Answer each of the following, and explain your answer. Submit them here and bring a copy to class next time so we can talk about them.

   a. Can a valid argument have true premises and a true conclusion?

   b. Can an invalid argument have true premises and a true conclusion?

   c. Can a valid argument have true premises and a false conclusion?

   d. Can an invalid argument have true premises and a false conclusion?

   e. Can a valid argument have false premises and a true conclusion?

   f. Can an invalid argument have false premises and a true conclusion?

   g. Can a valid argument have false premises and a false conclusion?

   h. Can an invalid argument have false premises and a false conclusion?

2. Put the following into standard form.

Sometimes it is morally acceptable to tell a person with dementia a lie. People with dementia are sometimes subject to delusions. Telling someone that their delusion is incorrect doesn't work (because you can't reason with delusions) and is often counterproductive (because people can get very stressed or agitated when they think they are losing touch with reality). Not addressing the delusion/hallucination can be dangerous. For example, if a person with dementia believes they have to pick up their child from preschool when in reality, that child is fully grown and the person with dementia does not have a driver's license or ability to drive, letting that person persist in the delusion could result in traffic deaths. Telling someone a lie in this case (e.g., "school is closed today") helps the person with dementia and harms no one. It doesn't harm other people, and since the person with dementia will forget this lie soon, it can't harm them either. In cases like these, it is morally acceptable to tell a lie. (This made-up argument is based off of factual information from the Weill Institute for Neurosciences.)

3. Download and watch/listen to this presentation, which has answers to #1 and #2 above. (Note: you MUST download it to hear the audio. You can't do the assignment without hearing the audio. Don't forget your technical support resources.) Correct your answers in a different color.

This assignment is graded based on completeness and effort, so leave in your mistakes.

PART 3

For this assignment, you will complete the exercises in tutorials A03 (skip the first one in exercise 2), A04, A05 (skip exercises 5-8) and A07.  Leave in your mistakes and correct your answers in a different color. 

This assignment is graded based on completeness and effort, so leave in your mistakes.

Should consent be required for people who are mourned as a griefbot? In this assignment, you will generate, analyze, and critically evaluate arguments about griefbots.

To learn about griefbots, read a case study entitled "AI, Death, and Mourning". (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.

Part 1: Generate two arguments with opposing conclusions about about whether consent should be required for people who are mourned as griefbots.

NOTE : You absolutely do need to cite your sources. Use APA format (Links to an external site.). You do need to use academic writing, and you do  need to write paragraphs (as opposed to bullet points). Also, don't put your argument in standard form. Write a paragraph. If your paragraph is clear, I should be able to put your argument in standard form.

I'm not looking for any specific word count. I'm looking for the quality of the argument. I'll be asking these questions:

1. Is there a conclusion? Is the conclusion clearly stated?

2. What are the premises? Are they clearly stated?

3. Does the author defend the premises where relevant? Is it clear what sub conclusions are in play?

4. Does the author consider relevant nuances when generating the premises?

We have talked in class about arguments, so you should know what a philosophical argument looks like. Your reader should be able to analyze your argument, which is possible if you are clear about your conclusion and your premises. Make your argument as strong as possible by keeping in mind what we have learned about logic and validity. Also, where possible, support your premises.

Part 2: Analyze the hypothetical argument by the fictional J. Doe below by (a) putting it in standard form, (b) diagramming it, and (c) writing an analysis paragraph.

"Consent for people who are mourned as griefbots should not be required because consent is unnecessary. The point of consent is to protect people from harm, but dead people can't be harmed. They can't be harmed physically because they feel no pain. They can't be harmed emotionally either. Death is either complete annihilation or continued existence in another realm. If the dead person is completely annihilated, they can't have emotions. If they exist in another realm, their emotions can't be affected by what happens here. That's why dead people can't be harmed, so consent is unnecessary, and so it should not be required." --J. Doe

NOTE: This will be graded based on completeness and effort. Don't stress if you don't think you did it correctly. This is a skill and you get better by practice.

Part 3: Critically evaluate the argument in part 2. Remember: A critical evaluation is an argument you create about an argument you’ve analyzed whose conclusion is about a premise in the argument you’ve analyzed. (The conclusion can disagree with a premise (most common; easiest). The conclusion can agree with a premise by giving novel reasons (less common; harder))

 

CHECKLIST: Make sure your assignment has all of these components.

PART 1: This part should have two paragraphs. Each paragraph gives an argument, but they have opposing conclusions.

PART 2A: Here you'll put the argument by J. Doe in standard form.

PART 2B: Here you'll give a diagram of what you wrote in 2A.

PART 2C: Here you'll write an analysis paragraph of J. Doe's argument.

PART 3: Here you'll write a critical evaluation of J. Doe's argument.

In this assignment, you are to watch the film named above (it is available underthe pages tab to your left). Then you are to write an essay in which you connect specific and specifiedideas in the film (characters, plot points, dialogue, etc.) to specific and specified ideas from the readings and from discussions in class. These  connections serve to develop and defend a thesis about the readings that draws novel connections and makes insightful claims (see below for tips on how to develop a thesis). By developing and defending your thesis, you will grapple with the readings more deeply than we could in class, you will further develop your skills at generating arguments, and you will engage in independent, philosophical thinking.

Note: People occasionally have reasons for finding that a particular film would not be good for them to watch. If you would like an alternate assignment, please message me. Give me the general reason (you are not obligated to go into detail) so I can know it is for an approved reason (e.g., psychological well-being, cultural considerations, inability to view without children present) and not for non-approved reasons (e.g., I'm hoping for a shorter film, I don't like this kind of movie).

Minimum requirements:

1. 700-1000 words, single spaced, page numbers at the bottom center. No title page, no running head.  The title and your name should be at the top, centered. Note that the word count is a ballpark minimum, and it is only provided to give people a sense of the depth I'm looking for. You are welcome and encouraged to write more. 

2. Works cited page that cites the film and the textbook (with as complete of information as you have). Papers that lack a works cited page and/or in text citations are considered plagiarized and will need to be rewritten and resubmitted.

     Use this style for the pdfs: Last name, first name (year). "Title." Journal Name (volume number): first page-last page.

     Use this style for films: Director (year). Title.

     For in text citations, use this format: (author of article, year, page number).

     For in text citations of the films, use this format (time, title).

     For in text citations from the textbook, use this format: (author of chapter, title of chapter, page number.)

3. Has a THESIS that is supported by citing both the film and the textbook for a minimum of 5 connections. I'm looking for whether or not you cite SPECIFIC things about the film and relate them to SPECIFIC things in the readings/class discussions. Note that the citation count is a ballpark minimum, and it is only provided to give people a sense of the depth I'm looking for. You are welcome and encouraged to cite more. 

     EXAMPLE: In UVU president Tuminez's remake of the classic Bambi, the scene where Bambi's mother dies (3:45-5:22 Bambi) contradicts Socrates's basic assertion that death is nothing to fear (Socrates, 2007, p. 20-21).

4. Does not include anything about yourself. (Do not include whether you liked the film, whether you are glad you saw it, or your opinion about the acting, style, casting, etc. Leave out all mere opinion.) Includes a brief synopsis of the film only as relevant.

Evaluation: 

The papers are evaluated based on (1) the sophistication of the thesis, (2) the defense of the thesis, and (to a lesser extent), (3) mechanics (in text citations, work cited page, paragraph organization, grammar, etc.). 

C papers either don't have a thesis or don't support the thesis with specific citations that are quoted/paraphrased and interpreted. They talk about the film and readings in general ways that don't show careful note-taking and re-viewing/re-reading.

B papers have a thesis that says that there are connections/similarities/dissimilarities between the film and the reading(s). Sample thesis from a B  paper: Bambi has characters that act in utilitarian ways.

A papers go beyond juxtaposing the film and the readings and provide an original philosophical view. Sample thesis from an A paper: Bambi can be understood as a refutation of virtue ethics. Another sample thesis from an A paper: Bambi shows that the theories of death that deny an afterlife will not adequately account for the trauma that those who remain face. Surprisingly, then, even though the film does not in any way discuss whether there is an afterlife, it nonetheless can be read as making an argument that only if there is an afterlife can we account for suffering.

Tips for generating a thesis:

There's no formula for generating a quality thesis, but you can ask yourself these questions to help get you started.

1. Does the film challenge in a new way a theory/theories? How?

2. Does it undermine a particular view, or illustrate a particular view, or provide a further reason to believe a particular view? If so, how?

3. Does the film show a limitation of a particular theory/theories? Or does a theory show a limitation of a character in the film?

4. If we view the film through the lens of a theory, how would we evaluate a character/action?

assignment_name: Analysis/Critical Evaluation assignment: Rights and Responsibilities
description:
Do pharmacists have a right to refuse to refer or transfer prescriptions based on their religious convictions?

In this assignment, you will generate, analyze, and critically evaluate arguments about that question.

To learn about a specific case study, read a case study entitled "Conscientious Refusal". (Links to an external site.)

 

Part 1: Generate two arguments with opposing conclusions about about whether pharmacists have a right to refuse to refer or transfer prescriptions based on their religious convictions.

NOTE : You absolutely do need to cite your sources. Use APA format (Links to an external site.). You do need to use academic writing, and you do  need to write paragraphs (as opposed to bullet points). Also, don't put your argument in standard form. Write a paragraph. If your paragraph is clear, I should be able to put your argument in standard form.

I'm not looking for any specific word count. I'm looking for the quality of the argument. I'll be asking these questions:

1. Is there a conclusion? Is the conclusion clearly stated?

2. What are the premises? Are they clearly stated?

3. Does the author defend the premises where relevant? Is it clear what sub conclusions are in play?

4. Does the author consider relevant nuances when generating the premises?

We have talked in class about arguments, so you should know what a philosophical argument looks like. Your reader should be able to analyze your argument, which is possible if you are clear about your conclusion and your premises. Make your argument as strong as possible by keeping in mind what we have learned about logic and validity. Also, where possible, support your premises.

Part 2: Analyze the hypothetical argument by the fictional J. Doe below by (a) putting it in standard form, (b) diagramming it, and (c) writing an analysis paragraph.

"Pharmacists do have a right to refuse to refer or transfer prescriptions based on their religious convictions. Moral laws are more important than legal laws because they are eternal and because they have to do with your conscience, where as legal laws are tied to a specific time and have to do only with how to make people get along, not with matters of conscience. Things that are eternal and have to do with conscience are more important than things that are not. Since moral laws are more important, we have a greater obligation to perform them. We have a right to protect our greater obligations. So pharmacists do have a right to refuse to refer or transfer prescriptions." --J. Doe

NOTE: This will be graded based on completeness and effort. Don't stress if you don't think you did it correctly. This is a skill and you get better by practice.

Part 3: Critically evaluate the argument in part 2. Remember: A critical evaluation is an argument you create about an argument you’ve analyzed whose conclusion is about a premise in the argument you’ve analyzed. (The conclusion can disagree with a premise (most common; easiest). The conclusion can agree with a premise by giving novel reasons (less common; harder).)

 

CHECKLIST: Make sure your assignment has all of these components.

PART 1: This part should have two paragraphs. Each paragraph gives an argument, but they have opposing conclusions.

PART 2A: Here you'll put the argument by J. Doe in standard form.

PART 2B: Here you'll give a diagram of what you wrote in 2A.

PART 2C: Here you'll write an analysis paragraph of J. Doe's argument.

PART 3: Here you'll write a critical evaluation of J. Doe's argument.

In this assignment, you are to watch the film named above (it is available undert he pages tab to your left). Then you are to write an essay in which you connect specific and specified ideas in the film (characters, plot points, dialogue, etc.) to specific and specified ideas from the readings and from discussions in class. These  connections serve to develop and defend a thesis about the readings that draws novel connections and makes insightful claims (see below for tips on how to develop a thesis). By developing and defending your thesis, you will grapple with the readings more deeply than we could in class, you will further develop your skills at generating arguments, and you will engage in independent, philosophical thinking.

Note: People occasionally have reasons for finding that a particular film would not be good for them to watch. If you would like an alternate assignment, please message me. Give me the general reason (you are not obligated to go into detail) so I can know it is for an approved reason (e.g., psychological well-being, cultural considerations, inability to view without children present) and not for non-approved reasons (e.g., I'm hoping for a shorter film, I don't like this kind of movie).

Minimum requirements:

1. 700-1000 words, single spaced, page numbers at the bottom center. No title page, no running head.  The title and your name should be at the top, centered. Note that the word count is a ballpark minimum, and it is only provided to give people a sense of the depth I'm looking for. You are welcome and encouraged to write more. 

2. Works cited page that cites the film and the textbook (with as complete of information as you have). Papers that lack a works cited page and/or in text citations are considered plagiarized and will need to be rewritten and resubmitted.

     Use this style for the pdfs: Last name, first name (year). "Title." Journal Name (volume number): first page-last page.

     Use this style for films: Director (year). Title.

     For in text citations, use this format: (author of article, year, page number).

     For in text citations of the films, use this format (time, title).

3. Has a THESIS that is supported by citing both the film and the textbook for a minimum of 5 connections. I'm looking for whether or not you cite SPECIFIC things about the film and relate them to SPECIFIC things in the readings/class discussions. Note that the citation count is a ballpark minimum, and it is only provided to give people a sense of the depth I'm looking for. You are welcome and encouraged to cite more. 

     EXAMPLE: In UVU president Tuminez's remake of the classic Bambi, the scene where Bambi's mother dies (3:45-5:22 Bambi) contradicts Socrates's basic assertion that death is nothing to fear (Socrates, 2007, p. 20-21).

4. Does not include anything about yourself. (Do not include whether you liked the film, whether you are glad you saw it, or your opinion about the acting, style, casting, etc. Leave out all mere opinion.) Includes a brief synopsis of the film only as relevant.

Evaluation: 

The papers are evaluated based on (1) the sophistication of the thesis, (2) the defense of the thesis, and (to a lesser extent), (3) mechanics (in text citations, work cited page, paragraph organization, grammar, etc.). 

C papers either don't have a thesis or don't support the thesis with specific citations that are quoted/paraphrased and interpreted. They talk about the film and readings in general ways that don't show careful note-taking and re-viewing/re-reading.

B papers have a thesis that says that there are connections/similarities/dissimilarities between the film and the reading(s). Sample thesis from a B  paper: Bambi has characters that act in utilitarian ways.

A papers go beyond juxtaposing the film and the readings and provide an original philosophical view. Sample thesis from an A paper: Bambi can be understood as a refutation of virtue ethics. Another sample thesis from an A paper: Bambi shows that the theories of death that deny an afterlife will not adequately account for the trauma that those who remain face. Surprisingly, then, even though the film does not in any way discuss whether there is an afterlife, it nonetheless can be read as making an argument that only if there is an afterlife can we account for suffering.

Tips for generating a thesis:

There's no formula for generating a quality thesis, but you can ask yourself these questions to help get you started.

1. Does the film challenge in a new way a theory/theories? How?

2. Does it undermine a particular view, or illustrate a particular view, or provide a further reason to believe a particular view? If so, how?

3. Does the film show a limitation of a particular theory/theories? Or does a theory show a limitation of a character in the film?

4. If we view the film through the lens of a theory, how would we evaluate a character/action?

Should UVU cancel Aristotle from all Ethics and Values classes? 

To learn more about the issue, read "Should We Cancel Aristotle?" by Agnes Callard .  (Links to an external site.)(Note: you have access to 10 free New York Times articles per month without a subscription. Message me immediately if you can't get this article, and I'll help you find an alternative.)

 

Part 1:

Generate two arguments with opposing conclusions about whether UVU professors should take Aristotle out of their Ethics and Values syllabus.

NOTE : You absolutely do need to cite your sources. Use APA format (Links to an external site.). You do need to use academic writing, and you do  need to write paragraphs (as opposed to bullet points). Also, don't put your argument in standard form. Write a paragraph. If your paragraph is clear, I should be able to put your argument in standard form.

I'm not looking for any specific word count. I'm looking for the quality of the argument. I'll be asking these questions:

1. Is there a conclusion? Is the conclusion clearly stated?

2. What are the premises? Are they clearly stated?

3. Does the author defend the premises where relevant? Is it clear what sub conclusions are in play?

4. Does the author consider relevant nuances when generating the premises?

We have talked in class about arguments, so you should know what a philosophical argument looks like. Your reader should be able to analyze your argument, which is possible if you are clear about your conclusion and your premises. Make your argument as strong as possible by keeping in mind what we have learned about logic and validity. Also, where possible, support your premises. 

Part 2: Analyze the hypothetical argument by the fictional J. Doe below by (a) putting it in standard form, (b) diagramming it, and (c) writing an analysis paragraph.

"Aristotle should not be taught in UVU's Ethics and Values classes. The reason isn't that he had immoral views. The reason is instead that we can't argue with him about his immoral views. This is because he is dead, so he has the last word on slavery from his own perspective. If you can't argue with someone about their views, then this defeats the whole point of an Ethics class, which is to come up with and understand arguments in order to think better. Additionally, there are other people who talk about virtue ethics but who don't advocate for slavery. These people, consequently, have views about virtue ethics that are inherently superior to Aristotle's. So these people should replace Aristotle on the syllabus." --J. Doe

NOTE: This will be graded based on completeness and effort. Don't stress if you don't think you did it correctly. This is a skill and you get better by practice.

Part 3: Critically evaluate the argument in part 2. Remember: A critical evaluation is an argument you create about an argument you’ve analyzed whose conclusion is about a premise in the argument you’ve analyzed. (The conclusion can disagree with a premise (most common; easiest). The conclusion can agree with a premise by giving novel reasons (less common; harder).)

 

CHECKLIST: Make sure your assignment has all of these components.

PART 1: This part should have two paragraphs. Each paragraph gives an argument, but they have opposing conclusions.

PART 2A: Here you'll put the argument by J. Doe in standard form.

PART 2B: Here you'll give a diagram of what you wrote in 2A.

PART 2C: Here you'll write an analysis paragraph of J. Doe's argument.

PART 3: Here you'll write a critical evaluation of J. Doe's argument.

In this assignment, you are to watch the film named above (it is available in the module). Then you are to write an essay in which you connect specific and specified ideas in the film (characters, plot points, dialogue, etc.) to specific and specified ideas from the readings and from discussions in class.

Minimum requirements:

1. 700-1000 words, single spaced, page numbers at the bottom center. No title page, no running head.  The title and your name should be at the top, centered.

2. Works cited page that cites the film and the textbook (with as complete of information as you have). Papers that lack a works cited page and/or in text citations are considered plagiarized. 

     Use this style for the textbook: Last name, first name (year). Title.

     Use this style for films: Director (year). Title.

     For in text citations, use this format: (author of article, year, page number).

     For in text citations of the films, use this format (time, title).

3. Has a THESIS that is supported by citing both the film and the textbook for a minimum of 5 connections. I'm looking for whether or not you cite SPECIFIC things about the film and relate them to SPECIFIC things in the readings/class discussions. Papers that fail to cite BOTH the film AND the textbook a minimum number of 5 times in a relevant way will receive a zero.

     EXAMPLE: In UVU president Tuminez's remake of the classic Bambi, the scene where Bambi's mother dies (3:45-5:22 Bambi) contradicts Weigel's basic assertion that death is just another part of life (Weigel, 2019, p. 1).

4. Does not include anything about yourself. (Do not include whether you liked the film, whether you are glad you saw it, or your opinion about the acting, style, casting, etc. Leave out all mere opinion.) Includes a brief synopsis only as relevant.

C papers meet these minimum requirements only. They state how thing x in the film is similar to or dissimilar to thing y in the reading. Because they display a basic comprehension only, they do not make arguments to back up their claims.

Sample claim from a C paper: In UVU president Tuminez's remake of the classic Bambi, the scene where Bambi's mother dies (3:45-5:22 Bambi) contradicts Weigel's basic assertion that death is just another part of life (Weigel, 2019).

B papers provide additional depth or insight. Instead of saying just that thing x in the film is similar or dissimilar to thing y in the reading, B papers additionally touch on some of these questions

1. Does the film challenges in a new way a theory/theories? How?

2. Does it undermine a particular view, or illustrate a particular view, or provide a further reason to believe a particular view? If so, how?

3. Does the film show a limitation of a particular theory/theories? Or does a theory show a limitation of a character in the film?

Additionally, B papers more thoroughly quote, cite and explain particular aspects of the readings and the film to back up their claims. They talk about specific passages in each and explain their relevance to the claim they are making.

Sample claim from a B paper: In UVU president Tuminez's remake of the classic Bambi, the scene where Bambi's mother dies (3:45-5:22 Bambi) contradicts Weigel's basic assertion that death is just another part of life (Weigel, 2019, p. 2). For Bambi's mother, death is just another progression, but Bambi herself is devastated. For Bambi, this event changes everything. She spends the rest of her life having terrible relationships (25:34-38:35 and 44:55-49:68 Bambi, for example). Since Weigel says that even for those who remain, other people's death is just another part of life, Weigel's view is limited.

A papers not only provide depth and insight; additionally, they connect themes in a way that develops an original thesis. They show independent readings--in other words, they go beyond what was said in class to draw new connections. Their views give an enriched understanding of both the reading(s) and the film: they show why juxtaposing them provides new insight.

Sample thesis from an A paper: Bambi shows that the theories of death that deny an afterlife will not adequately account for the trauma that those who remain face. Surprisingly, then, even though the film does not in any way discuss whether there is an afterlife, it nonetheless can be read as making an argument that only if there is an afterlife can we account for suffering.

Should doctors tell patients about negative side effects when doing so can lead to the "nocebo" effect?

To learn about the issue, read an opinion piece from the New York Times entitled "Beware the Nocebo Effect". (Links to an external site.)

 (Links to an external site.)(If you can't access that article, you can use am (Links to an external site.)an article from Web MD entitled "Is the Nocebo Effect Hurting Your Health?" (Links to an external site.) instead. Please note it has two pages you have to click through.)

If you're feeling motivated and/or curious, you can also read the original study about physical therapy and lower back pain. (Links to an external site.) (Links to an external site.)

Part 1: Generate two arguments with opposing conclusions about whether a physical therapist should tell their patients that certain exercises can lead to short term pain. 

NOTE : You absolutely do need to cite your sources. Use APA format (Links to an external site.). You do need to use academic writing, and you do  need to write paragraphs (as opposed to bullet points). Also, don't put your argument in standard form. Write a paragraph. If your paragraph is clear, I should be able to put your argument in standard form.

I'm not looking for any specific word count. I'm looking for the quality of the argument. I'll be asking these questions:

1. Is there a conclusion? Is the conclusion clearly stated?

2. What are the premises? Are they clearly stated?

3. Does the author defend the premises where relevant? Is it clear what sub conclusions are in play?

4. Does the author consider relevant nuances when generating the premises?

We have talked in class about arguments, so you should know what a philosophical argument looks like. Your reader should be able to analyze your argument, which is possible if you are clear about your conclusion and your premises. Make your argument as strong as possible by keeping in mind what we have learned about logic and validity. Also, where possible, support your premises. For this one, you should note whether you are using Utilitarian and/or Kantian reasoning and explain your answer.

Part 2: Analyze the hypothetical argument by the fictional J. Doe below by (a) putting it in standard form, (b) diagramming it, and (c) writing an analysis paragraph.

"All medical professionals take an oath which says they will do no harm. Telling a patient that they will feel pain from a physical therapy exercise harms the patient. The reason it harms the patient is that people are more likely to feel pain if they anticipate it. The pain is one kind of harm. Another kind of harm that results is that patients could be less likely to stick with their physical therapy. If they don't stick with their physical therapy, they are less likely to recover. Therefore, physical therapists should not tell patients that they might experience pain from exercises that are good for them." --J. Doe

NOTE: This will be graded based on completeness and effort. Don't stress if you don't think you did it correctly. This is a skill and you get better by practice.

Part 3: Critically evaluate the argument in part 2. Remember: A critical evaluation is an argument you create about an argument you’ve analyzed whose conclusion is about a premise in the argument you’ve analyzed. (The conclusion can disagree with a premise (most common; easiest). The conclusion can agree with a premise by giving novel reasons (less common; harder).)

 

CHECKLIST: Make sure your assignment has all of these components.

PART 1: This part should have two paragraphs. Each paragraph gives an argument, but they have opposing conclusions.

PART 2A: Here you'll put the argument by J. Doe in standard form.

PART 2B: Here you'll give a diagram of what you wrote in 2A.

PART 2C: Here you'll write an analysis paragraph of J. Doe's argument.

PART 3: Here you'll write a critical evaluation of J. Doe's argument.

Pierre Hadot believes that much of philosophy consists in what he calls “spiritual exercises.” This philosophy does not “consist in teaching an abstract theory—much less … the exegesis of texts—but rather in the art of living.” For Hadot, “It is a progress which causes us to be more fully, and makes us better” (Hadot, Philosophy as a Way of Life, p. 83). Ideally, such spiritual exercises make us less worried and more fulfilled. They might make us more self-aware, or less dominated by negative emotions, or more attentive to the world around us. They might make us better able to face difficult situations or build better habits. They might make us freer and heal our souls. (See Hadot, pp. 83-89). Our meditative exercises are modeled on Hadot’s ideas.

 

Each class period that is devoted to discussion (e.g., not the midterm or group project or review days), you will spend the last 15 minutes devoted to writing a meditative exercise. The meditative exercise should be connected to the class discussion, and it should be an exploration of how you could apply what we discussed to your life. How can our class discussion make you more self-aware? Less dominated by negative emotions? More attentive to the world around you? Better able to face difficult situations? Better able to build better habits? Freer?

 

Full credit will be awarded to those who connect their exercise to the class discussion of the day and explore applications. They are due at the end of class and count as your attendance. You can drop your lowest two scores because no make-ups are possible. All exercises will be read only by me, and if there is information that is too personal to include, you can indicate that.

 

NOTE: I have multiple sections in this canvas course. The due time is noon, but if you are in my noon section, it won't be counted as late (even though Canvas will say it is late) if you turn it in by 2pm, and if you are in my 2pm section, it won't be counted as late (even though Canvas will say it is late) if you turn it in by 4pm.

Pierre Hadot believes that much of philosophy consists in what he calls “spiritual exercises.” This philosophy does not “consist in teaching an abstract theory—much less … the exegesis of texts—but rather in the art of living.” For Hadot, “It is a progress which causes us to be more fully, and makes us better” (Hadot, Philosophy as a Way of Life, p. 83). Ideally, such spiritual exercises make us less worried and more fulfilled. They might make us more self-aware, or less dominated by negative emotions, or more attentive to the world around us. They might make us better able to face difficult situations or build better habits. They might make us freer and heal our souls. (See Hadot, pp. 83-89). Our meditative exercises are modeled on Hadot’s ideas.

 

Each class period that is devoted to discussion (e.g., not the midterm or group project or review days), you will spend the last 15 minutes devoted to writing a meditative exercise. The meditative exercise should be connected to the class discussion, and it should be an exploration of how you could apply what we discussed to your life. How can our class discussion make you more self-aware? Less dominated by negative emotions? More attentive to the world around you? Better able to face difficult situations? Better able to build better habits? Freer?

 

Full credit will be awarded to those who connect their exercise to the class discussion of the day and explore applications. They are due at the end of class and count as your attendance. You can drop your lowest two scores because no make-ups are possible. All exercises will be read only by me, and if there is information that is too personal to include, you can indicate that.

Readings: Chapter 8 of the textbook and Doris.

To prepare yourself for our class discussions, you will need to do each reading closely and carefully. To demonstrate this, and to help guide our discussions, you will need to provide ten things per reading. These ten things can be any combination of the following, so long as you have at least one #3 or #4. Each one should refer to a specific page number and each one should be labeled as a basic question, observation, critical thinking question, or argument. NOTE: most classes we will have two readings, so you will turn in 20 things total. These are due before class and cannot be turned in late, but you can drop your two lowest scores. NOTE: I have multiple sections in this canvas course. The due time is 10am, but if you are in my noon section, it won't be counted as late (even though Canvas will say it is late) if you turn it in by noon, and if you are in my 2pm section, it won't be counted as late (even though Canvas will say it is late) if you turn it in by 2pm.

  1. Basic Questions: The questions can be about terms, concepts, ideas, arguments, or passages, but they must refer to a specific page number.
    1. Example: On p. 2 of The Apology, in the first paragraph, I got lost in the discussion of older charges and newer charges. What are each of these charges?
    2. Example: On p. 9 of The Apology, how is Meletus defining an atheist?
  2. Observations: Here you can make any observation about anything you have read. Avoid personal attacks or opinions about your own experience as you do the reading.
    1. Example: Sometimes, like on p. 4, Socrates seems really humble, but sometimes when he talks to Meletus, he seems quite arrogant.
    2. But NOT anything like these: I dislike Socrates. Socrates is a total jerk. I found the reading boring/interesting.
  3. Critical thinking questions: By a critical thinking question, I mean a question that examines a premise or an underlying assumption in an argument.
    1. Example: On p. 8, Socrates says that no one likes to be injured, but how can that be true when people do dangerous things that end up in injury all the time (like risky driving or things like that)?
  4. Arguments: Here you can make a claim and support it with reasons. These are the best, and you should strive for as many as possible.
    1. Example: On pp. 20-21 when Socrates says that if death is like sleep, it will be great, he is making a false analogy. Sleep is only great because it feels good when you wake up. But if Socrates thinks death is permanent, then we never wake up. So death isn’t really like sleep.

  3. Critical thinking questions: By a critical thinking question, I mean a question that examines a premise or an underlying assumption in an argument.
    1. Example: On p. 8, Socrates says that no one likes to be injured, but how can that be true when people do dangerous things that end up in injury all the time (like risky driving or things like that)?
  4. Arguments: Here you can make a claim and support it with reasons. These are the best, and you should strive for as many as possible.
    1. Example: On pp. 20-21 when Socrates says that if death is like sleep, it will be great, he is making a false analogy. Sleep is only great because it feels good when you wake up. But if Socrates thinks death is permanent, then we never wake up. So death isn’t really like sleep.

Components of presentation:

  1. An explanation of the facts and background.
    1. People who do not know about the issue should come away with a solid understanding of what the issue is.
    2. People should know why this issue is important and why they should care about it.
    3. You can use a video here, but the clip should be short, and you should not use it as a substitute for explaining something yourself.
  2. An explanation of the relevant positions.
    1. You should indicate the pro and con (and middle, if any) positions. You should indicate the arguments people give for each of these positions.
    2. You should indicate to what extent, if any, these arguments are based on or implicitly draw on any of the theories we have studied (virtue ethics, utilitarianism, deontology).
    3. You should diagnose the disagreement (i.e., show how the disagreement is rooted in differing underlying theories, using anything we’ve studied this semester).

Note: This exam is open notes and open book. Design/build: Model Bridge (Course objective 2)

Construct a model bridge using up to two pieces of 8.5x11 paper and tape or string that spans a minimum of 7 inches and can hold a minimum of a full 12 ounce can of soda. 

Your bridge must function no matter what the vertical depth (how high/deep/tall the space is) and the ends of the bridge cannot be adhered to a surface (example, it cannot be taped in place) or anchored in any way.

To obtain credit for this assignment you must be in the picture or video demonstrating your creation and must also include a short summary of why it works as compared to other bridges.

Some aspects to consider might include stress/load distribution, geometrical shape strength, or similar.

Surfing the internet or other sources for ideas is completely acceptable and actually recommended.

See assignment expectations

Design/build: Paper/foam plate plane (Course objective 2)

Create a plane from a paper plate or a foam plate: Using only one or two paper plates or foam plates, tape, and a penny (optional), build a paper plate airplane that flies a minimum distance of twelve feet while remaining right side up. Using regular paper is not allowed and will result in no points given.

You can find templates on the Internet and you are also free (and encouraged) to experiment.  Think about what makes a plane fly and you can probably create your own cool invention.

Take a short video of the flight and submit the file on Canvas. You may also upload the video to Youtube, Vimeo, etc. and submit the URL. As usual, this must be original work. If the video is greater than 5MB then you must upload the file to YouTube, Vimeo, etc. and submit the URL.

To obtain credit for this assignment your video must have include:

  1. You holding or demonstrating your creation
  2. Verification that it flew a minimum of twelve feet
  3. You describing the various parts of your airplane in relation to a typical commercial airliner (see Chapter 6 Figure 8). 

See assignment expectations.

Using your design thinking skills (in the design thinking chapter of the course textbook) to come up with an idea not already in the chapter of how autonomous and semi-autonomous technologies could be used for military purposes and create a prototype of your idea along with a written explanation of how it would function.  You can use any materials on hand to create your prototype.

Submit an image or images of your prototype with you in the picture as well to receive points along with the written description.

Design/build: Buckyball (Course objective 4)

After reading the section "Nanomaterials" in the chapter relating to this module in the course textbook, use available materials to build a three dimensional buckyball model similar to the figure in the book. 

Note: A C60 buckyball is a molecule composed of 60 carbon atoms that resembles the shape of a soccer ball.  Each buckyball has thirty two faces (twelve pentagons and twenty hexagons), ninety edges, and sixty vertices (the atoms).  Important: When your buckyball molecular model has the correct shape, each of the twelve pentagon shapes will be surrounded by five hexagons and no pentagon will be touching another pentagon. Refer to the image to ensure your model is complete and correct.

For Credit:

1. Upload an image of your project with you in it.

2. Include a 200 word write-up or comment about how buckyballs are used in various fields (in your own words)

You will be assessed on the accuracy and professionalism of your model.  As with all assignments, this must be original work. 

See assignment expectations

Design/build: Predictive Analytics Model (Course objective 2)

The chapter discusses predictive analytics. Let's try our hand at making our own predictive prototypes.  

Predictive modeling uses statistics to predict outcomes through the use of models such as one of below:

  • Naive Bayes
  • k-nearest neighbor algorithm
  • Majority classifier
  • Support vector machines
  • Random forests
  • Boosted trees
  • Classification and Regression Trees (CART)
  • Multivariate adaptive regression splines (MARS)
  • Neural Networks
  • Ordinary Least Squares
  • Generalized Linear Models (GLM)
  • Logistic regression
  • Generalized additive models
  • Robust regression
  • Semiparametric regression

Choose one model to research further and then create a specific example/prototype of how it could be applied to a real-world problem.  You will be assessed on the accuracy, depth and relevance of your example/prototype. Remember to include your sources.

See assignment expectations

Submit

You have been given the opportunity to help create the physical design of a robot that is intended to be sold commercially to household consumers. This robot is known as “Mr. Walkyourdog”.  The idea is that Mr. Walkeryourdog can do the dog walking for the owner, without the owner present for the walk. Sketch your design and then explain why you added the elements you did.

Next, referencing the book and other sources, explain how machine learning would be applied and operate on your prototype.

Design/build: Solar Cooker (Course objective 2)

Create a solar cooker.  It must heat to a minimum of two (2) times the outdoor temperature in a four (4) hour period (so, if it is 40 degrees outside it must heat to 80 degrees in a four (4) hour period.  This can be demonstrated using an oven thermometer and taking pictures of the before and after temperatures. See below rubric for details. 

Use the Web to find ideas on sites such as "Build a Solar Cooker" and then post a video or images to demonstrate your work.
